description: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation while focusing on basic terminology, and concepts like CIA Triad, which is a set of core security principles that can provide as the foundation for security. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.

episodes.description: In this episode, Peter and Mike dive into MTA security fundamentals. They starting with defining key terms that will be used throughout the course like the CIA triad and risk management.
episodes.title: Core Security Principles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:02.082
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.082 --> 00:00:06.747
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.747 --> 00:00:08.201
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.201 --> 00:00:10.731
You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:10.731 --> 00:00:13.803
>> Hello and welcome to ITProTV.

6
00:00:13.803 --> 00:00:15.841
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam, and

7
00:00:15.841 --> 00:00:19.268
today we are starting our
MTA Security Fundamentals course.

8
00:00:19.268 --> 00:00:22.660
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna talk about core security principles.

9
00:00:22.660 --> 00:00:24.598
And here to help us understand those,

10
00:00:24.598 --> 00:00:28.190
we have the expert on core security
principles, Mr. Mike Roderick.

11
00:00:28.190 --> 00:00:29.250
Mike, how you doing?

12
00:00:29.250 --> 00:00:30.602
>> I'm doing great Peter,
thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:30.602 --> 00:00:34.292
And yeah, we wanna start off with
the MTA series, this particular one,

14
00:00:34.292 --> 00:00:38.528
Security Fundamentals is we really need to
make sure that we're all on the same page

15
00:00:38.528 --> 00:00:40.490
when it comes to those core concepts.

16
00:00:40.490 --> 00:00:45.438
Some terminology, some basic concepts that
we need in order to progress one through

17
00:00:45.438 --> 00:00:50.037
this course and pass the exam, as well as
if we want to get into managing servers

18
00:00:50.037 --> 00:00:53.670
and we want to get into security
as our field of expertise.

19
00:00:53.670 --> 00:00:56.673
These are going to be
important foundational skills.

20
00:00:56.673 --> 00:00:59.990
So the first thing we really wanna talk
about is something that you might or

21
00:00:59.990 --> 00:01:04.590
might not have heard already, and that
something known as the CIA Triad, Peter.

22
00:01:04.590 --> 00:01:06.420
It's a very important part of security.

23
00:01:06.420 --> 00:01:10.030
>> Sounds like CIA would be something that
we'd be talking about in security, but

24
00:01:10.030 --> 00:01:11.430
this isn't that CIA, right?

25
00:01:11.430 --> 00:01:15.040
>> Not the same, no not
the governmental agency in this case.

26
00:01:15.040 --> 00:01:16.750
When we talk about the CIA triad,

27
00:01:16.750 --> 00:01:20.590
we're really talking about
three core security principles.

28
00:01:20.590 --> 00:01:23.770
You can think of them,
they always use the old tripod thing or

29
00:01:23.770 --> 00:01:25.390
a little three-legged stool.

30
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:27.860
Without one of these,
it just doesn't stand up, right?

31
00:01:27.860 --> 00:01:31.150
So these are the three core principles
that we need to be familiar with.

32
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:33.680
It's really goals that we're striving for

33
00:01:33.680 --> 00:01:36.470
when we try to secure our environment,
right?

34
00:01:36.470 --> 00:01:41.730
And those are gonna be confidentiality,
integrity, and availability.

35
00:01:41.730 --> 00:01:45.900
Those three things, hence the CIA,
confidentiality, integrity, and

36
00:01:45.900 --> 00:01:46.970
availability.

37
00:01:46.970 --> 00:01:49.885
So let's break each one of them down and
talk a little bit about what they mean.

38
00:01:49.885 --> 00:01:53.710
Now when we talk about confidentiality,
Peter, this is something that I think most

39
00:01:53.710 --> 00:01:58.180
people have a pretty good understanding
of what the concept means, right?

40
00:01:58.180 --> 00:02:01.900
You have things in your life that you
don't want the public to know, right?

41
00:02:01.900 --> 00:02:05.270
>> Definitely, and
a lot of it is on my computer.

42
00:02:05.270 --> 00:02:07.086
>> Yeah, everybody is familiar with,

43
00:02:07.086 --> 00:02:10.026
I don't want my Social Security
number getting out there.

44
00:02:10.026 --> 00:02:13.955
Maybe my bank account information,
how much money I have in the bank, right,

45
00:02:13.955 --> 00:02:16.100
we don't want everybody to know that.

46
00:02:16.100 --> 00:02:18.380
We want to keep that
information confidential.

47
00:02:18.380 --> 00:02:20.530
My health records, things like that.

48
00:02:20.530 --> 00:02:23.195
Well, when it comes to our computers and
our networks, as you said, Peter, a lot of

49
00:02:23.195 --> 00:02:28.450
information's stored on our systems, on
our computers, on servers in our network.

50
00:02:28.450 --> 00:02:31.500
And we wanna make sure that
only authorized people

51
00:02:31.500 --> 00:02:33.710
are allowed to access the information.

52
00:02:33.710 --> 00:02:37.960
That means we want to maintain or
provide for confidentiality.

53
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:41.160
We wanna make sure that only those
that should be able to access it

54
00:02:41.160 --> 00:02:42.230
are able to access it.

55
00:02:42.230 --> 00:02:46.912
And that includes data, information,
It includes access to the networks, right?

56
00:02:46.912 --> 00:02:49.720
If you're not authorized, you shouldn't
be able to connect to our network.

57
00:02:49.720 --> 00:02:52.720
Or if you're not authorized, you shouldn't
be able to log on to our systems or

58
00:02:52.720 --> 00:02:54.240
connect to our servers.

59
00:02:54.240 --> 00:02:57.970
So it's really all about
preventing unauthorized access.

60
00:02:57.970 --> 00:03:01.330
Now another thing that really
goes along with confidentiality

61
00:03:01.330 --> 00:03:04.730
is something known as data classification.

62
00:03:04.730 --> 00:03:08.660
Because if we think about the information
that we deal with on a daily basis,

63
00:03:08.660 --> 00:03:10.080
one in your personal life, but

64
00:03:10.080 --> 00:03:13.820
also in a work environment,
not all data is the same, right?

65
00:03:13.820 --> 00:03:15.790
There's some information that
I wanna keep confidential,

66
00:03:15.790 --> 00:03:17.930
like how much money I
have in my bank account.

67
00:03:17.930 --> 00:03:20.510
But Peter, I want you to know
when my birthday is because

68
00:03:20.510 --> 00:03:21.790
I want presents, right?

69
00:03:21.790 --> 00:03:24.570
So that information would not
be considered confidential.

70
00:03:24.570 --> 00:03:29.062
>> So this is similar to what we talk
about with government information.

71
00:03:29.062 --> 00:03:31.540
You've got top secret, you've got
classified, code word clearance.

72
00:03:31.540 --> 00:03:34.150
That's kind of the different
levels you're saying here?

73
00:03:34.150 --> 00:03:35.940
>> That's exactly right,
that's exactly what it is.

74
00:03:35.940 --> 00:03:38.430
We're familiar with the movies,
with the government classifications,

75
00:03:38.430 --> 00:03:41.880
but private companies, public companies,
we all do the same thing.

76
00:03:41.880 --> 00:03:44.480
Because when we talk about
applying confidentiality,

77
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:47.310
there's work involved in
applying that confidentiality.

78
00:03:47.310 --> 00:03:50.620
It's not as easy as just saying okay,
keep that information confidential.

79
00:03:50.620 --> 00:03:53.679
We've gotta figure out how we're
gonna restrict access to it.

80
00:03:53.679 --> 00:03:56.115
We've gotta implement procedures and
technologies,

81
00:03:56.115 --> 00:03:58.140
we have man-hours to maintain that.

82
00:03:58.140 --> 00:04:00.830
So we classify data so

83
00:04:00.830 --> 00:04:05.260
that we can determine what level of
confidentiality we need to apply.

84
00:04:05.260 --> 00:04:09.080
If you don't classify your information,
then you really only have two choices.

85
00:04:09.080 --> 00:04:11.640
Treat everything as confidential and

86
00:04:11.640 --> 00:04:15.640
try to protect everything, which is
really expensive and a lot of work.

87
00:04:15.640 --> 00:04:19.731
Or, treat everything as public, right,
which is usually not the case because I

88
00:04:19.731 --> 00:04:24.066
have information, payroll, healthcare
stuff, Information about my employees,

89
00:04:24.066 --> 00:04:27.156
credit card information I might
be storing from customers.

90
00:04:27.156 --> 00:04:31.120
We have confidential information, so
the second option doesn't work either.

91
00:04:31.120 --> 00:04:33.980
So what we' do is we classify
our information using,

92
00:04:33.980 --> 00:04:36.610
like Peter said, the military example.

93
00:04:36.610 --> 00:04:40.580
Or your organization might make up
your own level of classification and

94
00:04:40.580 --> 00:04:44.570
then that allows me to apply
the appropriate level of confidentiality.

95
00:04:44.570 --> 00:04:48.170
If it's publicly available that
anybody should be able to get to

96
00:04:48.170 --> 00:04:51.720
like my company's information,
what we sell, what we're about,

97
00:04:51.720 --> 00:04:55.390
things like that,
I can make that available to the public.

98
00:04:55.390 --> 00:05:00.058
But if it's our financials from
the previous year, that's confidential.

99
00:05:00.058 --> 00:05:05.300
By classifying it, I can now make
sure that the company financial data

100
00:05:05.300 --> 00:05:09.110
is treated differently than
that public information.

101
00:05:09.110 --> 00:05:11.760
So that's first leg there
is that confidentiality.

102
00:05:11.760 --> 00:05:15.490
>> All right, so that covers
confidentiality and next we had integrity?

103
00:05:15.490 --> 00:05:18.740
>> Integrity, right,
that second leg of our CIA triad.

104
00:05:18.740 --> 00:05:24.140
Integrity is about making sure that
information or data is not modified

105
00:05:24.140 --> 00:05:27.970
either in an unintentional or
a malicious and intentional way.

106
00:05:27.970 --> 00:05:30.750
It's really all about just making
sure the data's not changed

107
00:05:30.750 --> 00:05:33.380
without us intending to change it, right?

108
00:05:33.380 --> 00:05:38.880
If we have information like
company records or sales receipts,

109
00:05:38.880 --> 00:05:42.860
I don't want that information being stored
on a system and then somebody modifying it

110
00:05:42.860 --> 00:05:48.220
either accidentally or maliciously to make
it look like we sold more than we did or

111
00:05:48.220 --> 00:05:51.450
changing pay rates, or
whatever the case may be.

112
00:05:51.450 --> 00:05:53.290
So integrity, very important,

113
00:05:53.290 --> 00:05:59.420
is to make sure the data's not modified
without the proper authorization, right?

114
00:05:59.420 --> 00:06:01.970
And there's a couple of
ways we can use integrity,

115
00:06:01.970 --> 00:06:06.680
it's used all the time behind the scenes
in a lot of stuff that we don't see.

116
00:06:06.680 --> 00:06:10.270
When we talk about our data that travels
out to the Internet and back, each one of

117
00:06:10.270 --> 00:06:14.150
those little packets has integrity checks
in it to make sure that it travels across

118
00:06:14.150 --> 00:06:18.400
the Internet and back to your computer
that it's not modified, either

119
00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:22.700
maliciously by a bad guy, or just through
normal errors in data transmission.

120
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:25.790
I wanna make sure that the web
page presents properly.

121
00:06:25.790 --> 00:06:29.130
When we look at our system files on
our computer, or operating system,

122
00:06:29.130 --> 00:06:32.340
every time we start it up,
it checks those really important files to

123
00:06:32.340 --> 00:06:35.350
make sure they haven't been
modified by malware, right?

124
00:06:35.350 --> 00:06:39.610
It's doing integrity checks on itself,
on it's own system files.

125
00:06:39.610 --> 00:06:42.460
So it's an important part of
keeping our information and

126
00:06:42.460 --> 00:06:45.180
our network secure is integrity.

127
00:06:45.180 --> 00:06:49.340
We can look at a few different
ways of providing integrity.

128
00:06:49.340 --> 00:06:52.330
We can use authentication and
authorization, right?

129
00:06:52.330 --> 00:06:55.670
You might think well wait,
how is that gonna give me integrity?

130
00:06:55.670 --> 00:06:59.960
Well, if you can't authenticate,
if you can't login to the system, or

131
00:06:59.960 --> 00:07:02.180
if you don't have permissions
to write to that file,

132
00:07:02.180 --> 00:07:05.210
you're gonna find it very difficult
to make changes to the file.

133
00:07:05.210 --> 00:07:09.240
Therefore, I'm providing
integrity over that file, right?

134
00:07:09.240 --> 00:07:10.490
We can audit.

135
00:07:10.490 --> 00:07:13.800
Doesn't do a lot for
preventing changes, but

136
00:07:13.800 --> 00:07:15.520
it will let me know that
there has been changes.

137
00:07:15.520 --> 00:07:17.340
And I can determine
whether there should or

138
00:07:17.340 --> 00:07:18.860
should not have been those changes, right?

139
00:07:18.860 --> 00:07:23.490
We can audit,
we can track who accessed that file last?

140
00:07:23.490 --> 00:07:24.970
Did they make any changes?

141
00:07:24.970 --> 00:07:26.670
When did they make those changes?

142
00:07:26.670 --> 00:07:30.730
So again, the change already occurred,
so it doesn't really provide integrity.

143
00:07:30.730 --> 00:07:34.550
But it does give me the ability to
validate my integrity, to say no,

144
00:07:34.550 --> 00:07:36.380
this file hasn't changed.

145
00:07:36.380 --> 00:07:39.460
With a lot of these regulations that
we have to deal with, I didn't mention

146
00:07:39.460 --> 00:07:44.520
this confidentiality, but just as a
business, we want good security practices.

147
00:07:44.520 --> 00:07:48.110
But a lot of businesses have to follow
regulations that are either industry or

148
00:07:48.110 --> 00:07:52.233
governmental regulations like HIPAA or
Sarbanes-Oxley.

149
00:07:52.233 --> 00:07:56.654
And a lot of these regulations require
that you track integrity, right?

150
00:07:56.654 --> 00:08:01.128
That you can validate that that customer's
or that patient's information Has not been

151
00:08:01.128 --> 00:08:04.320
modified either accidentally or
maliciously, right?

152
00:08:04.320 --> 00:08:04.986
Provide that integrity.

153
00:08:04.986 --> 00:08:08.048
And we have to prove that we have
systems in place to provide that, so

154
00:08:08.048 --> 00:08:10.630
it's a very important part of security.

155
00:08:10.630 --> 00:08:12.830
We can also do something known as hashing.

156
00:08:12.830 --> 00:08:17.330
Now we're not gonna get into the whole
algorithm here or anything like that, but

157
00:08:17.330 --> 00:08:19.970
it is important we understand the concept.

158
00:08:19.970 --> 00:08:23.610
Because when it comes to providing
integrity, hashing is a big part of it.

159
00:08:23.610 --> 00:08:29.340
What it is is just a mathematical formula
that I can take a file or a whole set

160
00:08:29.340 --> 00:08:34.520
of files or whatever I want and I can run
it through this mathematical algorithm.

161
00:08:34.520 --> 00:08:38.900
And what comes out the other end is
a value, known as a hash value or

162
00:08:38.900 --> 00:08:40.550
a message digest.

163
00:08:40.550 --> 00:08:43.860
And every time I run those set of files or
that file or

164
00:08:43.860 --> 00:08:47.045
whatever it is, every time I run
it through that hashing algorithm,

165
00:08:47.045 --> 00:08:52.510
it's always gonna generate the exact
same message digest for hash value.

166
00:08:52.510 --> 00:08:55.620
If I come back next week and
I run it through there again, and

167
00:08:55.620 --> 00:08:58.240
that values has changed,
that's my indicator.

168
00:08:58.240 --> 00:08:59.950
Hey, something has changed,

169
00:08:59.950 --> 00:09:04.080
cuz if nothing has change there
will always output the same value.

170
00:09:04.080 --> 00:09:09.700
If the value changes I know something in
that file, or set of files, has changed.

171
00:09:09.700 --> 00:09:10.260
So, again,

172
00:09:10.260 --> 00:09:15.600
it's one of those things that allows me to
verify that a file has not been modified.

173
00:09:15.600 --> 00:09:18.480
Now this is something you do when you
download stuff from the Internet.

174
00:09:18.480 --> 00:09:21.678
A lot of times you'll see an MD5 value.

175
00:09:21.678 --> 00:09:24.590
You're like, what the heck is that
big old long string of numbers?

176
00:09:24.590 --> 00:09:28.640
Well that's the hash digest or the message
digest and what they want you to do is

177
00:09:28.640 --> 00:09:32.080
download the file,
run it through a little hashing algorithm,

178
00:09:32.080 --> 00:09:36.040
generate that value and compare it to
the one they have up on their website.

179
00:09:36.040 --> 00:09:39.440
If those match that means your download
is complete, nothing got corrupted in

180
00:09:39.440 --> 00:09:43.030
the process and you've got an exact
copy of what's on that website.

181
00:09:43.030 --> 00:09:46.660
If they don't match, something went
wrong and I can go download it again.

182
00:09:46.660 --> 00:09:49.070
Maybe somebody tried to slip
some malware in there, right?

183
00:09:49.070 --> 00:09:51.720
So this is how we provide for
that integrity.

184
00:09:51.720 --> 00:09:54.610
So that's our second leg of the CIA triad.

185
00:09:54.610 --> 00:09:58.580
>> Okay so confidentiality, integrity and
finally we have availability.

186
00:09:58.580 --> 00:10:02.830
Are we talking about having access
to your content, to your data.

187
00:10:02.830 --> 00:10:06.470
>> Exactly, I mean a lot of people think
well how does that mean security, right?

188
00:10:06.470 --> 00:10:10.140
Availability doesn't sound
like a security thing

189
00:10:10.140 --> 00:10:12.660
to use our technical jargon,
a thing there.

190
00:10:12.660 --> 00:10:13.850
But it is.

191
00:10:13.850 --> 00:10:15.850
It is a big part of security.

192
00:10:15.850 --> 00:10:19.800
And when we, we can easily
take security too far, right.

193
00:10:19.800 --> 00:10:22.630
If I take that data,
that company information,

194
00:10:22.630 --> 00:10:27.130
I put it on a server and I encrypt it and
I unplug the network cable.

195
00:10:27.130 --> 00:10:27.980
That data is pretty safe.

196
00:10:27.980 --> 00:10:31.666
It's gonna be very difficult for somebody
to make changes or steal that information.

197
00:10:31.666 --> 00:10:33.092
But also means that Peter,

198
00:10:33.092 --> 00:10:36.200
when you go to do you job,
you can't get to the data either.

199
00:10:36.200 --> 00:10:38.431
And that's not gonna do you any good,

200
00:10:38.431 --> 00:10:42.543
so making sure that data is available
is a big part of security as well,

201
00:10:42.543 --> 00:10:46.950
because if you can't get to
the information, it's kind of useless.

202
00:10:46.950 --> 00:10:49.390
>> It sounds like yeah,
the most secure way would just be to have

203
00:10:49.390 --> 00:10:52.330
no one be able to access the content,
but that's not an ideal situation,

204
00:10:52.330 --> 00:10:56.120
so kind of finding that middle ground or
that happy medium there.

205
00:10:56.120 --> 00:10:57.570
So what's next to talk about here?

206
00:10:57.570 --> 00:10:58.670
>> Absolutely, so let's finish.

207
00:10:58.670 --> 00:10:59.640
A couple more things I want to do.

208
00:10:59.640 --> 00:11:02.580
I want to talk about availability
because it's not just making sure that

209
00:11:02.580 --> 00:11:03.270
people have access.

210
00:11:03.270 --> 00:11:07.120
It's also thinking about
things like redundancy.

211
00:11:07.120 --> 00:11:10.880
When we look at threats to availability,
they can be accidental or

212
00:11:10.880 --> 00:11:14.900
they can be natural or they can be
intentional or deliberate I guess.

213
00:11:14.900 --> 00:11:15.880
So accidental,

214
00:11:15.880 --> 00:11:20.170
things like natural disaster
>> Fires, hurricanes, tornadoes, equipment

215
00:11:20.170 --> 00:11:25.630
failure, power supply failures, hard drive
failures, unplanned network outages.

216
00:11:25.630 --> 00:11:28.870
These would be accidental
types of availability issues.

217
00:11:28.870 --> 00:11:33.440
And we can do things about it, we can move
to the area where there are no tornadoes,

218
00:11:33.440 --> 00:11:36.590
or we can have redundant power supplies,
multiple power supplies so

219

00:23:44.840 --> 00:23:48.500
I have a risk, I'm just gonna
transfer that risk to somebody else.

445
00:23:48.500 --> 00:23:51.938
I'm gonna pay company XYZ so
much money a month, and

446
00:23:51.938 --> 00:23:56.786
if that risk ever comes to fruition,
whatever they're insuring me for,

447
00:23:56.786 --> 00:23:59.534
they have to deal with the consequences.

448
00:23:59.534 --> 00:24:01.937
It's like car insurance, right,
you all have car insurance.

449
00:24:01.937 --> 00:24:07.950
So you pay a company so much money
a month to transfer the risk to them.

450
00:24:07.950 --> 00:24:10.580
Now, when you wreck your car,
they have to fix it.

451
00:24:10.580 --> 00:24:14.600
They have to come out-of-pocket and
pay that money to get that car fixed.

452
00:24:14.600 --> 00:24:17.070
So you've transferred
the risk to somebody else.

453
00:24:17.070 --> 00:24:20.210
You see this a lot of times
when we go to cloud, right?

454
00:24:20.210 --> 00:24:23.250
We're transferring some of that risk to
the cloud providers because now they're

455
00:24:23.250 --> 00:24:26.900
responsible for keeping those systems
up to date and keeping them patched.

456
00:24:28.020 --> 00:24:32.140
We look at insurance on
high profile people, right?

457
00:24:32.140 --> 00:24:35.810
What is that,
the key personnel type insurance.

458
00:24:35.810 --> 00:24:40.280
Where if that person's ever gone, we've
got issues with the company because they

459
00:24:40.280 --> 00:24:42.640
are the spokesperson,
the face of the company.

460
00:24:42.640 --> 00:24:44.790
And if they leave we lose credibility.

461
00:24:44.790 --> 00:24:46.800
So maybe we have insurance
against things like that.

462
00:24:46.800 --> 00:24:50.570
But we've basically transferred
the risk to somebody else.

463
00:24:51.800 --> 00:24:53.950
Now one last concept,
I know we're getting short on time,

464
00:24:53.950 --> 00:24:57.460
that I want to throw in here when we talk
about risk, and that's residual risk.

465
00:24:58.770 --> 00:25:02.460
Residual risk is the risk
that's left after

466
00:25:02.460 --> 00:25:04.490
you've taken one of these risk responses.

467
00:25:04.490 --> 00:25:06.990
Whether it's avoidance,
acceptance, mitigation, transfer,

468
00:25:06.990 --> 00:25:10.210
you're going to have some risk left over.

469
00:25:10.210 --> 00:25:12.820
I'll use the insurance example again.

470
00:25:12.820 --> 00:25:15.880
Now I pay so
much a month to my insurance company and

471
00:25:15.880 --> 00:25:18.260
now I've transferred that risk to them.

472
00:25:18.260 --> 00:25:21.360
When I get in an accident they're
gonna pay for it except for

473
00:25:21.360 --> 00:25:22.550
my deductible, right?

474
00:25:22.550 --> 00:25:25.280
So I still have a little
bit of residual risk on me.

475
00:25:25.280 --> 00:25:27.920
I have to pay that deductible
before they actually take over and

476
00:25:27.920 --> 00:25:28.800
make the rest of the payment.

477
00:25:28.800 --> 00:25:30.956
So that's an example of residual risk.

478
00:25:30.956 --> 00:25:33.405
Or maybe,
what would be another good example?

479
00:25:33.405 --> 00:25:35.457
You-
>> Also in the insurance examples,

480
00:25:35.457 --> 00:25:38.018
a lot of times they'll
have a maximum payout.

481
00:25:38.018 --> 00:25:41.130
So they'll cover your
accident up to $100,000, or

482
00:25:41.130 --> 00:25:43.282
the bodily injury up to a certain amount.

483
00:25:43.282 --> 00:25:46.130
So, beyond that,
if it's something that's gonna keep going,

484
00:25:46.130 --> 00:25:47.445
that's something you're responsible for.

485
00:25:47.445 --> 00:25:50.510
>> Exactly, and we could use that
XP one for an example as well.

486
00:25:50.510 --> 00:25:53.460
They had some residual risk there.

487
00:25:53.460 --> 00:25:54.690
They still ran XP.

488
00:25:54.690 --> 00:25:55.970
They've done what they could.

489
00:25:55.970 --> 00:25:59.640
They disconnected from the internet or
they'd maybe leave it connected but

490
00:25:59.640 --> 00:26:01.980
have a sticker on it
that says no browsing.

491
00:26:01.980 --> 00:26:04.960
Okay, but there's still the risk
that somebody says, yeah,

492
00:26:04.960 --> 00:26:07.510
I can't read English and
I'm gonna go ahead and browse anyway.

493
00:26:07.510 --> 00:26:11.930
Or somebody, a guest gets physical access
to that machine and tries to do something.

494
00:26:11.930 --> 00:26:13.980
So they didn't eliminate
the risk all together.

495
00:26:13.980 --> 00:26:16.970
That's that residual
risk that's left over.

496
00:26:16.970 --> 00:26:19.549
All right, so I know we've got
a lot more topics here to cover.

497
00:26:19.549 --> 00:26:21.984
Or the next one, some quick ones,
or should we go ahead and

498
00:26:21.984 --> 00:26:22.988
save that for part two?

499
00:26:22.988 --> 00:26:24.940
>> Yeah, rather than rush through it,
let's save it.

500
00:26:24.940 --> 00:26:25.620
Let's do a part two.

501
00:26:25.620 --> 00:26:28.304
It might not be a full length, but
I don't wanna rush through any of this.

502
00:26:28.304 --> 00:26:29.160
>> All right, sounds good, Mike.

503
00:26:29.160 --> 00:26:32.480
Well we've got some more core security
principles to talk about, but

504
00:26:32.480 --> 00:26:33.580
we're gonna do that in part two.

505
00:26:33.580 --> 00:26:35.132
So we're gonna go ahead and sign off now.

506
00:26:35.132 --> 00:26:37.850
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Peter VanRysdam.

507
00:26:37.850 --> 00:26:38.770
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

508
00:26:38.770 --> 00:26:39.640
>> And we'll see you next time.

509
00:26:39.640 --> 00:26:46.222
[MUSIC]

510
00:26:46.222 --> 00:26:49.509
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this part two, Peter and Mike pick up where they left off on security principles. They cover topics like the principle of least privilege, social engineering, and attack surface analysis.
episodes.title: Core Security Principles Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.501
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.501 --> 00:00:02.830
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.830 --> 00:00:05.923
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.923 --> 00:00:08.356
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.356 --> 00:00:12.615
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.615 --> 00:00:14.536
>> Hello and welcome to ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.536 --> 00:00:16.578
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam, and today,

8
00:00:16.578 --> 00:00:19.880
we're continuing with our
MTA Security Fundamentals course.

9
00:00:19.880 --> 00:00:24.000
And in this episode, we're continuing
to look at Core Security principles and

10
00:00:24.000 --> 00:00:26.380
we have Mr.
Mike Rodrick here to help us with that.

11
00:00:26.380 --> 00:00:27.230
Mike, how you doing?

12
00:00:27.230 --> 00:00:27.860
>> I'm doing great.

13
00:00:27.860 --> 00:00:28.750
Thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:28.750 --> 00:00:31.360
Excited to be here as always, and yet

15
00:00:31.360 --> 00:00:34.540
we left off talking about those
core security principles.

16
00:00:34.540 --> 00:00:36.925
If you missed part one,
make sure you go back and check it out.

17
00:00:36.925 --> 00:00:40.350
Talked to you about the CIA triad,
we talked a little bit about

18
00:00:40.350 --> 00:00:44.450
risk management and some terms that
we need to be familiar with there.

19
00:00:44.450 --> 00:00:48.380
Next on our list and when it comes
to our core security principles,

20
00:00:48.380 --> 00:00:52.450
is going to be something known as
the principle of least privilege.

21
00:00:52.450 --> 00:00:57.560
And this is something that I
think we hear about it a lot and

22
00:00:57.560 --> 00:01:02.090
now it seems to be pretty commonplace,
but not always the case.

23
00:01:02.090 --> 00:01:03.940
And we need to make sure we understand,
though,

24
00:01:03.940 --> 00:01:06.720
what they mean by principle
of least privilege.

25
00:01:06.720 --> 00:01:08.368
And it's just like the name implies,
right?

26
00:01:08.368 --> 00:01:13.280
Basically only gonna give you or
the system or whatever it

27
00:01:13.280 --> 00:01:17.920
is I'm trying to control what they
need to do their job and nothing more.

28
00:01:17.920 --> 00:01:20.660
In other words, I want to make sure
that you have all the rights and

29
00:01:20.660 --> 00:01:23.440
permissions that you need to do your job.

30
00:01:23.440 --> 00:01:28.810
Whether that's logging on to a particular
computer, able to access certain files,

31
00:01:28.810 --> 00:01:32.780
data, able to get into the server closet,
if that's part of your job.

32
00:01:33.840 --> 00:01:36.310
But then that's it, nothing more, right?

33
00:01:36.310 --> 00:01:40.800
It used to be way back in the day to
keep things really easy to administer,

34
00:01:40.800 --> 00:01:44.130
we would make everybody
administrators on the network.

35
00:01:44.130 --> 00:01:46.487
Because that way, you didn't
have to come to me and say, hey,

36
00:01:46.487 --> 00:01:47.746
I can't install this software.

37
00:01:47.746 --> 00:01:49.530
It says I need to be an administrator.

38
00:01:49.530 --> 00:01:52.640
And IT people were taking
the lazy approach and saying,

39
00:01:52.640 --> 00:01:54.660
you know what,
I'll just make you an administrator.

40
00:01:54.660 --> 00:01:55.660
Now you can do whatever you want.

41
00:01:55.660 --> 00:01:57.365
You don't have to come bug me anymore.

42
00:01:57.365 --> 00:01:59.000
But we've learned, right?

43
00:01:59.000 --> 00:02:00.770
We went through the pain of that.

44
00:02:00.770 --> 00:02:03.490
We learned how bad that can be and

45
00:02:03.490 --> 00:02:07.390
now most organizations do follow
the principle of least privilege.

46
00:02:07.390 --> 00:02:09.790
But again, like I said,
it's still an important concept and

47
00:02:09.790 --> 00:02:11.640
it can be a tricky one to implement.

48
00:02:11.640 --> 00:02:13.388
It seems easy.

49
00:02:13.388 --> 00:02:16.460
It sounds like it's something, well hey,
just give them what they need and

50
00:02:16.460 --> 00:02:17.090
nothing more.

51
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:19.710
And if you got an office of five people,

52
00:02:19.710 --> 00:02:24.480
it's relatively easy to do one facility,
five employees, not that big of deal.

53
00:02:24.480 --> 00:02:27.640
But when you're talking about
thousands of employees, and six or

54
00:02:27.640 --> 00:02:31.520
seven different facilities, some of those
employees need access to all facilities,

55
00:02:31.520 --> 00:02:33.350
some of them only certain facilities.

56
00:02:33.350 --> 00:02:35.140
Everybody needs access
to this document but

57
00:02:35.140 --> 00:02:37.780
only certain people need
access to these documents.

58
00:02:37.780 --> 00:02:40.860
It becomes a logistical nightmare
to try to manage all of this.

59
00:02:40.860 --> 00:02:44.870
Now we have software and
techniques that we can use to take care of

60
00:02:44.870 --> 00:02:48.890
this like Active Directory in Windows and
using security groups and permissions.

61
00:02:48.890 --> 00:02:52.240
And we're not getting into
how to do all this right now.

62
00:02:52.240 --> 00:02:54.770
I just want to make sure we
understand that concept of

63
00:02:54.770 --> 00:02:56.460
principle of least privilege.

64
00:02:56.460 --> 00:03:00.870
We want to make sure that when we're
signing permissions, and when we're giving

65
00:03:00.870 --> 00:03:06.050
access, whether that's to an employee,
or to a computer system, right?

66
00:03:06.050 --> 00:03:06.720
We're controlling.

67
00:03:06.720 --> 00:03:10.590
We're not just taking the easy way out and
saying, yeah, go ahead,

68
00:03:10.590 --> 00:03:12.403
have free reign of the network.

69
00:03:12.403 --> 00:03:13.902
Figure out what it is.

70
00:03:13.902 --> 00:03:17.120
Make sure that's all you're giving it,
and then nothing more.

71
00:03:17.120 --> 00:03:19.110
Why is that important?

72
00:03:19.110 --> 00:03:20.421
Well, couple of things.

73
00:03:20.421 --> 00:03:24.715
Well, one, it keeps employees
safe from themselves, right?

74
00:03:24.715 --> 00:03:27.540
It keeps our information
safe from employees.

75
00:03:27.540 --> 00:03:31.300
Because if they shouldn't have
access to that information but

76
00:03:31.300 --> 00:03:33.740
they have it anyway,
they're gonna end up poking around.

77
00:03:33.740 --> 00:03:36.900
Going to places that they shouldn't be,
looking at stuff they shouldn't see,

78
00:03:36.900 --> 00:03:40.820
possibly making accidental or
deliberate changes, right?

79
00:03:40.820 --> 00:03:44.100
If we give them, it's like mom
always told me when I was young,

80
00:03:44.100 --> 00:03:46.390
I give you an inch and you take a mile.

81
00:03:46.390 --> 00:03:49.650
Well, that's what happens with employees
is you give them a little bit and

82
00:03:49.650 --> 00:03:51.010
they're gonna push the boundaries.

83
00:03:51.010 --> 00:03:53.940
And they're gonna check and
see what else they can get into.

84
00:03:53.940 --> 00:03:57.030
A folder called payroll,
I wonder what's in here, double click.

85
00:03:57.030 --> 00:04:00.250
It let me in, I wonder what's in here,
double click, right?

86
00:04:00.250 --> 00:04:04.630
Just curiosity gets the best of us and
that's when bad things can happen.

87
00:04:04.630 --> 00:04:09.022
And two is we think about malware and
the way this works.

88
00:04:09.022 --> 00:04:12.661
And if I'm an administrator on
the system and I download or

89
00:04:12.661 --> 00:04:15.927
click on a link that has
malware associated with it,

90
00:04:15.927 --> 00:04:20.700
that malware is potentially now running
as me, right, as my user account.

91
00:04:20.700 --> 00:04:23.800
Whatever I have rights to,
that malware now has rights to.

92
00:04:23.800 --> 00:04:28.263
And if you didn't control my access at
all and you just made me an admin across

93
00:04:28.263 --> 00:04:32.115
the system, then now that malware
is an admin across the system.

94
00:04:32.115 --> 00:04:34.946
And I talk about this from a user
perspective, but it's the same thing for

95
00:04:34.946 --> 00:04:36.470
computers and software.

96
00:04:36.470 --> 00:04:37.900
Software needs permissions.

97
00:04:37.900 --> 00:04:40.900
If I have a software application
that has to reach out and

98
00:04:40.900 --> 00:04:45.540
talk to a different server to pull back
data to present in a dashboard, well,

99
00:04:45.540 --> 00:04:50.070
that system now needs access to
that server and that information.

100
00:04:50.070 --> 00:04:53.650
But I can limit to just that information,
rather than giving that system or

101
00:04:53.650 --> 00:04:56.020
that software application
free run of the network,

102
00:04:56.020 --> 00:05:00.100
I can say you need access to this
particular table and this particular

103
00:05:00.100 --> 00:05:03.790
database to pull that information back and
that's it and nothing more.

104
00:05:03.790 --> 00:05:07.630
So we apply that same principle of least
privilege not just to employees but

105
00:05:07.630 --> 00:05:11.120
to systems and to applications as well.

106
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:14.474
And that's gonna help us
maintain our networks and

107
00:05:14.474 --> 00:05:18.224
keep them safe from accidental and
malicious behavior.

108
00:05:18.224 --> 00:05:18.873
>> All right, Mike,

109
00:05:18.873 --> 00:05:21.280
I'm lucky enough to have a list of
all the terms we're covering here.

110
00:05:21.280 --> 00:05:22.850
So I see next up is social engineering.

111
00:05:22.850 --> 00:05:25.260
That's a pretty big topic,
but, for this exam,

112
00:05:25.260 --> 00:05:27.370
we just need to kind of
understand what it is, right?

113
00:05:27.370 --> 00:05:28.860
>> Yeah, very basic at this point.

114
00:05:28.860 --> 00:05:32.330
We've got other courses in our library if
you wanna go into a little more in-depth.

115
00:05:32.330 --> 00:05:33.850
It's a fascinating field.

116
00:05:33.850 --> 00:05:38.950
But social engineering Is
a technique that the bad guys use

117
00:05:40.140 --> 00:05:43.270
and what they're really doing is they're
taking advantage of human nature.

118
00:05:43.270 --> 00:05:45.240
I guess it's a good way to describe it,
right?

119
00:05:45.240 --> 00:05:49.855
We're going to try to convince,
as a social engineer,

120
00:05:49.855 --> 00:05:52.625
what you're trying to do
really is convince somebody to

121
00:05:52.625 --> 00:05:57.165
give you information that you shouldn't
have access to or give you access, right?

122
00:05:57.165 --> 00:05:59.865
Give you credentials, basically trying to

123
00:05:59.865 --> 00:06:03.745
get you to give up information to
somebody that should not have it.

124
00:06:03.745 --> 00:06:06.465
And there's several different
techniques that they will

125
00:06:06.465 --> 00:06:08.335
use to do social engineering.

126
00:06:08.335 --> 00:06:11.115
But it's all about misrepresentation.

127
00:06:11.115 --> 00:06:14.930
You'll hear things like
the whole phone call to the help

128
00:06:14.930 --> 00:06:18.670
desk pretending to be a new employee and
having trouble with a password and

129
00:06:18.670 --> 00:06:20.380
trying to get a password reset.

130
00:06:20.380 --> 00:06:22.280
Or the help desk calling an employee,

131
00:06:22.280 --> 00:06:26.640
the help desk calling an employee saying
hey, we upgraded the system last night.

132
00:06:26.640 --> 00:06:29.020
We want to make sure
you have access to it.

133
00:06:29.020 --> 00:06:31.600
Let's reset your password or
give me your old password so

134
00:06:31.600 --> 00:06:33.790
I can make sure you're in the system.

135
00:06:33.790 --> 00:06:36.340
Or this is Bob down in IT and

136
00:06:36.340 --> 00:06:41.330
I need you to log into an application and
take a screenshot, those kinds of things.

137
00:06:41.330 --> 00:06:46.242
Social engineering is a lot of
times it is done over the phone.

138
00:06:46.242 --> 00:06:50.010
And the reason it's done over the phone
is because it's harder to verify

139
00:06:50.010 --> 00:06:51.320
identity, right?

140
00:06:51.320 --> 00:06:54.805
If I call you up and I use the right names
and you've never talked to me before,

141
00:06:54.805 --> 00:06:58.399
in a small organization it might be more
difficult but in a large organization,

142
00:06:58.399 --> 00:07:01.375
how many times have you talked to
the people down on the help desk?

143
00:07:01.375 --> 00:07:03.090
Do you know every one of them by voice?

144
00:07:03.090 --> 00:07:06.430
Or could I convince you
using the right names and

145
00:07:06.430 --> 00:07:09.060
the right information that I'm
part of your help desk system?

146
00:07:09.060 --> 00:07:10.800
Would you be able to tell?

147
00:07:10.800 --> 00:07:12.760
So a lot of times it is
done over the phone.

148
00:07:12.760 --> 00:07:18.290
It can also be done through email though
when we look at things like phishing.

149
00:07:19.380 --> 00:07:21.053
These are examples of social engineering.

150
00:07:21.053 --> 00:07:22.410
I want you to click on that link.

151
00:07:22.410 --> 00:07:27.150
I want you to update your password
at PayPal, or log into your bank

152
00:07:27.150 --> 00:07:31.610
account using this link that takes you to
a site that looks just like your bank.

153
00:07:31.610 --> 00:07:34.848
Now those are examples of phishing
which falls under social engineering.

154
00:07:34.848 --> 00:07:37.870
But there's non-technical methods as well.

155
00:07:37.870 --> 00:07:43.500
We talk about things like tailgating,
all right.

156
00:07:43.500 --> 00:07:47.460
If your front door has card access,
card-controlled access,

157
00:07:47.460 --> 00:07:51.530
I can maybe hang out by the door, wait for
a group of you to come back from lunch,

158
00:07:51.530 --> 00:07:53.860
and just try to slip into your group and
slip in.

159
00:07:53.860 --> 00:07:55.896
And nobody noticing cuz
there's a group of you.

160
00:07:55.896 --> 00:07:58.987
One person swipes their card and
holds the door for everybody else and

161
00:07:58.987 --> 00:08:00.220
maybe I can just slip on in.

162
00:08:00.220 --> 00:08:03.723
Or I put on an old work suit, jumpsuit,
and yeah, I'm here to fix the phone.

163

00:20:27.974 --> 00:20:30.559
I wanna make sure you don't
have any errors in there,

391
00:20:30.559 --> 00:20:33.850
any crazy vulnerabilities or
any back doors hidden in there.

392
00:20:33.850 --> 00:20:34.680
They are gonna laugh at me.

393
00:20:34.680 --> 00:20:36.870
They're not gonna give me their
code because it's proprietary.

394
00:20:36.870 --> 00:20:38.420
They make their money selling that.

395
00:20:38.420 --> 00:20:39.400
They're not gonna give it to me.

396
00:20:39.400 --> 00:20:43.260
So if we can,
we can decompose applications.

397
00:20:43.260 --> 00:20:48.150
There are, there's software out there that
will let us take an application, run it.

398
00:20:48.150 --> 00:20:50.300
It will look and see what it does and

399
00:20:50.300 --> 00:20:53.610
it can help us break down what calls
it's making, things like that.

400
00:20:53.610 --> 00:20:56.050
But this would again help us determine

401
00:20:56.050 --> 00:20:58.550
what vulnerabilities
that software might have.

402
00:20:58.550 --> 00:21:01.950
Identify your threats, document your
threats, and rate your threats.

403
00:21:03.360 --> 00:21:06.470
Really kind of the same thing
we did with risk management.

404
00:21:06.470 --> 00:21:11.238
So that's why I say threat modeling is,
it's just another term that kind of

405
00:21:11.238 --> 00:21:16.320
talks about the same thing but
whereas risk we're dealing with.

406
00:21:16.320 --> 00:21:20.920
Remember, a risk is anything that
could have an impact on my network and

407
00:21:20.920 --> 00:21:24.340
we wanna look at the likelihood and
the impacts.

408
00:21:24.340 --> 00:21:28.430
Threat modeling,
we're gonna take a look at behaviors, but

409
00:21:28.430 --> 00:21:30.540
doing all of those same kind of things.

410
00:21:31.760 --> 00:21:34.760
Identifying the assets,
breaking down the application,

411
00:21:34.760 --> 00:21:37.080
identifying what those threats are.

412
00:21:37.080 --> 00:21:42.307
I'm trying to think of a good example
we could do some threat modeling with.

413
00:21:42.307 --> 00:21:46.010
We have, in here,
we're a multi-tenant facility, right?

414
00:21:46.010 --> 00:21:51.120
So we have ours and then we have other
businesses in the same building as us.

415
00:21:51.120 --> 00:21:55.820
So the threat might be one of
those other business employees

416
00:21:55.820 --> 00:22:00.370
walking through our office area, and
seeing information they shouldn't see.

417
00:22:00.370 --> 00:22:04.252
Or trying to gain access to systems that
they shouldn't gain or have access to.

418
00:22:04.252 --> 00:22:07.460
So when we look at our architecture
overview, this might be more of

419
00:22:07.460 --> 00:22:11.340
a floor plan, looking at how
different rooms are connected.

420
00:22:11.340 --> 00:22:13.330
Decompose the application.

421
00:22:13.330 --> 00:22:15.580
In this case, not really an app,
but we might break down,

422
00:22:15.580 --> 00:22:17.840
what doors do we have in place.

423
00:22:17.840 --> 00:22:21.750
The threat is somebody coming in and
accessing information or

424
00:22:21.750 --> 00:22:23.590
seeing stuff they shouldn't see.

425
00:22:23.590 --> 00:22:25.083
So we put locks in place or

426
00:22:25.083 --> 00:22:28.795
we'll put some kind of controlled
access on those doorways.

427
00:22:28.795 --> 00:22:30.580
But that's really threat modeling.

428
00:22:30.580 --> 00:22:35.290
It's kinda taking a step back,
looking at the different threats, and

429
00:22:35.290 --> 00:22:37.070
working through those threats, and

430
00:22:37.070 --> 00:22:42.300
seeing where I might apply controsl
to limit the impact of those threats.

431
00:22:42.300 --> 00:22:43.400
I guess that'd be a good way to put it.

432
00:22:43.400 --> 00:22:44.170
>> Alright, sounds good, Mike.

433
00:22:44.170 --> 00:22:44.970
I'm looking at it,

434
00:22:44.970 --> 00:22:47.430
that looks like the last of
the items on my glossary list here.

435
00:22:47.430 --> 00:22:51.640
I imagine we're gonna be hearing these
words a lot throughout this series?

436
00:22:51.640 --> 00:22:55.300
>> Absolutely, this really gives us
those foundational terms that we need to

437
00:22:55.300 --> 00:22:58.909
understand as we progress
through our career and security.

438
00:22:58.909 --> 00:23:00.790
>> Awesome, well,
now that I think we understand those,

439
00:23:00.790 --> 00:23:02.100
it's time to go ahead and move on.

440
00:23:02.100 --> 00:23:04.060
But, not in this episode
where we're out of time.

441
00:23:04.060 --> 00:23:05.940
So we're gonna save that for
the next episodes.

442
00:23:05.940 --> 00:23:08.369
So for now, signing off I've
been your host Peter VanRysdam.

443
00:23:08.369 --> 00:23:09.553
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

444
00:23:09.553 --> 00:23:10.673
>> And we will see you next time.

445
00:23:10.673 --> 00:23:18.869
[MUSIC]

446
00:23:18.869 --> 00:23:21.473
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Before you consider your cyber security, it is important to understand the importance of your physical security risks. Peter and Mike explain the levels of physical security like the external perimeter, internal perimeter, and secure areas before getting into the physical security related to your computers themselves.
episodes.title: Physical Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.590
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.590 --> 00:00:03.824
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.824 --> 00:00:05.424
[CROSSTALK]
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:05.424 --> 00:00:11.746
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.746 --> 00:00:13.508
>> Hello, and welcome to ITProTV.

6
00:00:13.508 --> 00:00:15.422
I'm your host, Peter VansRysdam,

7
00:00:15.422 --> 00:00:19.660
and today we are continuing with our
series on MTA security fundamentals.

8
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:23.190
And specifically in this episode,
we're talking about physical security.

9
00:00:23.190 --> 00:00:26.640
And here to help us learn all about
that and help us get started,

10
00:00:26.640 --> 00:00:29.000
we have Mr Mike Rodrick, so
Mike, let's get physical.

11
00:00:29.000 --> 00:00:32.060
>> I was just gonna say, to quote,
who was that, Olivia Newton John?

12
00:00:32.060 --> 00:00:35.340
>> I believe it was.
>> Yes, let's get physical, right?

13
00:00:35.340 --> 00:00:39.520
Because physical security is one of
those aspects of security that is often

14
00:00:39.520 --> 00:00:45.440
overlooked or maybe not given as much
attention or as thought as it should be.

15
00:00:45.440 --> 00:00:49.580
Because one of the things we wanna
remember is that physical security trumps

16
00:00:49.580 --> 00:00:50.520
everything else.

17
00:00:50.520 --> 00:00:52.390
There's an old set of ten immutable laws.

18
00:00:52.390 --> 00:00:55.580
I think Microsoft put
them out a long time ago.

19
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:59.758
But one of my favorites was,
if the bad guy can touch your computer,

20
00:00:59.758 --> 00:01:02.266
it's no longer your computer, right?

21
00:01:02.266 --> 00:01:06.580
What they're trying to stress there is
the importance of physical security.

22
00:01:06.580 --> 00:01:12.270
As tech geeks, you and I, we love to
think about all of the technologies

23
00:01:12.270 --> 00:01:17.410
that we could put in place and controls to
help control access and secure resources.

24
00:01:17.410 --> 00:01:20.990
And those are great, and they're very
important, and we have to do them.

25
00:01:20.990 --> 00:01:25.040
But if somebody can get physical access
to your machine, whether that's a user's

26
00:01:25.040 --> 00:01:30.000
workstation or a laptop or
an iPhone or a server in your closet,

27
00:01:30.000 --> 00:01:33.555
if they can physically touch it, odds
are they're gonna give it enough time.

28
00:01:33.555 --> 00:01:35.078
They're gonna be able to get into it.

29
00:01:35.078 --> 00:01:39.122
There's just too many things that they can
try to do if they have physical access.

30
00:01:39.122 --> 00:01:42.180
A lot of our controls
are based on the fact that

31
00:01:42.180 --> 00:01:46.280
people are coming across the network
to break into that machine.

32
00:01:46.280 --> 00:01:49.150
But if they're physically there,
they can boot to an alternate OS,

33
00:01:49.150 --> 00:01:50.958
they can pull hard drives out.

34
00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.680
There's just too many things they can do,

35
00:01:52.680 --> 00:01:56.100
and you might well figure
it's now their computer.

36
00:01:56.100 --> 00:01:57.230
So the point is,

37
00:01:57.230 --> 00:02:00.690
physical security is something
that we have to pay attention to.

38
00:02:00.690 --> 00:02:03.390
Again, sometimes it gets overlooked or

39
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:06.370
maybe just doesn't get enough emphasis,
I think.

40
00:02:06.370 --> 00:02:10.808
But physical security starts way away from
the computers, as far as I understand.

41
00:02:10.808 --> 00:02:13.600
So what are some of the first layers
of physical security when you

42
00:02:13.600 --> 00:02:14.180
think about that?

43
00:02:14.180 --> 00:02:16.760
>> We're gonna start and
basically it's like concentric rings.

44
00:02:16.760 --> 00:02:20.410
We're gonna work our way in from,
as you said, from the outside.

45
00:02:20.410 --> 00:02:22.870
We'll be talking about access control.

46
00:02:22.870 --> 00:02:25.540
But keep in mind when we're
talking about physical security,

47
00:02:25.540 --> 00:02:29.640
access control is not permissions and
access control lists.

48
00:02:29.640 --> 00:02:35.370
But more about guards checking people in
or doors or fences or things like that.

49
00:02:35.370 --> 00:02:39.983
So still access control,
we're controlling access, but

50
00:02:39.983 --> 00:02:44.512
not to information and data,
but to physical locations.

51
00:02:44.512 --> 00:02:48.151
And so, Peter, as you're alluding to
there, we'll start with site security, and

52
00:02:48.151 --> 00:02:51.800
we'll also talk about computer security
as far as the physical world goes.

53
00:02:51.800 --> 00:02:54.130
And then we'll talk a little
bit about mobile devices and

54
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:55.280
things like that as well.

55
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:58.569
But when we look at site security,
we'll start at the very outside and

56
00:02:58.569 --> 00:02:59.360
work our way in.

57
00:02:59.360 --> 00:03:02.340
That's what we call out
external perimeter.

58
00:03:02.340 --> 00:03:07.740
And the external perimeter is really
the outside of your physical presence.

59
00:03:07.740 --> 00:03:10.680
So if you have a building, and
then that building sits on a lot,

60
00:03:10.680 --> 00:03:15.680
and that lot has a parking lot and
a driveway, or an entryway of some kind.

61
00:03:15.680 --> 00:03:21.650
All of those grounds, the fence that runs
around your facility's physical location,

62
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:22.800
right, that's your perimeter.

63
00:03:22.800 --> 00:03:26.150
That's really your first
line in physical defense.

64
00:03:26.150 --> 00:03:31.420
So your parking lots, any green spaces,
little bench areas for people to sit and

65
00:03:31.420 --> 00:03:36.800
take their breaks or what have you,
driveways, entryways from

66
00:03:36.800 --> 00:03:41.560
public areas into your, not so much to the
building, but to the grounds themselves.

67
00:03:41.560 --> 00:03:46.010
Those would be considered your exterior or
your external perimeter.

68
00:03:46.010 --> 00:03:47.330
Now how do we protect this?

69
00:03:47.330 --> 00:03:50.926
Well, think about what would you
do if it was your house, right?

70
00:03:50.926 --> 00:03:52.560
You might put up a fence.

71
00:03:52.560 --> 00:03:53.360
That was a good idea.

72
00:03:53.360 --> 00:03:56.990
That keeps people out of your yard or
makes it a little more difficult, right?

73
00:03:56.990 --> 00:04:01.950
It's one more obstacle they would have
to go through to get into your yard.

74
00:04:01.950 --> 00:04:03.740
What else might you put around your house,
Peter?

75
00:04:03.740 --> 00:04:06.180
>> I was suggesting a moat.

76
00:04:06.180 --> 00:04:08.180
>> A moat, yes,
a moat would be a great thing.

77
00:04:08.180 --> 00:04:09.630
Especially if we filled it with sharks and

78
00:04:09.630 --> 00:04:10.300
laser beams-
>> Yeah.

79
00:04:10.300 --> 00:04:11.100
>> Or something.

80
00:04:11.100 --> 00:04:15.425
That would be a great barrier,
definitely slow a lot of people down.

81
00:04:15.425 --> 00:04:18.600
But things like cameras, fences,

82
00:04:18.600 --> 00:04:23.920
guards, dogs that we allow to run
inside the fence maybe after hours.

83
00:04:23.920 --> 00:04:26.790
Lighting is one that is very important.

84
00:04:26.790 --> 00:04:28.640
It plays a big part in security.

85
00:04:28.640 --> 00:04:32.270
It's amazing how much security you
can get out of a little bit of light.

86
00:04:32.270 --> 00:04:33.690
My wife and I, we go back and forth.

87
00:04:33.690 --> 00:04:37.830
I love to leave my porch light on all
night long, my front porch light.

88
00:04:37.830 --> 00:04:39.670
And there's a street light
very near to our house, so

89
00:04:39.670 --> 00:04:40.980
a lot of my yard is lit up there.

90
00:04:40.980 --> 00:04:42.730
And she's like,
why are you leaving that on?

91
00:04:42.730 --> 00:04:44.880
You're just wasting electricity.

92
00:04:44.880 --> 00:04:48.610
And I go out in the street and
I look at my front door, and it's lit up.

93
00:04:48.610 --> 00:04:51.620
You can see my door,
my doorknob, everything's there.

94
00:04:51.620 --> 00:04:55.240
I turn and I look at the neighbor's front
door, and it's a little black alcove.

95
00:04:55.240 --> 00:04:57.080
I can't even tell what color his door is.

96
00:04:57.080 --> 00:05:00.580
And I'm thinking to myself, if I'm a bad
guy, which one am I going to try to get

97
00:05:00.580 --> 00:05:03.860
into, the one where everybody
can see what I'm doing, or

98
00:05:03.860 --> 00:05:06.720
the one where I can be hidden in
darkness and take my time, right?

99
00:05:06.720 --> 00:05:08.810
>> And that's why motion
sensors are such a great thing,

100
00:05:08.810 --> 00:05:12.860
too, especially if you've got ten
entrances around your building.

101
00:05:12.860 --> 00:05:15.410
If the guard is able to see,
hey, this one's lit up now,

102
00:05:15.410 --> 00:05:18.770
that means someone or something is there,
whether it's a raccoon or

103
00:05:18.770 --> 00:05:20.910
it's someone trying to get in,
it's something go check out.

104
00:05:20.910 --> 00:05:21.750
>> It's a great point.

105
00:05:21.750 --> 00:05:25.630
Something has set off that motion
detector, so let's go find out what it is.

106
00:05:25.630 --> 00:05:30.540
So that's kind of our external perimeter
gates with access controls, patrols.

107
00:05:30.540 --> 00:05:32.427
If you're a big facility
you may have guards.

108
00:05:32.427 --> 00:05:36.510
You think about a smaller business,
maybe not so much for a larger business.

109
00:05:36.510 --> 00:05:38.370
I lived in DC for a while.

110
00:05:38.370 --> 00:05:43.180
And after the whole 9/11 thing,
you had concrete barricades and

111
00:05:43.180 --> 00:05:47.860
men and women standing on top of
Humvees with automatic weapons, right?

112
00:05:47.860 --> 00:05:51.680
That's a great deterrent,
keeping that external perimeter secure.

113
00:05:51.680 --> 00:05:53.590
And again, we're talking about layers.

114
00:05:53.590 --> 00:05:55.330
We always talk about layers of defense.

115
00:05:55.330 --> 00:05:57.000
We're not putting all of
our eggs in one basket.

116
00:05:57.000 --> 00:06:00.450
We don't put up a fence and go,
done, we don't have to do any more.

117
00:06:00.450 --> 00:06:04.660
We've got fences and dogs and
cameras and locks, and things like that.

118
00:06:04.660 --> 00:06:05.435
>> All that redundancy.

119
00:06:05.435 --> 00:06:09.120
So Mike, now that we've covered
kind of the external part,

120
00:06:09.120 --> 00:06:10.670
what happens when we get to the building?

121
00:06:10.670 --> 00:06:14.080
>> That would be called our
internal parameter, right?

122
00:06:14.080 --> 00:06:18.560
We've got our external borders
of our grounds basically,

123
00:06:18.560 --> 00:06:22.700
the internal perimeter is your buildings
and the walls to those buildings.

124
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:26.330
So it starts there at the building walls,
and it would really include

125
00:06:26.330 --> 00:06:31.380
most of our internal security measures,
stuff we would find inside the facility.

126
00:06:31.380 --> 00:06:34.150
So that lock on the front door,
that keypad, or

127
00:06:34.150 --> 00:06:37.620
that biometric unit, all of which
we'll talk about a little bit later,

128
00:06:37.620 --> 00:06:40.840
would be part of my internal perimeter
because it's preventing people

129
00:06:40.840 --> 00:06:45.498
from getting past that second
perimeter to our facilities.

130
00:06:45.498 --> 00:06:46.239
Cameras, again,

131
00:06:46.239 --> 00:06:50.822
would most likely be used here, might
be card readers just inside the door.

132
00:06:50.822 --> 00:06:55.000
A lot of times we find it guard desk or
I'm a visitor, I have to check in and

133
00:06:55.000 --> 00:06:58.310
verify that I've got an appointment with
somebody, and show my identification, and

134
00:06:58.310 --> 00:06:59.750
get a visitor badge.

135
00:06:59.750 --> 00:07:03.720
So that they can tell that I'm a visitor,

136
00:07:03.720 --> 00:07:06.740
as I go through the building and make sure
I don't go into places I shouldn't be.

137
00:07:07.830 --> 00:07:09.898
Smoke detectors, turnstiles.

138
00:07:09.898 --> 00:07:14.318
When you think about a train station or
a subway, right, you go in there,

139
00:07:14.318 --> 00:07:18.440
and you can get down into the subway
just walking down the steps.

140
00:07:18.440 --> 00:07:20.660
But then there's a second
level of defense there,

141
00:07:20.660 --> 00:07:23.230
that turnstile, where I've gotta
have my ticket to get through.

142
00:07:23.230 --> 00:07:26.004
And we might have something like
that in place in larger facilities.

143
00:07:26.004 --> 00:07:29.028
You'll see them in courthouses and
places like that,

144
00:07:29.028 --> 00:07:32.680
where I have to go through metal
detectors, maybe, or x-rays.

145
00:07:32.680 --> 00:07:36.220
Man traps, in your high-secure facilities.

146
00:07:36.220 --> 00:07:38.230
They'll have two sets of doors.

147
00:07:38.230 --> 00:07:39.930
One door opens up and

148
00:07:39.930 --> 00:07:42.890
that second door will not open
up until the first door closes.

149
00:07:42.890 --> 00:07:44.990
Now you're in between the doors and

150
00:07:44.990 --> 00:07:47.520
there might be several
security measures taking place

151
00:07:47.520 --> 00:07:51.430
while you're between those doors before
the back door opens up to let you through.

152
00:07:51.430 --> 00:07:53.938
Might be checking your weight.

153
00:07:53.938 --> 00:07:55.590
Does it have a weight limit here,

154
00:07:55.590 --> 00:07:59.680
that's not right you can't discriminate
against me because I'm fat.

155
00:07:59.680 --> 00:08:02.251
Well what they're going to do is
they weigh you on the way in and

156
00:08:02.251 --> 00:08:03.645
they can weigh you on the way out.

157
00:08:03.645 --> 00:08:07.091
And if you're carrying an extra
two pounds, they're looking for

158
00:08:07.091 --> 00:08:10.550
that laptop that you didn't walk
in with but you did walk out with.

159
00:08:10.550 --> 00:08:12.330
Could be again, scanners or

160
00:08:12.330 --> 00:08:16.880
some biometrics to get that second door
open before you're allowed to go through.

161
00:08:16.880 --> 00:08:19.220
>> And I've seen those kinds
of doors too at banks and

162
00:08:19.220 --> 00:08:23.300
places like that where it's not just for
getting in, it's for going out.

163
00:08:23.300 --> 00:08:26.930
So all of a sudden if you're running
out with the loot you just stole,

164
00:08:26.930 --> 00:08:29.340
they've got you trapped pretty much
in between these two doors and

165
00:08:29.340 --> 00:08:31.640
they can just wait for the officials.

166
00:08:31.640 --> 00:08:34.460
>> Yeah it's like a fish in
a bowl right at that point.

167
00:08:34.460 --> 00:08:36.820
You think you're home free you went
right through that first door.

168
00:08:36.820 --> 00:08:40.420
The second door doesn't open, you turn
around, the door's locked behind you,

00:25:39.390 --> 00:25:42.650
a username and password,
you should look at your address bar.

476
00:25:42.650 --> 00:25:44.560
Every browser's going to be different, but

477
00:25:44.560 --> 00:25:48.650
they all have some way of indicating
whether you're on a secure site.

478
00:25:48.650 --> 00:25:54.770
HTTPS, HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure
is the first thing we should look for,

479
00:25:54.770 --> 00:25:56.710
because that is the secure
version of HTTP.

480
00:25:56.710 --> 00:25:59.740
They said, all right,
let's encrypt this traffic, right?

481
00:25:59.740 --> 00:26:03.370
That way if somebody's standing in
between you two, I say standing, right.

482
00:26:03.370 --> 00:26:06.950
Some connection, that they're able
to sniff or capture that data,

483
00:26:06.950 --> 00:26:10.440
as it travels across the Internet,
it'll be encrypted.

484
00:26:10.440 --> 00:26:13.080
They can still capture it, but
they won't be able to read it.

485
00:26:13.080 --> 00:26:16.333
It will be like computer language to them.

486
00:26:16.333 --> 00:26:19.017
So HTTPS is what we're looking for,
and again,

487
00:26:19.017 --> 00:26:23.350
most browsers will let you, they'll
give you some kind of visual indicator.

488
00:26:23.350 --> 00:26:26.941
A green lock, or a green address bar for
additional verification,

489
00:26:26.941 --> 00:26:29.910
we're not really going to go
into all of that right now.

490
00:26:29.910 --> 00:26:32.674
But just understand that
before you submit anything,

491
00:26:32.674 --> 00:26:37.230
you should really pay attention to that
address bar and make sure it's secure.

492
00:26:37.230 --> 00:26:43.020
Some sites will not flip over to HTTPS
until after you've entered the site,

493
00:26:43.020 --> 00:26:43.710
be careful with that.

494
00:26:43.710 --> 00:26:47.040
Don't put your credentials in there,
until you see the HTTPS.

495
00:26:47.040 --> 00:26:50.960
Also be careful, because some sites will
secure the authentication process, but

496
00:26:50.960 --> 00:26:52.740
their entire site is not secure.

497
00:26:52.740 --> 00:26:57.860
So even though it says HTTPS up there, you
might have an iframe that is not secure.

498
00:26:57.860 --> 00:27:02.120
So anything submitted in that particular
part of the webpage could be in plaintext.

499
00:27:02.120 --> 00:27:04.640
Or they'll secure
the authentication traffic, but

500
00:27:04.640 --> 00:27:07.710
then once you've authenticated,
it'll flip back to HTTP.

501
00:27:07.710 --> 00:27:10.030
And no longer is your
data being encrypted.

502
00:27:10.030 --> 00:27:13.890
And that might be fine,
if it's a site like Wikipedia,

503
00:27:13.890 --> 00:27:16.790
where it's not private information,
that's okay.

504
00:27:16.790 --> 00:27:17.632
I don't know, can you authenticate?

505
00:27:17.632 --> 00:27:20.084
I don't think you can
authenticate to Wikipedia.

506
00:27:20.084 --> 00:27:22.348
>> Well, if you're an author, you can.

507
00:27:22.348 --> 00:27:23.306
>> Can you?
Okay, yeah so,

508
00:27:23.306 --> 00:27:25.829
I've never written anything on Wikipedia.

509
00:27:25.829 --> 00:27:28.379
But, so
some sites may switch back to HTTP.

510
00:27:28.379 --> 00:27:30.387
And you feel like you're secure, and

511
00:27:30.387 --> 00:27:33.630
you're willing to type in
a Social Security number.

512
00:27:33.630 --> 00:27:38.470
You didn't look and go, wait,
they switched back to HTTP, not HTTPS, so

513
00:27:38.470 --> 00:27:40.200
pay attention to that.

514
00:27:40.200 --> 00:27:43.870
Last two things, I know Peter is giving me
that signal, we're getting short on time,

515
00:27:43.870 --> 00:27:45.378
so I'll speed up just a little bit.

516
00:27:45.378 --> 00:27:48.795
Phishing and pharming,
both words we're familiar with, but

517
00:27:48.795 --> 00:27:52.478
we're going to spell them a little
differently for this exercise.

518
00:27:52.478 --> 00:27:55.678
We're going to call it phishing
with a P-H, P-H-I-S-H-I-N-G.

519
00:27:55.678 --> 00:27:57.889
And pharming, P-H-A-R-M-I-N-G,
if I spelled that right,

520
00:27:57.889 --> 00:27:58.888
English is not my strong suit.

521
00:27:58.888 --> 00:28:03.001
>> Yeah,
I don't know why you enunciated the R,

522
00:28:03.001 --> 00:28:09.580
because that's not the different part,
but P-H-A-R-M-I-N-G.

523
00:28:09.580 --> 00:28:14.441
>> Yeah,
obviously English is not my strong suit.

524
00:28:14.441 --> 00:28:18.095
But phishing and farming,
with the PH in front of it there,

525
00:28:18.095 --> 00:28:23.620
is a technique that the bad guys use to
basically do, to steal your information.

526
00:28:23.620 --> 00:28:28.657
They are trying to trick you into giving
up personally identifiable information.

527
00:28:28.657 --> 00:28:32.190
Be it user name and password,
Social Security numbers,

528
00:28:32.190 --> 00:28:35.366
bank account numbers,
credit card information.

529
00:28:35.366 --> 00:28:38.705
Anything that they can might
find useful or valuable,

530
00:28:38.705 --> 00:28:40.830
that they can steal and/or sell.

531
00:28:40.830 --> 00:28:44.490
Or steal and sell, or
whatever they want to try to do with it.

532
00:28:44.490 --> 00:28:46.380
So what is the difference?

533
00:28:46.380 --> 00:28:50.260
Well, phishing is typically
done through email,

534
00:28:50.260 --> 00:28:53.380
it can be done through voice,
though, with phone calls.

535
00:28:53.380 --> 00:28:58.050
And that's the whole, hey, click on
this link, well, let me take that back.

536
00:28:58.050 --> 00:29:01.436
With the phishing, it's hey,
send us your password, right?

537
00:29:01.436 --> 00:29:04.593
We need to know your password, so that we
can get you entered into the new system.

538
00:29:04.593 --> 00:29:07.471
Or hey, what's your account number for
such and such, or

539
00:29:07.471 --> 00:29:09.710
what's your Social Security number?

540
00:29:09.710 --> 00:29:11.850
So I can make sure that you
are entered in the system, so

541
00:29:11.850 --> 00:29:14.750
tomorrow morning everything
should work as planned, right?

542
00:29:14.750 --> 00:29:19.820
This is bad guys trying to convince
you to give up information.

543
00:29:19.820 --> 00:29:22.470
Rule number one, email is insecure.

544
00:29:22.470 --> 00:29:25.168
There are ways we can try to secure it,
we can encrypt it,

545
00:29:25.168 --> 00:29:26.584
we can do all kinds of things.

546
00:29:26.584 --> 00:29:31.810
But in your mind, you should always
think email is insecure, right?

547
00:29:31.810 --> 00:29:36.880
Peter, what did you learn about putting
money in the mail, good thing, bad thing?

548
00:29:36.880 --> 00:29:39.285
>> It's frowned upon,
I think I want to send a money order or

549
00:29:39.285 --> 00:29:41.348
a check that's written
out to someone's name.

550
00:29:41.348 --> 00:29:44.350
Or just use the Internet.

551
00:29:44.350 --> 00:29:46.970
>> Yeah, I mean, but it's illegal
to go into somebody's mailbox,

552
00:29:46.970 --> 00:29:48.050
it's a federal crime.

553
00:29:48.050 --> 00:29:51.990
And if I take that $100 bill and
wrap it up in a piece of paper, so

554
00:29:51.990 --> 00:29:55.270
you can't see it, and it should be safe.

555
00:29:55.270 --> 00:29:57.420
Yeah, it should be, but
do you wanna take that risk?

556
00:29:57.420 --> 00:29:59.950
It's the same thing when
you're using email.

557
00:29:59.950 --> 00:30:01.820
Yes it should be safe,
it should be secure,

558
00:30:01.820 --> 00:30:05.900
but should you really put your
Social Security number in an email?

559
00:30:05.900 --> 00:30:10.080
What if somebody gets it,
odds are not great, but what if they do?

560
00:30:10.080 --> 00:30:11.760
Now we're talking identity theft, and

561
00:30:11.760 --> 00:30:14.500
try to recover from that it's a nightmare,
right?

562
00:30:14.500 --> 00:30:18.010
So just consider email pretty insecure,

563
00:30:18.010 --> 00:30:21.040
always consider what information
you're putting in an email.

564
00:30:21.040 --> 00:30:25.400
Never give out personal identifiable
information in an email.

565
00:30:25.400 --> 00:30:28.940
If my bank account, if my bank
needs my Social Security number,

566
00:30:28.940 --> 00:30:32.040
first of all, they better
already have it on file, right?

567
00:30:32.040 --> 00:30:36.250
And if they need it, I will pick up
the phone and I will call them, or

568
00:30:36.250 --> 00:30:37.650
I will stop by and talk to them.

569
00:30:37.650 --> 00:30:39.670
I'm not gonna put it in
the email they sent me,

570
00:30:39.670 --> 00:30:41.320
cuz my bank's not gonna do that to me.

571
00:30:41.320 --> 00:30:44.190
My bank is not that,
well they shouldn't be.

572
00:30:44.190 --> 00:30:49.690
No organization should ever ask you to
submit personal information in an email.

573
00:30:49.690 --> 00:30:52.380
But that's what phishing is all about,
trying to get you to do that.

574
00:30:52.380 --> 00:30:55.635
And a lot us fall victim to it,
that's why it's still around.

575
00:30:55.635 --> 00:30:59.460
Pharming takes it a little bit further,
pharming

576
00:30:59.460 --> 00:31:04.470
is when I'll set up an actual fake
website, that looks like the real deal.

577
00:31:04.470 --> 00:31:07.423
So instead of just trying to get you
to put your password in an email, or

578
00:31:07.423 --> 00:31:09.236
put your Social Security number in there.

579
00:31:09.236 --> 00:31:10.982
I'm going to give you a link,
I'm going to say hey,

580
00:31:10.982 --> 00:31:13.100
you need to come update your password,
it's ready to expire.

581
00:31:13.100 --> 00:31:15.571
And you won't have access
until you update it, and

582
00:31:15.571 --> 00:31:18.200
here's a link to quickly
update your password.

583
00:31:18.200 --> 00:31:21.700
Convenient for you, right, I'm going to
give you a link, I'm such a nice guy.

584
00:31:21.700 --> 00:31:25.050
You click on the link, and it goes to
a site that looks just like PayPal.

585
00:31:25.050 --> 00:31:26.530
And you type in your username and
your password,

586
00:31:26.530 --> 00:31:28.180
you click Submit, and nothing happens.

587
00:31:29.630 --> 00:31:30.310
What do most people do?

588
00:31:30.310 --> 00:31:32.492
>> They're gonna type it again, right?

589
00:31:32.492 --> 00:31:35.660
>> Yes, if it didn't work the first time,
I'm gonna type it again, and

590
00:31:35.660 --> 00:31:37.140
click Submit one more time.

591
00:31:37.140 --> 00:31:40.540
Just to make sure the bad guy now has your
credentials, cuz that what's happening.

592
00:31:40.540 --> 00:31:45.049
If he's a really good bad guy, he'll
redirect you to the real PayPal site,

593
00:31:45.049 --> 00:31:46.041
you'll log in.

594
00:31:46.041 --> 00:31:50.023
And most people'll be like,
it was a glitch, something hung up, but

595
00:31:50.023 --> 00:31:51.630
it's all good now.

596
00:31:51.630 --> 00:31:54.240
In the meantime,
he's logging into your PayPal account,

597
00:31:54.240 --> 00:31:57.890
changing your password, and getting
access to everything you have there.

598
00:31:57.890 --> 00:32:01.320
So phishing is trying to get you
to give up personal information,

599
00:32:01.320 --> 00:32:03.060
typically via email.

600
00:32:03.060 --> 00:32:06.950
Pharming is when we set up fake
websites to try to do the same thing.

601
00:32:06.950 --> 00:32:11.110
Get you to come there and submit your
information, typically log-on information,

602
00:32:11.110 --> 00:32:12.880
that's what we're trying
to get with pharming.

603
00:32:12.880 --> 00:32:15.230
So a couple terms we
need to be familiar with.

604
00:32:15.230 --> 00:32:18.533
>> I think the key takeaway there is,
if you actually use a bank that asks for

605
00:32:18.533 --> 00:32:21.416
that information via email,
you should use a different bank.

606
00:32:21.416 --> 00:32:24.920
>> Change banks immediately,
yes I would, honestly.

607
00:32:24.920 --> 00:32:25.850
>> [LAUGH].

608
00:32:25.850 --> 00:32:29.280
>> Well I think that does a pretty good
job of covering Internet security as it

609
00:32:29.280 --> 00:32:34.310
relates to Microsoft Internet Explorer,
as well a little bit on that Adge.

610
00:32:34.310 --> 00:32:36.010
Thanks for giving us those tips as well,

611
00:32:36.010 --> 00:32:39.265
even though that's something that's
not gonna come up on the exam, per se.

612
00:32:39.265 --> 00:32:41.511
But we are out of time for this episode.

613
00:32:41.511 --> 00:32:45.449
We have a lot more great content coming
about security fundamentals in the future,

614
00:32:45.449 --> 00:32:46.640
so stay tuned for those.

615
00:32:46.640 --> 00:32:50.220
But for now signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Peter VanRysdam.

616
00:32:50.220 --> 00:32:51.200
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

617
00:32:51.200 --> 00:32:51.992
>> And we will see you next time.

618
00:32:51.992 --> 00:32:56.620
[MUSIC]

619
00:32:56.620 --> 00:33:02.196
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV.

6

7
00:00:14.332 --> 00:00:16.194
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam and

8

today we're continuing with our series of
the Microsoft MTA Security Fundamentals.

And specifically in this episode,
we're going to be talking about

00:00:23.610 --> 00:00:26.460

00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:33.620
Mike, how are you doing?

This will be a really short show.

15
00:00:35.260 --> 00:00:36.990
Don't use wireless,
