16
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:37.580
>> There you go.

17
00:00:37.580 --> 00:00:38.500
Well, you see, I'm excited.

18
00:00:38.500 --> 00:00:40.250
So we got a wireless
access point set up here.

19
00:00:40.250 --> 00:00:42.010
We're gonna do some fun hands-on stuff.

20
00:00:42.010 --> 00:00:43.320
So where do we start?

21
00:00:43.320 --> 00:00:46.200
>> We'll take a look at some different
techniques we can use to try to

22
00:00:46.200 --> 00:00:47.580
secure our wireless networks.

23
00:00:48.640 --> 00:00:50.230
I shouldn't say try to.

24
00:00:50.230 --> 00:00:54.450
We're gonna secure our wireless
networks as best we can, anyway.

25
00:00:54.450 --> 00:00:57.250
And again,
this is not a super in depth look at it.

26
00:00:57.250 --> 00:01:00.410
We just want to talk about some of
the terms that we're going to need to be

27
00:01:00.410 --> 00:01:01.070
familiar with.

28
00:01:01.070 --> 00:01:04.780
Like when we look at our router or our
wireless access point configuration, and

29
00:01:04.780 --> 00:01:09.550
it gives us these choices to pick as far
as security goes, which one do I pick?

30
00:01:09.550 --> 00:01:10.870
What's the difference between them?

31
00:01:10.870 --> 00:01:13.430
Why would I choose one over the other?

32
00:01:13.430 --> 00:01:18.960
That's what I want to talk about here
when we talk about wireless security.

33
00:01:18.960 --> 00:01:22.570
So let's start by talking about

34
00:01:22.570 --> 00:01:27.200
what they call the specific
security types, all right?

35
00:01:27.200 --> 00:01:29.010
When we look at wireless security,

36
00:01:29.010 --> 00:01:31.640
there's a couple of different
protocols that we can use.

37
00:01:31.640 --> 00:01:33.160
One, we can leave it wide open I guess.

38
00:01:33.160 --> 00:01:34.550
So there's a third option.

39
00:01:34.550 --> 00:01:36.550
Not really a protocol, but it's an option.

40
00:01:36.550 --> 00:01:38.090
You just leave security off, right.

41
00:01:38.090 --> 00:01:41.040
Which is the default unfortunately,

42
00:01:41.040 --> 00:01:44.980
on many routers although that has
changed over the last couple of years.

43
00:01:44.980 --> 00:01:49.010
But it used to be a big problem,
is that they would just come wide open.

44
00:01:49.010 --> 00:01:52.470
And what that means is,
let's back up for a second.

45
00:01:52.470 --> 00:01:55.590
A wireless access point or a WAP for

46
00:01:55.590 --> 00:02:00.650
short, I know Titus has got a shot
of the one we've got sitting here.

47
00:02:00.650 --> 00:02:04.460
And we've already been informed before we
started the show about how old this one

48
00:02:04.460 --> 00:02:09.660
is, since it says Cisco Linksys on there,
which is no longer the case,

49
00:02:09.660 --> 00:02:12.440
but that's beside the point with this.

50
00:02:12.440 --> 00:02:14.960
And again, it's a wireless access point.

51
00:02:14.960 --> 00:02:21.430
What this allows us to do is to connect
wireless devices to our wired network.

52
00:02:21.430 --> 00:02:21.980
all right.

53
00:02:21.980 --> 00:02:25.720
Though you'll notice there is a cable
coming out of the back of this.

54
00:02:25.720 --> 00:02:29.060
You think, wait, it's a wireless
access point, why do you have wires?

55
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:32.290
One is for power, but the other one
is to connect to the wired network.

56
00:02:32.290 --> 00:02:35.480
At some point we need to transition
to the wired networks so

57
00:02:35.480 --> 00:02:38.580
that it can go out my
Internet connection cable.

58
00:02:38.580 --> 00:02:42.650
If I'm at home, Cox, Comcast,
Bright House, whoever is doing that.

59
00:02:42.650 --> 00:02:47.010
Or if you're at work connecting your
mobile devices to the work network, so

60
00:02:47.010 --> 00:02:50.940
you can get access to the work resources
or the Internet through there.

61
00:02:50.940 --> 00:02:53.630
So there is at some point it
gets to the wired network, and

62
00:02:53.630 --> 00:02:56.760
that's what the wireless
access point is for.

63
00:02:56.760 --> 00:03:00.360
It's for allowing wireless
clients to connect to the wired

64
00:03:00.360 --> 00:03:02.570
portion of your network.

65
00:03:02.570 --> 00:03:04.460
>> So Mike, this cable here in this case,

66
00:03:04.460 --> 00:03:07.280
this is an input bringing
the Internet into it?

67
00:03:07.280 --> 00:03:08.800
Or you're saying-
>> Well,

68
00:03:08.800 --> 00:03:10.610
I've kind of tricked it a little bit.

69
00:03:10.610 --> 00:03:13.190
This is actually going straight
to my computer, just so

70
00:03:13.190 --> 00:03:14.870
we can see the configuration page.

71
00:03:14.870 --> 00:03:18.715
But if we were to look at the back of this
guy, normally you're going to have one

72
00:03:18.715 --> 00:03:21.591
port that's a little bit
different than the rest of them.

73
00:03:21.591 --> 00:03:27.390
It will say WAN or Internet and
that would actually go to my modem that

74
00:03:27.390 --> 00:03:33.555
my ISP provided for me, or
at work it would tie back into a switch.

75
00:03:33.555 --> 00:03:36.545
And these other ports are to
support wired clients.

76
00:03:36.545 --> 00:03:41.335
Because you can do wired and
wireless clients with a device like this.

77
00:03:41.335 --> 00:03:44.755
Now I've plugged into one
of the wired ports just so

78
00:03:44.755 --> 00:03:48.555
that I can show you the configuration
options inside here.

79
00:03:48.555 --> 00:03:53.361
But normally that cable would be going
from the Internet port to my cable

80
00:03:53.361 --> 00:03:55.613

00:15:42.710 --> 00:15:46.730
It was when wireless access points
first came out, this is what we had.

309
00:15:46.730 --> 00:15:48.530
And it was better than nothing.

310
00:15:48.530 --> 00:15:51.894
But it didn't take long for the bad guys
to find some vulnerabilities in there.

311
00:15:51.894 --> 00:15:56.254
And as computers became more powerful,
it became pretty easy to crack.

312
00:15:56.254 --> 00:16:03.100
And today, WEP is considered Unusually,
I don't wanna say unusual, unusable.

313
00:16:04.460 --> 00:16:09.120
But it's not much better than turning
off your SSID broadcast, honestly.

314
00:16:09.120 --> 00:16:12.350
Anybody that really wants to
crack it can crack it in minutes.

315
00:16:12.350 --> 00:16:14.200
It will not take them long.

316
00:16:14.200 --> 00:16:16.780
But the passerby,

317
00:16:16.780 --> 00:16:21.430
the kids from the neighbor, they might
not go to those extreme lengths.

318
00:16:21.430 --> 00:16:23.780
So, should you turn it on?

319
00:16:23.780 --> 00:16:26.740
If that's all you have available,
absolutely, right?

320
00:16:26.740 --> 00:16:28.330
It's better than nothing.

321
00:16:28.330 --> 00:16:30.080
You look at the lock on my kitchen window.

322
00:16:30.080 --> 00:16:33.565
It's one of those old kind of flip
the lever type locks that anybody can take

323
00:16:33.565 --> 00:16:36.677
a butter knife and stick up in there and
jimmy along and pop it open.

324
00:16:36.677 --> 00:16:38.440
It would take two seconds.

325
00:16:38.440 --> 00:16:39.700
Do I lock it anyway?

326
00:16:39.700 --> 00:16:42.240
Absolutely, because hopefully
I will hear somebody

327
00:16:42.240 --> 00:16:43.780
trying to get through the window, right?

328
00:16:43.780 --> 00:16:45.564
We always still turn it on.

329
00:16:45.564 --> 00:16:47.590
So WEP if that's all you have.

330
00:16:47.590 --> 00:16:50.922
Then we have WPA, and we have WPA2.

331
00:16:50.922 --> 00:16:56.074
WPA is my WiFi Protected Alliance,
and WPA2 is the second

332
00:16:56.074 --> 00:17:01.560
iteration of WPA, and
I'll expand on that in a second.

333
00:17:01.560 --> 00:17:06.366
Each one of those, WPA and
WPA2, has a personal mode and

334
00:17:06.366 --> 00:17:09.180
an Enterprise mode, all right.

335
00:17:09.180 --> 00:17:15.420
WPA was the WiFi Alliance's attempt
to fix some of the problems with WEP.

336
00:17:15.420 --> 00:17:19.900
We have a body for the promote standards,
IEEE, the Institute of Electronics and

337
00:17:19.900 --> 00:17:22.430
Electrical Engineers, and
they put out standards.

338
00:17:22.430 --> 00:17:24.580
But it takes them awhile to do this.

339
00:17:24.580 --> 00:17:26.340
And in the meantime, nobody was buying or

340
00:17:26.340 --> 00:17:29.526
implementing wireless networks because
the security for WEP was so poor.

341
00:17:29.526 --> 00:17:32.522
So the WiFi Alliance said hey,
we're gonna fix it.

342
00:17:32.522 --> 00:17:35.200
We're gonna come up with some
things that we can do better and

343
00:17:35.200 --> 00:17:36.380
make it a little more secure.

344
00:17:36.380 --> 00:17:38.560
And that was where WPA came in.

345
00:17:38.560 --> 00:17:43.169
Well eventually, the IEEE got around
to ratifying all their standards, and

346
00:17:43.169 --> 00:17:49.740
the WPA2 is what implements all of the
standards that are called out by the IEEE.

347
00:17:49.740 --> 00:17:53.390
So once they came up with their standards,
the WPA2 came about.

348
00:17:54.810 --> 00:17:57.940
Personal enterprise,
whether it's WPA or WPA2,

349
00:17:57.940 --> 00:18:02.075
personal is gonna use pass phrases or
passwords, much like WEP did.

350
00:18:02.075 --> 00:18:04.555
Where you put a password
in on the access point, and

351
00:18:04.555 --> 00:18:07.820
then anybody that wants to
connect has to know the password.

352
00:18:07.820 --> 00:18:09.250
So if Peter comes over to my house or

353
00:18:09.250 --> 00:18:12.694
to my place of work, he says hey,
what's your access point?

354
00:18:12.694 --> 00:18:14.798
It's SkyNet, what's your password?

355
00:18:14.798 --> 00:18:15.419
It's password 123.

356
00:18:15.419 --> 00:18:18.130
He can type it in and now connect to it.

357
00:18:18.130 --> 00:18:20.370
That's what the personal option is.

358
00:18:20.370 --> 00:18:24.460
It doesn't require any
additional equipment,

359
00:18:24.460 --> 00:18:25.710
just have to configure the password.

360
00:18:25.710 --> 00:18:30.364
And if I make it strong enough,
I'm relatively secured, not WEP,

361
00:18:30.364 --> 00:18:32.170
WEP is still vulnerable.

362
00:18:32.170 --> 00:18:35.980
WPA is also vulnerable,
but not as bad as WEP.

363
00:18:35.980 --> 00:18:39.665
And a good, long,
strong password will help.

364
00:18:39.665 --> 00:18:44.845
WPA or WPA2 Enterprise uses something
known as digital certificates for

365
00:18:44.845 --> 00:18:46.580
authentication.

366
00:18:46.580 --> 00:18:49.365
These are electronic documents that
have your identifying information

367
00:18:49.365 --> 00:18:50.010
stored in them.

368
00:18:50.010 --> 00:18:55.210
And they're much more secure and
much harder to fake than a password.

369
00:18:55.210 --> 00:18:58.440
You can guess passwords,
I can try to crack passwords.

370
00:18:58.440 --> 00:19:00.280
I can't do that with a certificate.

371
00:19:00.280 --> 00:19:02.780
But it also requires me
having the infrastructure to

372
00:19:02.780 --> 00:19:06.330
issue certificates to all my laptops or
mobile devices.

373
00:19:06.330 --> 00:19:09.294
Installing them on those devices,
so that when they go to connect,

374
00:19:09.294 --> 00:19:12.060
the access point can say,
hey laptop, prove to me who you are.

375
00:19:12.060 --> 00:19:16.370
Here's my certificate, just like you would
your driver's license to a police officer.

376
00:19:16.370 --> 00:19:19.130
And then once they identify each other,
it'll allow that laptop or

377
00:19:19.130 --> 00:19:21.750
mobile device to connect
to the access point.

378
00:19:21.750 --> 00:19:25.610
So a lot more secure because it's
a lot more difficult to try to

379
00:19:25.610 --> 00:19:30.750
impersonate a certificate, but
extra infrastructure, extra setup.

380
00:19:30.750 --> 00:19:33.940
That's why they call it Enterprise cuz
typically that's something you see

381
00:19:33.940 --> 00:19:38.050
in an enterprise, where I've got
the money to spend on things like that.

382
00:19:38.050 --> 00:19:42.480
So when we look at these,
I want you to think about them in order.

383
00:19:42.480 --> 00:19:45.935
WEP was the first one we had,
it's better than nothing.

384
00:19:45.935 --> 00:19:50.830
But it's just the illusion
of security at this point.

385
00:19:50.830 --> 00:19:52.390
It's very, very crackable.

386
00:19:52.390 --> 00:19:55.430
But if it's all you have, turn it on.

387
00:19:55.430 --> 00:19:59.480
WPA was intended to replace WEP,
it's more secure.

388
00:19:59.480 --> 00:20:02.540
Still has some of the vulnerabilities that
we had in WEP because it was backwards

389
00:20:02.540 --> 00:20:03.940
compatible with WEP.

390
00:20:03.940 --> 00:20:05.580
So there are some vulnerabilities.

391
00:20:05.580 --> 00:20:09.554
But it uses something known as
temporal key integrity protocol,

392
00:20:09.554 --> 00:20:12.587
which is something we
don't need to worry about,

393
00:20:12.587 --> 00:20:17.081
but it changes up the keys very fast,
and it makes it a lot harder to crack.

394
00:20:17.081 --> 00:20:21.923
WP2 was the second iteration of WPA,
and this was developed after

395
00:20:21.923 --> 00:20:26.347
the IEEE formalized their standard for
the 802.11i.

396
00:20:26.347 --> 00:20:31.068
And it includes all of the things that
are called out in those standards.

397
00:20:31.068 --> 00:20:33.820
Personal uses passphrases or passwords for

398
00:20:33.820 --> 00:20:36.290
the authentication process
to the access point.

399
00:20:36.290 --> 00:20:41.930
Enterprise uses typically
certificates to do the authentication

400
00:20:41.930 --> 00:20:45.850
between the device and the access point.

401
00:20:45.850 --> 00:20:46.788
All right, so those are our choices.

402
00:20:46.788 --> 00:20:49.925
I mean WPA2 is first choice, personal or

403
00:20:49.925 --> 00:20:54.260
enterprise depending on
what your environment is.

404
00:20:54.260 --> 00:20:57.475
If I can't do WPA2 because some
of my devices don't support it,

405
00:20:57.475 --> 00:20:58.359
maybe I go to WPA.

406
00:20:58.359 --> 00:21:03.165
If I can't do WPA, I go to WEP,
if I can't do WEP, I give up and

407
00:21:03.165 --> 00:21:05.815
I don't run wireless, right?

408
00:21:05.815 --> 00:21:09.540
Cuz at that point, everything that
goes across it is insecure and

409
00:21:09.540 --> 00:21:10.139
anybody can read it.

410
00:21:11.370 --> 00:21:13.260
All right,
how're we doing on time there, Peter?

411
00:21:13.260 --> 00:21:14.310
>> Great question, Mike.

412
00:21:14.310 --> 00:21:16.790
We are pretty much out of time, and
I see we've got a lot more to cover and

413
00:21:16.790 --> 00:21:17.730
I don't wanna rush through it.

414
00:21:17.730 --> 00:21:20.470
So let's go ahead and move this up
to a part 2, does that sound good?

415
00:21:20.470 --> 00:21:21.620
>> Sounds like a plan to me.

416
00:21:21.620 --> 00:21:24.950
>> All right, well, we're gonna go ahead
and sign off then for this episode.

417
00:21:24.950 --> 00:21:27.144
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Peter VanRysdam.

418
00:21:27.144 --> 00:21:28.230
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

419
00:21:28.230 --> 00:21:28.950
>> And we will see you next time.

420
00:21:28.950 --> 00:21:36.790
[MUSIC]

421
00:21:36.790 --> 00:21:38.415
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this part two, Peter and Mike go beyond wireless keys to cover topics like SSID configuration and MAC filtering. They show hands on how to set up each of these.
episodes.title: Wireless Security Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.349
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.349 --> 00:00:03.055
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.055 --> 00:00:06.693
[CROSSTALK].

4
00:00:06.693 --> 00:00:08.483
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.483 --> 00:00:12.292
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.292 --> 00:00:15.100
>> Hello, everybody,
and welcome to ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.100 --> 00:00:16.470
I'm your host, Peter VanRysdam.

8
00:00:16.470 --> 00:00:20.160
Today, we're continuing with our
MTA Security Fundamentals course.

9
00:00:20.160 --> 00:00:23.980
And this is actually a part two
of our wireless security course.

10
00:00:23.980 --> 00:00:25.390
We started it last time.

11
00:00:25.390 --> 00:00:26.450
A lot to cover in it, so

12
00:00:26.450 --> 00:00:30.600
we're gonna go ahead and pick up where we
left off right now with Mr Mike Rodrick.

13
00:00:30.600 --> 00:00:31.610
Mike, how you doing?

14
00:00:31.610 --> 00:00:36.250
>> I'm doing great, although I do have
a correction to make from our part one.

15
00:00:36.250 --> 00:00:37.500
>> This is mortifying, Mike.

16
00:00:37.500 --> 00:00:38.855
What did we do wrong?

17
00:00:38.855 --> 00:00:40.640
>> Well, I was goofing around and

18
00:00:40.640 --> 00:00:43.720
I was trying to show everybody
how change the SSID.

19
00:00:43.720 --> 00:00:45.640
And then it didn't change in the list and

20
00:00:45.640 --> 00:00:47.770
I was kinda getting a little
flustered with that there.

21
00:00:47.770 --> 00:00:50.900
And I realized I was not
changing it in the right spot.

22
00:00:50.900 --> 00:00:53.275
Remember, I had the Wi-Fi
protected setup or

23
00:00:53.275 --> 00:00:56.540
Wi-Fi protected setup turned on and
it was hiding a bunch of features?

24
00:00:57.560 --> 00:00:58.250
I'll show you here.

25
00:00:58.250 --> 00:00:59.790
Let's just take a look at my screen.

26
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:00.610
What I was doing,

27
00:01:00.610 --> 00:01:04.530
I was on the set up, and every wireless
access point will be slightly different.

28
00:01:04.530 --> 00:01:08.200
And I was changing it right here in
the middle of my screen where it says

29
00:01:08.200 --> 00:01:09.690
Device Name.

30
00:01:09.690 --> 00:01:11.775
That has nothing to do with the SSID.

31
00:01:11.775 --> 00:01:13.980
That's just its internal name.

32
00:01:13.980 --> 00:01:14.990
That's where I was changing.

33
00:01:14.990 --> 00:01:19.220
And that's why it wasn't working, because
I wasn't actually changing the SSID.

34
00:01:19.220 --> 00:01:22.014
So let me show you how to
actually change the SSID.

35
00:01:22.014 --> 00:01:24.885
If I go back over to wireless, and

36
00:01:24.885 --> 00:01:29.720
I do no longer have my Wi-Fi
protected set up turned on.

37
00:01:29.720 --> 00:01:34.250
I've got it on manual, so
now I can see the SSID broadcast option.

38
00:01:34.250 --> 00:01:35.910
It's currently disabled.

39
00:01:35.910 --> 00:01:38.830
And the network name, not the device name.

40
00:01:38.830 --> 00:01:43.360
The network name, that's the SSID,
and that's what I need to change.

41
00:01:43.360 --> 00:01:48.688
So let me zoom back out, and
I will change this to Skynet,

42
00:01:48.688 --> 00:01:53.251
and I'm gonna enable
the broadcast of the SSID.

43
00:01:53.251 --> 00:01:55.210
I'm gonna save those settings.

44
00:01:55.210 --> 00:01:59.872
>> And so now this is when we'll
see the different names show up in

45
00:01:59.872 --> 00:02:03.530
our list of available Wi-Fi hotspots.

46
00:02:03.530 --> 00:02:05.025
Fingers crossed, right?

47
00:02:05.025 --> 00:02:08.466
[LAUGH] Yes, that's what it should be,
so if I go back now,

48
00:02:08.466 --> 00:02:11.933
look at my list of networks,
I hopefully will see Skynet.

49
00:02:11.933 --> 00:02:12.550
>> Hey!

50
00:02:12.550 --> 00:02:15.670
>> Right there, in my list, all right.

51
00:02:15.670 --> 00:02:17.588
And if I disable Broadcast now,

52
00:02:17.588 --> 00:02:20.870
we should [LAUGH] also be able
to see that name go away.

53
00:02:20.870 --> 00:02:23.052
So I'll choose Disable,
I'll save settings.

54
00:02:25.560 --> 00:02:26.648
Maybe it's gonna save settings.

55
00:02:26.648 --> 00:02:29.620
>> And while that's saving, I'll let you
know it just changed on mine as well.

56
00:02:29.620 --> 00:02:32.750
So I am seeing the broadcast
now saying Skynet.

57
00:02:32.750 --> 00:02:35.190
Well, now I'm not seeing anything.

58
00:02:35.190 --> 00:02:36.190
>> It's not, did it disappear?

59
00:02:37.490 --> 00:02:37.990
Is it gone?

60
00:02:39.270 --> 00:02:41.860
I still have it in my list, but
it'd probably take a minute or two.

61
00:02:41.860 --> 00:02:45.250
My computer still
remembers it being there.

62
00:02:45.250 --> 00:02:49.880
So it'll be a few minutes before that
cache times out, and it goes away.

63
00:02:49.880 --> 00:02:52.670
If it wasn't there, but
I know the network exists,

64
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:55.900
because my company's disabled
the broadcast of the SSID.

65
00:02:55.900 --> 00:02:59.890
Or my friend comes over to my house and
I've disabled that, how do they connect?

66
00:02:59.890 --> 00:03:02.020
Well, it's not gonna show up in the list,
so

67
00:03:02.020 --> 00:03:05.180
they're gonna have to manually go into
their network and Internet settings.

68
00:03:05.180 --> 00:03:08.340
Typically, you're gonna
go over here to Wi-Fi.

69
00:03:08.340 --> 00:03:13.330
And in here,
I should be able to click on a network.

70
00:03:13.330 --> 00:03:16.470
Show available networks just
takes me back to that list.

71
00:03:16.470 --> 00:03:20.770
Manage no networks, and
I can add a new network.

72
00:03:20.770 --> 00:03:22.670
And this is where I
would type in the name.

73
00:03:22.670 --> 00:03:24.870
So I would have to get that
information from the owner or

74
00:03:24.870 --> 00:03:27.470
operator of the access point, type it in.

75
00:03:27.470 --> 00:03:29.980
And I can choose connect automatically,

76
00:03:29.980 --> 00:03:33.790
connect even if this network is not
broadcasting, I will have to select that.

77
00:03:33.790 --> 00:03:37.760
Because I've turned the broadcast
off on the actual device all right?

78
00:03:37.760 --> 00:03:38.860
But then I can connect to it.

79
00:03:38.860 --> 00:03:41.250
It'll connect automatically
when I'm in range.

80
00:03:41.250 --> 00:03:43.520
There are some security
concerns with that,

81
00:03:43.520 --> 00:03:46.700
really beyond the level
of this particular exam.

82
00:03:46.700 --> 00:03:49.010
I will tell you, though,
that there are some issues.

83
00:03:49.010 --> 00:03:54.210
Remember, turning off the broadcast to the
SSID, in my personal opinion, doesn't give

84
00:03:54.210 --> 00:03:59.410
me enough to warrant the inconvenience for
the people that I want to connect to it.

85
00:03:59.410 --> 00:04:02.250
Unless I'm in a really high
security sensitive area,

86
00:04:02.250 --> 00:04:06.500
maybe I take that additional step, but
it's not giving me a lot of protection.

87
00:04:06.500 --> 00:04:10.050
In fact,
if I choose to connect automatically, and

88
00:04:10.050 --> 00:04:12.610
connect if it's not broadcasting, right?

89
00:04:12.610 --> 00:04:17.380
Well, now what's gonna happen is when my
laptop comes in range of the access point,

90
00:04:17.380 --> 00:04:18.850
how does it know it's in range?

91
00:04:18.850 --> 00:04:21.530
The access point is no longer beaconing so
it's not gonna show up and

92
00:04:21.530 --> 00:04:22.580
go, hey, there's Skynet.

93
00:04:22.580 --> 00:04:24.670
I'm supposed to connect automatically.

94
00:04:24.670 --> 00:04:26.710
So now my laptop has to do the opposite.

95
00:04:26.710 --> 00:04:29.130
It has to holler out, hey,
Skynet, are you out there?

96
00:04:29.130 --> 00:04:30.780
Hey, Skynet, are you out there?

97
00:04:30.780 --> 00:04:33.240
It could be at Starbucks 200 miles away.

98
00:04:33.240 --> 00:04:34.100
My computer is unknown.

99
00:04:34.100 --> 00:04:36.080
It's like, hey, Skynet, are you out there?

100
00:04:36.080 --> 00:04:36.720
So technically,

101
00:04:36.720 --> 00:04:42.800
I'm giving away the SSID now because
I chose to disable to SSID broadcast.

102
00:04:42.800 --> 00:04:44.070
See how that works?

103
00:04:44.070 --> 00:04:47.380
So again, my opinion,
it's probably not something we should do

104
00:04:47.380 --> 00:04:50.840
unless just certain
circumstances warrant it.

105
00:04:50.840 --> 00:04:55.041
All right, I'm gonna go just turn
it back on for giggles sake, and

106
00:04:55.041 --> 00:05:00.430
the next thing I wanna talk about is,
we talked about WEP, WPA and WPA2.

107
00:05:00.430 --> 00:05:03.360
We talked about personal and enterprise.

108
00:05:03.360 --> 00:05:07.870
I wanna mention a term key, we said that
a couple times in the previous episode.

109
00:05:07.870 --> 00:05:09.780
Wanna kinda define that again.

110
00:05:09.780 --> 00:05:14.620
For the MTA we don't have to set up
an entire certificate infrastructure or

111
00:05:14.620 --> 00:05:17.830
understand synchronous and
asynchronous encryption.

112
00:05:17.830 --> 00:05:21.030
But I do want you to understand
the concept of a key, right?

113
00:05:21.030 --> 00:05:26.210
Because the key is what we
use to encrypt the data.

114
00:05:26.210 --> 00:05:28.930
So when we enable WEP, or we enable WPA or

115
00:05:28.930 --> 00:05:33.800
WPA2, it uses an encryption algorithm,
a set of instructions on

116
00:05:33.800 --> 00:05:37.910
how to encrypt the data and
a key along with the instructions.

117
00:05:37.910 --> 00:05:39.470
Now why do we use that key?

118
00:05:39.470 --> 00:05:43.010

00:05:43.010 --> 00:05:45.710

00:05:45.710 --> 00:05:49.810

00:05:49.810 --> 00:05:51.020
to encrypt it.

00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:56.120

00:05:56.120 --> 00:05:58.320

00:05:58.320 --> 00:06:01.170

00:06:01.170 --> 00:06:05.390

00:06:05.390 --> 00:06:06.700

00:06:06.700 --> 00:06:10.190

00:06:10.190 --> 00:06:12.170
But I can't go to my neighbor's house and

00:06:12.170 --> 00:06:15.650

use a key with the lock.

00:06:15.650 --> 00:06:19.340
Everybody has a lock, but
we all have our own keys.

00:06:19.340 --> 00:06:22.400
And my key is the only key
that will unlock my lock.

132
00:06:22.400 --> 00:06:25.290

anybody else's.

00:06:25.290 --> 00:06:27.790
And that's what keys are when

00:06:27.790 --> 00:06:30.320
It's a simplified way of looking at it.

00:06:30.320 --> 00:06:33.630
But it's something that makes

00:06:33.630 --> 00:06:37.510

00:06:37.510 --> 00:06:39.720

00:06:39.720 --> 00:06:44.360

00:06:44.360 --> 00:06:47.898

00:06:47.898 --> 00:06:51.073

00:06:51.073 --> 00:06:55.144

00:06:55.144 --> 00:06:58.890

00:06:58.890 --> 00:07:02.140

00:07:13.930 --> 00:07:14.893

because I've got to keep
that list up to date.

345
00:18:03.840 --> 00:18:07.330
If we're doing the allow option people are
gonna bring in devices that haven't been

346
00:18:07.330 --> 00:18:10.150
there before, they're gonna complain they
can't connect, you got to bring me your

347
00:18:10.150 --> 00:18:13.680
device, I got to get your Mac address,
I've got to add you to the list.

348
00:18:13.680 --> 00:18:17.755
If I have more than one access point,
I get to add it to all the access points.

349
00:18:17.755 --> 00:18:21.480
The prevents, it will block people, but

350
00:18:21.480 --> 00:18:24.520
also keep in mind that Mac
addresses can be spoofed.

351
00:18:24.520 --> 00:18:28.610
So all I need to do is figure
out what devices are allowed,

352
00:18:28.610 --> 00:18:32.870
change my Mac address to that, and
I'll still be able to connect.

353
00:18:32.870 --> 00:18:36.900
And I tell you these things, again, not to
make you think, gosh well wireless is so

354
00:18:36.900 --> 00:18:38.930
insecure, why even bother?

355
00:18:38.930 --> 00:18:43.130
Because as long as you're aware of it,
you'll know what the weaknesses are and

356
00:18:43.130 --> 00:18:44.615
we can combine methods.

357
00:18:44.615 --> 00:18:48.250
And if MAC address filtering
is not my only method,

358
00:18:48.250 --> 00:18:50.190
it can definitely help keep me secure.

359
00:18:50.190 --> 00:18:54.350
Because it does stop
the casual passersbys and

360
00:18:54.350 --> 00:18:56.120
the wanna be hackers and things like that.

361
00:18:56.120 --> 00:18:57.890
And that's a good step.

362
00:18:57.890 --> 00:18:59.665
It's not gonna keep out the black hats.

363
00:18:59.665 --> 00:19:03.350
But in the end it's kinda like people say,

364
00:19:03.350 --> 00:19:06.770
if somebody wants to break into your
house, they're gonna break into your

365
00:19:06.770 --> 00:19:09.590
house, no matter what kinds of locks
you have and windows you have.

366
00:19:09.590 --> 00:19:11.372
Given enough time and
effort, they can get in, and

367
00:19:11.372 --> 00:19:13.123
it's the same thing with
our wireless networks.

368
00:19:13.123 --> 00:19:18.051
But we can definitely slow them down and
make them take more time and more effort,

369
00:19:18.051 --> 00:19:22.580
and hopefully more time and more effort
is more than they want to put in.

370
00:19:22.580 --> 00:19:24.040
The payoff is not big enough,

371
00:19:24.040 --> 00:19:27.040
and they're going to go on to
the next easier target, all right.

372
00:19:28.190 --> 00:19:31.280
So when it comes to wireless security,
a lot of things to consider.

373
00:19:31.280 --> 00:19:34.610
You gotta think about the one thing
I didn't do was turn on the security.

374
00:19:34.610 --> 00:19:38.990
Let me go over to the security tab,
I'm sorry the wireless tab, and

375
00:19:38.990 --> 00:19:41.540
then take a look at my wireless security.

376
00:19:42.710 --> 00:19:45.740
Remember I think I showed you the list but
I didn't actually turn anything on.

377
00:19:45.740 --> 00:19:49.290
I'm gonna go ahead and
turn on WPA personal.

378
00:19:49.290 --> 00:19:50.830
All right, and

379
00:19:50.830 --> 00:19:55.360
it tells me that it's going to drop down
to G, that's just this particular adapter.

380
00:19:55.360 --> 00:19:59.182
And once I turn it on to WAP personal,
look what I get.

381
00:19:59.182 --> 00:20:01.060
An option to put a pass phrase.

382
00:20:01.060 --> 00:20:03.670
And now once I put that in there and
save my settings,

383
00:20:03.670 --> 00:20:07.210
anybody that wants to connect to the
access point will need that pass phrase.

384
00:20:08.530 --> 00:20:12.000
All right, if I go to WPA2, personal.

385
00:20:12.000 --> 00:20:15.470
Not gonna see a whole lot of difference
here because it's still just based

386
00:20:15.470 --> 00:20:16.010
on password.

387
00:20:16.010 --> 00:20:18.380
It is the background using
different encryption and

388
00:20:18.380 --> 00:20:22.670
it is stronger than WPA, but
it's still just using a pass phrase.

389
00:20:22.670 --> 00:20:30.050
If I go to enterprise, You'll see
the options are a little bit different.

390
00:20:30.050 --> 00:20:34.845
Now all of a sudden I have RADIUS server
IP address, port, and shared secret.

391
00:20:34.845 --> 00:20:38.980
And we're going to talk in another
episode a lot about what RADIUS is.

392
00:20:38.980 --> 00:20:42.210
The short answer is,
we're telling the access point, look,

393
00:20:42.210 --> 00:20:45.370
you're no longer responsible for
checking passwords.

394
00:20:45.370 --> 00:20:47.530
You just take the information,

395
00:20:47.530 --> 00:20:52.140
send it over the RADIUS server that
I've entered in here, let them do it.

396
00:20:52.140 --> 00:20:53.872
And the RADIUS server will tell you,

397
00:20:53.872 --> 00:20:56.830
Mr Access Point,
whether to allow them or not.

398
00:20:56.830 --> 00:20:59.830
So we're moving the authentication
process off of the access point

399
00:20:59.830 --> 00:21:03.702
which is usually a good thing because
the access point are, especially this one,

400
00:21:03.702 --> 00:21:07.310
it's relative inexpensive, doesn't have
a huge amount of processing power, and

401
00:21:07.310 --> 00:21:09.490
it's exposed so people can hack on it.

402
00:21:09.490 --> 00:21:14.070
That RADIUS server's gonna be back behind
my firewall, much beefier security on

403
00:21:14.070 --> 00:21:17.770
that, a lot more difficult for the bad
guys to try to access and attempt to hack.

404
00:21:18.800 --> 00:21:21.800
But we usually don't have RADIUS
servers sitting around at home,

405
00:21:21.800 --> 00:21:23.990
so that's why we call this one Enterprise.

406
00:21:23.990 --> 00:21:26.920
So hopefully that'll give you some
information you need to, one,

407
00:21:26.920 --> 00:21:32.440
secure your wireless network at home and
at work, as well as pass the MTA exam.

408
00:21:32.440 --> 00:21:33.640
>> Sounds good, Mike, I appreciate it.

409
00:21:33.640 --> 00:21:35.750
And if there's anything that
you didn't hear in that one,

410
00:21:35.750 --> 00:21:37.520
make sure you went back and
watched the part one.

411
00:21:37.520 --> 00:21:40.690
Cuz we did have two parts of that episode
with a lot of great information on

412
00:21:40.690 --> 00:21:41.560
setting all those up.

413
00:21:41.560 --> 00:21:44.550
And what the benefits of
the different types of security are.

414
00:21:44.550 --> 00:21:47.260
So go back and check that for
sure, but that's gonna wrap up for

415
00:21:47.260 --> 00:21:48.130
wireless security.

416
00:21:48.130 --> 00:21:51.110
So we're gonna go ahead and
wrap up this episode as well.

417
00:21:51.110 --> 00:21:54.310
So signing off for ITProTV,
I have been your host Peter VanRysdam.

418
00:21:54.310 --> 00:21:55.090
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

419
00:21:55.090 --> 00:21:57.117
>> And we will see you next time.

420
00:21:57.117 --> 00:22:03.516
[MUSIC]

421
00:22:03.516 --> 00:22:06.757
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Passwords are just one way to authenticate users on your network. In this episode, Peter and Mike outline the different pieces that make up multifactor authentication while discussing the pros and cons of each.
episodes.title: User Authentication
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:04.340
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.340 --> 00:00:06.299
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.299 --> 00:00:08.195
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.195 --> 00:00:12.158
>> You're watching ITProTV
>> Hello and

5
00:00:12.158 --> 00:00:15.422
welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Peter VanRysdam and

6
00:00:15.422 --> 00:00:19.381
today we are continuing our series
on MTA security fundamentals and

7
00:00:19.381 --> 00:00:22.570
specifically in this episode
>> We're gonna be talking about

8
00:00:22.570 --> 00:00:24.150
user authentication.

9
00:00:24.150 --> 00:00:26.280
And here to help us understand
everything that goes into that,

10
00:00:26.280 --> 00:00:27.550
we have Mr Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:28.700
Mike, how are you doing?

12
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:31.310
>> I'm doing great, thanks for having me
back, and yeah excited, cuz we're getting

13
00:00:31.310 --> 00:00:35.990
into that authentication portion,
which is always fun to talk about.

14
00:00:35.990 --> 00:00:39.760
So yeah, when we're talking about
basic concepts when it comes to.

15
00:00:39.760 --> 00:00:41.210
>> User authentication.

16
00:00:41.210 --> 00:00:46.779
And the first big thing I wanna talk about
is something known as the triple A or AAA.

17
00:00:46.779 --> 00:00:50.520
And I know Peter's gonna say you mean
they're gonna come tow our car for us?

18
00:00:50.520 --> 00:00:51.160
>> Yeah.

19
00:00:51.160 --> 00:00:53.370
>> No, no not that triple A, right?

20
00:00:53.370 --> 00:00:54.840
For those of you that are in the US.

21
00:00:54.840 --> 00:00:58.010
For those of you that are not triple
A is a service you can get to come give

22
00:00:58.010 --> 00:01:00.950
you a free a tow or battery or
gas if you run out.

23
00:01:00.950 --> 00:01:02.830
Anyway, that's not what
we're here to talk about it.

24
00:01:02.830 --> 00:01:06.630
We are here to talk about authentication,
authorization and accounting.

25
00:01:06.630 --> 00:01:09.350
That is the triple A of which we speak.

26
00:01:09.350 --> 00:01:12.580
Now the other day in another episode
we talked about the CIA triad.

27
00:01:12.580 --> 00:01:16.480
And we said that was the foundation or
the goals of security

28
00:01:16.480 --> 00:01:19.570
is to provide that confidentiality,
integrity and availability.

29
00:01:19.570 --> 00:01:23.850
And this is another and we're gonna
call it an access control model.

30
00:01:23.850 --> 00:01:27.530
And it's a pretty standard
one that we try to follow.

31
00:01:27.530 --> 00:01:31.440
And again, AAA is authentication,
authorization and accounting.

32
00:01:31.440 --> 00:01:35.320
And we need to make sure that we
understand what those terms mean.

33
00:01:35.320 --> 00:01:38.610
And believe it or not,
sometimes there is some confusion there.

34
00:01:38.610 --> 00:01:39.490
So let's break it down.

35
00:01:39.490 --> 00:01:42.310
We're gonna start with authentication,
pretty straight forward.

36
00:01:42.310 --> 00:01:47.560
Authentication is proving your identity,
or verifying

37
00:01:47.560 --> 00:01:52.690
the identity of someone or something
doesn't necessarily have to be a person.

38
00:01:52.690 --> 00:01:55.940
We could be talking about a computer
that's being authenticated.

39
00:01:55.940 --> 00:01:59.170
For example, when you go to your
machine at work and you turn it on,

40
00:01:59.170 --> 00:02:03.720
before you ever get the dialog box to
log in your computer has to log in.

41
00:02:03.720 --> 00:02:06.900
It's gonna be talking to servers on
your network assuming you're running

42
00:02:06.900 --> 00:02:09.100
a domain and
it's gonna authenticate with that.

43
00:02:09.100 --> 00:02:13.710
Verify that it did has right password and
can connect to the network and resources.

44
00:02:13.710 --> 00:02:14.870
And then you get to log on.

45
00:02:14.870 --> 00:02:17.120
So remember when we think about
authentication we're not talking about

46
00:02:17.120 --> 00:02:21.880
just users computers, services have to
authenticate when they reach out and

47
00:02:21.880 --> 00:02:24.610
talk to other machines,
and access resources.

48
00:02:24.610 --> 00:02:30.170
So authentication in general is verifying
the identity of someone, or something.

49
00:02:30.170 --> 00:02:33.300
And we'll talk about how we can
do that in just a little bit.

50
00:02:33.300 --> 00:02:34.270
So that's authentication.

51
00:02:35.480 --> 00:02:39.580
Then we have authorization, and this is
where people sometimes get confused cuz

52
00:02:39.580 --> 00:02:44.320
they'll try to use authentication and
authorization interchangeably, or

53
00:02:44.320 --> 00:02:46.980
maybe not really understand
the difference between the two, and

54
00:02:46.980 --> 00:02:48.670
I wanna make sure that we do.

55
00:02:48.670 --> 00:02:51.770
Authorization is
determining what rights or

56
00:02:51.770 --> 00:02:55.440
permissions you have over resource, right?

57
00:02:55.440 --> 00:02:57.540
Can you read this file?

58
00:02:57.540 --> 00:02:59.230
Can you make changes to this file?

59
00:02:59.230 --> 00:03:01.520
Can you create new files in this folder?

60
00:03:01.520 --> 00:03:03.940
Are you allowed to log on to the system?

61
00:03:03.940 --> 00:03:06.690
Are you allowed to reboot the system or
do Windows updates?

62
00:03:06.690 --> 00:03:09.670
Those kind of things,
that's what authorization is about.

63
00:03:09.670 --> 00:03:14.280
Is determining what rights or
permissions you have of a resource.

64
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:16.490
An important little note
that we need to make here,

65
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:21.770
we cannot authorize somebody until
after they're authenticated.

66
00:03:21.770 --> 00:03:23.510
Think about that for a second, right?

67
00:03:23.510 --> 00:03:27.600
If I'm gonna authorize you, and decide
what rights or permissions I should give

68
00:03:27.600 --> 00:03:31.490
you over this resource,
I have to know who you are first, right?

69
00:03:31.490 --> 00:03:34.740
If I don't know who you are how
can I determine what rights or

70
00:03:34.740 --> 00:03:35.410
permissions you have?

71
00:03:35.410 --> 00:03:39.140
And so that's the same thing when
we talk about information security,

72
00:03:39.140 --> 00:03:41.320
authentication comes first.

73
00:03:41.320 --> 00:03:43.990
Once you're authenticated and
we know who you are,

74
00:03:43.990 --> 00:03:47.660
now we can determine what your permissions
are, and what rights you have.

75
00:03:47.660 --> 00:03:50.130
And we can authorize you, right?

76
00:03:50.130 --> 00:03:54.050
And then the last A in
the triple A is accounting.

77
00:03:54.050 --> 00:03:56.010
Depending on what you read,
it might be accounting,

78
00:03:56.010 --> 00:03:58.870
it might be auditing,
all meaning the same thing.

79
00:03:58.870 --> 00:04:03.050
But accounting or
auditing is keeping track of what's going.

80
00:04:03.050 --> 00:04:06.010
Who logged onto that system at what time?

81
00:04:06.010 --> 00:04:09.694
Who made a change to that file,
or who deleted that resource, or

82
00:04:09.694 --> 00:04:14.214
who created that new group in active
directory or that new user on your laptop?

83
00:04:14.214 --> 00:04:15.810
Who made that.

84
00:04:15.810 --> 00:04:17.960
That's what accounting is all about.

85
00:04:17.960 --> 00:04:20.120
What time you made that VPN connection.

86
00:04:20.120 --> 00:04:21.370
How long you stayed connected.

87
00:04:21.370 --> 00:04:22.440
How much bandwidth.

88
00:04:22.440 --> 00:04:25.250
We can determine what
it is we wanna audit.

89
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:29.590
But when we talk about access control
those are the big things we deal with.

90
00:04:29.590 --> 00:04:32.865
Authentication, authorization and
accounting.

91
00:04:32.865 --> 00:04:36.980
And as far as access control
goes accounting might be.

92
00:04:36.980 --> 00:04:40.460
The guard at the front desk that checks
everybody in as they come through, right?

93
00:04:40.460 --> 00:04:43.980
He's accounting, he's keeping
track of who entered the building,

94
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:48.180
how long they stayed, what time they left,
who were they here to see.

95
00:04:48.180 --> 00:04:49.880
I mean, that's accounting, right?

96
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:54.780
So that's our triple A, Authentication,
authorization and accounting.

97
00:04:54.780 --> 00:05:01.000
Now, the next term is one that's, well,
I'll just say, it's non-repudiation.

98
00:05:01.000 --> 00:05:01.951
Everybody say it with me.

99
00:05:01.951 --> 00:05:04.290
Non-repudiation.

100
00:05:04.290 --> 00:05:05.170
>> That's a fun one to say.

101
00:05:05.170 --> 00:05:06.400
>> It is a fun one to say, right?

102
00:05:06.400 --> 00:05:07.648
I don't know why,
it makes me think of Rumpelstiltskin.

103
00:05:07.648 --> 00:05:12.405
But non-repudiation is when you can't deny

104
00:05:12.405 --> 00:05:17.210
that you carried out a specific action.

105
00:05:17.210 --> 00:05:21.640
Like if I digitally sign an email and
then send it to you.

106
00:05:21.640 --> 00:05:25.045
I can't deny that I sent the email
because it has my digital signature on

107
00:05:25.045 --> 00:05:25.857
there, right?

108
00:05:25.857 --> 00:05:29.290
So, when we talk about providing for
non repudiation.

109
00:05:29.290 --> 00:05:34.230
We're talking about being able to
verify the identity of the sender or,

110
00:05:34.230 --> 00:05:36.140
maybe, of the creator.

111
00:05:36.140 --> 00:05:41.250
Or of who modified a file,
that is known as non repudiation,

112
00:05:41.250 --> 00:05:43.900
cannot deny that the actions
were carried out, all right?

113
00:05:43.900 --> 00:05:47.400
And it's something that we really wanna
think about when we talk about security,

114
00:05:47.400 --> 00:05:52.190
and we talk about some of the things
that people do, they'll share passwords.

115
00:05:52.190 --> 00:05:55.090
It's like, hey, I need to log on real
quick, can I just get your password,

116
00:05:55.090 --> 00:05:57.130
cuz I know you have
access to that resource.

117
00:05:57.130 --> 00:06:01.340
Well, we always know sharing
passwords is bad right?

118
00:06:01.340 --> 00:06:02.300
Why?

119
00:06:02.300 --> 00:06:04.120
Well because of a couple things.

120
00:06:04.120 --> 00:06:05.910
If I give my password to Peter.

121
00:06:05.910 --> 00:06:09.430
Peter can now log on to the system as me.

122
00:06:09.430 --> 00:06:14.010
Does the system have any way of knowing
it's not actually me at the keyboard.

123
00:06:14.010 --> 00:06:16.400
Right, he used my username and
my password, so

124
00:06:16.400 --> 00:06:19.420
according to the system
he is me at this point.

125
00:06:19.420 --> 00:06:23.830
He has all the rights and permissions that
I would have over whatever resources, and

126
00:06:23.830 --> 00:06:27.840
any changes or anything he does when
we talk about the accounting part,

127
00:06:27.840 --> 00:06:31.190
right, is not going to be Peter
made a change to this file,

128
00:06:31.190 --> 00:06:35.540
Peter deleted that entire folder of
ISOs It's gonna be me on the line.

129
00:06:35.540 --> 00:06:39.640
And I'm gonna have a difficult time
saying it wasn't me until I fess up and

130
00:06:39.640 --> 00:06:41.390
say, I shared my password.

131
00:06:41.390 --> 00:06:43.560
And even then, Peter could deny it.

132
00:06:43.560 --> 00:06:46.290
>> Sure.
>> And I would have a tough time, unless I

133
00:06:46.290 --> 00:06:49.780
had camera footage of where I was in
timestamps, have a tough time denying it.

134
00:06:49.780 --> 00:06:52.100
So something to think about when we
talk about sharing passwords, and

135
00:06:52.100 --> 00:06:53.290
why that's bad.

136
00:06:53.290 --> 00:06:57.680
This is why, because the systems use
that authentication that we go through

137
00:06:57.680 --> 00:06:59.750
is what determines our authorization.

138
00:06:59.750 --> 00:07:04.312
And if we start sharing passwords, now
we're bypassing all the security measures

139
00:07:04.312 --> 00:07:08.172
that IT has put in place as far as
restricting what Peter has access to.

140
00:07:08.172 --> 00:07:13.143
And the accounting part get's all thrown
out because now it's gonna be logged as me

141
00:07:13.143 --> 00:07:15.710
accessing those resources and not Peter.

142
00:07:17.090 --> 00:07:21.290
All right, moving down our list
multi factor authentication.

143
00:07:22.790 --> 00:07:26.480
Peter I'm guessing you can probably
figure out what that means, right?

144
00:07:26.480 --> 00:07:29.870
>> Yeah, I think I've definitely
dealt with this on my banking and

145
00:07:29.870 --> 00:07:33.600
things like that where you first put
in a password and then you have to

146
00:07:33.600 --> 00:07:36.410
click on the picture or something
that you've selected in the past.

147
00:07:36.410 --> 00:07:39.060
Or something with your
phone number I've even had

148
00:07:39.060 --> 00:07:41.750
you get a text message with a pin
number then that you have to put in.

149
00:07:41.750 --> 00:07:45.775

232
00:12:15.935 --> 00:12:16.775
great deals.

233
00:12:16.775 --> 00:12:20.030
Or reading the latest security blogs,
and things like that.

234
00:12:20.030 --> 00:12:23.387
And I don't need administrative access
to perform those actions, right?

235
00:12:24.640 --> 00:12:27.931
But, I've got an administrative account,
and that's what I log in as.

236
00:12:27.931 --> 00:12:30.736
And now as I'm doing those tasks,

237
00:12:30.736 --> 00:12:36.760
I'm running the risk of having my session,
or my account comprised.

238
00:12:36.760 --> 00:12:40.630
And then whoever compromises it now
has administrative access, right?

239
00:12:40.630 --> 00:12:42.530
If I opening up my email, and

240
00:12:42.530 --> 00:12:46.460
I happen to click on a link in an email
that tries to install malware?

241
00:12:46.460 --> 00:12:48.840
Well now it's installing as administrator,

242
00:12:48.840 --> 00:12:51.990
because I was logged on with
an administrative account.

243
00:12:51.990 --> 00:12:54.269
So one of the things we do is,
we give everybody,

244
00:12:54.269 --> 00:12:57.670
anybody that needs administrative
access typically has two accounts.

245
00:12:57.670 --> 00:12:59.873
They have their administrative account,

246
00:12:59.873 --> 00:13:02.205
then they have their
standard user account.

247
00:13:02.205 --> 00:13:06.590
And we log in as
the standard user account.

248
00:13:06.590 --> 00:13:10.670
And then anytime I need administrative
access, we can then provide those

249
00:13:10.670 --> 00:13:15.270
that other account credentials I was
assigned, for administrative access.

250
00:13:15.270 --> 00:13:17.710
And then the way that
helps us with security is,

251
00:13:17.710 --> 00:13:20.000
I'm normally logged on as a standard user.

252
00:13:20.000 --> 00:13:22.811
I check my email, I surf the web,
I'm just a standard user.

253
00:13:22.811 --> 00:13:25.550
Still bad if I get compromised,
or install malware.

254
00:13:25.550 --> 00:13:30.198
But it could potentially limit the effects
of that malware because I'm not

255
00:13:30.198 --> 00:13:32.060
an administrator.

256
00:13:32.060 --> 00:13:34.610
But then when I need to do
something administratively,

257
00:13:34.610 --> 00:13:38.710
I can tell the system to
run this as another user.

258
00:13:38.710 --> 00:13:41.610
I know I'm signed on as Standard Mike,
but I want you to run

259
00:13:41.610 --> 00:13:46.840
this particular application as
Administrator Mike, all right.

260
00:13:46.840 --> 00:13:48.510
We can do that in a couple different ways.

261
00:13:48.510 --> 00:13:54.460
Starting with Windows Vista, we actually
don't need the Run As command as much.

262
00:13:54.460 --> 00:13:59.460
Because we have something no known as
the UAC, or the User Account Control.

263
00:13:59.460 --> 00:14:03.350
And what this does is it limits,

264
00:14:03.350 --> 00:14:07.590
even when you log on as an administrator,
it really limits what you can do.

265
00:14:07.590 --> 00:14:10.710
And then if you try to do something
that requires administrative access,

266
00:14:10.710 --> 00:14:13.270
it prompts you and says hey,
did you mean to do this?

267
00:14:13.270 --> 00:14:16.660
If you click Yes, it'll say okay,
I'll escalate my credentials, and

268
00:14:16.660 --> 00:14:17.770
let it run as administrator.

269
00:14:17.770 --> 00:14:20.250
If you say no, it doesn't let it run.

270
00:14:20.250 --> 00:14:22.950
What's cool about it is,
that it's only that one task.

271
00:14:22.950 --> 00:14:27.050
So, let's say I have my email client open,
and I have my web browser open, and

272
00:14:27.050 --> 00:14:29.740
then I needed to run
PowerShell as administrator.

273
00:14:29.740 --> 00:14:33.800
Run As, or the UAC would kick in,
and I'd get a prompt saying,

274
00:14:33.800 --> 00:14:36.630
do you want to allow administrative
access to this PowerShell window?

275
00:14:36.630 --> 00:14:39.975
And I can say yes, and now PowerShell
will have administrative access.

276
00:14:39.975 --> 00:14:44.052
But my email application that I had
open is still running as Standard Mike,

277
00:14:44.052 --> 00:14:47.630
and my web browser is still
running as Standard Mike, right?

278
00:14:47.630 --> 00:14:50.053
So it's keeping administrative access,

279
00:14:50.053 --> 00:14:54.440
it's limiting it to just that one
application, which makes me more secure.

280
00:14:54.440 --> 00:14:57.925
If you're logged on as a standard user,
not as administrator?

281
00:14:57.925 --> 00:14:59.879
Well, the UAC's still gonna kick in,

282
00:14:59.879 --> 00:15:03.360
if you try to launch PowerShell
with administrative access.

283
00:15:03.360 --> 00:15:06.810
But now it can't just give you a yes or
no, because you're not an administrator.

284
00:15:06.810 --> 00:15:10.840
You're standard Mike, and
you can't just say yes or no.

285
00:15:10.840 --> 00:15:14.579
It's gonna give a log-on dialog box and
say, okay, standard Mike.

286
00:15:14.579 --> 00:15:16.241
I'll run this administrator,

287
00:15:16.241 --> 00:15:20.240
if you can give me some credentials
that have administrative rights.

288
00:15:20.240 --> 00:15:22.906
And so I can type those in,
it'll run, again,

289
00:15:22.906 --> 00:15:25.878
just that one window as administrator,
all right.

290
00:15:25.878 --> 00:15:30.170
So that's the UAC, and again, it takes
away the need for the Run As as much.

291
00:15:30.170 --> 00:15:31.680
Now, we can still use the Run As,

292
00:15:31.680 --> 00:15:34.090
I've seen times when UAC
doesn't kick in properly.

293
00:15:35.860 --> 00:15:40.100
Or it's an application that doesn't
normally need administrative access.

294
00:15:40.100 --> 00:15:44.865
An example I always use, Peter, is if
you try to modify the host file on your

295
00:15:44.865 --> 00:15:47.679
system, you need administrative access.

296
00:15:47.679 --> 00:15:52.037
Well, I open up Notepad or I browse
into my System32 folder, drivers, etc.

297
00:15:52.037 --> 00:15:54.424
And I double-click on it,
Notepad opens up,

298
00:15:54.424 --> 00:15:58.600
there's the file I can't make changes
to it because I'm not an administrator.

299
00:15:58.600 --> 00:16:04.110
So what I need to do is open
Notepad first as an administrator.

300
00:16:04.110 --> 00:16:07.845
And then File > Open from within
the administrative notepad and browse and

301
00:16:07.845 --> 00:16:08.680
find that file.

302
00:16:08.680 --> 00:16:10.350
And now I can make changes to it.

303
00:16:10.350 --> 00:16:12.359
But when you double-click on Notepad,
it doesn't say,

304
00:16:12.359 --> 00:16:14.220
hey, do you wanna run
this as an administrator?

305
00:16:14.220 --> 00:16:16.460
>> Yeah.
>> It doesn't automatically kick in.

306
00:16:16.460 --> 00:16:17.320
>> I'm a visual learner.

307
00:16:17.320 --> 00:16:19.770
Can you show us an example here
of what you're talking about,

308
00:16:19.770 --> 00:16:21.350
and how we use the runas command?

309
00:16:21.350 --> 00:16:22.670
>> Absolutely, let's do this.

310
00:16:22.670 --> 00:16:25.140
Let's get out Notepad, and

311
00:16:25.140 --> 00:16:29.370
I'm just going to pin this to,
can I send it to my desktop anymore?

312
00:16:29.370 --> 00:16:30.330
I'll pin it to my taskbar.

313
00:16:31.580 --> 00:16:33.410
All right, so now I got Notepad down here.

314
00:16:33.410 --> 00:16:36.999
If I double-click Notepad, it doesn't
prompt me for administrative rights or

315
00:16:36.999 --> 00:16:37.960
anything like that.

316
00:16:37.960 --> 00:16:39.120
It's a text editor.

317
00:16:39.120 --> 00:16:42.010
Well, again,
what if I need to modify the host file?

318
00:16:42.010 --> 00:16:46.220
If I try to go in here now,
File > Open, and I go back into,

319
00:16:46.220 --> 00:16:48.935
if I can remember where that guy is,

320
00:16:48.935 --> 00:16:55.500
C:Windows> System 32 Drivers > Etsy, and

321
00:16:55.500 --> 00:17:01.790
we get rid of that.

322
00:17:01.790 --> 00:17:04.840
I'll find my host file and
I'll open it up.

323
00:17:04.840 --> 00:17:11.850
And now I wanna make a new line in here,
and I wanna save it, and I'm gonna try.

324
00:17:13.620 --> 00:17:15.450
And it's going to say you cannot do that.

325
00:17:15.450 --> 00:17:16.910
Would you like to save
it to your documents?

326
00:17:16.910 --> 00:17:18.840
You can write there, but
you are not an administrator.

327
00:17:18.840 --> 00:17:21.336
You can't save anything into
this particular folder.

328
00:17:21.336 --> 00:17:25.705
All right, so I need to run
Notepad as an administrator, but

329
00:17:25.705 --> 00:17:28.030
the UAC is not kicking in.

330
00:17:28.030 --> 00:17:29.710
So how do I do that?

331
00:17:29.710 --> 00:17:31.165
I'm going to not save my changes.

332
00:17:31.165 --> 00:17:36.350
If I right-click on Notepad, sometimes
you will and sometimes you won't.

333
00:17:36.350 --> 00:17:39.290
That's gonna give me a history of files.

334
00:17:39.290 --> 00:17:42.530
But it's not giving me anything
that says runas, right?

335
00:17:42.530 --> 00:17:45.470
I'm double checking to make sure
everything's appropriate there.

336
00:17:45.470 --> 00:17:47.230
So nothing good.

337
00:17:47.230 --> 00:17:51.460
So what I can do is I can hold
down Shift and right-click, and

338
00:17:51.460 --> 00:17:55.230
now all of the sudden I get this
runas Administrator option.

339
00:17:55.230 --> 00:17:59.140
So I was holding down Shift and
then right-clicking on the icon.

340
00:17:59.140 --> 00:18:01.476
I could choose runas administrator.

341
00:18:01.476 --> 00:18:02.207
Now the UAC kicks in.

342
00:18:02.207 --> 00:18:04.821
I say yes, and so Notepad opens up, but

343
00:18:04.821 --> 00:18:08.161
now let's see what happens
when I go File > Open.

344
00:18:08.161 --> 00:18:11.530
And we'll change this back to all files,
hosts.

345
00:18:11.530 --> 00:18:13.275
And I'm gonna make a change to this.

346
00:18:13.275 --> 00:18:14.491
I don't wanna mess my host file.

347
00:18:14.491 --> 00:18:18.427
So I'll just put in a couple
of new comment lines in here.

348
00:18:18.427 --> 00:18:24.480
I'll do File > Save, and I'll close it,
and everything worked fine.

349
00:18:24.480 --> 00:18:28.090
And only that application is
running with administrative access.

350
00:18:28.090 --> 00:18:30.500
Nothing else on my system
had administrative access.

351
00:18:30.500 --> 00:18:35.590
So that's what runas is all about when
you need to escalate your credentials.

352
00:18:35.590 --> 00:18:38.480
I will show the old
school way of doing this.

353
00:18:38.480 --> 00:18:42.800
You can do runas from the, if I could
spell it, runas from the command line.

354
00:18:43.890 --> 00:18:44.910
Let me try to zoom in.

355
00:18:44.910 --> 00:18:46.920
I don't know if I can zoom in and
type at the same time.

356
00:18:46.920 --> 00:18:48.890
We're gonna find out.

357
00:18:48.890 --> 00:18:53.314
runas /user:administrator, or

358
00:18:53.314 --> 00:18:59.170
whatever user account you wanted to use.

359
00:18:59.170 --> 00:19:02.210
Space and
then the name of the application.

360
00:19:03.250 --> 00:19:07.700
All right, so runas /user:,
the name of the account, and

361
00:19:07.700 --> 00:19:09.850
then the name of the application.

362
00:19:09.850 --> 00:19:11.820
I'll zoom back in or out.

363
00:19:11.820 --> 00:19:14.610
I'll hit Enter, and it says,
well, what's the password?

364
00:19:14.610 --> 00:19:19.090
And assuming I can type in the
appropriate, let's see if I can do that.

365
00:19:21.410 --> 00:19:24.702
And I don't even know my
own administrator password.

366
00:19:24.702 --> 00:19:26.459
Actually I don't know what it is.

367
00:19:26.459 --> 00:19:29.710
[LAUGH]
>> That's probably a good thing.

368
00:19:29.710 --> 00:19:31.290
>> Yeah, it probably is,
let me try one more time.

369
00:19:36.700 --> 00:19:39.367
You know what?
I think my administrator account is

370
00:19:39.367 --> 00:19:40.676
actually disabled.

371
00:19:40.676 --> 00:19:45.005
Yeah, you don't need that slash,
it's actually a mistake in my notes there.

372
00:19:45.005 --> 00:19:46.250
[LAUGH]
>> All right.

373
00:19:46.250 --> 00:19:48.420
>> But that is the command,
and you know what?

374
00:19:48.420 --> 00:19:50.990
Let's do this,
because you can put any user.

375
00:19:50.990 --> 00:19:55.516
So I'll just come back here and
say Michael.

376
00:19:58.090 --> 00:20:00.645
Right, I know the password for
this guy, I think.

377
00:20:00.645 --> 00:20:01.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

378
00:20:01.870 --> 00:20:05.580
now Notepad opens up with whatever
credentials I happen to use.

379
00:20:05.580 --> 00:20:08.250
And in my case, that particular account
does have administrative rights.

380
00:20:08.250 --> 00:20:11.134
My built-in administrator
account is actually disabled.

381
00:20:11.134 --> 00:20:16.110
And so the runas is a different user
command that could help if, for example,

382
00:20:16.110 --> 00:20:17.210
I'm in support and

383
00:20:17.210 --> 00:20:20.660
I come and I need to run something on
your computer you don't have access to.

384
00:20:20.660 --> 00:20:25.020
I can go ahead and run that as myself
then make those changes to your system so

385
00:20:25.020 --> 00:20:29.200
that I'm not giving you access to be able
to basically break your computer later.

386
00:20:29.200 --> 00:20:32.060
>> Exactly right,
like you're doing a remote assistance or

387
00:20:32.060 --> 00:20:36.670
something like that and you need to
use those administrative credentials.

388
00:20:36.670 --> 00:20:39.720
I'll show you one more thing here,
we can really drive this point home.

389
00:20:39.720 --> 00:20:45.110
Let me right-click, runas administrator
on Notepad again, and I'll say yes.

390
00:20:45.110 --> 00:20:48.048
And then I'm gonna open up Task Manager.

391
00:20:48.048 --> 00:20:52.370
And we'll take a look at my details,
I believe.

392
00:20:52.370 --> 00:20:56.430
And what we'll see here is just about
everything is running as Michael, right?

393
00:20:56.430 --> 00:20:57.780
That's my account.

394
00:20:57.780 --> 00:20:59.148
Something's running as systems.

395
00:20:59.148 --> 00:21:02.950
Something's running as local system.

396
00:21:02.950 --> 00:21:07.940
But if I find Notepad, which is

397
00:21:07.940 --> 00:21:11.480
right there, yeah, again,
I am the administrator,

398
00:21:11.480 --> 00:21:15.910
so I guess it's not making it as visual as
I thought it might, but try that at home.

399
00:21:15.910 --> 00:21:18.510
If you log in with
a non-administrator account and

400
00:21:18.510 --> 00:21:21.140
do a runas,
you can open up Task Manager and

401
00:21:21.140 --> 00:21:25.330
you'll be able to see that that
account is running just that one app.

402
00:21:25.330 --> 00:21:26.660
Everything else is running.

403
00:21:26.660 --> 00:21:27.400
You know what I could do?

404
00:21:27.400 --> 00:21:28.800
Let's do this.

405
00:21:28.800 --> 00:21:31.850
We'll do one more demo of Notepad here.

406
00:21:31.850 --> 00:21:35.170
Let's just do,
because I have another account,

407
00:21:38.860 --> 00:21:41.278
whoops, I could do,
is I could do it this way.

408
00:21:41.278 --> 00:21:47.590
We could do, let's see if we can make it
look a little different, we'll say Mike.

409
00:21:47.590 --> 00:21:48.624
>> And you know the password to this one?

410
00:21:48.624 --> 00:21:49.650
>> I think.

411
00:21:49.650 --> 00:21:50.290
>> All right.

412
00:21:50.290 --> 00:21:52.240
>> This will be my test.

413
00:21:52.240 --> 00:21:52.850
All right, there we go.

414
00:21:52.850 --> 00:21:55.940
So Notepad's open up back in here and
now look at that.

415
00:21:57.100 --> 00:22:00.560
You see that everything's running as
Michael or system except for Notepad and

416
00:22:00.560 --> 00:22:01.760
it's running as Mike.

417
00:22:01.760 --> 00:22:02.840
So you use your imagination,

418
00:22:02.840 --> 00:22:06.240
Michael is non-administrative,
Mike is the administrator account and

419
00:22:06.240 --> 00:22:09.530
you can see that just that one
application is running as admin.

420
00:22:09.530 --> 00:22:11.170
So that's what runas is all about.

421
00:22:11.170 --> 00:22:13.100
Runas administrator.

422
00:22:13.100 --> 00:22:15.873
You right-click on an icon
to launch an application and

423
00:22:15.873 --> 00:22:18.350
you should see that runas administrator.

424
00:22:18.350 --> 00:22:21.940
If you don't see it when you right-click
on it, try holding down Shift and

425
00:22:21.940 --> 00:22:25.740
then right-clicking on it, and you should
see that runas administrator option.

426
00:22:25.740 --> 00:22:27.570
You could also do it
from the command line.

427
00:22:27.570 --> 00:22:32.390
Keep in mind that the UAC is basically
doing a runas for you in the background.

428
00:22:32.390 --> 00:22:35.655
So if you see the UAC
that is a runas as well.

429
00:22:35.655 --> 00:22:36.810
>> All right, sounds good, Mike.

430
00:22:36.810 --> 00:22:39.720
Anything else we need to
cover on user authentication?

431
00:22:39.720 --> 00:22:42.570
>> I think we covered just about
all we need for this exam.

432
00:22:42.570 --> 00:22:46.660
All right, and like we said there
is content back on part one.

433
00:22:46.660 --> 00:22:49.180
So make sure if you just came in
on this episode you go back and

434
00:22:49.180 --> 00:22:52.100
watch part one of user
authentication as well.

435
00:22:52.100 --> 00:22:52.990
Some great info there.

436
00:22:52.990 --> 00:22:55.150
But that's gonna do it for this episode.

437
00:22:55.150 --> 00:22:58.610
So signing off for ITProTV I have
been your host, Peter VanRysdam.

438
00:22:58.610 --> 00:22:59.580
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

439
00:22:59.580 --> 00:23:00.994
>> And we will see you next time.

440
00:23:00.994 --> 00:23:07.033
[MUSIC]

441
00:23:07.033 --> 00:23:10.300
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

00:25:33.000 --> 00:25:35.220
Now I'm gonna go inside the folder, and

464
00:25:35.220 --> 00:25:40.510
I'm gonna right-click on this second
folder > Properties > Security,

465
00:25:40.510 --> 00:25:44.510
and I'll zoom in, and
look what you see here.

466
00:25:44.510 --> 00:25:47.872
Now, I just created this folder,
so there's no way I went in and

467
00:25:47.872 --> 00:25:51.526
right-clicked on and
added Mike without you seeing me, right?

468
00:25:51.526 --> 00:25:54.860
I guess we could've used the magic of TV
time out and really tricked you guys.

469
00:25:54.860 --> 00:25:55.599
>> But we did not do that.

470
00:25:55.599 --> 00:25:56.240
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

471
00:25:56.240 --> 00:25:58.430
Zach as my witness,
we did not do that, right?

472
00:25:58.430 --> 00:26:01.720
But Mike is there on this
folder that just got created.

473
00:26:01.720 --> 00:26:05.290

he has full control over this folder.

474
00:26:05.290 --> 00:26:07.160
Hm, that's interesting.

475
00:26:07.160 --> 00:26:08.940
Let's go check these files out.

476
00:26:08.940 --> 00:26:13.308
So we'll go to Doc1 > Properties
> Security, and sure enough,

477
00:26:13.308 --> 00:26:17.607
there's Mike and he's got full
control over this file, right?

478
00:26:17.607 --> 00:26:21.268
And inside Folder2,
you get where I'm going, right?

479
00:26:21.268 --> 00:26:27.410
If I right-click on that guy, Properties >
Security, there's Mike and full control.

480
00:26:27.410 --> 00:26:29.625
That, my friends, is inheritance.

481
00:26:29.625 --> 00:26:30.696
>> Inheritance.

482
00:26:30.696 --> 00:26:36.037
>> NTFS, on an NTFS volume,
NTFS permissions are inherited

483
00:26:36.037 --> 00:26:40.750
from parent objects to child objects,
right?

484
00:26:40.750 --> 00:26:45.530
So if I have a folder, right, and
inside that folder I have files,

485
00:26:45.530 --> 00:26:50.050
then those files are children
of that parent folder, right?

486
00:26:50.050 --> 00:26:52.900
And when I assign permissions
to that parent object,

487
00:26:52.900 --> 00:26:55.600
it inherits down to everything inside it.

488
00:26:55.600 --> 00:26:57.900
And that saves me a ton of work.

489
00:26:57.900 --> 00:27:01.471
You saw, not just files, but
other folders inside there,

490
00:27:01.471 --> 00:27:03.481
other files inside that folder.

491
00:27:03.481 --> 00:27:07.744
If I would've made a third folder, and
a fourth folder, and put a file in there,

492
00:27:07.744 --> 00:27:10.420
it would have inherited all the way down,
right?

493
00:27:10.420 --> 00:27:15.700
Now, this folder that I made,
EmpDocs, is actually the root of C.

494
00:27:15.700 --> 00:27:19.453
So EmpDocs is actually
a child to the C drive.

495
00:27:19.453 --> 00:27:22.572
The C drive itself has to follow
permissions that allow all

496
00:27:22.572 --> 00:27:23.880
users to read, right?

497
00:27:23.880 --> 00:27:26.398
That gets inherited down to that folder.

498
00:27:26.398 --> 00:27:28.960
That's what NTFS inheritance is all about.

499
00:27:28.960 --> 00:27:32.780
And it makes our life of assigning
permissions a whole lot easier.

500
00:27:32.780 --> 00:27:37.750
Because now I don't have to worry about
assigning those permissions to each and

501
00:27:37.750 --> 00:27:41.040
every object,
if I organize them correctly.

502
00:27:41.040 --> 00:27:45.010
I know that all my sales people
need access, at least read and

503
00:27:45.010 --> 00:27:47.270
write to all these documents.

504
00:27:47.270 --> 00:27:50.134
Well, what I can do is make
a folder called sales resources.

505
00:27:50.134 --> 00:27:53.316
And I can put all those sales
resources inside that folder,

506
00:27:53.316 --> 00:27:56.446
and I can assign that permission
once at the folder level.

507
00:27:56.446 --> 00:27:58.340
And it takes care of everything else.

508
00:27:58.340 --> 00:28:01.573
If I add new files to that folder later,
they automatically,

509
00:28:01.573 --> 00:28:04.370
as soon as I drop them in there,
they're like, ooh,

510
00:28:04.370 --> 00:28:08.934
I've got a new parent, let me inherit the
permissions down from that parent, right?

511
00:28:08.934 --> 00:28:10.670
>> It sounds like a real time saver.

512
00:28:10.670 --> 00:28:11.260
>> It's huge.

513
00:28:11.260 --> 00:28:16.320
It makes administration and
permissions a whole lot easier.

514
00:28:16.320 --> 00:28:19.550
Now, there is one last thing,
I know we're running out of time here,

515
00:28:19.550 --> 00:28:23.370
one last thing I wanna cover before
we move to our next episode.

516
00:28:23.370 --> 00:28:24.990
And that is, where was I going?

517
00:28:24.990 --> 00:28:27.480
We talked about explicit permissions,
let's talk about what they look like.

518
00:28:27.480 --> 00:28:31.655
How do I know if a permission
is explicit or inherited?

519
00:28:31.655 --> 00:28:32.717
And do I care?

520
00:28:32.717 --> 00:28:36.770
Well, do I care, cuz in the end read
is read, whether it was inherited or

521
00:28:36.770 --> 00:28:38.565
explicitly assigned.

522
00:28:38.565 --> 00:28:42.546
So what I'm gonna do is I've still got
that document two properties opened up.

523
00:28:42.546 --> 00:28:45.169
And I'm gonna pull up the properties for
that folder,

524
00:28:45.169 --> 00:28:48.335
where we assigned informations explicitly.

525
00:28:48.335 --> 00:28:52.740
And I want you to take a close look,
I'm gonna select Mike here,

526
00:28:52.740 --> 00:28:54.250
there is my full control.

527
00:28:54.250 --> 00:28:56.819

528
00:28:56.819 --> 00:29:00.819
I will zoom in just a little bit,
and you see anything different,

529
00:29:00.819 --> 00:29:05.790
it's gonna be this subtle, but
then you gonna be like, duh, difference.

530
00:29:05.790 --> 00:29:07.798
Anything Zach, what do you think?

531
00:29:07.798 --> 00:29:10.097
>> I'm not immediately
seeing anything different.

I don't know.

00:29:12.238 --> 00:29:15.610

be like [SOUND], I had a V8 moment there.

535

[LAUGH]

536
00:29:16.437 --> 00:29:17.531
>> Yes, [LAUGH] all right,

537
00:29:17.531 --> 00:29:20.229
what color would you say these
check marks are on the left?

538
00:29:21.560 --> 00:29:22.387
>> This is kind of looking
like a black right?

539
00:29:22.387 --> 00:29:24.515
>> So it's the color of the checkmarks,
there you go.

540
00:29:24.515 --> 00:29:26.550
>> So these over here are gray.

541
00:29:26.550 --> 00:29:27.560
And this gets everybody.

542
00:29:27.560 --> 00:29:28.790
It's a trick question.

543
00:29:28.790 --> 00:29:32.629
I always throw it on people, and they're
looking for different permissions and

544
00:29:32.629 --> 00:29:33.540
things like that.

545
00:29:33.540 --> 00:29:34.406
No, it's just the color of the checkmarks.

546
00:29:34.406 --> 00:29:35.148
>> Color of the checkmarks.

547
00:29:35.148 --> 00:29:39.160
>> [LAUGH] All right, but the black
checkmarks are explicit permissions.

548
00:29:39.160 --> 00:29:43.100
So I know that those permissions were
assigned directly to that folder,

549
00:29:43.100 --> 00:29:45.050
just by looking at the checkmarks.

550
00:29:45.050 --> 00:29:47.890
These gray ones over here,
are inherited permissions.

551
00:29:47.890 --> 00:29:51.250
I know that the permissions were
not assigned to that resource.

552
00:29:51.250 --> 00:29:53.120
They were inherited from somewhere.

553
00:29:53.120 --> 00:29:56.390
Might be his direct parent, might be
the parent above that, or the parent above

554
00:29:56.390 --> 00:29:59.860
that, but they were inherited,
they weren't explicitly assigned.

555
00:29:59.860 --> 00:30:01.600
Now, why do I care?

556
00:30:01.600 --> 00:30:05.633
Let's click Edit on the explicit,
all right?

557
00:30:05.633 --> 00:30:06.602
Oops, did I click?

558
00:30:06.602 --> 00:30:10.442
And let's go back to Mike, and
notice that I can check and

559
00:30:10.442 --> 00:30:13.770
uncheck these checkmarks freely.

560
00:30:13.770 --> 00:30:18.110
Let's go to edit on the inherited
permissions, select Mike and

561
00:30:18.110 --> 00:30:18.975
look at my checkmarks.

562
00:30:20.000 --> 00:30:23.584
I cannot uncheck them,
they're grayed out, right?

563
00:30:23.584 --> 00:30:27.771
You cannot change inherited permissions.

564
00:30:27.771 --> 00:30:31.227
There is a way, but
it's not as simple as opening it up and

565
00:30:31.227 --> 00:30:33.700
making the change directly.

566
00:30:33.700 --> 00:30:38.560
There's two ways, three ways,
that I can make those changes.

567
00:30:38.560 --> 00:30:40.443
But, unfortunately, Zach,
I know we're a little short on time.

568
00:30:40.443 --> 00:30:40.986
>> And we're there.

569
00:30:40.986 --> 00:30:42.290
>> So I'm thinking we leave a cliffhanger.

570
00:30:42.290 --> 00:30:47.050
>> Yeah, in fact, there's gonna be
a part two of, of course, permissions.

00:30:47.050 --> 00:30:48.399
And you'll wanna catch that.

572
00:30:48.399 --> 00:30:50.573
You wanna do a real quick recap
of where we've been this episode?

573
00:30:50.573 --> 00:30:51.890
>> Yeah, absolutely.

574
00:30:51.890 --> 00:30:55.830
So far, what we've done, is we've really
talked about what permissions are, and

575
00:30:55.830 --> 00:30:56.720
why we have them.

576
00:30:56.720 --> 00:30:58.540
Because of our NTFS file system,

577
00:30:58.540 --> 00:31:02.270
that's what provides us the ability
to set the permissions.

578
00:31:02.270 --> 00:31:04.690
We've talked about where
those permissions are stored.

579
00:31:04.690 --> 00:31:09.790
Every object on an NTFS partition has
an access control list associated with it.

580
00:31:09.790 --> 00:31:14.230
I can make changes to that list,
by adding or removing ACEs, or

581
00:31:14.230 --> 00:31:15.980
Access Control Entries.

582
00:31:15.980 --> 00:31:18.570
Those Access Control Entries
are what allow me to

583
00:31:18.570 --> 00:31:23.260
choose what permission you have, or
don't have, by checking and unchecking.

584
00:31:23.260 --> 00:31:26.830
We talked about the different permissions
themselves, what they mean, read, write,

585
00:31:26.830 --> 00:31:28.210
modify, etc.

586
00:31:28.210 --> 00:31:32.830
And we also talked about explicit
versus inherited permissions.

587
00:31:32.830 --> 00:31:34.782
And the cliffhanger
we're leaving you with,

something to think about before you watch
the next episode see if you get this,

how can I change inherited permissions?

00:31:39.850 --> 00:31:41.842
>> [SOUND]
>> [CROSSTALK] Yeah, [LAUGH].

>> I'm sorry,
I had to throw that in there.

So there's gonna be a lot more to

So you'll wanna catch everything

1

13

I'm excited to be here as always.

14
