And yes,
we're continuing on with permissions.

15
00:00:34.970 --> 00:00:39.114
And we actually left our viewers with
a little bit of a cliffhanger didn't we?

16
00:00:39.114 --> 00:00:41.350
>> And do you remember what
the cliffhanger question was?

17
00:00:41.350 --> 00:00:41.990
>> I don't know.

18
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:43.740
>> I'll refresh, I'll refresh.

19
00:00:43.740 --> 00:00:47.790
So, you have an inherited permission.

20
00:00:47.790 --> 00:00:48.730
Can you change that?

21
00:00:48.730 --> 00:00:49.850
How do you change that?

22
00:00:49.850 --> 00:00:50.690
>> Right.
>> What do we have to do?

23
00:00:50.690 --> 00:00:52.078
>> That was the question, right?

24
00:00:52.078 --> 00:00:53.680
How do you change those
inherited permissions?

25
00:00:53.680 --> 00:00:56.771
Cuz remember, they were gray,
they were kinda grayed out, and

26
00:00:56.771 --> 00:00:58.890
you can't click on them, right?

27
00:00:58.890 --> 00:01:02.985
Well, there's actually three ways,
if I can remember all three.

28
00:01:02.985 --> 00:01:04.210
We'll put myself to the test here,

29
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:06.980
if I can remember all three ways that
we can change inherited permissions.

30
00:01:06.980 --> 00:01:10.770
And I'll show you here in just a second,
but let me go through all three first.

31
00:01:10.770 --> 00:01:14.330
So the first way is go to
where they're explicit, right?

32
00:01:14.330 --> 00:01:15.990
If you're looking at a file, and

33
00:01:15.990 --> 00:01:19.810
the permissions have been inherited
from a parent object somewhere,

34
00:01:19.810 --> 00:01:24.490
go back up to wherever that parent is,
find the explicit permissions.

35
00:01:24.490 --> 00:01:25.980
And make the changes there.

36
00:01:25.980 --> 00:01:29.480
Because if you change them,
that change will get inherited down.

37
00:01:29.480 --> 00:01:32.540
So you'll, in effect,
change the inherited permissions

38
00:01:32.540 --> 00:01:35.250
by changing the parent permissions,
all right?

39
00:01:35.250 --> 00:01:36.750
Or the explicit permissions.

40
00:01:36.750 --> 00:01:38.230
It might not be the direct parent, right?

41
00:01:38.230 --> 00:01:41.400
It might be the parent of the parent
of the parent where you have to go.

42
00:01:41.400 --> 00:01:44.390
But find out where they're black,
where they're explicit, and

43
00:01:44.390 --> 00:01:45.210
make the changes there.

44
00:01:45.210 --> 00:01:46.740
So that's one way.

45
00:01:46.740 --> 00:01:52.240
The second way you can do it is to assign
the opposite permission, all right?

46
00:01:53.250 --> 00:01:59.186
Let's say a user has write permission that
has been inherited from a parent object.

47
00:01:59.186 --> 00:02:02.550
But I don't want them to write
to this particular object.

48
00:02:02.550 --> 00:02:05.760
I can deny write on there, right?

49
00:02:05.760 --> 00:02:11.160
So, even though the allow write is
checked, I'll also check deny write.

50
00:02:11.160 --> 00:02:15.070
And I'll go over the hierarchy
here in just a second, but

51
00:02:15.070 --> 00:02:21.130
that explicit deny will end up
overriding that inherited allow.

52
00:02:21.130 --> 00:02:23.990
So the second way you can change
inherited permissions is to assign

53
00:02:23.990 --> 00:02:25.230
the opposite permission.

54
00:02:25.230 --> 00:02:29.040
I can't change what's being inherited,
but I can assign other permissions.

55
00:02:29.040 --> 00:02:32.420
And if my other permission counteracts
the one that's being inherited,

56
00:02:32.420 --> 00:02:34.280
in a sense I change
the inherited permission.

57
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:39.906
Third way I can do it is I can
disable inheritance altogether.

58
00:02:39.906 --> 00:02:42.729
I can say,
stop inheriting from your parents.

59
00:02:42.729 --> 00:02:46.137
It's like we build a little wall and those
permissions that would normally flow down

60
00:02:46.137 --> 00:02:48.393
from parent to child,
we're just gonna build a wall and

61
00:02:48.393 --> 00:02:50.749
they're not gonna be able
come down any further, right?

62
00:02:50.749 --> 00:02:54.770
And now couple things to keep in
mind when you block inheritance.

63
00:02:54.770 --> 00:02:59.270
You can do it at the file level or
you can do it at the folder level, right?

64
00:02:59.270 --> 00:03:01.380
If I do it at a folder level,

65
00:03:01.380 --> 00:03:06.030
if I block inheritance, it will block
it from everything inside there.

66
00:03:06.030 --> 00:03:09.060
All the files inside there
will no longer inherit either.

67
00:03:09.060 --> 00:03:12.530
Once you build the wall,
no more inheritance past there.

68
00:03:12.530 --> 00:03:14.630
Not from anything above, right?

69
00:03:14.630 --> 00:03:18.609
But if I assign a permission
underneath the wall explicitly,

70
00:03:18.609 --> 00:03:20.990
it will still inherit down, right?

71
00:03:20.990 --> 00:03:24.995
Cuz the wall's above it, so it's not
gonna affect any inheritance below that.

72
00:03:24.995 --> 00:03:28.950
That'll stop everything from the parent
from being able to come down.

73
00:03:28.950 --> 00:03:33.040
And you can't be particular
about what you block.

74
00:03:33.040 --> 00:03:35.580
You either turn inheritance on or
you turn it off.

75
00:03:35.580 --> 00:03:36.730
It's on by default.

76
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:41.000
You can turn it off, but I can't say
inherit these, but don't inherit those.

77
00:03:41.000 --> 00:03:42.390
It's either inherit, or don't.

78
00:03:42.390 --> 00:03:43.937
It's all or nothing, all right?

79
00:03:43.937 --> 00:03:45.978
>> And do you have to get another
country to pay for that wall?

80
00:03:45.978 --> 00:03:49.369
I'm just wondering.
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] you do sometimes.

81
00:03:49.369 --> 00:03:49.947
>> Okay.

82
00:03:49.947 --> 00:03:52.671
>> No, we're gonna pay for it ourselves,
and it's gonna be better than your wall.

83
00:03:52.671 --> 00:03:57.660
[LAUGH] So yeah, you can't be
selective about blocking inheritance.

84
00:03:57.660 --> 00:03:59.660
You either block it or you don't.

85
00:03:59.660 --> 00:04:03.060
Now, when you block it,
it is gonna ask you a question, and

86
00:04:03.060 --> 00:04:04.780
again I'm gonna show you this in a second.

87
00:04:04.780 --> 00:04:09.690
But when you choose to block inheritance,
NTFS has to make a decision.

88
00:04:09.690 --> 00:04:12.770
Cuz remember,
as soon as I made that second folder,

89
00:04:12.770 --> 00:04:14.460
those permissions had already inherited,
right?

90
00:04:14.460 --> 00:04:17.780
There was no time for me to say,
I'm gonna make a folder.

91
00:04:17.780 --> 00:04:19.870
Do I want permissions to inherit or not?

92

00:17:09.517 --> 00:17:15.655
group A has read permission over a
resource, but I also belong to group B and

315
00:17:15.655 --> 00:17:19.663
group B has write permission
over the resource.

316
00:17:19.663 --> 00:17:21.733
Guess what permission I have?

317
00:17:21.733 --> 00:17:25.082
A gets read, B gets write,
I'm in both groups,

318
00:17:25.082 --> 00:17:28.740
I get all the permissions,
I get to add them up.

319
00:17:28.740 --> 00:17:33.420
So in the end, I would have read and
write permission over the resource.

320
00:17:33.420 --> 00:17:34.069
Make sense?

321
00:17:34.069 --> 00:17:34.900
>> Mm-hm.
>> All right,

322
00:17:34.900 --> 00:17:36.710
they're cumulative in that respect.

323
00:17:38.510 --> 00:17:42.650
So sometimes what we
have to do is determine,

324
00:17:42.650 --> 00:17:44.497
what are your effective permissions,
right?

325
00:17:45.650 --> 00:17:49.170
Because when I look at that
access control list, normally,

326
00:17:49.170 --> 00:17:53.250
we're gonna see a whole list of groups,
not individual users.

327
00:17:53.250 --> 00:17:58.360
And I might not be 100% on
what groups you belong to.

328
00:17:58.360 --> 00:18:03.440
So what I need to do is calculate
your effective permissions.

329
00:18:03.440 --> 00:18:07.670
And what effective permissions
are when we're talking about NTFS is

330
00:18:07.670 --> 00:18:09.840
take everything all into consideration.

331
00:18:09.840 --> 00:18:14.460
Take the groups you belong to and
cumulate all those permissions.

332
00:18:14.460 --> 00:18:19.150
And think about allow versus deny,
because remember, denies override allows,

333
00:18:19.150 --> 00:18:21.000
and we can get some conflict there.

334
00:18:21.000 --> 00:18:22.460
So effective permissions say,

335
00:18:22.460 --> 00:18:26.730
in the end, all things considered,
what do you actually have?

336
00:18:26.730 --> 00:18:28.090
What do you end up with?

337
00:18:28.090 --> 00:18:31.520
Because I would be wrong if
I just looked and said, hey,

338
00:18:31.520 --> 00:18:33.840
you're part of A,
you have read permission.

339
00:18:33.840 --> 00:18:37.390
That's not true because you also belong to
group B, and you have write permission.

340
00:18:37.390 --> 00:18:39.110
So you really have read and write.

341
00:18:39.110 --> 00:18:41.007
So I need to take all
that into consideration,

342
00:18:41.007 --> 00:18:43.120
what groups does Zach belong to?

343
00:18:43.120 --> 00:18:45.220
Which ones are allowed,
which ones are denied?

344
00:18:45.220 --> 00:18:47.325
Let me add all this up,
it's a lot of work.

345
00:18:48.405 --> 00:18:51.709
Windows gives us a tool to
make that a whole lot easier.

346
00:18:51.709 --> 00:18:52.339
>> Thank you.

347
00:18:52.339 --> 00:18:53.675
>> [LAUGH] I know, right?

348
00:18:53.675 --> 00:18:59.571
There is an effective permissions tab that
we can use for this purpose, all right?

349
00:18:59.571 --> 00:19:03.990
So what I meant,
this is under the Advanced, and

350
00:19:03.990 --> 00:19:07.090
if I zoom in on this Advanced, remember,
this is where we were to work with these

351
00:19:07.090 --> 00:19:10.760
special permissions and
the blocking of inheritance.

352
00:19:10.760 --> 00:19:13.290
There's the Effective Access tab.

353
00:19:13.290 --> 00:19:16.850
What this allows me to do is

354
00:19:16.850 --> 00:19:20.710
select who I'm trying to find
out what permissions they have.

355
00:19:20.710 --> 00:19:24.140
I don't know what permissions Mike has,
so let me go ahead and

356
00:19:24.140 --> 00:19:26.580
find his account, all right.

357
00:19:26.580 --> 00:19:29.390
And I'm not worried about what
device Mike is logging in from.

358
00:19:30.700 --> 00:19:34.830
So I'll say Mike and
then View effective access.

359
00:19:34.830 --> 00:19:38.190
And there we go, let me zoom back out, so
you can actually see the whole window.

360
00:19:38.190 --> 00:19:42.979
Here you can see it telling me
exactly what permissions Mike has,

361
00:19:42.979 --> 00:19:46.997
all right, and
what permissions Mike doesn't have.

362
00:19:46.997 --> 00:19:53.440
All right, let's do this,
what's another way I could do this?

363
00:19:53.440 --> 00:19:57.866
Let's go back here and say,
change this user to administrators.

364
00:20:01.100 --> 00:20:05.099
And how about my backup operators?

365
00:20:07.591 --> 00:20:11.260
And I see I can't find any of my
groups today, that is really odd.

366
00:20:11.260 --> 00:20:13.590
We're gonna go advanced and find out,

367
00:20:13.590 --> 00:20:16.200
cuz I know I have some
backup operators somewhere.

368
00:20:16.200 --> 00:20:20.070
We'll do cert publishers,
I'll select them and I'll click OK.

369
00:20:20.070 --> 00:20:22.770
Now, remember the access control
list we were looking at?

370
00:20:22.770 --> 00:20:26.380
And there was no cert
publishers in that list, right?

371
00:20:26.380 --> 00:20:31.180
So, let's click OK and
then View effective access.

372
00:20:31.180 --> 00:20:37.280
And we'll scroll down, and sure enough,
they don't have any access, all right.

373
00:20:37.280 --> 00:20:38.580
What about this?

374
00:20:38.580 --> 00:20:41.080
Let's go back up here and change users.

375
00:20:41.080 --> 00:20:46.840
And I'm gonna put domain users,
and I'll click OK.

376
00:20:46.840 --> 00:20:50.540
Domain users was not in that
list of permissions there.

377
00:20:50.540 --> 00:20:55.740
But if I click View effective access,
Actually they don't, which is really odd.

378
00:20:55.740 --> 00:20:57.275
Something is going on with my device,

379
00:20:57.275 --> 00:21:01.990
it is not talking to my domain controller
very nicely right now, but that's okay.

380
00:21:01.990 --> 00:21:04.139
I think you guys understand the idea here.

381
00:21:04.139 --> 00:21:06.059
>> The principle there is very clear,
yeah.

382
00:21:06.059 --> 00:21:07.630
>> This helps you figure out.

383
00:21:07.630 --> 00:21:11.510
Because what Windows is gonna do,
all that stuff I was saying we had to do.

384
00:21:11.510 --> 00:21:14.390
Windows is gonna go find
the domain users group, and

385
00:21:14.390 --> 00:21:16.400
it's gonna go see if they're
in any other groups.

386
00:21:16.400 --> 00:21:17.690
And it's gonna start adding it up.

387
00:21:17.690 --> 00:21:19.250
And it's gonna take into effect, or

388
00:21:19.250 --> 00:21:24.690
into account, explicit permissions,
inherited permissions, allows, denies.

389
00:21:24.690 --> 00:21:30.640
It's gonna do all the calculation and
show me, in the end, what we get, right?

390
00:21:30.640 --> 00:21:32.210
That is known as effective permissions.

391
00:21:32.210 --> 00:21:34.730
And that's something they probably
will call out on the exam.

392
00:21:34.730 --> 00:21:37.030
And it's something that we
can use in the real world.

393
00:21:37.030 --> 00:21:40.170
Because there's many times, Zach calls
me up at the help desk and says, hey,

394
00:21:40.170 --> 00:21:44.650
Mike, for some reason,
I can't get into the employee phone book.

395
00:21:44.650 --> 00:21:46.360
Can you check that out for me?

396
00:21:46.360 --> 00:21:49.402
Well, the first thing I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna navigate to that employee phone

397
00:21:49.402 --> 00:21:52.593
book, wherever it's stored, and I'm gonna
go to the Effective Permissions tab.

398
00:21:52.593 --> 00:21:56.220
I'm gonna drop Zach in there, and I'm
gonna see what permissions it says he has.

399
00:21:56.220 --> 00:21:58.890
And if they're all red Xs,
okay, there's the problem.

400
00:21:58.890 --> 00:22:00.810
Zach doesn't have any
permissions over the resource.

401
00:22:00.810 --> 00:22:03.730
And then I can go troubleshoot why
he doesn't have those permissions.

402
00:22:03.730 --> 00:22:06.470
But at least I know now
the problem is permissions.

403
00:22:06.470 --> 00:22:10.043
You can't read that file because you
don't have read permission, all right?

404
00:22:10.043 --> 00:22:12.630
I didn't have to go look at
what group Zach belongs to.

405
00:22:12.630 --> 00:22:16.550
I didn't have to calculate all the allows
and denies or anything like that.

406
00:22:16.550 --> 00:22:20.600
I simply typed his name,
click View effective permissions, and

407
00:22:20.600 --> 00:22:21.680
it gives me the answer.

408
00:22:21.680 --> 00:22:25.011
So it's a very important tool
in managing our permissions.

409
00:22:25.011 --> 00:22:28.263
>> It's because they're making up those
prank calls, they're going to stop that.

410
00:22:28.263 --> 00:22:30.670
>> I think we gotta watch that guy,
he's crazy.

411
00:22:30.670 --> 00:22:34.854
All right, last thing I'm gonna
be able to squeeze into this one,

412
00:22:34.854 --> 00:22:39.970
one thing I kind of skipped over is
the hierarchy of precedence, all right?

413
00:22:39.970 --> 00:22:44.060
When we look at these permissions,
we need to know, let's say,

414
00:22:44.060 --> 00:22:48.020
you belong to one group, and
they've got the allow write permission.

415
00:22:48.020 --> 00:22:52.090
You belong to a second group, and
it has the deny write permission.

416
00:22:52.090 --> 00:22:53.980
Well I told you,
permissions are cumulative.

417
00:22:53.980 --> 00:22:58.180
You get to add up all the permissions
from all the groups you belong to.

418
00:22:58.180 --> 00:23:01.620
Well I just told you, you've got
an allow write and a deny write.

419
00:23:01.620 --> 00:23:03.010
Which one do you get?

420
00:23:03.010 --> 00:23:07.480
Right, you probably want the allow write,
that's a better permission to have.

421
00:23:07.480 --> 00:23:08.860
But that's not the way Windows works.

422
00:23:08.860 --> 00:23:11.200
Windows isn't gonna say, yeah,
that one gives you more stuff,

423
00:23:11.200 --> 00:23:12.330
let's give you that one.

424
00:23:12.330 --> 00:23:16.400
There's a specific precedence
to these permissions.

425
00:23:16.400 --> 00:23:21.560
And it's basically from the top down,
explicit deny, and then explicit

426
00:23:21.560 --> 00:23:27.210
allow underneath that, and then inherited
deny, and then inherited allow.

427
00:23:27.210 --> 00:23:31.560
So, if you write those down in a list,
explicit deny, explicit allow,

428
00:23:31.560 --> 00:23:35.680
inherited deny, inherited allow,
that is the order of precedence.

429
00:23:35.680 --> 00:23:40.337
The top, the explicit deny,
that has the highest precedence, so

430
00:23:40.337 --> 00:23:43.594
explicit denies will always win,
all right.

431
00:23:43.594 --> 00:23:46.387
There's nothing that has
a higher precedence than them.

432
00:23:46.387 --> 00:23:49.835
So you could get allow
from 15 different groups.

433
00:23:49.835 --> 00:23:54.674
You could belong to a dozen groups
that all give you allow full control.

434
00:23:54.674 --> 00:23:59.174
But if you belong to one group,
one of those 15 gives you a deny right

435
00:23:59.174 --> 00:24:03.440
explicitly, that will overwrite
all of the other allows.

436
00:24:03.440 --> 00:24:06.510
Nothing beats an explicit deny all right?

437
00:24:06.510 --> 00:24:08.236
>> Sounds like we're playing
a board game almost there.

438
00:24:08.236 --> 00:24:13.041
>> Yes and that's an important concept
though because there are going to be

439
00:24:13.041 --> 00:24:18.150
times where,let's say I wanna deny
Zach access to this file, right?

440
00:24:18.150 --> 00:24:20.860
Well, I could actually do it
a couple of different ways.

441
00:24:20.860 --> 00:24:23.770
It could be inherited from
the folder above it, and

442
00:24:23.770 --> 00:24:26.890
that would deny Zach the permission,
right?

443
00:24:26.890 --> 00:24:29.600
Or I could just not put
Zach in the list at all.

444
00:24:29.600 --> 00:24:32.690
Remember, and I don't know if this
is something we've even mentioned,

445
00:24:32.690 --> 00:24:36.160
NTFS works on an implicit deny system.

446
00:24:36.160 --> 00:24:40.281
In other words I can go and
add you to the list, and deny you, or

447
00:24:40.281 --> 00:24:42.199
just not put you on the list.

448
00:24:42.199 --> 00:24:43.053
>> And it will deny you anyway.

449
00:24:43.053 --> 00:24:46.948
>> It'll deny you anyway,
think about the VIP club, right?

450
00:24:46.948 --> 00:24:50.962
You got the bouncer out there, and
the red velvet rope and you walk up there,

451
00:24:50.962 --> 00:24:53.310
and you say, hey, I wanna go in.

452
00:24:53.310 --> 00:24:55.520
What does he do, he looks at the list.

453
00:24:55.520 --> 00:24:57.033
What happens if you're not on the list?

454
00:24:57.033 --> 00:24:57.807
>> You're denied.

455
00:24:57.807 --> 00:24:59.828
>> You don't get in,
you are denied, right.

456
00:24:59.828 --> 00:25:04.460
Nobody had to put your name on the list
and say hey, don't allow Mike to come in.

457
00:25:04.460 --> 00:25:06.875
They just don't put you on the list and
you don't get in.

458
00:25:06.875 --> 00:25:09.343
It's the same thing with NTFS files and
folders,

459
00:25:09.343 --> 00:25:12.000
if I don't add you to the list
you don't get access.

460
00:25:12.000 --> 00:25:13.860
I don't have to deny you but

461
00:25:13.860 --> 00:25:17.690
what if I didn't want Zack
to have access to that file?

462
00:25:17.690 --> 00:25:22.710
But some other admin added the HR group
and gave them permission over the file.

463
00:25:22.710 --> 00:25:25.508
And they didn't realize that
Zack was in that group.

464
00:25:25.508 --> 00:25:27.240
Well since Zack belongs to the group and

465
00:25:27.240 --> 00:25:30.010
the group was given permission,
Zack now has that permission.

466
00:25:30.010 --> 00:25:33.891
So even though I left him on the list,
left him off of the list intentionally so

467
00:25:33.891 --> 00:25:35.456
that he wouldn't get access.

468
00:25:35.456 --> 00:25:39.141
He still managed to get access
because he belongs to some group and

469
00:25:39.141 --> 00:25:41.200
that group got access, right?

470
00:25:41.200 --> 00:25:43.325
And that's the way it would work all right
>> That's good information to know.

471
00:25:43.325 --> 00:25:48.819
>> Yeah, but if I go to that resource and
I explicitly deny Zack.

472
00:25:50.050 --> 00:25:53.530
Now it doesn't matter what groups
are there and what permissions they have,

473
00:25:53.530 --> 00:25:56.760
because the explicit deny will
always override the allows, right?

474
00:25:56.760 --> 00:25:59.696
So that's why sometimes,
we need to do explicit denies.

475
00:25:59.696 --> 00:26:02.374
Because we wanna make sure that
no matter whatever else happens,

476
00:26:02.374 --> 00:26:04.037
not matter what groups you get added to.

477
00:26:04.037 --> 00:26:06.817
No matter what groups get added
to the access control list,

478
00:26:06.817 --> 00:26:08.547
you're still denied access right.

479
00:26:08.547 --> 00:26:10.143
We've got contractors that work for
us, and

480
00:26:10.143 --> 00:26:12.250
they've got accounts in
our active directory.

481
00:26:12.250 --> 00:26:16.090
They cannot get into
the financial information.

482
00:26:16.090 --> 00:26:20.110
I could take a chance, not add them to the
list and hope they never get access to it.

483
00:26:20.110 --> 00:26:22.810
Or I could explicitly deny
the contractors group

484
00:26:22.810 --> 00:26:25.700
to ensure that they
never get access to it.

485
00:26:25.700 --> 00:26:28.850
Now that's why Windows pops up
that warning though all right.

486
00:26:28.850 --> 00:26:31.840
Because you can get yourself in
trouble with explicit denies,

487
00:26:31.840 --> 00:26:33.360
you give an explicit deny to Zack.

488
00:26:33.360 --> 00:26:36.440
And then later on Zack
changes departments, and

489
00:26:36.440 --> 00:26:39.830
he get in this other department that
now needs access to the resource.

490
00:26:39.830 --> 00:26:43.840
So IT adds him to the group that everybody
else is in that gives them permissions.

491
00:26:43.840 --> 00:26:46.966
And Zack comes to you and
says I still can't get access.

492
00:26:46.966 --> 00:26:50.060
And you're pulling your hair out
going why can't Zack get access?

493
00:26:50.060 --> 00:26:54.570
He's in the group, everybody else in
the group has access, why can't Zack?

494
00:26:54.570 --> 00:26:58.784
There was an explicit deny that's
overriding everything else right?

495
00:26:58.784 --> 00:27:02.507
So explicits can get you into a little
bit of a trouble if you're not careful.

496
00:27:02.507 --> 00:27:07.354
You use them very sparingly, only where
I would need to 100% assure you'd never

497
00:27:07.354 --> 00:27:09.780
get access to that resource, right?

498
00:27:09.780 --> 00:27:12.257
Like that contractor's group or
something like that.

499
00:27:12.257 --> 00:27:14.582
>> Well Mike, you know I think we're
gonna need a part three aren't we?

500
00:27:14.582 --> 00:27:17.569
>> Yeah [LAUGH] I was gonna say,
I'm running out of air for this one and

501
00:27:17.569 --> 00:27:18.941
we still have more to go Zach.

502
00:27:18.941 --> 00:27:20.442
>> Yeah we absolutely do and

503
00:27:20.442 --> 00:27:24.737
it's exciting because this is
information we need on a regular basis.

504

MTAs, security fundamentals,
this is permissions part two.

505

We have a part one and
there will be a part three.

506
00:27:30.628 --> 00:27:32.026
You want to see all of those.

507
00:27:32.026 --> 00:27:34.520
Once again Mike thanks for
doing a great job.

508

You're watching ITProTV,
you know an IT Pro is always learning.

509
00:27:38.858 --> 00:27:39.884
I'm Zach Memos.

00:27:39.884 --> 00:27:40.790
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

>> And we'll see you next time.

00:12:28.870 --> 00:12:32.950
It's still a new object, and it's going

00:12:41.526 --> 00:12:47.564

00:12:59.120 --> 00:13:02.780

00:13:02.780 --> 00:13:04.760

00:13:08.960 --> 00:13:13.390

When you do advanced sharing, and let me
type in credentials so that I can do this.

705
00:37:59.430 --> 00:38:02.470
I can say share the folder and
notice the share name.

706
00:38:02.470 --> 00:38:04.280
By default,
it takes the name of the folder.

707
00:38:04.280 --> 00:38:08.021
So the folder's named share,
so is the share itself.

708
00:38:08.021 --> 00:38:13.458
But if I add a dollar sign to the end
of that name and I click OK and

709
00:38:13.458 --> 00:38:20.900
then I zoom out and I click OK, I just
created my own hidden share, all right?

710
00:38:20.900 --> 00:38:26.450
If I go back over to DCO 1,
I open up File Explorer, and

711
00:38:26.450 --> 00:38:31.670
I go //client01,

712
00:38:31.670 --> 00:38:36.150
notice that that share doesn't show up.

713
00:38:36.150 --> 00:38:41.685
But what if I put, /share$?

714
00:38:41.685 --> 00:38:43.740
And I connect, no problem, right?

715
00:38:43.740 --> 00:38:49.100
So you can create your own hidden shares.

716
00:38:49.100 --> 00:38:53.260
If you have shares hidden, you just have
to know the exact name to type it in.

717
00:38:53.260 --> 00:38:55.790
Now keep this in mind.

718
00:38:55.790 --> 00:38:59.670
These hidden shares don't do anything for
security.

719
00:38:59.670 --> 00:39:02.640
Those administrative shares,
the built-in ones, Admin$,

720
00:39:02.640 --> 00:39:07.020
Print$, we have to be an administrator
to connect to those folders.

721
00:39:07.020 --> 00:39:12.450
But if I create my own hidden share,
it doesn't really secure it.

722
00:39:12.450 --> 00:39:16.450
What it's doing is making sure
that other people can't see it.

723
00:39:16.450 --> 00:39:19.417
But if they know the name,
they can type it in.

724
00:39:19.417 --> 00:39:22.010
And if they have permissions,
they can still connect to it.

725
00:39:22.010 --> 00:39:25.180
So don't think it's a way to completely
hide a folder from everybody on

726
00:39:25.180 --> 00:39:27.340
the network, and it's super secure.

727
00:39:27.340 --> 00:39:30.940
But most people don't know
the name of the share you created.

728
00:39:30.940 --> 00:39:32.260
They don't even know it's there.

729
00:39:32.260 --> 00:39:35.790
And it's not gonna show up on their list,
and tempt them to click on it.

730
00:39:35.790 --> 00:39:38.930
So it's kind of security
through obscurity.

731
00:39:38.930 --> 00:39:40.850
Doesn't guarantee security.

732
00:39:40.850 --> 00:39:44.089
But it does give you a little
bit of a secure feeling.

733
00:39:44.089 --> 00:39:45.905
And as a help desk person,

734
00:39:45.905 --> 00:39:50.873
I used to have a folder of all the tools
that I needed that was shared out.

735
00:39:50.873 --> 00:39:53.561
So that when I was out running
around to people's desks,

736
00:39:53.561 --> 00:39:55.200
I could get to those tools.

737
00:39:55.200 --> 00:39:59.250
But I didn't want Joe User
opening up File Explorer and

738
00:39:59.250 --> 00:40:02.200
stumbling across this folder
with all these tools.

739
00:40:02.200 --> 00:40:06.380
Because those tools could be used for
malicious purposes if you weren't careful.

740
00:40:06.380 --> 00:40:07.580
So I hid the share.

741
00:40:07.580 --> 00:40:10.470
That way I could get to it
from wherever I was at, but

742
00:40:10.470 --> 00:40:12.960
nobody stumbled across it and
found it accidentally.

743
00:40:12.960 --> 00:40:15.850
So, shares, administrative shares, aka,

744
00:40:15.850 --> 00:40:18.900
hidden shares,
can be a very powerful feature.

745
00:40:18.900 --> 00:40:22.772
>> Awesome information, and this is
the conclusion of Permissions Part 3.

746
00:40:22.772 --> 00:40:25.020
There is a Part 1 and Part 2, of course.

747
00:40:25.020 --> 00:40:27.490
And you're gonna wanna
rewatch all of them.

748
00:40:27.490 --> 00:40:30.972
And you can, because you have access
to the library cuz you're very smart.

749
00:40:30.972 --> 00:40:32.740
Mike, you did a great job,
thank you so very much.

750
00:40:32.740 --> 00:40:34.703
This is MTA Security Fundamentals.

751
00:40:34.703 --> 00:40:37.502
Thanks for watching that,
and this is ITPro.TV.

752
00:40:37.502 --> 00:40:41.450
And you know at ITPro.TV,
we say an IT Pro is always learning.

753
00:40:41.450 --> 00:40:42.710
And that's the way it should be.

754
00:40:42.710 --> 00:40:43.630
I'm Zach Memos.

755
00:40:43.630 --> 00:40:44.510
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

756
00:40:44.510 --> 00:40:46.757
>> And we will see you next time.

25

And we'll talk about what is,

26

00:01:07.792 --> 00:01:11.109

28
00:01:11.109 --> 00:01:12.688
>> So here's my formal question to you.

29

>> Uh-huh?

30

>> What is a registry permission?

31
00:01:15.973 --> 00:01:17.452
A registry permission, well,

32
00:01:17.452 --> 00:01:20.261
a registry permission is
a permission within the registry.

33

>> Okay.

34

>> Easy enough, right?

35
00:01:21.733 --> 00:01:23.739
[LAUGH]
>> Time to go, thanks for watching.

36
00:01:23.739 --> 00:01:26.480
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, right, that would be
nice if that was all there is to it.

37
00:01:26.480 --> 00:01:30.670
But when we talk about the permissions,
I mean, we're thinking the same things.

38
00:01:30.670 --> 00:01:35.820
Permissions control what level of access
someone or something has over an object.

39
00:01:35.820 --> 00:01:38.586
And when we get into the registry,
it's gonna be the same thing,

40
00:01:38.586 --> 00:01:40.459
we're gonna have objects in the registry.

41
00:01:40.459 --> 00:01:44.695
And each one of those objects is gonna
have one of those good old access control

42
00:01:44.695 --> 00:01:48.931
lists associated with it where we can
put down, we can assign permissions and

43
00:01:48.931 --> 00:01:52.740
control or deny, allow or
deny access to these registry keys.

44
00:01:52.740 --> 00:01:56.590
So really what we need to start off with,
what the heck is the registry even, right?

45
00:01:56.590 --> 00:02:01.420
And that is going to be,
the registry is a database of sorts.

46
00:02:01.420 --> 00:02:05.020
It's a place where Windows,
our operating system,

47
00:02:05.020 --> 00:02:08.700
stores all this configuration information,
right?

48
00:02:08.700 --> 00:02:13.105
We're talking about hardware
configuration, software configuration,

49
00:02:13.105 --> 00:02:16.543
some of our system security
policies are stored in here, so

50
00:02:16.543 --> 00:02:18.001
all of that gets stored.

51
00:02:18.001 --> 00:02:22.345
And when you think about logging onto your
Windows system, right, you log onto your

52
00:02:22.345 --> 00:02:26.220
work computer or your home computer,
your laptop, whatever it is.

53
00:02:26.220 --> 00:02:30.060
And let's say you wanna make a change,
let's say you change your background,

54
00:02:30.060 --> 00:02:31.910
the picture that's in you're background.

55
00:02:31.910 --> 00:02:33.710
Well, how does Windows remember that so

56
00:02:33.710 --> 00:02:38.050
that the next time you log on, that same
picture's being shown on your background?

57
00:02:38.050 --> 00:02:40.120
It stores that information
in the registry.

58
00:02:40.120 --> 00:02:43.880
There is a entry in the registry for
your user account and

59
00:02:43.880 --> 00:02:45.790
what background you've chosen.

60
00:02:45.790 --> 00:02:48.880
Or what font size in Notepad or

61
00:02:48.880 --> 00:02:53.640
how long the screensaver takes before
it kicks in and locks your screen.

62
00:02:53.640 --> 00:02:56.318
All of those stuff,
everything that you can change or

63
00:02:56.318 --> 00:02:58.290
configure within windows get stored.

64
00:02:58.290 --> 00:03:02.960
Well, I shouldn't say everything but
the vast majority of it gets stored

65
00:03:02.960 --> 00:03:04.250
in the registry
>> And

66
00:03:04.250 --> 00:03:07.030
normally you don't have to go in and
modify that, do you?

67
00:03:07.030 --> 00:03:11.920
>> Correct, we don't modify it directly,
we do end up modifying it indirectly.

68
00:03:11.920 --> 00:03:15.220
When you go to your setting,
you open up the control panel, or

69
00:03:15.220 --> 00:03:17.460
you go to your display preferences, right?

70
00:03:17.460 --> 00:03:20.930
And you go to the background options, and
you browse through all your pictures, and

71
00:03:20.930 --> 00:03:23.340
you're doing this with
your mouse in the GUI.

72
00:03:23.340 --> 00:03:24.640
Well, when you make that change and

73
00:03:24.640 --> 00:03:28.090
you click Save, what it's doing
is it's writing to the registry.

74
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:31.680
Now, we could open up
the registry ourselves and

75
00:03:31.680 --> 00:03:35.450
find where that value is stored and
just change it manually.

76
00:03:35.450 --> 00:03:39.690
I could type the path and the name to
the image that I wanted to set for

77
00:03:39.690 --> 00:03:40.700
my background.

78
00:03:40.700 --> 00:03:44.480
So technically I could make the change
in the registry, manually, myself.

79
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:45.190
But here's the problem,

80
00:03:45.190 --> 00:03:49.550
here's why we don't do that,
because there's no safety checks, right?

81
00:03:49.550 --> 00:03:52.920
When you go through the GUI, when
you're opening up the little wizard and

82
00:03:52.920 --> 00:03:54.590
it's saying here's all
the pictures you have,

83
00:03:54.590 --> 00:03:56.470
which one do you wanna
set as your background?

84
00:03:56.470 --> 00:03:58.614
There's no chance of it
getting the wrong path,

85
00:03:58.614 --> 00:04:00.770
there's no chance of it
getting the wrong name.

86
00:04:00.770 --> 00:04:04.023
You don't have to spell anything,
type anything, you're clicking on it and

87
00:04:04.023 --> 00:04:05.520
you're clicking Save.

88
00:04:05.520 --> 00:04:07.900
And so
those are the safety checks that the GUI,

89
00:04:07.900 --> 00:04:10.410
the graphical user interface, gives me.

90
00:04:10.410 --> 00:04:12.890
Typically I can't make
choices that aren't allowed.

91
00:04:12.890 --> 00:04:15.175
It might say, hey, or
what do you want to set this to?

92
00:04:15.175 --> 00:04:18.897
Your options are this, this, and this and
you have to pick one of those three.

93
00:04:18.897 --> 00:04:23.857
If I go into the registry and try to do it
manually, I could type anything I want.

94
00:04:23.857 --> 00:04:26.335
And what I end up typing
could be completely wrong and

95
00:04:26.335 --> 00:04:29.050
in fact it could cause serious
problems for my computer.

96
00:04:29.050 --> 00:04:32.060
It tries to read it and it's looking for
a picture that it's supposed

97
00:04:32.060 --> 00:04:35.100
to put as my background, and
I mistakenly put my phone number.

98
00:04:35.100 --> 00:04:36.200
Well, now what's Windows gonna do?

99
00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:39.800
It's probably gonna blue screen, it's
gonna crash, or it's gonna have a problem.

100
00:04:39.800 --> 00:04:42.677
Depending on what key it is,
it could cause the system to crash,

101
00:04:42.677 --> 00:04:45.255
could even prevent it from
booting up in the first place.

102
00:04:45.255 --> 00:04:48.280
And now we've gotta go
an repair the entire thing.

103
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:51.010
So when you hear people say
don't ever touch your registry,

104
00:04:51.010 --> 00:04:54.170
don't make changes to it,
that's a bad, bad thing.

105
00:04:54.170 --> 00:04:55.870
Well, you should turn around and
tell them,

106
00:04:55.870 --> 00:04:59.270
you make changes to your registry
every time you log onto your computer.

107
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:01.720
You're just not doing it manually-
>> Or directly.

108
00:05:01.720 --> 00:05:03.850
>> Yeah, to the actual registry,

109
00:05:03.850 --> 00:05:08.130
you're using tools that are ending up
changing the registry in the background.

110
00:05:08.130 --> 00:05:10.480
So if you know what you're doing,
or if you're careful and

111
00:05:10.480 --> 00:05:11.895
you pay attention to what you're doing,

112
00:05:11.895 --> 00:05:16.220
there's nothing wrong with going into
the registry and making changes.

113
00:05:16.220 --> 00:05:20.080
It's just that we run the risk
of causing problems, all right?

114
00:05:20.080 --> 00:05:22.760
So it's not that editing it
manually causes problems.

115
00:05:22.760 --> 00:05:24.400
It's the fact that there's
no safety checks and

116
00:05:24.400 --> 00:05:28.110
I can make a silly typo that
can cause a problem, all right?

117
00:05:28.110 --> 00:05:30.510
>> My question for you, what is Regedit?

118
00:05:30.510 --> 00:05:31.260
What is that?

119
00:05:31.260 --> 00:05:35.332
>> Regedit or Regedit, depending on how
people wanna pronounce that, is the tool

120
00:05:35.332 --> 00:05:39.187
that we would use to make those changes,
or just to go look at the registry.

121
00:05:39.187 --> 00:05:42.220
Cuz sometimes we don't need to make
changes but maybe we wanna look at it.

122
00:05:42.220 --> 00:05:45.920
Maybe we have a program that we're
getting ready to install and

123
00:05:45.920 --> 00:05:48.060
it's gonna make changes to the registry.

124
00:05:48.060 --> 00:05:50.622
And before I do that I wanna
back the registry up so

125
00:05:50.622 --> 00:05:56.120
that if something goes wrong I can restore
a known good copy of the registry.

126
00:05:56.120 --> 00:05:58.520
All of these things I would
end up doing with Regedit.

127
00:05:58.520 --> 00:06:01.260
>> I can make changes,
I can export keys, and

128
00:06:01.260 --> 00:06:06.090
I can import keys into that registry,
all right?

129
00:06:06.090 --> 00:06:10.370
So let's take a look at the registry and
then we'll kinda keep going from there.

130
00:06:10.370 --> 00:06:12.230
We're gonna pull up my screen.

131
00:06:12.230 --> 00:06:16.070
And I've just got a Windows
10 domain member here.

132
00:06:16.070 --> 00:06:20.854
And I'm simply gonna go to my Start
menu and type regedit, all one word.

133
00:06:20.854 --> 00:06:25.116
And you can see there in my
Start menu that the choice for

134
00:06:25.116 --> 00:06:29.481
regedit comes up, oops,
a little ZoomIt issue there.

135
00:06:29.481 --> 00:06:35.144
We'll do that one more time, regedit,
and I'll hit Enter and there we go.

136
00:06:35.144 --> 00:06:39.654
Right, so this is my registry editor,
this is the tool Microsoft gives

137
00:06:39.654 --> 00:06:43.276
me to manually manipulate or
at least view the registry.

138
00:06:43.276 --> 00:06:43.852
>> Okay.

139
00:06:43.852 --> 00:06:50.017
>> Now, as I zoom in over here, you'll see
that it's broken down into these sections.

140
00:06:50.017 --> 00:06:54.625
And each one of these
has a specific purpose.

141
00:06:54.625 --> 00:06:57.100
And if we want to,
we can go through these guys.

142
00:06:57.100 --> 00:06:58.764
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT, and

143
00:06:58.764 --> 00:07:03.070
unfortunately I'm gonna have to
probably zoom out to click on anything.

144
00:07:03.070 --> 00:07:05.170
My ZoomIt tool is not, there we go.

145
00:07:05.170 --> 00:07:09.153
All right, so HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT,
this key, or this,

146
00:07:09.153 --> 00:07:14.103
I wanna use this term, we haven't
really defined it yet, hive, right?

147
00:07:14.103 --> 00:07:15.277
>> Hive.
>> Yeah, so now-

148
00:07:15.277 --> 00:07:17.058
>> I was gonna ask you what a hive was.

149
00:07:17.058 --> 00:07:19.240
>> I knew you were,
you were asking me about that earlier.

150
00:07:19.240 --> 00:07:24.740
And that hive, it's just a name for
each one of these groups here, all right?

151
00:07:24.740 --> 00:07:26.790
So really there's five hives.

152
00:07:26.790 --> 00:07:31.470
There's HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT and
hive key or HKEY for short.

153
00:07:31.470 --> 00:07:36.753
There's CLASSES_ROOT, CURRENT_USER,
LOCAL_MACHINE, USERS, and CURRENT_CONFIG.

154
00:07:36.753 --> 00:07:38.555
So those are my five hives.

155
00:07:38.555 --> 00:07:42.870
Now, we talk about this as being
a database, it's not really a database.

156
00:07:42.870 --> 00:07:47.124
Because it's actually different files on
your hard drive that are storing these

157
00:07:47.124 --> 00:07:47.755
settings.

158
00:07:47.755 --> 00:07:53.210
And they might not necessarily all be,
there is no file HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE.

159
00:07:53.210 --> 00:07:56.223
There might be two or
three files that hold all these settings.

160
00:07:56.223 --> 00:07:59.716
What the registry editor does is go and
get those files, read them,

161
00:07:59.716 --> 00:08:02.434
and then put them in this
nice organized view for us.

162
00:08:02.434 --> 00:08:05.805
So there's no guarantee that these
are actually a specific file,

163
00:08:05.805 --> 00:08:09.544
is what I'm trying to say, and
it's really not important for us either.

164
00:08:09.544 --> 00:08:13.997
Cuz the register editor goes and gets all
the files necessary, compiles it up, and

165
00:08:13.997 --> 00:08:18.020
puts it in this nice pretty view
that allows us to work with it.

166
00:08:18.020 --> 00:08:19.570
So HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT,

167
00:08:19.570 --> 00:08:24.960
this is one where we store registered
applications and file type associations.

168
00:08:24.960 --> 00:08:27.421
So when you double click

00:27:39.880 --> 00:27:41.820

00:27:41.820 --> 00:27:45.250

00:27:45.250 --> 00:27:49.690

00:27:49.690 --> 00:27:50.830

00:27:50.830 --> 00:27:54.120

454

00:23:45.530 --> 00:23:49.410

461

I'm gonna jump over to

00:24:15.120 --> 00:24:17.331

477

480

481

482

483

Your password has been changed.

484
00:24:59.794 --> 00:25:02.746

485

Great.

504
00:25:48.277 --> 00:25:49.870
>> No, no, let's go ahead and

505
00:25:49.870 --> 00:25:51.890
Cuz these are pretty straightforward.

506
00:25:51.890 --> 00:25:54.090
We've already talked about user accounts.

508

509
00:25:59.840 --> 00:26:01.580
And you might think,
wow, that's kinda odd.

510
00:26:01.580 --> 00:26:04.380
Why would a computer need an account?

511
00:26:04.380 --> 00:26:08.510
Think back to when we talked about
permissions, and we talked about

512
00:26:08.510 --> 00:26:12.770
the triple A, right, authentication,
authorization, and accounting?

513
00:26:12.770 --> 00:26:17.430
Well, if a computer doesn't have
an account then I cannot authenticate that

514
00:26:17.430 --> 00:26:18.657
computer, right?

515
00:26:18.657 --> 00:26:21.658
That means you can just bring any
computer you want in off the street,

516
00:26:21.658 --> 00:26:25.060
plug it into my network and
attempt to authenticate to my domain.

517
00:26:25.060 --> 00:26:28.300
I do not want users bringing
just any old computer in and

518
00:26:28.300 --> 00:26:29.410

519
00:26:29.410 --> 00:26:31.150
I need to manage those computers.

520
00:26:31.150 --> 00:26:33.014
So computers must authenticate.

521
00:26:33.014 --> 00:26:36.806
A lot of people don't realize this,
when you turn a computer on at work,

522
00:26:36.806 --> 00:26:40.907

you turn your computer on, before you see

523
00:26:40.907 --> 00:26:45.520

actually logging in in the background.

524
00:26:45.520 --> 00:26:48.400
It's talking to Active Directory and
saying, hey,

525
00:26:48.400 --> 00:26:51.417
my name's client laptop 22 and
here's my password.

526
00:26:51.417 --> 00:26:53.840
That's right,
computers have passwords, too.

527
00:26:53.840 --> 00:26:55.040
We don't see them.

528
00:26:55.040 --> 00:26:57.330
Active Directory and
the computer manage it.

529
00:26:57.330 --> 00:27:00.400
They change it every so
often just like a user account would.

530
00:27:00.400 --> 00:27:02.770
It's just all automated and
done behind the scenes.

531
00:27:02.770 --> 00:27:06.410
So yeah, computers have accounts in Active
Directory so that they can authenticate.

532
00:27:06.410 --> 00:27:09.134

533
00:27:09.134 --> 00:27:12.852
What if that computer shouldn't be
allowed to connect to certain resources,

534
00:27:12.852 --> 00:27:14.570

535
00:27:14.570 --> 00:27:17.610
Well, that marketing
computer has no business

536
00:27:17.610 --> 00:27:19.930
looking at the stuff in that R&D database.

537
00:27:19.930 --> 00:27:24.182
Because the computer has an account
I could then go to that resource and

538
00:27:24.182 --> 00:27:25.198

539
00:27:25.198 --> 00:27:28.180
If the computer didn't have an account

We're gonna do a whole episode

546

But auditing is keeping track
of who did what when and where.

547
00:27:46.260 --> 00:27:47.043
Just not the why.

548
00:27:47.043 --> 00:27:49.180
That's something we have to ask.

549
00:27:49.180 --> 00:27:54.452
But let's say I wanna see who made
a change to a particular file.

550
00:27:54.452 --> 00:28:00.590
Well, when I'm auditing I can say, look,
Wes Brian, at 10:42 AM, deleted this file.

551
00:28:01.630 --> 00:28:03.570
Because the computer has an account,

552
00:28:03.570 --> 00:28:07.520
I can also see what machine he was
sitting at when he did it, right?

553
00:28:07.520 --> 00:28:09.100
So I can trace all of that back.

554
00:28:09.100 --> 00:28:13.366
And so computers have accounts so
we can do that authorization,

555
00:28:13.366 --> 00:28:17.714
the authentication, the authorization,
and the accounting.

556
00:28:17.714 --> 00:28:22.320
And so we can apply group policy to them,
and we apply settings to them.

557
00:28:22.320 --> 00:28:25.283
If we take look at my screen here,
I'll go ahead and create one.

558
00:28:25.283 --> 00:28:27.743
Let me save, let's just do,

I'll call this client, clients.

562

And then what I really should do is
take that client 01 computer account and

563

We'll talk about those warnings and
things in a future episode or

00:28:50.870 --> 00:28:53.576
But here is the account for that client,

567

the one that I just logged
on with Wes' account.

568
00:28:56.846 --> 00:29:01.005
And I can see it has certain properties,
like its name, what operating system,

569
00:29:01.005 --> 00:29:05.380
whether or not it's a member of groups,
and groups are coming up in a minute.

570
00:29:05.380 --> 00:29:10.190
We can delegate control, who it's

571
00:29:10.190 --> 00:29:13.970
Hey, that laptop belongs to

572
00:29:13.970 --> 00:29:15.790
Not nearly as many properties.

573

One thing I didn't show you

00:29:19.500 --> 00:29:23.160
We look at this and look at all

575

So now, with a user account, remember I
said you just need first name, last name,

00:29:27.445 --> 00:29:28.131
log on name?

577
00:29:28.131 --> 00:29:32.052
Well, once you actually create it,
you can go back and fill in all this other

578
00:29:32.052 --> 00:29:36.286
information, Description, Office,
Telephone Number, Addresses, Account

579
00:29:36.286 --> 00:29:41.160
information, Telephones, Organization,
and the list goes on, and on, and on.

580
00:29:41.160 --> 00:29:45.900
And the more information I fill out, the

581
00:29:45.900 --> 00:29:50.770
Because let's say I wanna see all the user
accounts that are managed by Tim Broom.

582
00:29:50.770 --> 00:29:53.751
Well, if I haven't filled that
information out in Active Directory,

583

00:29:59.440 --> 00:30:01.050
Again, if I haven't gone back in and

it's gonna be very difficult

So the more of those properties we
can fill in, both user accounts and

3

>> Hello and welcome back to another

I'm your host Wes Bryan and
today's episode,

6
00:00:23.131 --> 00:00:26.093
I'm coming back with a part three
on Active Directory permissions and

7
00:00:26.093 --> 00:00:27.761
it's none other than Mr Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:27.761 --> 00:00:28.739
Mike how are you doing, sir?

9

>> I'm doing great and

10

12
00:00:33.200 --> 00:00:36.200
Well yes, so yes I'm glad to be back,
excited to be here.

13
00:00:36.200 --> 00:00:41.140
>> Love out MTA, love Active Directory,

14
00:00:41.140 --> 00:00:43.620
You might have been able to tell, right?

15
00:00:43.620 --> 00:00:48.310
[LAUGH] We left off getting ready, we
talked about Active Directory itself and

16
00:00:48.310 --> 00:00:50.350
what it was, and why we like it.

17
00:00:50.350 --> 00:00:54.640
We talked about objects that we might find
in Active Directory like computer accounts

18
00:00:54.640 --> 00:00:55.650
and user accounts.

19
00:00:55.650 --> 00:01:00.910
Now, I wanna talk about another object
that we'll find in Active Directory.

20
00:01:00.910 --> 00:01:05.070
Very, very useful object and
that is groups.

21
00:01:05.070 --> 00:01:08.900
Groups will be your second best friend.

22
00:01:08.900 --> 00:01:14.150
Active Directory's your first best friend,
groups would probably be second.

23
00:01:14.150 --> 00:01:19.170
We've talked a lot about permissions and
we've talked about how every resource and

24
00:01:19.170 --> 00:01:22.080
on an NTFS partition has
an access control list.

25
00:01:22.080 --> 00:01:25.960
And I can add user accounts, or
ACEs, access control entries and

26
00:01:25.960 --> 00:01:28.590
I can control what permissions
they have or don't have, right.

27
00:01:28.590 --> 00:01:32.300
I can allow or deny permissions
over each one of those resources.

28
00:01:32.300 --> 00:01:34.220
And it seems great and it is great.

29
00:01:34.220 --> 00:01:36.770
We love NTFS and we love permissions.

30
00:01:36.770 --> 00:01:40.200
But, we've only talked about it
on a very small scale, right.

31
00:01:40.200 --> 00:01:43.210
Taking one user and
added it to a resource and allowed or

32
00:01:43.210 --> 00:01:46.530
denied them some permission and
said woo-hoo.

33
00:01:46.530 --> 00:01:49.390
The problem is when you get into
an Active Directory environment,

34
00:01:49.390 --> 00:01:54.035
we are gonna have more than just
a couple of objects, right.

35
00:01:54.035 --> 00:01:59.100
[COUGH] We said Active Directory can scale
up to hundreds of thousands of objects.

36
00:01:59.100 --> 00:02:03.690
Well, now imagine that you
have 175 sales people.

37
00:02:03.690 --> 00:02:07.590
And here's a new resource, that somebody
created, and I now need to give read,

38
00:02:07.590 --> 00:02:10.830
write access to all 175 sales people.

39
00:02:10.830 --> 00:02:15.590
So, I open up the access control list,
and one at a time I click add, find, and

40
00:02:15.590 --> 00:02:18.950
I find each user account and
I add them and I give them a permission.

41
00:02:18.950 --> 00:02:20.590
Does that sound like
something we wanna do?

42
00:02:20.590 --> 00:02:21.200
>> No it does not.

43
00:02:21.200 --> 00:02:24.430
The only thing I can think of is this is
like running contrary to why you would

44
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:26.290
even use Active Directory to begin with.

45
00:02:26.290 --> 00:02:26.920
>> It really does.

46
00:02:26.920 --> 00:02:29.050
We said it was going to
simplify administration,

47
00:02:29.050 --> 00:02:34.310
not make things more difficult and
it will, if we use it in the right way.

48
00:02:34.310 --> 00:02:36.880
So we will use Groups.

49
00:02:36.880 --> 00:02:42.357
Groups are going to allow us to
collect up all 175 of those sales

50
00:02:42.357 --> 00:02:47.890
people that need that same permission, and
I can put all those people in a group.

51
00:02:47.890 --> 00:02:51.710
And then I cannot add the people to
the access control list, not the user

52
00:02:51.710 --> 00:02:57.280
accounts, but I can add the group itself
to the access control list one time.

53
00:02:57.280 --> 00:02:59.780
And I can assign
the permission to that group.

54
00:02:59.780 --> 00:03:02.180
Read and write over this particular file.

55
00:03:02.180 --> 00:03:06.160
Now, everybody in that group
will pick up those permissions,

56
00:03:06.160 --> 00:03:08.890
because they're a member of that group.

57
00:03:08.890 --> 00:03:13.460
Anybody that belongs to the group will get
any permissions assigned to that group.

58
00:03:13.460 --> 00:03:17.440
So right then and there,
it simplifies everything, right?

59
00:03:17.440 --> 00:03:20.629
Cuz I had to do it once
instead of 175 times.

60
00:03:20.629 --> 00:03:24.261
Now, imagine tomorrow we hire
five new people in sales.

61
00:03:24.261 --> 00:03:28.325
Instead of having to go back to that
resource and add each one of those people

62
00:03:28.325 --> 00:03:31.746
and then add their permissions
to their access control entry,

63
00:03:31.746 --> 00:03:35.120
I can just add those those
five accounts to the group.

64
00:03:35.120 --> 00:03:37.260
The group's already in the access
control list from before,

65
00:03:37.260 --> 00:03:38.710
it already has it's permissions.

66
00:03:38.710 --> 00:03:42.020
As soon as I add them to the group,
they get the permissions.

67
00:03:42.020 --> 00:03:43.920

00:28:57.450 --> 00:28:59.530
They can backup and
restore domain controllers.

530
00:28:59.530 --> 00:29:01.300
They can also now physically log on.

531
00:29:01.300 --> 00:29:03.680
They can log on locally to
those domain controllers.

532
00:29:03.680 --> 00:29:05.018
I might not have wanted that.

533
00:29:05.018 --> 00:29:08.478
Yes, I want them to back up,
but not to be able to log on.

534
00:29:08.478 --> 00:29:13.686
Or a lot of organizations split those
responsibilities, backup and restore.

535
00:29:13.686 --> 00:29:18.036
Because if one person has the ability
to do both backup and restore,

536
00:29:18.036 --> 00:29:21.050
that's considered a security issue.

537
00:29:21.050 --> 00:29:24.930
Because now if I get malicious,
if I'm a disgruntled employee.

538
00:29:24.930 --> 00:29:28.740
I could back something up, do something
bad, try to get away with something, and

539
00:29:28.740 --> 00:29:31.010
then restore it to cover my tracks.

540
00:29:31.010 --> 00:29:34.720
But if I can only back it up and somebody
else has to restore, that won't work.

541
00:29:34.720 --> 00:29:38.330
I'm gonna have to back up something, do
something malicious, and then go to Wes.

542
00:29:38.330 --> 00:29:41.980
Hey Wes, here's 100 bucks, can you
restore this and cover my tracks for me?

543
00:29:41.980 --> 00:29:46.160
Wes is most likely gonna say no,
although, 100 bucks is 100 bucks.

544
00:29:46.160 --> 00:29:48.400
But the idea is we split those up.

545
00:29:48.400 --> 00:29:52.788
But if I use that built-in group, I have
no way of saying, Wes, you can backup but

546
00:29:52.788 --> 00:29:54.388
you can't restore, right?

547
00:29:54.388 --> 00:29:57.200
I can create my own groups and
give them the ability to back up.

548
00:29:57.200 --> 00:29:59.860
Create a separate group,
give it the ability to restore.

549
00:29:59.860 --> 00:30:03.710
So the short of the story is,
there are several built-in groups,

550
00:30:03.710 --> 00:30:06.160
feel free to use them,
that's what they're there for.

551
00:30:06.160 --> 00:30:08.838
But just make sure you
understand what rights and

552
00:30:08.838 --> 00:30:12.756
permissions go along with those groups,
so you don't end up violating

553
00:30:12.756 --> 00:30:16.432
principle of least privilege when
you add people to those groups.

554
00:30:16.432 --> 00:30:18.742
All right, last thing I wanna talk about,

555
00:30:18.742 --> 00:30:23.210
I know I've been mentioning this a couple
of times and that is delegation.

556
00:30:23.210 --> 00:30:26.860
All right,
we've really talk about what it is.

557
00:30:26.860 --> 00:30:29.680
We say we can assign permissions
in Active Directory.

558
00:30:29.680 --> 00:30:31.830
Now, let's take a look at my screen here.

559
00:30:31.830 --> 00:30:34.540
When we look at,
let's say this employee's OU.

560
00:30:36.000 --> 00:30:38.400
Let's go down to the sales OU,
as a matter of fact.

561
00:30:38.400 --> 00:30:42.480
All right, if I right-click on that
sales OU and then go to Properties.

562
00:30:42.480 --> 00:30:45.580
We're gonna see a whole bunch of tabs,
three.

563
00:30:45.580 --> 00:30:47.200
A whole bunch Mike, [LAUGH] all right?

564
00:30:47.200 --> 00:30:49.960
You don't get to see
all of them by default.

565
00:30:49.960 --> 00:30:53.520
In order to see all of the tabs,
I have to go to my View menu, and

566
00:30:53.520 --> 00:30:56.180
turn on Advanced Features.

567
00:30:56.180 --> 00:30:58.406
Once I do that,
I go back to that same group,

568
00:30:58.406 --> 00:31:01.909
notice there's a bunch of other
things that weren't there before.

569
00:31:01.909 --> 00:31:09.460
I go back to that same OU,
Sales, right-click Properties.

570
00:31:09.460 --> 00:31:11.720
And now you will see several more tabs.

571
00:31:11.720 --> 00:31:13.860
One of them being the Security tab.

572
00:31:13.860 --> 00:31:16.272
And look, is that familiar?

573
00:31:16.272 --> 00:31:19.622
It's an access control list just like
we saw like with NTFS permissions,

574
00:31:19.622 --> 00:31:21.688
just like we saw with
registry permissions.

575
00:31:21.688 --> 00:31:24.030
It's just an access control list.

576
00:31:24.030 --> 00:31:26.580
Now, the permissions are different.

577
00:31:26.580 --> 00:31:32.210
It's not just read, write, modify,
list, and read next queue, and read.

578
00:31:32.210 --> 00:31:37.110
There are lots and lots of permissions and
this is just a small sampling.

579
00:31:37.110 --> 00:31:41.010
But the point of the story
here is it works the same way.

580
00:31:41.010 --> 00:31:43.751
You can add somebody to this list or
a group and

581
00:31:43.751 --> 00:31:47.950
then I can choose what permissions
they have or don't have, right?

582
00:31:47.950 --> 00:31:53.197
Which is fine, but if that ever changes,
you're gonna have to come in here.

583
00:31:53.197 --> 00:31:54.833
What's a good way to say this?

584
00:31:54.833 --> 00:31:56.351
If I wanna give you, or a group,

585
00:31:56.351 --> 00:32:00.330
let's say I want to give Helpdesk
the ability to reset passwords.

586
00:32:00.330 --> 00:32:03.170
All right, what permissions
are needed to reset passwords?

587
00:32:04.500 --> 00:32:08.010
I don't know, I mean, I know you're
gonna need to read the object.

588
00:32:08.010 --> 00:32:10.370
You're probably gonna need write
permissions over the object.

589
00:32:10.370 --> 00:32:13.145
I don't know if there's any other
permissions needed to reset the password.

590
00:32:13.145 --> 00:32:15.989
I'm gonna have to go do research and
look it up and come in here and

591
00:32:15.989 --> 00:32:17.736
choose the appropriate permissions.

592
00:32:17.736 --> 00:32:20.510
Cuz when I say there's a lot,
let's take a look here.

593
00:32:20.510 --> 00:32:25.680
If I click Advanced and I move this
over where we can actually see it,

594
00:32:25.680 --> 00:32:29.050
and I'm gonna click, where are we at?

595
00:32:29.050 --> 00:32:36.190
Let's do, And I'm gonna have to zoom out,
I cannot see everything at once here.

596
00:32:36.190 --> 00:32:39.539
All right, here is a list of all the
possible permissions that I can assign.

597
00:32:43.596 --> 00:32:44.660
Still going.

598
00:32:44.660 --> 00:32:46.045
>> Yeah,
that's definitely gonna keep me busy.

599
00:32:46.045 --> 00:32:47.120
[LAUGH]
>> Right,

600
00:32:47.120 --> 00:32:49.030
I don't want to do all that manually.

601
00:32:49.030 --> 00:32:52.780
That's crazy, that's where
the Delegation Wizard comes into play.

602
00:32:52.780 --> 00:32:55.320
Microsoft has given us a wizard
that we can use to assign

603
00:32:55.320 --> 00:32:58.380
permissions in Active Directory and
simplify the process.

604
00:32:58.380 --> 00:33:00.660
So, again,
let's make a group called Helpdesk.

605
00:33:00.660 --> 00:33:06.070
So I'll go to Groups >
New Groups > Helpdesk,

606
00:33:06.070 --> 00:33:08.865
and I'll make it a global security group,
and I'll click OK.

607
00:33:08.865 --> 00:33:12.831
Right, and then I would put all
my helpdesk users in that group.

608
00:33:12.831 --> 00:33:16.720
And I want them to be able to reset
passwords for the salespeople.

609
00:33:16.720 --> 00:33:18.680
So I can right-click on that Sales and

610
00:33:18.680 --> 00:33:24.730
I can choose Delegate Control and
that launches my Delegation Wizard.

611
00:33:24.730 --> 00:33:29.040
I simply click Next and it says, well,
who are you trying to delegate to?

612
00:33:29.040 --> 00:33:32.530
And I click Add and
I find my Helpdesk group.

613
00:33:34.800 --> 00:33:36.910
All right, oops, and
I don't wanna add anybody else, mis-click.

614
00:33:36.910 --> 00:33:41.470
And it's like, great, now it knows who I
wanna give permission to and I click Next.

615
00:33:41.470 --> 00:33:43.060
What do you want to delegate?

616
00:33:43.060 --> 00:33:45.660
I want to be able to reset user passwords.

617
00:33:45.660 --> 00:33:48.608
There's a list of about 12 or
13 common tasks,

618
00:33:48.608 --> 00:33:51.913
you can also go to create
a custom task which is very cool.

619
00:33:51.913 --> 00:33:55.790
I'm gonna just use the one since
there's a common task already set for

620
00:33:55.790 --> 00:33:59.483
exactly what I need to do,
I'll just use that, Reset passwords.

621
00:33:59.483 --> 00:34:04.060
I'll click Next and Finish,
and it was that easy.

622
00:34:04.060 --> 00:34:07.790
A lot easier than going through that list
of about 50 different permissions and

623
00:34:07.790 --> 00:34:10.200
trying to figure out which one's which,
right?

624
00:34:10.200 --> 00:34:16.270
And now the Helpdesk can reset
passwords for accounts in the sales OU.

625
00:34:16.270 --> 00:34:19.922
Here's a very important thing to keep
in mind about the Delegation Wizard.

626
00:34:19.922 --> 00:34:24.250
I right-clicked on the Sales OU and
delegated those permissions.

627
00:34:24.250 --> 00:34:30.020
So now they can reset passwords for user
accounts in the OU but not in Marketing.

628
00:34:30.020 --> 00:34:34.143
Not anywhere else, right, because I
specifically said only the Sales OU.

629
00:34:34.143 --> 00:34:38.460
Now if I had gone up to the Employees OU
that contains the Marketing and

630
00:34:38.460 --> 00:34:41.289
Sales OU, and delegated permission there,

631
00:34:41.289 --> 00:34:45.300
then those permissions would
inherit just like NTFS does.

632
00:34:45.300 --> 00:34:49.298
And they'd be able to reset both
Marketing and Sales users passwords.

633
00:34:49.298 --> 00:34:52.583
So you can get very, very,
you can fully customize or

634
00:34:52.583 --> 00:34:55.584
you can get very creative
with your delegation.

635
00:34:55.584 --> 00:34:59.510
Again, it goes back to setting up the OUs
properly in the first place, right?

636
00:34:59.510 --> 00:35:03.540
If I hadn't created those OUs,
if all employees were in one big fat OU,

637
00:35:03.540 --> 00:35:08.300
how could I delegate permission to
reset Sales users passwords, but

638
00:35:08.300 --> 00:35:09.860
not Marketing passwords?

639
00:35:09.860 --> 00:35:11.290
It wouldn't work, right?

640
00:35:11.290 --> 00:35:13.820
So it falls back to that
creating those OUs and

641
00:35:13.820 --> 00:35:18.460
structuring it in a way that's gonna
help me manage our Active Directory.

642
00:35:18.460 --> 00:35:22.270
So that's delegation,
I will leave you with one thought,

643
00:35:22.270 --> 00:35:25.761
always delegate to groups, never
delegate to individual users, all right?

644
00:35:27.140 --> 00:35:29.290
We just talked about group strategy.

645
00:35:29.290 --> 00:35:32.413
In this case I didn't delegate
to a domain local group,

646
00:35:32.413 --> 00:35:34.546
technically I probably should've.

647
00:35:34.546 --> 00:35:38.290
But I don't want you delegating
to an individual user.

648
00:35:38.290 --> 00:35:42.320
Cuz let's say I delegated to
Wes Bryan directly, his user account.

649
00:35:42.320 --> 00:35:44.010
If I ever wanna undo those permissions,

650
00:35:44.010 --> 00:35:46.470
Wes doesn't need to do that anymore,
I've gotta go in and

651
00:35:46.470 --> 00:35:50.270
manually uncheck all those permissions
from all those different places.

652
00:35:50.270 --> 00:35:54.220
And I don't even sure which ones the
wizard set, much less can I go back and

653
00:35:54.220 --> 00:35:55.410
undo them.

654
00:35:55.410 --> 00:35:58.663
If I delegate to a group instead
of directly to Wes's account, and

655
00:35:58.663 --> 00:36:02.670
I put Wes's account in that group,
well, Wes gets the permissions.

656
00:36:02.670 --> 00:36:04.730
If Wes doesn't need
the permissions anymore,

657
00:36:04.730 --> 00:36:08.380
I simply pull him out of the group,
now he doesn't have those permissions.

658
00:36:08.380 --> 00:36:09.950
I don't have to worry about undelegating,

659
00:36:09.950 --> 00:36:13.330
I can leave the group empty if
nobody needs those permissions.

660
00:36:13.330 --> 00:36:16.600
If next week we hire somebody
that needs those permissions,

661
00:36:16.600 --> 00:36:18.960
I just put them back in the group
it's already been delegated to.

662
00:36:18.960 --> 00:36:22.732
So always delegate to a group, never
delegate to an individual user account.

663
00:36:22.732 --> 00:36:27.740
And that, my friends, I think wraps
up Active Directory and permissions.

664
00:36:27.740 --> 00:36:30.859
>> Well it's been a journey [LAUGH] but
it's a road well covered.

665
00:36:30.859 --> 00:36:33.950
So Mike, we do appreciate you being here.

666
00:36:33.950 --> 00:36:35.720
Now I know that we're coming to the end,
and

667
00:36:35.720 --> 00:36:37.810
I know you did have a final
word that you said.

668
00:36:37.810 --> 00:36:40.910
But before we sign out on this episode,
any other

669
00:36:40.910 --> 00:36:44.670
maybe words of wisdom you might like to
impart to our viewers before we sign off?

670
00:36:44.670 --> 00:36:47.140
>> I can't think of any
off the top of my head.

671
00:36:47.140 --> 00:36:52.224
The biggest thing that I would recommend
is follow that group strategy, AGDLP.

672
00:36:52.224 --> 00:36:55.563
It seems like an extra step in the
beginning but over time you'll learn to

673
00:36:55.563 --> 00:37:00.080
appreciate it and you'll be like gosh, I'm
glad we followed that from the beginning.

674
00:37:00.080 --> 00:37:02.850
And never assign permissions,
NTFS permissions,

675
00:37:02.850 --> 00:37:06.150
registry permissions, delegating
permissions in Active Directory,

676
00:37:06.150 --> 00:37:08.020
never do that to
an individual user account.

677
00:37:08.020 --> 00:37:12.868
Always do it to a group, that way I can
control who has those permissions just by

678
00:37:12.868 --> 00:37:17.367
changing group membership,
not by modifying the access control list.

679
00:37:17.367 --> 00:37:21.250
Cuz one of the things I didn't mention,
when we were showing you that drawing.

680
00:37:21.250 --> 00:37:25.040
And we were putting these Sales users into
the global group and then into the domain

681
00:37:25.040 --> 00:37:30.065
local group, and then giving that
permissions, is it was just one resource.

682
00:37:30.065 --> 00:37:33.900
There's hundreds and thousands of
resources they need access to, right.

683
00:37:33.900 --> 00:37:36.790
So I can put that global group in all
these different domain local groups,

684
00:37:36.790 --> 00:37:38.212
it's gonna make your life a lot easier.

685
00:37:38.212 --> 00:37:42.120
One other thing that I just though of,
Wes, I just keep going and

686
00:37:42.120 --> 00:37:43.090
going and going.

687
00:37:44.380 --> 00:37:48.006
Universal groups are a little
bit different than other groups.

688
00:37:48.006 --> 00:37:51.440
And it was talked about in a couple of
the reference materials for this exam.

689
00:37:51.440 --> 00:37:53.970
So let me make sure I mention this.

690
00:37:53.970 --> 00:37:57.059
Global groups, domain local groups, all
stored in the Active Directory database.

691
00:37:58.130 --> 00:38:02.830
Universal groups are actually stored in
something known as the global catalog.

692
00:38:02.830 --> 00:38:07.140
And this is because, remember,
universal groups are used between domains.

693
00:38:07.140 --> 00:38:10.510
So domain controllers
from different domains

694
00:38:10.510 --> 00:38:13.510
need to be able to access the group
membership of universal groups.

695
00:38:13.510 --> 00:38:16.000
So it's actually stored outside
of the Active Directory database.

696
00:38:16.000 --> 00:38:18.841
It's stored on something known
as a global catalog server and

697
00:38:18.841 --> 00:38:21.969
that replicates to all the domain
controllers and all the domains.

698
00:38:21.969 --> 00:38:25.807
Way more than we need to know but
the point of this is,

699
00:38:25.807 --> 00:38:29.474
when you change membership
of a universal group,

700
00:38:29.474 --> 00:38:34.560
that will trigger replication
between the global catalog servers.

701
00:38:34.560 --> 00:38:37.747
And that can be a lot of replication
traffic on your network,

702
00:38:37.747 --> 00:38:40.622
especially if you have
multiple physical locations,

703
00:38:40.622 --> 00:38:44.970
replication going across the WAN
link which slows everything down.

704
00:38:44.970 --> 00:38:50.310
If I follow group strategy and I only
put global groups in universal groups,

705
00:38:51.570 --> 00:38:54.800
then rarely will my universal
group members have change.

706
00:38:54.800 --> 00:38:57.531
Because if I hire new people,
I'm adding them to the global group.

707
00:38:57.531 --> 00:38:59.606
The global group's already
in the universal group,

708
00:38:59.606 --> 00:39:01.370
I didn't change anything there.

709
00:39:01.370 --> 00:39:06.250
So by adding and removing members from the
global group, technically I'm not changing

710
00:39:06.250 --> 00:39:11.090
the universal group membership and I'm
not triggering forest-wide replication.

711
00:39:11.090 --> 00:39:13.760
If I put users directly
in the universal group,

712
00:39:13.760 --> 00:39:17.901
every time I change that I'm
triggering forest-wide replication, and

713
00:39:17.901 --> 00:39:20.390
your network is not gonna be happy for
that.

714
00:39:20.390 --> 00:39:23.810
So just follow the strategy and

715
00:39:23.810 --> 00:39:27.560
try to limit your universal group
membership to global groups only.

716
00:39:27.560 --> 00:39:30.155
>> Mike,
we appreciate you being here as always and

717
00:39:30.155 --> 00:39:31.937
we do appreciate you the viewer.

718
00:39:31.937 --> 00:39:34.560
But it does look like we're gonna
go ahead and wrap this one up.

719
00:39:34.560 --> 00:39:37.780
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

720
00:39:37.780 --> 00:39:39.400
>> And I'm the talk forever Mike Rodrick.

721
00:39:39.400 --> 00:39:40.432
>> And [LAUGH] we'll see you next time.

722
00:39:40.432 --> 00:39:48.242
[MUSIC]

723
00:39:48.242 --> 00:39:49.860
Thank you for watching ITProvTV.

7

You've made that intelligent

9

10

I'm your host, Zach Memos, as we continue
on with MTA Security Fundamentals.

11
00:00:23.881 --> 00:00:27.001
And we're going to be looking at
password policies today, aren't we?

12
00:00:27.001 --> 00:00:29.920
With the person who truly is our expert,
Mike Rodrick.

13
00:00:29.920 --> 00:00:30.460
Hey Mike.

14
00:00:30.460 --> 00:00:31.590
>> Hey how's it going Zach?

15
00:00:31.590 --> 00:00:36.210
Glad to be back here and yeah, password
policies are the topic of the day.

16
00:00:36.210 --> 00:00:40.289
And we've already talked a little bit
about passwords in some previous episodes,

17
00:00:40.289 --> 00:00:42.456
so make sure you go back and
check those out.

18
00:00:42.456 --> 00:00:48.467
When we talk about password policies,
we're really talking about how can I.

19
00:00:48.467 --> 00:00:51.169
I wouldn't say force but
it really is what we're doing,

20
00:00:51.169 --> 00:00:55.320
insure might be a better way to put it,

21
00:00:55.320 --> 00:01:00.735
Insure that my users are following
our security policies, and using or

22
00:01:00.735 --> 00:01:06.695
creating strong passwords, or passwords
that are less likely to be cracked, right.

23
00:01:06.695 --> 00:01:09.935
>> So here we're steering our
users into using passwords that

24
00:01:09.935 --> 00:01:13.533
we would like them to use or we approve
of, that we think are more secure?

25
00:01:13.533 --> 00:01:14.571
>> Exactly right,

26
00:01:14.571 --> 00:01:18.425
