319
00:16:43.905 --> 00:16:45.410
>> But, there's gonna be a lot more.

320
00:16:45.410 --> 00:16:47.310
>> There's a couple that
we'll talk about here, and

321
00:16:47.310 --> 00:16:50.220
there's actually more that we don't need
to go over for this particular exam.

322
00:16:50.220 --> 00:16:53.170
Go check out a lot of our security
courses in our library and

323
00:16:53.170 --> 00:16:54.980
we'll cover these much more in depth.

324
00:16:54.980 --> 00:16:59.570
What we need to as an MTA, what we need to
understand is why am I doing these things?

325
00:16:59.570 --> 00:17:03.846
Why am I so worried about password length
and strength and account lockouts and

326
00:17:03.846 --> 00:17:04.891
things like that?

327
00:17:04.891 --> 00:17:09.358
It's because the bad guys have techniques
they can use to try to get your password

328
00:17:09.358 --> 00:17:13.824
and then log into the system as a user,
see what access they have, try to escalate

329
00:17:13.824 --> 00:17:17.503
their credentials to another account
that has even more access and

330
00:17:17.503 --> 00:17:19.760
do harm to your network and to your data.

331
00:17:20.950 --> 00:17:25.470
So, we wanna make sure that
we're implementing procedures

332
00:17:25.470 --> 00:17:28.790
to use strong passwords and
to change them every so often.

333
00:17:28.790 --> 00:17:31.070
Now, what attacks are they using?

334
00:17:31.070 --> 00:17:35.300
Well, the two most common attacks we
see against passwords are password

335
00:17:35.300 --> 00:17:39.100
dictionary attacks and
brute force attacks, right?

336
00:17:39.100 --> 00:17:41.920
Password guessing is another attack.

337
00:17:41.920 --> 00:17:44.990
They actually don't mention
it in this particular exam.

338
00:17:44.990 --> 00:17:50.690
It's really because password guessing
is kinda not as common nowadays,

339
00:17:50.690 --> 00:17:56.150
because users are slowly getting
better at creating passwords.

340
00:17:56.150 --> 00:18:00.670
And we've got policies that we can use
to enforce creating strong passwords.

341
00:18:00.670 --> 00:18:03.130
So password guessing is not
as easy as it was before.

342
00:18:03.130 --> 00:18:06.950
It used to be, I could talk to Zach for
a couple minutes, an hour,

343
00:18:06.950 --> 00:18:10.250
maybe I could go have lunch with Zach or
something and

344
00:18:10.250 --> 00:18:14.730
I learn his wife's name and his and
his kids' names, anniversaries, and

345
00:18:14.730 --> 00:18:18.530
his dog's name, and odds are that
one of those is his password, right?

346
00:18:18.530 --> 00:18:20.534
>> Well, the answer to all those is Ann.

347
00:18:20.534 --> 00:18:22.144
Ann's everything.

348
00:18:22.144 --> 00:18:23.666
>> But not so much anymore.

349
00:18:23.666 --> 00:18:27.906
People are wising up and they're not using
their birthdays as their password, or

350
00:18:27.906 --> 00:18:29.880
at least they shouldn't be.

351
00:18:29.880 --> 00:18:33.170
And so, that's why I think Microsoft
is kind of saying password guessing

352
00:18:33.170 --> 00:18:37.150
is not as common of an attack any more,
but it's definitely still a possibility.

353
00:18:37.150 --> 00:18:41.211
But dictionary attacks and
brute force attacks are used a lot.

354
00:18:41.211 --> 00:18:43.736
And we've talked about these
in the password episode, so

355
00:18:43.736 --> 00:18:46.160
I'm just gonna quickly
rehash what those were.

356
00:18:46.160 --> 00:18:50.460
Remember, a dictionary attack is
when the bad guy uses a program

357
00:18:50.460 --> 00:18:53.120
that is gonna do the password guessing for
him.

358
00:18:53.120 --> 00:18:57.260
It's got one word on each line,
that's the dictionary, and

359
00:18:57.260 --> 00:18:59.500
the program just rifles through each word.

360
00:18:59.500 --> 00:19:01.200
It says, maybe Zach's password is this.

361
00:19:01.200 --> 00:19:02.210
No?
Move on to the next one.

362
00:19:02.210 --> 00:19:04.360
And it just goes through that entire list,

363
00:19:04.360 --> 00:19:08.290
one at a time, trying to see if one
of those words is Zach's password.

364
00:19:08.290 --> 00:19:11.860
That's known as the dictionary attack and
that dictionary, again,

365
00:19:11.860 --> 00:19:15.060
is just a text file with
one word on each line.

366
00:19:15.060 --> 00:19:18.590
And, so, as a bad guy, what they do
is they build these dictionary files.

367
00:19:18.590 --> 00:19:21.952
They typically start with
somebody elses copy,

368
00:19:21.952 --> 00:19:26.690
like I've got a copy of the Webster's
Dictionary, one word on each line.

369
00:19:27.870 --> 00:19:30.630
But, then they'll add to it.

370
00:19:30.630 --> 00:19:35.890
If I'm gonna try to crack passwords at
ITProTV, I'm gonna add to my dictionary

371
00:19:35.890 --> 00:19:42.510
file some industry specific terms,
like PCI, motherboard, CPU.

372
00:19:42.510 --> 00:19:47.079
I might scour your website for
people's names and I'll put Zach and

373
00:19:47.079 --> 00:19:52.226
memos and all of that in my dictionary
file, so I can try all those, as well.

374
00:19:52.226 --> 00:19:54.754
But that's what a dictionary attack is.

375
00:19:54.754 --> 00:19:58.331
Basically, they take a text file,
one word on each line and

376
00:19:58.331 --> 00:20:00.500
they rifle through it, all right?

377
00:20:00.500 --> 00:20:06.640
Brute force attacks were when we tried
every possible combination of letter,

378
00:20:06.640 --> 00:20:08.140
number and special character.

379
00:20:08.140 --> 00:20:11.094
You're basically throwing
the kitchen sink at it, right?

380
00:20:11.094 --> 00:20:12.926
That's a brute force attack.

381
00:20:12.926 --> 00:20:16.400
It's gonna take much longer
to do a brute force attack.

382
00:20:16.400 --> 00:20:18.620
>> Sounds like that would take months,
or it could take months.

383
00:20:18.620 --> 00:20:22.070
>> It can take days, months,
years, thousands of years,

384
00:20:22.070 --> 00:20:24.620
depending on how long and
strong your password is.

385
00:20:26.060 --> 00:20:30.150
But it's also a guaranteed
way to break the password,

386
00:20:31.270 --> 00:20:34.430
but my lifespan is not 250 years.

387
00:20:34.430 --> 00:20:39.230
So if you've got a 20 character password
that includes 4 different character sets,

388
00:20:39.230 --> 00:20:42.260
I'm not gonna crack it in my
lifetime using a brute force attack

389
00:20:42.260 --> 00:20:43.920
with today's technology, right?

390
00:20:43.920 --> 00:20:48.310
That could change tomorrow as
we come out with faster CPUs and

391
00:20:48.310 --> 00:20:49.590
all of that fun stuff.

392
00:20:50.690 --> 00:20:52.080
But again, that's not so

393
00:20:52.080 --> 00:20:54.780
important as understanding
what a brute force attack is.

394
00:20:54.780 --> 00:20:57.370
Trying every possible
combination of letter, number,

395
00:20:57.370 --> 00:21:00.580
special character until
we break that password.

396
00:21:00.580 --> 00:21:04.740
So those are two of the big attack
methods that the bad guys use

397
00:21:04.740 --> 00:21:06.780
How do we protect from that?

398
00:21:06.780 --> 00:21:11.250
Well, those policies that we just looked
at, will help with the dictionary attacks,

399
00:21:11.250 --> 00:21:16.140
because they can't rifle through 2,000
words, because after 5 bad attempts,

400
00:21:16.140 --> 00:21:16.858
the account locks out.

401
00:21:16.858 --> 00:21:17.438
>> Mm-hm.

402
00:21:17.438 --> 00:21:21.376
>> Right, so we've stopped the dictionary
attack in its tracks right there.

403
00:21:21.376 --> 00:21:25.080
Brute force attacks
are typically done offline.

404
00:21:26.420 --> 00:21:31.370
But, by having strong passwords,
by making those passwords long and

405
00:21:31.370 --> 00:21:35.360
complex, we can make it to
where it's not feasible for

406
00:21:35.360 --> 00:21:38.750
the bad guys to a do a brute
force attack on the password.

407
00:21:38.750 --> 00:21:40.871
It's just gonna take too long, right?

408
00:21:40.871 --> 00:21:42.520
And that's the idea.

409
00:21:42.520 --> 00:21:48.550
Our passwords need to be strong
enough to withstand these attacks for

410
00:21:48.550 --> 00:21:50.362
only a short amount of time.

411
00:21:50.362 --> 00:21:53.000
If you're changing your
password every 30 days,

412
00:21:53.000 --> 00:21:56.320
then your password doesn't
have to last 200 years.

413
00:21:56.320 --> 00:21:58.380
It needs to last 31 days.

414
00:21:58.380 --> 00:22:01.910
So if it takes them more than
30 days to crack your password,

415
00:22:01.910 --> 00:22:04.550
you've already changed it to something
else by the time they do crack it.

416
00:22:04.550 --> 00:22:06.360
Does that make sense, right?

417
00:22:06.360 --> 00:22:09.690
So that's all we're trying to do with
these policies is make sure that our

418
00:22:09.690 --> 00:22:14.530
passwords are long enough and
strong enough to withstand attack for

419
00:22:14.530 --> 00:22:18.740
whatever period we're choosing that
we have to change those passwords.

420
00:22:18.740 --> 00:22:20.090
And it's no guarantee.

421
00:22:20.090 --> 00:22:22.760
Keep in mind this is not an exact science.

422
00:22:22.760 --> 00:22:24.638
When I say do a brute force attack, and

423
00:22:24.638 --> 00:22:28.890
I'm gonna go through every single possible
letter, number and special character.

424
00:22:28.890 --> 00:22:29.981
I might get lucky.

425
00:22:29.981 --> 00:22:33.360
I might hit it on the second try,
just out of sheer luck, right?

426
00:22:33.360 --> 00:22:38.242
I mean, it's like the lottery, the odds
are completely against you, but there's

427
00:22:38.242 --> 00:22:43.200
nothing that says the very last one I
try is gonna be your password, right?

428
00:22:43.200 --> 00:22:46.000
I might get lucky and
get it on the second try.

429
00:22:46.000 --> 00:22:47.440
So none of these are foolproof and

430
00:22:47.440 --> 00:22:50.610
none of these are guaranteed
to protect your passwords.

431
00:22:50.610 --> 00:22:55.510
But all of this used together will
make it much more difficult for

432
00:22:55.510 --> 00:22:57.680
the bad guy, all right?

433
00:22:57.680 --> 00:23:02.400
The last thing I wanna talk about here is
protecting domain user account passwords.

434
00:23:02.400 --> 00:23:06.050
And really when we talk about that,
Windows does that for us.

435
00:23:06.050 --> 00:23:09.600
As I said, when you store
a password in active directory,

436
00:23:09.600 --> 00:23:13.820
it's run through a hashing algorithm and
that hash value is what gets stored.

437
00:23:13.820 --> 00:23:16.710
The output of that is stored,
not your actual password.

438
00:23:17.960 --> 00:23:21.985
So that's one way that we protect them, by
using a good strong authentication method.

439
00:23:21.985 --> 00:23:28.880
Like FTP, File Transfer Protocol,
is still used today for

440
00:23:28.880 --> 00:23:33.420
transferring files around, but
it used passwords that were in plain text.

441
00:23:33.420 --> 00:23:36.120
In other words,
it didn't bother encrypting the passwords.

442
00:23:36.120 --> 00:23:41.520
So if the bad guy was watching what went
across the network with certain programs,

443
00:23:41.520 --> 00:23:44.630
called sniffers,
they could see your password go by.

444
00:23:44.630 --> 00:23:47.833
And it wasn't encrypted at all, so
they could just get your password and

445
00:23:47.833 --> 00:23:49.473
now they could log on as you, right?

446
00:23:49.473 --> 00:23:53.003
So the first thing as far as protecting
domain accounts, or any accounts for

447
00:23:53.003 --> 00:23:55.320
that matter,
is making sure we're using a good,

448
00:23:55.320 --> 00:23:57.804
strong authentication
protocol in the first place,

449
00:23:57.804 --> 00:24:01.308
one that encrypts those passwords and
stores them in an encrypted format.

450
00:24:01.308 --> 00:24:03.014
The other one is user education.

451
00:24:03.014 --> 00:24:06.900
Making sure that my users know how
to protect their own password.

452
00:24:06.900 --> 00:24:10.320
Not, if somebody's watching them,
say, excuse me.

453
00:24:10.320 --> 00:24:15.500
Or how many of you guys do this when you
go up to the convenience store nowadays

454
00:24:15.500 --> 00:24:21.180
and they mount these darn card
readers like up on a pole right here.

455
00:24:21.180 --> 00:24:25.180
And so I'm supposed to put my card
up here and punch in my information.

456
00:24:25.180 --> 00:24:27.760
There's people behind me that
have a clear view of this thing.

457
00:24:27.760 --> 00:24:30.550
Not a chance in heck I'm
gonna be doing that.

458
00:24:30.550 --> 00:24:32.320
Just use common sense.

459
00:24:32.320 --> 00:24:36.700
Educate your users on, look around
before you type in your password.

460
00:24:36.700 --> 00:24:39.380
We talked about looking at the back of
your computer to make sure there's no

461
00:24:39.380 --> 00:24:42.830
keystroke loggers recording
everything you've typed.

462
00:24:42.830 --> 00:24:45.868
Make sure our users understand
not to share passwords.

463
00:24:45.868 --> 00:24:50.318
Because if I give Zach my password,
Zach can now log on as me.

464
00:24:50.318 --> 00:24:54.375
And that means everything that he
does is now gonna be logged under me.

465
00:24:54.375 --> 00:24:56.039
It's gonna look like I did it.

466
00:24:56.039 --> 00:24:58.473
Zach might not have access
to the same stuff I do.

467
00:24:58.473 --> 00:25:01.924
So if he gets my password,
if I share it with him,

468
00:25:01.924 --> 00:25:06.405
then he can get access to
all the stuff that I access.

469
00:25:06.405 --> 00:25:07.365
And you know how it goes.

470
00:25:07.365 --> 00:25:11.352
If I give my password with Zach and say,
Zach, don't give this to anybody else.

471
00:25:11.352 --> 00:25:13.997
Zach's gonna says, no,
I wouldn't share your password.

472
00:25:13.997 --> 00:25:14.891
>> Well, I'd give it to Ann.

473
00:25:14.891 --> 00:25:17.051
>> Thank you for giving me your
password and trusting me with it.

474
00:25:17.051 --> 00:25:18.790
I won't share it with anybody.

475
00:25:18.790 --> 00:25:22.200
And then Titus comes over and says,
hey Zach, how'd you get access to that?

476
00:25:22.200 --> 00:25:23.230
Mike gave me his password.

477
00:25:23.230 --> 00:25:25.317
Here you go.
Don't tell him I gave it to you, right?

478
00:25:25.317 --> 00:25:28.280
And before long,
the entire building has my password.

479
00:25:28.280 --> 00:25:30.730
>> Yeah, don't share passwords.

480
00:25:30.730 --> 00:25:32.480
That is a bad, bad, bad thing.

481
00:25:32.480 --> 00:25:35.650
>> I was even gonna ask you,
do people even still use keyloggers?

482
00:25:35.650 --> 00:25:38.755
I mean that's-
>> [CROSSTALK] No, they're still there.

483
00:25:38.755 --> 00:25:40.460
Hardware based, software based.

484
00:25:40.460 --> 00:25:45.120
In fact, I was just reading an interesting
article today about Bluetooth keyboards.

485
00:25:45.120 --> 00:25:48.162
A lot of people are now going
with wireless keyboards.

486
00:25:48.162 --> 00:25:48.721
>> Certainly.

487
00:25:48.721 --> 00:25:53.371
>> Which is very convenient, but
there's also wireless packet sniffers,

488
00:25:53.371 --> 00:25:57.580
which means I could be sitting ten feet or
fifty feet away from you.

489
00:25:58.700 --> 00:26:01.539
Probably not that far,
it is Bluetooth, so it's short range.

490
00:26:01.539 --> 00:26:05.017
But I could put something in place
that could sniff those packets.

491
00:26:05.017 --> 00:26:09.901
And so basically I'm intercepting your
wireless keystrokes that are going to

492
00:26:09.901 --> 00:26:11.690
your computer.

493
00:26:11.690 --> 00:26:13.460
So yeah, definitely still is use.

494
00:26:13.460 --> 00:26:15.300
Yeah, you gotta look for
those kind of things.

495
00:26:15.300 --> 00:26:17.740
Gotta pay attention to your environment.

496
00:26:17.740 --> 00:26:19.850
Something's changed and
you didn't change it,

497
00:26:19.850 --> 00:26:23.560
a new piece of hardware is
attached to your computer.

498
00:26:23.560 --> 00:26:27.219
Something looks different,
ask somebody, right?

499
00:26:27.219 --> 00:26:31.609
Our help desk, your help desk would much
rather you come to them and ask them, hey,

500
00:26:31.609 --> 00:26:34.680
is this supposed to be hanging
out at my computer, than for

501
00:26:34.680 --> 00:26:37.401
you to ignore it because
you're too embarrassed.

502
00:26:37.401 --> 00:26:41.544
And your computer gets compromised and
they have to shut the network down to try

503
00:26:41.544 --> 00:26:44.330
to find the malware and
get rid of it, right?

504
00:26:44.330 --> 00:26:45.220
Don't be embarrassed.

505
00:26:45.220 --> 00:26:48.310
I know sometimes IT people
can be intimidating.

506
00:26:48.310 --> 00:26:53.632
But you gotta teach your user, we, as IT
people, you guys out there watching me,

507
00:26:53.632 --> 00:26:57.337
we have to make sure that we
understand that end-users,

508
00:26:57.337 --> 00:27:01.760
they don't wanna know how the computer
works and all of that stuff.

509
00:27:01.760 --> 00:27:03.790
Otherwise they'd get into IT, right?

510
00:27:03.790 --> 00:27:05.440
It's like when you take
your car to the mechanic,

511
00:27:05.440 --> 00:27:07.690
you don't want the mechanic telling you
don't want the mechanic telling you

512
00:27:07.690 --> 00:27:10.100
the nitty gritty details of
what's going on inside there.

513
00:27:10.100 --> 00:27:14.290
Just fix it so that when I put my key in,
I can get to work, right?

514
00:27:14.290 --> 00:27:16.421
And that's the same thing our
end-user's doing with their computer.

515
00:27:16.421 --> 00:27:21.189
So be nice and make sure that they feel
comfortable coming to you saying, hey,

516
00:27:21.189 --> 00:27:24.530
I didn't recognize this or
this is a new mouse.

517
00:27:24.530 --> 00:27:25.507
Did you give this to me?

518
00:27:25.507 --> 00:27:29.604
Because as a bad guy, what easier way to
get a keystroke logger installed than to

519
00:27:29.604 --> 00:27:32.860
just swap keyboards with one
that's built into it, right?

520
00:27:32.860 --> 00:27:37.550
And if you're an end-user and they
look at it and go, well, I don't know,

521
00:27:37.550 --> 00:27:39.110
I'll just use it anyway, right?

522
00:27:39.110 --> 00:27:43.400
We wanna make sure that we
convey to our end-users

523
00:27:43.400 --> 00:27:46.760
that we want them to communicate with
us and we want them to ask questions.

524
00:27:46.760 --> 00:27:49.696
So anyway, when it comes to protecting
domain user account passwords,

525
00:27:49.696 --> 00:27:51.150
those are the things that we can do.

526
00:27:51.150 --> 00:27:53.942
One, making sure that
we're encrypting them and

527
00:27:53.942 --> 00:27:58.570
not using that reversible encryption
option unless we absolutely have to.

528
00:27:58.570 --> 00:28:00.755
Wanna make sure we educate our users,

529
00:28:00.755 --> 00:28:05.547
use our policies to ensure that they
are using strong, complex, long passwords.

530
00:28:05.547 --> 00:28:08.611
And make sure they understand
the dangers of writing them down and

531
00:28:08.611 --> 00:28:10.540
then sharing those passwords.

532
00:28:10.540 --> 00:28:11.464
>> Awesome information as usual, Mike.

533
00:28:11.464 --> 00:28:15.830
And it's practical information and
stuff we need to know and need to use.

534
00:28:15.830 --> 00:28:17.931
But more importantly,
for the exam as well,

535
00:28:17.931 --> 00:28:20.102
there's a lot of answers
to those questions.

536
00:28:20.102 --> 00:28:23.839
Password policies that you're watching,
MTA security fundamentals.

537
00:28:23.839 --> 00:28:28.499
There's more in this series and you're
lucky because you're involved with ITProTV

538
00:28:28.499 --> 00:28:30.450
and you got access to that library.

00:28:30.450 --> 00:28:31.530
Lucky you.

540
00:28:31.530 --> 00:28:32.540
I'm Zach Memos.

00:28:32.540 --> 00:28:33.440
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

Go ahead and use it,
it's a great technology to have,

great features to have.

689

Mike, it does look like we're coming

pay attention to your regulations.

A lot of that will dictate

Don't over audit.

Right?

and you aren't using up

13

14

And here at our MTA it's always important

16

Don't worry, we're not gonna be breaking
out any mathematical formulas and

17

breaking these encryption
algorithms down for you.

18
00:00:45.616 --> 00:00:48.421
Here we just wanna understand
some basic concepts so

19
00:00:48.421 --> 00:00:51.863
that we can make good decisions
when talking about encryption or

20

choosing encryption,
figuring out which ones we wanna use.

21
00:00:55.192 --> 00:00:55.700
>> Well, fundamentals.

22
00:00:55.700 --> 00:00:56.840
Security fundamentals, right?

23
00:00:56.840 --> 00:00:57.748
>> That's exactly right.

24
00:00:57.748 --> 00:01:00.120
>> We need to begin by talking
about better security algorithms.

25
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:01.477
>> Yeah, let's talk about these guys.

26
00:01:01.477 --> 00:01:03.980
So when we talk about
encryption algorithms.

27
00:01:03.980 --> 00:01:07.676
We really can classify them in three
different groups if you will, or

28
00:01:07.676 --> 00:01:08.770
classifications.

29
00:01:08.770 --> 00:01:11.554
There's symmetric encryption algorithms,

30
00:01:11.554 --> 00:01:16.622
there's asymmetric encryption algorithms,
and there's hashing algorithms.

31
00:01:16.622 --> 00:01:19.560
And it's important we understand
the differences and the strengths and

32
00:01:19.560 --> 00:01:23.480
weaknesses of those three classes
of encryption algorithms.

33
00:01:23.480 --> 00:01:24.920
So let's just break it down.

34
00:01:24.920 --> 00:01:28.040
When we talk about symmetric
encryption algorithms.

35
00:01:28.040 --> 00:01:33.008
This is also known as
private key cryptography or

36
00:01:33.008 --> 00:01:35.800
single key cryptography.

37
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:37.571
But I like to refer to it as symmetric and

38
00:01:37.571 --> 00:01:40.540
what that means when we
talk about symmetric.

39
00:01:40.540 --> 00:01:43.724
There's a single key that's being used.

40
00:01:43.724 --> 00:01:47.402
And this key is used to encrypt and
decrypt the traffic.

41
00:01:47.402 --> 00:01:50.904
Now, before we go any further, let's
take a step back and talk about the key

42
00:01:50.904 --> 00:01:54.606
itself because that's something I think
a lot of people have a little trouble.

43
00:01:54.606 --> 00:01:55.790
What the heck is this key?

44
00:01:55.790 --> 00:02:00.620
There's no physical key like I put on
my front door to unlock this file.

45
00:02:00.620 --> 00:02:01.400
So what do you mean by a key?

46
00:02:01.400 --> 00:02:03.290
>> It's like a code, yeah?

47
00:02:03.290 --> 00:02:04.746
>> It is it's very similar to that,

48
00:02:04.746 --> 00:02:07.398
when we look at these encryption
algorithms there's only so

49
00:02:07.398 --> 00:02:10.790
many encryption algorithms out there and
we all typically use the same ones.

50
00:02:10.790 --> 00:02:15.175
Like a program is hard coded to use
a particular algorithm and you might think

51
00:02:15.175 --> 00:02:19.423
well wait a second, if we're all
using the same encryption algorithms,

52
00:02:19.423 --> 00:02:24.515
if I can encrypt something, what's to
keep you then from decrypting it, right?

53
00:02:24.515 --> 00:02:29.663
If you think back to some of those
simple things we did when we were kid,

54
00:02:29.663 --> 00:02:34.114
the little decipher rings
an a becomes an n, a b becomes an o,

55
00:02:34.114 --> 00:02:38.160
c becomes a p,
that's a very simple shift algorithm.

56
00:02:38.160 --> 00:02:40.687
It's like a Caesar cipher type thing and

57
00:02:40.687 --> 00:02:45.815
if you know if I tell you that I'm gonna
shift everything three letters, right and

58
00:02:45.815 --> 00:02:50.740
I hand you encrypted text you could then
shift everything back three letters.

59
00:02:50.740 --> 00:02:53.610
And you will get the original back out,
right?

60
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:56.854
Well, what a key does, so in other words,
we wouldn't be able to show or

61
00:02:56.854 --> 00:03:00.758
use that same algorithm, cuz I'll be able
to decrypting anything you had encrypted.

62
00:03:00.758 --> 00:03:05.382
What a key does is a key ends up
making the algorithm unique to you.

63
00:03:05.382 --> 00:03:08.843
So let's say we are using an algorithm
that shifts everything three

64
00:03:08.843 --> 00:03:09.760
letter, right?

65
00:03:09.760 --> 00:03:10.290
Three letters up.

66
00:03:11.490 --> 00:03:14.745
But then on top of that
you're gonna have a key.

67
00:03:14.745 --> 00:03:19.610
Your key might be plus four so
if you're using an algorithm

68
00:03:19.610 --> 00:03:24.180
that's shift everything three but
your key is plus four,

69
00:03:24.180 --> 00:03:28.230
you're gonna end up shifting everything
seven but my key's different.

70
00:03:28.230 --> 00:03:30.110
My key is negative two.

71
00:03:30.110 --> 00:03:35.500
So instead of shifting everything three,
I'm actually only shifting one, right?

72
00:03:35.500 --> 00:03:38.130
Now we'll end up, we'll both end
up being able to encrypt text, but

73
00:03:38.130 --> 00:03:40.210
if you don't know what key I used.

74
00:03:40.210 --> 00:03:41.316
You know the algorithm.

75
00:03:41.316 --> 00:03:43.582
You know it was plus three.

76
00:03:43.582 --> 00:03:45.370
But what key did I use along with it,
right?

77
00:03:45.370 --> 00:03:48.280
You don't know if it was plus three
plus seven, plus three minus two.

78
00:03:48.280 --> 00:03:50.985
You could use any number of keys in there,
so

79
00:03:50.985 --> 00:03:56.196
that's a very simplistic way of looking at
it, but I think it gets the point across.

80
00:03:56.196 --> 00:04:00.629
A key is used in conjunction with
the algorithm to make it unique to

81
00:04:00.629 --> 00:04:05.466
your usage so that we can all use
the same encryption and algorithm, but

82
00:04:05.466 --> 00:04:09.598
I can't decrypt your stuff and
you can't decrypt my stuff.

83
00:04:09.598 --> 00:04:13.500
Because the key I used remains secret,
and you don't know what that key is.

84
00:04:13.500 --> 00:04:15.150
You know the algorithm I used, but

85
00:04:15.150 --> 00:04:17.880
you don't know what key I plugged into it,
right?

86
00:04:17.880 --> 00:04:19.720
And we've talked a little
bit about this before.

87
00:04:19.720 --> 00:04:24.650
I think, in previous episode we talked
about how short keys make a weak

88
00:04:24.650 --> 00:04:30.670
algorithm, because let's say there's only
two possible keys, plus four or minus two.

89
00:04:30.670 --> 00:04:32.340
Well, you don't know which one I used but

90
00:04:32.340 --> 00:04:34.120
how long would it take
you to try both right?

91
00:04:34.120 --> 00:04:36.074
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean and you're done,

92
00:04:36.074 --> 00:04:39.465
you've decrypted my stuff because,
let me try plus seven or plus one,

93
00:04:39.465 --> 00:04:42.950
it's gotta be one of those two,
there's only two possible keys.

94
00:04:42.950 --> 00:04:47.360
But if I had a thousand keys,
now try to decrypt my information.

95
00:04:47.360 --> 00:04:49.821
You're gonna have to
try all 1,000 keys and

96
00:04:49.821 --> 00:04:51.990
it's gonna take you a lot longer, right?

97
00:04:51.990 --> 00:04:55.780
And when we talk about keys and
encryption, we're talking about

98
00:04:55.780 --> 00:04:59.820
hundreds of thousands and millions and
billions of possible keys.

99
00:04:59.820 --> 00:05:02.440
Which means the computer just
takes too long to try to go

100
00:05:02.440 --> 00:05:04.640
through all those possibilities.

101
00:05:04.640 --> 00:05:07.760
So with symmetric, now that we
get an understand what a key is.

102
00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:13.162
A key is use in conjunction with
an algorithm to make it unique for you.

103
00:05:13.162 --> 00:05:15.086
Symmetric there is a single key,

104
00:05:15.086 --> 00:05:18.822
what that means is I'm gonna take
my data that I want to encrypt.

105
00:05:18.822 --> 00:05:23.560
I'm gonna take my encryption algorithm and
my key and I am going to

106
00:05:23.560 --> 00:05:27.400
plug the key into my encryption algorithm,
I'm gonna run the data through it,

107
00:05:27.400 --> 00:05:31.410
on the way in, it's known as plaintext,
it's human readable, right?

108
00:05:31.410 --> 00:05:34.142
I run it through that algorithm
along with the key and

109
00:05:34.142 --> 00:05:37.510
what comes out the back side of
the algorithm is encrypted data.

110
00:05:37.510 --> 00:05:39.810
This is known as ciphertext.

111
00:05:39.810 --> 00:05:44.156
So we take plaintext, human readable
information, we run it through

112
00:05:44.156 --> 00:05:48.660
the encryption algorithm along with
a key and the output is ciphertext.

113
00:05:48.660 --> 00:05:51.890
Now I'm gonna send that ciphertext
over to Zach cuz it's encrypted,

114
00:05:51.890 --> 00:05:55.410
no one else can intercept it or they can
intercept it but they can't read it.

115
00:05:55.410 --> 00:05:57.992
Now Zach has this encrypted data and

116
00:05:57.992 --> 00:06:03.516
he knows what algorithm I used to do
the encryption, he wants to decrypt it.

117
00:06:03.516 --> 00:06:07.450
What he needs is the key that I used
to encrypt it in the first place.

118
00:06:08.650 --> 00:06:09.870
Does that make sense?

119
00:06:09.870 --> 00:06:15.648
Symmetric means the same key is used to
do the encryption and the decryption.

120
00:06:15.648 --> 00:06:19.382
So I take the key that I used to
encrypted it, and I give it to Zach.

121
00:06:19.382 --> 00:06:23.591
And now Zach can take the algorithm,
and the key, and that cypher text,

122
00:06:23.591 --> 00:06:27.386
run it through the algorithm,
in combination with they key, and

123
00:06:27.386 --> 00:06:30.980
out comes plaintext,
the original message all right.

124
00:06:30.980 --> 00:06:36.230
That is symmetric key cryptography,
or private key cryptography.

125
00:06:36.230 --> 00:06:38.708
Same key does the encryption and
the decryption.

126
00:06:38.708 --> 00:06:42.180
Now let's talk about pros and
cons of symmetric encryption.

127
00:06:42.180 --> 00:06:43.010
It's very fast.

128
00:06:43.010 --> 00:06:44.570
It's very what we call lightweight.

129
00:06:44.570 --> 00:06:47.440
It doesn't take a lot of
processing power to perform.

130
00:06:47.440 --> 00:06:51.410
So computers can do this type
of encryption really quickly.

131
00:06:51.410 --> 00:06:54.530
It's good to use when you've
got a lot of data to encrypt.

132
00:06:54.530 --> 00:06:58.388
Symmetric encryption is almost
always the way we wanna go.

133
00:06:58.388 --> 00:07:03.230
The downside of symmetric encryption is
that single key because here's the thing.

134
00:07:03.230 --> 00:07:09.190
I'm gonna take that key, plug it into
the algorithm and encrypt my date.

135
00:07:09.190 --> 00:07:11.900
Then I'm going to send that
encrypted data over to Zach.

136
00:07:11.900 --> 00:07:14.190
What does Zach need to decrypt it?

137
00:07:14.190 --> 00:07:19.130
He needs the key I used to encrypt it,
so I'm gonna send the key over to Zach.

138
00:07:19.130 --> 00:07:23.157
Now if a bad guy intercepted the data,
it's not that big of a deal because

139
00:07:23.157 --> 00:07:27.646
he doesn't have the key to decrypt it, but
now I gotta send the key to Zack because

140
00:07:27.646 --> 00:07:30.174
he needs this because
he needs to decrypt it.

141
00:07:30.174 --> 00:07:34.811
If the bad guy was able to intercept
my data good chance he's also able to

142
00:07:34.811 --> 00:07:36.140
intercept the key.

143
00:07:36.140 --> 00:07:38.590
And can the bad guy now
decrypt my information?

144
00:07:38.590 --> 00:07:39.970
>> I would think he can do that.

145
00:07:39.970 --> 00:07:43.362
>> Yes, because he has the cipher text and
he has the key that's all he needs.

146
00:07:43.362 --> 00:07:46.390
And so now the bad guy can
decrypt the information as well.

147
00:07:46.390 --> 00:07:50.940
So the issue is symmetric encryption
algorithms is key distribution.

148
00:07:50.940 --> 00:07:53.540
How do I get the key
that I used to encrypt it

149
00:07:53.540 --> 00:07:57.400
to the other side where they
need to decrypt it securely?

150
00:07:57.400 --> 00:08:00.214
And that's a real problem
we deal with in networks.

151
00:08:00.214 --> 00:08:04.556
It's either you use out of band methods
like I might send the encrypted

152
00:08:04.556 --> 00:08:06.780
information to MVAE email.

153
00:08:06.780 --> 00:08:10.490
But I'm gonna call him and
give him the key needed to decrypt it.

154
00:08:10.490 --> 00:08:14.240
That way, the bad guy hopefully doesn't
have access to both, my email and

155
00:08:14.240 --> 00:08:15.310
my phone system.

156
00:08:15.310 --> 00:08:19.020
Yeah, but that's a pain, I might write
it down and walk it over to his office.

157
00:08:19.020 --> 00:08:21.827
By the time I do that, I could've
just brought the message to him and

158
00:08:21.827 --> 00:08:24.250
not transmitted on the network anyway,
right?

159
00:08:24.250 --> 00:08:28.000
So, symmetric encryptions have an issue,
and that is key distributions.

160
00:08:28.000 --> 00:08:30.180
Somehow I have to get the key needed,

161
00:08:30.180 --> 00:08:34.840
to do the decryption securely
to the other end all right.

162
00:08:34.840 --> 00:08:39.160
Other category is known as asymmetric
encryption, let me back up.

163
00:08:39.160 --> 00:08:42.330
We call that method symmetric encryption,

164
00:08:42.330 --> 00:08:46.150
also private key because the key
needs to remain private.

165
00:08:46.150 --> 00:08:50.120
Anybody that gets a hold of
the key can now decrypt my data.

166
00:08:50.120 --> 00:08:51.310
Because there's only one key.

167
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:53.290
It does the encryption and the decryption.

168
00:08:54.340 --> 00:08:56.362
Now asymmetric encryption.

169
00:08:56.362 --> 00:09:00.749
Asymmetric, if we think back to our
vocabulary, asymmetric is not the same on

170
00:09:00.749 --> 00:09:05.560
both sides, which is giving us
an indicator of what's gonna happen here.

171
00:09:05.560 --> 00:09:09.140
In asymmetric,
we're gonna have two keys, right?

172
00:09:09.140 --> 00:09:14.538
This is known as public key cryptography,
or asymmetric encryption.

173
00:09:14.538 --> 00:09:19.559
And we're gonna have like I said two keys
and these keys are mathematically related.

174
00:09:19.559 --> 00:09:23.786
They're a pair, they're generated in a way
that they work together, they're not

175
00:09:23.786 --> 00:09:27.475
the same but there mathematically
related and if you have one of the keys,

176
00:09:27.475 --> 00:09:31.642
it's mathematically impractical that you
can figure out where the other key is and

177
00:09:31.642 --> 00:09:33.690
that's an important thing.

178
00:09:33.690 --> 00:09:37.400
So, two keys mathematically related
they're gonna work together, but

179
00:09:37.400 --> 00:09:41.210
if you have one of the keys, you can't
figure out what the other key is, or

180
00:09:41.210 --> 00:09:42.290
it's very, very impractical.

181
00:09:43.330 --> 00:09:47.840
So the way asymmetric works,
whatever key does the encryption,

182
00:09:47.840 --> 00:09:51.060
the other key has to
be used to decrypt it.

183
00:09:51.060 --> 00:09:54.925
Let's say you have key A and
key B right so we got key A and key B.

184
00:09:54.925 --> 00:09:59.039
If I encrypt my data with Key A in
an asymmetric encryption,

185
00:09:59.039 --> 00:10:02.180
the only way to decrypt
it is if you have key B.

186
00:10:02.180 --> 00:10:05.480
You cannot use key A to
get the data back out.

187
00:10:05.480 --> 00:10:06.750
You could flip it around.

188
00:10:06.750 --> 00:10:11.806
You could encrypt it with key B, but
then you would need key A to decrypt it.

189
00:10:11.806 --> 00:10:14.223
So whichever key you use to encrypt it,

190
00:10:14.223 --> 00:10:17.900
the other half of the key pair
needs to be used to decrypt it.

191
00:10:19.010 --> 00:10:23.190
Now, asymmetric encryption algorithms
are much more processor intensive,

192
00:10:23.190 --> 00:10:26.960
they take a lot more work,
mathematical calculations to do, so

193
00:10:26.960 --> 00:10:30.610
they're a lot slower at
doing bulk amounts of data.

194
00:10:30.610 --> 00:10:35.346
But they've got a very big upside and
that is the key distribution issue that we

195
00:10:35.346 --> 00:10:39.528
have with symmetric encryption,
because different keys are used.

196
00:10:39.528 --> 00:10:44.533
Now when we generate those two
keys to do a symmetric encryption,

197
00:10:44.533 --> 00:10:47.816
we're gonna call one of them a public key.

198
00:10:47.816 --> 00:10:52.550
And typically this is put inside a digital
certificate that proves your identity.

199
00:10:52.550 --> 00:10:56.430
The other half of the key pair
is known as your private key.

200
00:10:56.430 --> 00:11:00.704
The public key is named that because
anybody can have your public key.

201
00:11:00.704 --> 00:11:03.058
You can give it to anybody,
you can post on your website,

202
00:11:03.058 --> 00:11:05.412
you can do a mass mailing,
you can send it to your mother,

203
00:11:05.412 --> 00:11:07.842
you can put it on Facebook I
don't care what you do with it.

204
00:11:07.842 --> 00:11:11.010
It's a public key,
it's meant to be public.

205
00:11:11.010 --> 00:11:16.936
The private key has to remain private,
it can not be given to anybody.

206
00:11:16.936 --> 00:11:20.736
It is stored in a secure location
on your computers hard drive.

207
00:11:20.736 --> 00:11:22.940
>> So Mike we have actually
essentially two keys.

208
00:11:22.940 --> 00:11:27.150
We have one that anyone can get or
obtain and

209
00:11:27.150 --> 00:11:29.380
then we have the key that
only you have is that right?

210
00:11:29.380 --> 00:11:30.830
>> That's exactly right.

211
00:11:30.830 --> 00:11:34.494
And so now lets take that same scenario
where I was trying to send an encrypted

212
00:11:34.494 --> 00:11:37.650
message to Zach and
the problem with symmetric remember.

213
00:11:37.650 --> 00:11:40.720
Was if somebody intercepts the data,
the encrypted data,

214
00:11:40.720 --> 00:11:42.540
and then I have to send the key.

215
00:11:42.540 --> 00:11:45.430
They intercept the key, now they can
decrypt that information as well.

216
00:11:45.430 --> 00:11:49.480
So let's see how asymmetric encryption
solves that key distribution problem.

217
00:11:49.480 --> 00:11:52.899
Same scenario, I've got a message
that I wanna send to Zack, and

218
00:11:52.899 --> 00:11:54.026
I want to encrypt it.

219
00:11:54.026 --> 00:11:58.434
So what I'm gonna do is I'm going to
take that asymmetric algorithm and

220
00:11:58.434 --> 00:12:01.560
I'm going to obtain Zach's public key.

221
00:12:01.560 --> 00:12:02.680
Remember, anybody can have it.

222
00:12:02.680 --> 00:12:04.960
I can query Active Directory.

223
00:12:04.960 --> 00:12:09.500
I can have Zach email me his certificate,
that's gonna contain that public key.

224
00:12:09.500 --> 00:12:14.060
And I'm gonna use Zach's public key along
with the algorithm to encrypt the message.

225
00:12:14.060 --> 00:12:17.590
So I take my plain text,
I feed it into the encryption algorithm

226
00:12:17.590 --> 00:12:21.040
along with Zack's public key and
out comes ciphertext.

227
00:12:21.040 --> 00:12:24.704
And now I send that encrypted
message over to Zack.

228
00:12:24.704 --> 00:12:28.034
Well if Zack's public key
was used to encrypt it,

229
00:12:28.034 --> 00:12:32.250
what's the only key that
can be used to decrypt it?

230
00:12:32.250 --> 00:12:35.254
The other half of the key pair
which would be Zack's private key.

231
00:12:35.254 --> 00:12:37.624
Who's the only one that
has Zack's private key?

232
00:12:37.624 --> 00:12:38.742
>> Me.

233
00:12:38.742 --> 00:12:40.200
>> Hopefully you,right?

234
00:12:40.200 --> 00:12:42.411
If you've done your job and
kept that key safe,

235
00:12:42.411 --> 00:12:44.310
then you are the only one who has it.

236
00:12:44.310 --> 00:12:47.664
And so you can decrypt it because you
have have the other half of the key pair.

237
00:12:47.664 --> 00:12:51.402
But if the bad guy intercepted my data,
he can encrypt it.

238
00:12:51.402 --> 00:12:54.638
Because I'm never sending
the key necessary to decrypt it.

239
00:12:54.638 --> 00:12:57.610
The bad guy might have Zack's public key.

240
00:12:57.610 --> 00:12:59.530
Because it is public information.

241
00:12:59.530 --> 00:13:00.336
But remember,

242
00:13:00.336 --> 00:13:04.560
I used Zach's public key along with my
encryption to encrypt in the first place.

243
00:13:04.560 --> 00:13:09.479
And you cannot use the same key with
asymmetric encryption to get the data

244
00:13:09.479 --> 00:13:10.210
back out.

245
00:13:10.210 --> 00:13:13.130
The other half of the key has to be used.

246
00:13:13.130 --> 00:13:16.073
So by using Zach's public
key to encrypt the data,

247
00:13:16.073 --> 00:13:18.680
I've ensured that only
Zach can decrypt it.

248
00:13:18.680 --> 00:13:20.714
I can't even decrypt it at this point,
right.

249
00:13:20.714 --> 00:13:25.521
Once it's encrypted with Zach's pubic key
the only key that can decrypt it is Zach's

250
00:13:25.521 --> 00:13:26.660
private key.

251
00:13:26.660 --> 00:13:30.469
And as long as we've done our job,
and kept Zach's private key private,

252
00:13:30.469 --> 00:13:33.860
then nobody else is going to be
able to decrypt that information.

253
00:13:33.860 --> 00:13:37.513
So asymmetric solves the key
Key distribution problem by,

254
00:13:37.513 --> 00:13:39.810
there is no key to distribute right.

255
00:13:39.810 --> 00:13:41.915
I've got access to
everybody's public keys and

256
00:13:41.915 --> 00:13:44.789
if I wanna send you out there in
the audience an encrypted message,

257
00:13:44.789 --> 00:13:48.196
all I have to do was obtain your public
key which should be publicly available.

258
00:13:48.196 --> 00:13:52.787
Encrypt message with asymmetric encryption
algorithm and your public key and now,

259
00:13:52.787 --> 00:13:55.560
I can send it to everybody in the world.

260
00:13:55.560 --> 00:13:57.396
But only you,
the owner of the private key,

261
00:13:57.396 --> 00:13:59.688
are gonna be able to decrypt that message,
all right?

262
00:13:59.688 --> 00:14:03.250
So asymmetric solves that
key distribution problem.

263
00:14:03.250 --> 00:14:04.400
>> Mike, what is hashing?

264
00:14:04.400 --> 00:14:07.490
I know we've talked about that before,
but let's talk about it again.

265
00:14:07.490 --> 00:14:10.103
>> Yeah, hashing is one of those ones that
sometimes people will try to argue it's

266
00:14:10.103 --> 00:14:11.438
not actually an encryption algorithm.

267
00:14:11.438 --> 00:14:16.110
It is and it isn't,
I can kinda see both sides of this.

268
00:14:16.110 --> 00:14:19.420
Hashing is what we would
call a one-way encryption.

269
00:14:19.420 --> 00:14:24.860
It does take something that's in plain
text and turn it into an encrypted form.

270
00:14:24.860 --> 00:14:28.300
But the difference between symmetric and
asymmetric and

271
00:14:28.300 --> 00:14:33.096
hashing is that once you hash something,
run it through a hashing algorithm you

272
00:14:33.096 --> 00:14:37.760
cannot reverse the encryption to
get the original data back out.

273
00:14:37.760 --> 00:14:40.640
So as far as protecting files or

274
00:14:40.640 --> 00:14:44.040
sending messages hashing
doesn't do you a lot of good.

275
00:14:44.040 --> 00:14:45.420
Because what's the point right?

276
00:14:45.420 --> 00:14:46.930
If I hashed it and I sent it over to Zach.

277
00:14:46.930 --> 00:14:49.335
He's like what is this gobbledygook mean?

278
00:14:49.335 --> 00:14:50.074
>> [LAUGH]
>> And there is

279
00:14:50.074 --> 00:14:52.244
no way to get the original
message back out.

280
00:14:52.244 --> 00:14:54.460
So it's not gonna do us any good.

281
00:14:54.460 --> 00:14:58.570
But hashing does play a big part in
a lot of things we do in security.

282
00:14:58.570 --> 00:15:03.713
Because an interesting thing about hashing
is that when you run a piece of data,

283
00:15:03.713 --> 00:15:06.080
through hashing algorithm.

284
00:15:06.080 --> 00:15:10.716
It generates what we call a fixed
length string or a hash value or

285
00:15:10.716 --> 00:15:12.122
a message digest.

286
00:15:12.122 --> 00:15:14.511
And every time, if you take an email, and

287
00:15:14.511 --> 00:15:18.270
you run through this
hashing algorithm 15 times.

288
00:15:18.270 --> 00:15:23.484
It's gonna generate the exact same
hash value every single time.

289
00:15:23.484 --> 00:15:25.349
Change one letter in that email and

290
00:15:25.349 --> 00:15:28.190
run it through that same
hashing algorithms again.

291
00:15:28.190 --> 00:15:30.624
You're gonna get a completely
different output,

292
00:15:30.624 --> 00:15:33.100
a completely different message digest.

293
00:15:33.100 --> 00:15:37.360
So while hashing doesn't really
provide for confidentiality,

294
00:15:37.360 --> 00:15:39.830
we're not gonna be able to get
the original message back out.

295
00:15:39.830 --> 00:15:42.036
It does provide for integrity.

296
00:15:42.036 --> 00:15:45.210
Because I can tell,
now if somethings modified.

297
00:15:45.210 --> 00:15:46.990
This happens on your network all day long.

298
00:15:46.990 --> 00:15:50.240
It happens in your operating
system all day long.

299
00:15:50.240 --> 00:15:54.926
Your operating system, there's important
files, that it uses to start up,

300
00:15:54.926 --> 00:15:56.740
and run your computer.

301
00:15:56.740 --> 00:16:00.300
And if those files are changed
maliciously, that's what bad guys do,

302
00:16:00.300 --> 00:16:02.180
right, they try to change
those start up files,

303
00:16:02.180 --> 00:16:05.560
insert malware that can try
to take over your machine.

304
00:16:05.560 --> 00:16:10.454
So what Windows has done to keep the boot
process safe is it has a hash value,

305
00:16:10.454 --> 00:16:13.732
a message digest,
of all those important files.

306
00:16:13.732 --> 00:16:18.137
When you install Windows it runs each
one of those files through a hashing

307
00:16:18.137 --> 00:16:20.602
algorithm and stores the information.

308
00:16:20.602 --> 00:16:22.106
Every time you start up windows,

309
00:16:22.106 --> 00:16:24.648
it runs those files through
a hashing algorithm again.

310
00:16:24.648 --> 00:16:29.142
And it looks at the output and it compares
it to the output it got a long time ago.

311
00:16:29.142 --> 00:16:33.511
If those two values match then it knows
the file hasnt changed since the beginning

312
00:16:33.511 --> 00:16:35.630
and everything is good.

313
00:16:35.630 --> 00:16:40.520
If the operating system starts up and one
of those files hash values is different.

314
00:16:40.520 --> 00:16:42.620
That means something
has changed that file.

315
00:16:42.620 --> 00:16:46.472
Doesn't know what, can't verify, it
doesn't know what changed it, but it knows

316
00:16:46.472 --> 00:16:50.780
there had been a change and it throw up
an alarm and we can do something about it.

317
00:16:50.780 --> 00:16:56.470
When we send TCPIP packets across
a network, right, those packets are,

318
00:16:57.620 --> 00:17:01.770
there's a CRC, a cyclical redundancy
checker is in the footer.

319
00:17:01.770 --> 00:17:04.740
Is basically a hash or a message digest.

320
00:17:04.740 --> 00:17:08.183
So when that packet gets packaged up and
it is ready to transmit, it runs it

321
00:17:08.183 --> 00:17:11.862
through a hashing algorithm and it puts
the hash value on the end of the packet.

322
00:17:11.862 --> 00:17:14.263
And then it goes over
to the receiving end,

323
00:17:14.263 --> 00:17:18.065
the receiving end can run that
packet through a hashing algorithm,

324
00:17:18.065 --> 00:17:21.348
compare its output to the one
that you added to the packet.

325
00:17:21.348 --> 00:17:27.160
If those match, then the received packet
has not been changed since it was set.

326
00:17:27.160 --> 00:17:30.480
The sent packet and
the received packet are exactly the same.

327
00:17:30.480 --> 00:17:34.840
If those values don't match, something
happen to that pack and transmission, and

328
00:17:34.840 --> 00:17:37.530
I know to drop it and send it again right?

329
00:17:37.530 --> 00:17:41.232
So we see hashing used all the time.

330
00:17:41.232 --> 00:17:44.630
It's used for when you download
something from the internet.

331
00:17:44.630 --> 00:17:47.280
This is how you can verify that
your download was complete and

332
00:17:47.280 --> 00:17:49.100
that you got your original file back.

333
00:17:49.100 --> 00:17:51.028
>> So it's a great way to authenticate.

334
00:17:51.028 --> 00:17:52.920
>> Well, too, to provide integrity.

335
00:17:52.920 --> 00:17:54.949
>> Right.
>> To make sure that something has not

336
00:17:54.949 --> 00:17:56.458
been modified, all right.

337
00:17:56.458 --> 00:17:58.096
So those are my three classes,

338
00:17:58.096 --> 00:18:02.310
if you will, of encryption algorithms
that we need to be familiar with.

339
00:18:02.310 --> 00:18:06.860
You get symmetric encryption,
which is private key cryptography.

340
00:18:06.860 --> 00:18:11.048
There's only a single key,
that key is used to encrypt and decrypt.

341
00:18:11.048 --> 00:18:14.551
There's asymmetric encryption,
or public key cryptography,

342
00:18:14.551 --> 00:18:17.760
it's a key pair that
are mathematically related.

343
00:18:17.760 --> 00:18:22.130
Whichever key does the encryption,
the other key does the decryption, right?

344
00:18:22.130 --> 00:18:24.520
And it solves the problem
of key distribution.

345
00:18:24.520 --> 00:18:31.491
Then we have hashing encryption
algorithms which are one-way encryption.

346
00:18:31.491 --> 00:18:34.321
They allow me to check for integrity.

00:18:34.321 --> 00:18:39.393
Because I can run something through a
hashing algorithm and if the hash output,

if the message digest has been changed or
is not matched the original I know that

349
00:18:44.389 --> 00:18:47.972

whatever it is has been modified.

00:27:50.840 --> 00:27:56.190
MIME is an older protocol that we used
with e-mails to put on attachments and

518
00:27:56.190 --> 00:27:57.305
photos and things like that.

519
00:27:57.305 --> 00:28:00.150
And that was multipurpose
Internet mail extension.

520
00:28:00.150 --> 00:28:02.380
Allowed me to extend
the functionality of e-mail, right?

521
00:28:02.380 --> 00:28:04.340
Attachments and things like that.

522
00:28:04.340 --> 00:28:08.280
SMIME, or secure multi-purpose
Internet mail extension,

523
00:28:08.280 --> 00:28:10.670
is a way that I can encrypt e-mails,
right?

524
00:28:10.670 --> 00:28:15.500
Now this is gonna be supported by whatever
application you used whether that's

525
00:28:15.500 --> 00:28:20.770
Outlook or some Web based that
your e-mail application would

526
00:28:20.770 --> 00:28:23.590
have to support encrypting e-mails.

527
00:28:23.590 --> 00:28:27.870
Another protocol we can use to encrypt
e-mail is something known as PGP,

528
00:28:27.870 --> 00:28:29.685
or pretty good privacy.

529
00:28:29.685 --> 00:28:34.335
>> [LAUGHTER]
>> It's a great name.

530
00:28:34.335 --> 00:28:35.640
But it is.

531
00:28:35.640 --> 00:28:37.830
It's been around for a long time.

532
00:28:37.830 --> 00:28:39.870
I want to say Semantec now owns it.

533
00:28:39.870 --> 00:28:41.510
It's no longer free.

534
00:28:41.510 --> 00:28:44.440
We used to talk about it
as a free alternative, but

535
00:28:44.440 --> 00:28:45.820
unfortunately it's no longer free.

536
00:28:45.820 --> 00:28:49.330
But for this exam,
be aware of those two protocols.

537
00:28:49.330 --> 00:28:51.420
If you wanna encrypt e-mail,

538
00:28:51.420 --> 00:28:56.189
two of the most popular ways to
do that are using S/MIME or PGP.

539
00:28:57.510 --> 00:29:00.580
I think we've talked enough about VPNs or
virtual private networks.

540
00:29:00.580 --> 00:29:04.610
If you wanna rehash on that make sure you
go check out the episodes were we talked

541
00:29:04.610 --> 00:29:08.070
about VPNs as well as public and
private key.

542
00:29:08.070 --> 00:29:09.990
Check out part one of this episode.

543
00:29:09.990 --> 00:29:10.900
>> My goodness, yeah.

544
00:29:10.900 --> 00:29:14.250
>> We talk all about the difference
there and what that means.

545
00:29:14.250 --> 00:29:16.709
So that leaves us with what, certificates.

546
00:29:18.330 --> 00:29:22.800
And certificates
are electronic documents that

547
00:29:22.800 --> 00:29:26.040
tie your identity to a key pair, right?

548
00:29:26.040 --> 00:29:28.010
That's a technical definition, and

549
00:29:28.010 --> 00:29:30.810
let's break that down
a little bit further, right?

550
00:29:30.810 --> 00:29:32.490
A certificate is an electronic document,

551
00:29:32.490 --> 00:29:34.320
meaning it's not a piece
of paper we print out.

552
00:29:34.320 --> 00:29:38.540
It's a file, it's an electronic
document on my system, and

553
00:29:38.540 --> 00:29:43.280
it's issued by something known
as a certificate authority.

554
00:29:43.280 --> 00:29:46.060
A certificate authority
generates certificates.

555
00:29:46.060 --> 00:29:47.280
You have to apply for them.

556
00:29:47.280 --> 00:29:50.660
You provide information, just like
when you go get a driver's license.

557
00:29:50.660 --> 00:29:51.550
You can't just go in there and

558
00:29:51.550 --> 00:29:56.460
say, hey, my name's Bill Gates and I want
a driver's license that says that, right?

559
00:29:56.460 --> 00:29:57.210
It's not gonna work.

560
00:29:57.210 --> 00:29:59.840
You've gotta prove who you
are before they're gonna issue you

561
00:29:59.840 --> 00:30:00.950
a driver's license.

562
00:30:00.950 --> 00:30:02.980
You gotta bring in birth certificates,

563
00:30:02.980 --> 00:30:07.690
Social Security numbers, utility bills,
whatever the case may be.

564
00:30:07.690 --> 00:30:10.200
Same thing happens with
the certificate authority.

565
00:30:10.200 --> 00:30:12.020
You're gonna provide information.

566
00:30:12.020 --> 00:30:14.640
If you are doing this through a third
party out on the Internet you might have

567
00:30:14.640 --> 00:30:18.640
to mail them documents, you might
even have to go visit them personally

568
00:30:18.640 --> 00:30:21.390
depending on how what type of
certificate I am trying to buy.

569
00:30:21.390 --> 00:30:26.840
If I am doing this internally in my
company, that information could be pulled

570
00:30:26.840 --> 00:30:30.880
from Active directory because it already
knows who I am and stuff like that.

571
00:30:30.880 --> 00:30:33.490
But the point is you prove
your identity one way or

572
00:30:33.490 --> 00:30:35.670
the other to the certificate authority,
and

573
00:30:35.670 --> 00:30:39.730
then the certificate authority does
two things, it generates a key pair.

574
00:30:39.730 --> 00:30:42.470
Remember we were talking about
asymmetric and key pairs?

575
00:30:42.470 --> 00:30:46.960
It's gonna generate a key pair,
it's gonna take your public key and

576
00:30:46.960 --> 00:30:51.150
put it in the certificate along with
your other identifying information, and

577
00:30:51.150 --> 00:30:56.260
it's going to then deliver to you
a certificate and a private key.

578
00:30:56.260 --> 00:30:59.720
And the private key is gonna get
stored securely on your hard drive.

579
00:30:59.720 --> 00:31:02.150
And now you're gonna have
the certificate that goes with it.

580
00:31:02.150 --> 00:31:07.830
So now you have a certificate that has
a public key in it and a private key.

581
00:31:07.830 --> 00:31:12.120
And you could now do asymmetric
encryption using that certificate and

582
00:31:12.120 --> 00:31:13.660
associated private key.

583
00:31:13.660 --> 00:31:15.850
And it's tied to your identity.

584
00:31:15.850 --> 00:31:19.520
Because that certificate is, like I said,
like a driver's license or a passport.

585
00:31:19.520 --> 00:31:22.380
All your identifying
information was verified

586
00:31:22.380 --> 00:31:25.360
before that certificate was generated and
issued.

587
00:31:25.360 --> 00:31:29.340
And that certificated is signed, just like
the state of Florida puts their seal on

588
00:31:29.340 --> 00:31:32.220
there before they laminate my
driver's license that says, hey,

589
00:31:32.220 --> 00:31:35.430
we verified all this information,
we're gonna seal it up.

590
00:31:35.430 --> 00:31:39.314
And now when I had it to police officer,
they don't have to verify my info,

591
00:31:39.314 --> 00:31:43.570
they see the state of Florida seal, they
know they did their job before they issued

592
00:31:43.570 --> 00:31:47.535
it so they can trust all the information
on that driver license is accurate.

593
00:31:47.535 --> 00:31:50.180
Well, your computers when
you use certificates,

594
00:31:50.180 --> 00:31:53.081
those certificates run
through a validation process.

595
00:31:53.081 --> 00:31:57.689
Part of that is verifying
the the creator of the certificate.

596
00:31:57.689 --> 00:32:02.259
Making sure that the certificate authority
that issued the certificate in the first

597
00:32:02.259 --> 00:32:04.530
place is somebody I trust, right?

598
00:32:04.530 --> 00:32:08.050
Because what if Zach set up
his own certificate authority?

599
00:32:08.050 --> 00:32:11.640
He could technically issue
himself a certificate

600
00:32:11.640 --> 00:32:12.930
that said his name was Bill Gates.

601
00:32:12.930 --> 00:32:14.380
>> I have done that several times.

602
00:32:14.380 --> 00:32:16.330
[LAUGH]
>> And he might try to pawned that

603
00:32:16.330 --> 00:32:22.090
certificate off on some unwary a site or
user something like that.

604
00:32:22.090 --> 00:32:26.490
But the problem Zach's gonna have
is that certificate was sign

605
00:32:26.490 --> 00:32:30.180
by his own Private CA, right?

606
00:32:30.180 --> 00:32:33.500
And nobody else in the world is gonna
trust that CA because it's not some

607
00:32:33.500 --> 00:32:37.040
public company that my
computer knows to trust.

608
00:32:37.040 --> 00:32:41.020
It's not my internal CA that my
organization knows to trust.

609
00:32:41.020 --> 00:32:44.270
Certificates are all
about a chain of trust.

610
00:32:44.270 --> 00:32:50.100
And you have to trust the person or the
entity that's issuing the certificates.

611
00:32:50.100 --> 00:32:55.350
Just like that Florida State Trooper
trusts the Florida DMV did their job.

612
00:32:55.350 --> 00:32:58.310
But if I take my drivers
license to some other country,

613
00:32:58.310 --> 00:33:01.940
are they gonna be as willing to
trust the information on there?

614
00:33:01.940 --> 00:33:03.070
Maybe not, right?

615
00:33:03.070 --> 00:33:04.720
Cuz they don't know the State of Florida.

616
00:33:04.720 --> 00:33:07.500
They don't necessarily
trust the State of Florida.

617
00:33:07.500 --> 00:33:09.700
And that's the same thing will
happen with certificates.

618
00:33:09.700 --> 00:33:11.980
You could try to create
a fake certificate.

619
00:33:11.980 --> 00:33:16.380
But if you try to use it anywhere, you're
probably not gonna be successful because

620
00:33:17.440 --> 00:33:21.020
you can't fake the signature.

621
00:33:21.020 --> 00:33:23.348
You can't make it look like it came
from a trusted certificate authority.

622
00:33:23.348 --> 00:33:26.212
>> I've said awesome about
25 times in this show.

623
00:33:26.212 --> 00:33:27.014
>> [LAUGH]
>> No really,

624
00:33:27.014 --> 00:33:28.600
you're information is so incredible.

625
00:33:28.600 --> 00:33:29.480
Thank you so much.

626
00:33:29.480 --> 00:33:30.170
>> Good, good.
All right,

627
00:33:30.170 --> 00:33:32.170
we do have a little bit more
of try to squeeze in here so

628
00:33:32.170 --> 00:33:36.300
we don't do a part three so pardon me for
going a little bit over our 30 minutes.

629
00:33:36.300 --> 00:33:38.360
We talked about the certificates.

630
00:33:38.360 --> 00:33:44.920
A term we need to be familiar with PKI or
public key infrastructure.

631
00:33:44.920 --> 00:33:47.560
This is the certificate server.

632
00:33:47.560 --> 00:33:51.460
These are the ones, this is
the infrastructure that we will set up

633
00:33:51.460 --> 00:33:56.430
to generate, manage and maintain
certificates throughout their lifetime.

634
00:33:56.430 --> 00:34:00.460
So as an organization, if I want to
issue all my users certificates,

635
00:34:00.460 --> 00:34:04.475
that I can put on smart cards and they can
use to log in or get through doorways.

636
00:34:04.475 --> 00:34:07.780
Or if I wanted to issue certificates
to all my computers, so

637
00:34:07.780 --> 00:34:12.550
they can do IPsec between them and
those secure file servers.

638
00:34:12.550 --> 00:34:17.280
I will set up my own public key
infrastructure, where I have certificate

639
00:34:17.280 --> 00:34:21.770
authorities that I can tell
everybody on my domain to trust, and

640
00:34:21.770 --> 00:34:24.090
I can start issuing certificates, right.

641
00:34:24.090 --> 00:34:26.500
There are private CAs,

642
00:34:26.500 --> 00:34:29.460
public infrastructures that I
maintain within my organization.

643
00:34:29.460 --> 00:34:35.760
There are also public CAs, places like
VeriSign, or Thought, or GTE, or EquiFax.

644
00:34:35.760 --> 00:34:38.820
These are companies that I can go and
buy certificates from.

645
00:34:38.820 --> 00:34:40.130
Now, what's the difference?

646
00:34:40.130 --> 00:34:43.690
Well, if I'm only using
the certificates internally,

647
00:34:43.690 --> 00:34:47.870
within my organization, then I can set
up my own public key infrastructure.

648
00:34:47.870 --> 00:34:49.138
I can issue certificates.

649
00:34:49.138 --> 00:34:53.571
And everybody inside my company can
be told, hey, trust CA number two,

650
00:34:53.571 --> 00:34:55.326
because that's our own CA.

651
00:34:55.326 --> 00:34:57.660
And you can trust the certificates
that it produces.

652
00:34:58.780 --> 00:35:03.470
But outside my organization,
they don't know to trust my CA so

653
00:35:03.470 --> 00:35:07.700
my certificates are only going
to be good internally, right.

654
00:35:07.700 --> 00:35:11.860
We have public CAs though that issues
certificates that the public trusts,

655
00:35:11.860 --> 00:35:14.723
if you go,
I don't wanna go too far into this, but.

656
00:35:14.723 --> 00:35:15.704
>> Verified by a Verisign.

657
00:35:15.704 --> 00:35:16.376
>> Yes.

658
00:35:16.376 --> 00:35:17.247
>> I've seen that so many times.

659
00:35:17.247 --> 00:35:20.771
Exactly right, so when you go to
a public website and it says hey,

660
00:35:20.771 --> 00:35:23.420
this certificate was issued by Verisign.

661
00:35:23.420 --> 00:35:25.970
Your computer already knows
to trust Verisign, right?

662
00:35:25.970 --> 00:35:29.700
Because it's been configured
that way out of the box.

663
00:35:29.700 --> 00:35:34.630
So public CAs are useful if I need
to provide a public resource,

664
00:35:34.630 --> 00:35:39.570
whereas private CAs are used
internally to issue certificates.

665
00:35:39.570 --> 00:35:40.790
There's much more to it than that.

666
00:35:40.790 --> 00:35:44.915
I'm trying to sum up public key
infrastructure in three minutes or less.

667
00:35:44.915 --> 00:35:46.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's plenty for

668
00:35:46.800 --> 00:35:48.960
us to pass the MTA exam.

669
00:35:48.960 --> 00:35:51.459
If you want more information
on public key infrastructure,

670
00:35:51.459 --> 00:35:53.616
make sure you check out our
Windows Server classes.

671
00:35:53.616 --> 00:35:57.025
And some of those others where
we go into much more depth,

672
00:35:57.025 --> 00:36:01.147
talk about the hierarchy of public
key infrastructure, root CAs and

673
00:36:01.147 --> 00:36:04.648
subordinate CAs and
all of that fun stuff and revocation.

674
00:36:04.648 --> 00:36:09.325
There's a lot more to it but we don't
need to know it for this particular exam.

675
00:36:09.325 --> 00:36:14.145
Last thing I will talk about is
going to be about token devices,

676
00:36:14.145 --> 00:36:16.775
which is another one that we
talked about a little bit.

677
00:36:16.775 --> 00:36:20.610
When we talked about authentication
way back in episodes long ago.

678
00:36:20.610 --> 00:36:26.670
A token, a security token is just a device
that I can use to authenticate with.

679
00:36:26.670 --> 00:36:28.370
This may be a smart card.

680
00:36:28.370 --> 00:36:31.210
It could be a little USB device.

681
00:36:31.210 --> 00:36:35.240
It might be something that I have to
plug in in order to authenticate.

682
00:36:35.240 --> 00:36:38.100
It could also be something
that generates a code.

683
00:36:38.100 --> 00:36:41.310
And when I go to authenticate,
I have to look at the code

684
00:36:41.310 --> 00:36:45.350
that was generated by this device and
punch that code in as well.

685
00:36:45.350 --> 00:36:49.230
So token devices are physical devices

686
00:36:49.230 --> 00:36:53.490
that we can use when we want to
implement multi-factor authentication.

687
00:36:53.490 --> 00:36:54.900
>> Fantastic job as usual.

688
00:36:54.900 --> 00:36:59.370
And like I said, I said awesome like
150 times in the show Encryption and

689
00:36:59.370 --> 00:37:01.180
this is MTA security fundamentals.

690
00:37:01.180 --> 00:37:02.500
This is encryption part two.

691
00:37:02.500 --> 00:37:05.700
There is a part one, and there's so
much more to be seen in the library,

692
00:37:05.700 --> 00:37:07.520
which you have access to,
because you're smart.

693
00:37:07.520 --> 00:37:08.490
Good for you.

694
00:37:08.490 --> 00:37:11.590
Thanks so much Mike, and this ITProTV.

695
00:37:11.590 --> 00:37:15.310
Thanks for watching and
do you know an ITPro is always learning.

696
00:37:15.310 --> 00:37:16.250
I'm Zach Memos.

697
00:37:16.250 --> 00:37:17.050
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

698
00:37:17.050 --> 00:37:20.213
>> And we'll see you very soon.

any other type of security that

So that's what a back door is all about.

00:21:01.870 --> 00:21:04.940
But they're assigned
a certain amount of memory.

387
00:21:04.940 --> 00:21:08.840
A buffer overflow is when
we get the application to

388
00:21:08.840 --> 00:21:11.100

389
00:21:11.100 --> 00:21:14.380
In that buffer, that amount of

00:21:14.380 --> 00:21:18.900

00:21:18.900 --> 00:21:23.090

00:21:31.430 --> 00:21:34.470
But if there's Issues

It might not turn the faucet off.

00:21:38.160 --> 00:21:41.160

Not once when an application runs

It's actually over,

A few different things can happen.

00:21:58.120 --> 00:22:01.310
It's like taking apiece of paper

00:22:01.310 --> 00:22:03.940

just start writing at the top and

00:22:03.940 --> 00:22:06.250

00:22:06.250 --> 00:22:08.710
Then I would say,
I can't read that gobbledygook and

00:22:08.710 --> 00:22:11.680

00:22:11.680 --> 00:22:15.200
Now, the operating system itself, the

00:22:19.750 --> 00:22:22.670

00:03:31.840 --> 00:03:35.800

Because it comes across

00:03:52.629 --> 00:03:57.147
Like 80, typically, for

00:03:57.147 --> 00:04:02.010
3389 for remote desktop in

00:04:10.577 --> 00:04:14.490

00:04:14.490 --> 00:04:18.720
I can establish a connection on

77
00:04:18.720 --> 00:04:23.130
So what a firewall does is basically say,

00:04:23.130 --> 00:04:27.603
And then I can pick and choose what

00:04:27.603 --> 00:04:32.215
So it gives me that ability to

00:04:32.215 --> 00:04:37.492
Now technically, I guess a firewall could

00:04:37.492 --> 00:04:41.630
And we have to create rules

00:04:41.630 --> 00:04:45.390
Most firewalls nowadays, however,

00:04:45.390 --> 00:04:47.450

00:04:47.450 --> 00:04:51.620
Meaning I'm gonna block everything, and

00:04:51.620 --> 00:04:56.930

00:05:02.449 --> 00:05:06.784

00:05:06.784 --> 00:05:12.769

00:05:12.769 --> 00:05:16.170

00:05:16.170 --> 00:05:21.710

00:05:21.710 --> 00:05:24.810
Where the packet's coming from,

00:05:24.810 --> 00:05:27.488

00:05:27.488 --> 00:05:30.554
What port the computer that was

00:05:30.554 --> 00:05:32.105
and what port it is destined for?

00:05:32.105 --> 00:05:35.210
Port 80 on my web server, maybe.

00:05:35.210 --> 00:05:39.790
We can also look at the type of packet,

98
00:05:39.790 --> 00:05:44.210
is it UDP, is it FTP, and what can
of traffic is coming across there?

99
00:05:44.210 --> 00:05:49.350
But that's about all a packet-filtering
firewall can look at,

100
00:05:49.350 --> 00:05:52.470
is that header information

101
00:05:52.470 --> 00:05:56.197
It can also look at interface IDs,

102
00:05:56.197 --> 00:06:00.268
But it doesn't look at the content of

103
00:06:00.268 --> 00:06:02.845

00:06:02.845 --> 00:06:05.446
Or the piece of software

105
00:06:05.446 --> 00:06:07.489
the email that somebody is sending to you.

00:06:07.489 --> 00:06:10.001
Doesn't look at any of that,
just the source and

107
00:06:10.001 --> 00:06:12.956
destination IP, source and

108
00:06:12.956 --> 00:06:15.016
Interface IDs, type of package, or

109
00:06:15.016 --> 00:06:18.480
basically protocol that we're
sending those packets with.

110
00:06:19.900 --> 00:06:22.310
So that's a very basic firewall.

111
00:06:22.310 --> 00:06:25.500
Did a great job,
it does what it's supposed to do.

00:06:25.500 --> 00:06:28.935
But that, again,

Is because attacks have got

00:06:35.260 --> 00:06:38.520
It's not just your basic
black-and-white type of attack,

00:06:38.520 --> 00:06:41.050
where it's just an IP address,

117
00:06:41.050 --> 00:06:42.448
They're getting a lot more sophisticated.

00:06:42.448 --> 00:06:46.820
So that basic-packet filtering
firewall isn't really gonna cut

00:06:46.820 --> 00:06:47.970
the mustard, per se, today.

00:06:47.970 --> 00:06:50.560
>> Yeah, there's a lot of other

00:06:50.560 --> 00:06:53.210
to determine whether or
not I'm gonna allow that data in.

122
00:06:53.210 --> 00:06:57.778
So we're gonna get more control,
more capabilities on our next-generation,

123
00:06:57.778 --> 00:06:59.870
our later-generation firewalls.

124
00:07:01.690 --> 00:07:06.590
So the next one we'll talk about is
what's known as a circuit-level firewall.

125
00:07:06.590 --> 00:07:10.910
And a circuit level firewall looks at
what we would call sessions, right?

126
00:07:10.910 --> 00:07:12.607
A TCP session, for example.

127
00:07:12.607 --> 00:07:17.229
When you connect to a web server,
TCP goes through something known,

128
00:07:17.229 --> 00:07:19.950
TCP, transmission control protocol.

129
00:07:19.950 --> 00:07:22.380
Goes through something known
as a three-way handshake.

130
00:07:22.380 --> 00:07:27.890
It establishes my computer and that
web server are establishing a session,

131
00:07:27.890 --> 00:07:30.420
so we can start sending packets back and
forth.

132
00:07:30.420 --> 00:07:34.186
And it goes, there's a three step process
that bounces back and forth between there.

133
00:07:34.186 --> 00:07:38.344
And circuit-level firewalls
monitor those TCP handshakes,

134
00:07:38.344 --> 00:07:42.193
those session creation portion
of these conversations.

135
00:07:42.193 --> 00:07:43.750
And it will keep track of those.

136
00:07:43.750 --> 00:07:49.681
It'll say, Wes' computer and
Newegg.com have established a session.

137
00:07:49.681 --> 00:07:52.692
And from then on,
traffic from Wes' computer to Newegg, or

138
00:07:52.692 --> 00:07:55.714
from Newegg back to Wes' computer,
is going to be allowed.

139
00:07:55.714 --> 00:07:58.057
Because it's part of that session.

140
00:07:58.057 --> 00:08:02.769
It has a memory that it stores information
about all of the sessions that have been

141
00:08:02.769 --> 00:08:06.110
established on your network and
it keeps track of those.

142
00:08:06.110 --> 00:08:09.410
And so it's making its decisions based on,
all right,

143
00:08:09.410 --> 00:08:11.980
Wes has established
a connection with Newegg.

144
00:08:11.980 --> 00:08:14.343
I've got newegg.com or some other website.

145
00:08:14.343 --> 00:08:18.042
I've got data coming back from Newegg.

146
00:08:18.042 --> 00:08:20.760
It's part of that same session, so
I'm gonna go ahead and allow it.

147
00:08:20.760 --> 00:08:24.314
If Newegg had tried to send data in
without any session we had established

148
00:08:24.314 --> 00:08:27.240
from our inside users,
then it would not allow it, right?

149
00:08:27.240 --> 00:08:31.409
This data is not part of a session that
somebody's established, therefore,

150
00:08:31.409 --> 00:08:32.491
I'm gonna drop it.

151
00:08:32.491 --> 00:08:34.740
So that's what a circuit
level firewall is doing.

152
00:08:34.740 --> 00:08:38.090
It's looking at the sessions,
the TCP handshakes, and

153
00:08:38.090 --> 00:08:42.730
then it's restricting access
to only authorized computers.

154
00:08:42.730 --> 00:08:46.390
Like I said, they're the ones that are
coming from inside my network, all right?

155
00:08:46.390 --> 00:08:51.120
Now the circuit level firewalls are also

00:08:51.120 --> 00:08:52.090
proxies.

157
00:08:52.090 --> 00:08:57.390
Cuz an interesting thing about the way

158
00:08:57.390 --> 00:08:59.420
like Newegg, in our example,

00:08:59.420 --> 00:09:03.430
doesn't ever see Wes as the one

160
00:09:03.430 --> 00:09:07.830
It actually sees the firewall

161
00:09:07.830 --> 00:09:12.780
So it hides our internal
network from the outside,

162
00:09:12.780 --> 00:09:17.590
which is why we call it

163
00:09:17.590 --> 00:09:21.950
Typically, these are run in conjunction

164
00:09:21.950 --> 00:09:24.520
Cuz they don't really give

165
00:09:24.520 --> 00:09:27.480
They're only good at making sure only

166
00:09:27.480 --> 00:09:31.140
authorized computers are allowed
to establish these sessions.

167
00:09:31.140 --> 00:09:32.260
But that's about it, right?

168
00:09:32.260 --> 00:09:34.660
It doesn't look at any
of the other details,

169
00:09:34.660 --> 00:09:37.949
can't make any other decisions based
on information in those packets.

170
00:09:39.050 --> 00:09:41.250
Then, you've got application
level firewalls.

171
00:09:41.250 --> 00:09:43.680
And application level firewalls

172
00:09:43.680 --> 00:09:47.400

173
00:09:47.400 --> 00:09:49.100
They can look at the application data.

174
00:09:49.100 --> 00:09:54.800
The information that's
inside those packets, right?

175
00:09:54.800 --> 00:09:57.730
So they can make sure that an application
is following the rules that

176
00:09:57.730 --> 00:09:58.440
it's supposed to.

177
00:09:58.440 --> 00:10:01.678
That it's always sending
appropriate information.

178
00:10:01.678 --> 00:10:07.070
It gives us the ability to
block malicious activity.

179
00:10:07.070 --> 00:10:14.080
We can log user activity,
we can do content filtering.

180
00:10:14.080 --> 00:10:17.290
These are also known as a proxy server,

181
00:10:19.310 --> 00:10:21.560
You see this run in a lot of schools or

182
00:10:21.560 --> 00:10:27.195
any place I need to control what
my users are accessing, right?

183
00:10:27.195 --> 00:10:32.440
Cuz unlike a packet filtering firewall,

00:10:32.440 --> 00:10:36.350

185
00:10:36.350 --> 00:10:37.570
So I can set up rules and say, hey,

186
00:10:37.570 --> 00:10:43.320
anybody that requests a page from

187
00:10:43.320 --> 00:10:45.250
I can look inside the packet.

00:10:45.250 --> 00:10:48.130

are trying to connect to and

00:10:48.130 --> 00:10:50.090

00:10:50.090 --> 00:10:54.448

00:10:54.448 --> 00:10:58.952

00:11:05.670 --> 00:11:10.250

It can see that in those packets.

00:11:12.910 --> 00:11:17.640
If it recognizes a definition or something

00:11:17.640 --> 00:11:19.560
you can block those packets.

00:11:19.560 --> 00:11:25.762

00:11:25.762 --> 00:11:30.383
