240
00:13:34.536 --> 00:13:37.117
it's working with the application data.

241
00:13:37.117 --> 00:13:42.092
And that's what they mean by multi-level
is this is working with those packets

242
00:13:42.092 --> 00:13:45.910
at multiple levels within that OSI model,
all right?

243
00:13:45.910 --> 00:13:47.370
So might wanna go back and review that.

244
00:13:47.370 --> 00:13:49.790
Go back and
take a look at your basic networking.

245
00:13:49.790 --> 00:13:53.040
If you're like me, and you get some
brain cramps when you're trying

246
00:13:53.040 --> 00:13:56.610
to remember the different
layers in the OSI model.

247
00:13:56.610 --> 00:13:59.750
But back to what we're talking about,
stateful multi-level firewall,

248
00:13:59.750 --> 00:14:02.370
now we know why they say multi-level.

249
00:14:02.370 --> 00:14:06.319
Because it is working with the packets
at multiple levels in the OSI.

250
00:14:06.319 --> 00:14:07.386
So also stateful,

251
00:14:07.386 --> 00:14:12.230
because it does some of what we talked
about with the circuit-level firewall.

252
00:14:12.230 --> 00:14:14.560
It does pay attention to conversations or

253
00:14:14.560 --> 00:14:18.080
to states,
sessions that have been established.

254
00:14:18.080 --> 00:14:21.464
Because that makes it a little
bit easier on the firewall

255
00:14:21.464 --> 00:14:24.497
when it sees that a session
has been established.

256
00:14:24.497 --> 00:14:27.556
It can say, okay, that packet's going
to be allowed because it's part

257
00:14:27.556 --> 00:14:29.122
of an existing session, all right?

258
00:14:29.122 --> 00:14:32.686
It has memory, where it keeps track of
these sessions that have been established.

259
00:14:32.686 --> 00:14:35.103
And when a packet comes through,
it looks at the information,

260
00:14:35.103 --> 00:14:38.127
it matches that to a session, it says,
okay, already established session.

261
00:14:38.127 --> 00:14:39.970
We'll go ahead and
allow that to come through.

262
00:14:39.970 --> 00:14:45.380
It can still do the detailed,
deep inspection

263
00:14:45.380 --> 00:14:51.560
of those packets doing content filtering
and things like that, all right?

264
00:14:52.580 --> 00:14:55.030
Let's see what else I wanna
make sure we cover there.

265
00:14:55.030 --> 00:15:00.440
So we talked about stateless being
what our packet filtering does, right?

266
00:15:00.440 --> 00:15:01.650
It's not paying attention.

267
00:15:01.650 --> 00:15:06.850
Every packet that comes through on
a stateless firewall has to be looked at

268
00:15:06.850 --> 00:15:08.290
individually, right?

269
00:15:08.290 --> 00:15:10.150
On its own honors, in other words.

270
00:15:10.150 --> 00:15:12.090
It has nothing to do with
the packet in front of it.

271
00:15:12.090 --> 00:15:14.430
It has nothing to do with
the packet coming after it.

272
00:15:14.430 --> 00:15:17.798
Here's a packet, let's inspect it, run
it through all of the rules, yes or no.

273
00:15:17.798 --> 00:15:20.050
Allow it, throw it,
whatever we're gonna do with it.

274
00:15:20.050 --> 00:15:23.302
Next one comes in,
repeat the process, right?

275
00:15:23.302 --> 00:15:27.709
Stateful pays attention to conversations,
and it says, this packet is part of

276
00:15:27.709 --> 00:15:31.761
the conversation that that last packet
that I already allowed to go through.

277
00:15:31.761 --> 00:15:33.921
Therefore, I can just
put it on its coattails,

278
00:15:33.921 --> 00:15:36.570
let it go right through with it, right?

279
00:15:36.570 --> 00:15:38.600
As I said, with stateful, more expensive,

280
00:15:38.600 --> 00:15:42.780
more complex to configure these
types of firewalls as well.

281
00:15:44.500 --> 00:15:46.270
And then, let's go back and

282
00:15:46.270 --> 00:15:49.300
talk about hardware and
software based firewalls again.

283
00:15:49.300 --> 00:15:52.396
Let's add a little bit more
to what we discussed already.

284
00:15:52.396 --> 00:15:57.354
A hardware firewall dedicated device has
hardware dedicated to the job of being

285
00:15:57.354 --> 00:15:58.169
a firewall.

286
00:15:58.169 --> 00:16:01.976
So you can probably already
guess that performance-wise,

287
00:16:01.976 --> 00:16:08.040
A hardware based firewall is usually going
to out perform a software based firewall.

288
00:16:08.040 --> 00:16:13.100
Not because the software based
firewall is just that much worse or

289
00:16:13.100 --> 00:16:15.450
not able to perform as well.

290
00:16:15.450 --> 00:16:19.330
But because typically a software based
firewall is installed on a device that is

291
00:16:19.330 --> 00:16:22.205
not dedicated to acting as a firewall.

292
00:16:22.205 --> 00:16:25.320
At the minimum it probably
it has an operating system

293
00:16:25.320 --> 00:16:28.270
that is running in the background and
taking up some resources.

294
00:16:28.270 --> 00:16:32.300
It might have other tasks, processes,
services that are running,

295
00:16:32.300 --> 00:16:35.820
performing other jobs,
that are taking up resources.

296
00:16:35.820 --> 00:16:39.200
So it's not dedicated like
a hardware firewall would be.

297
00:16:39.200 --> 00:16:42.330
That's not to say that you can beef
up the heck out of that server and

298
00:16:42.330 --> 00:16:45.570
make a software based firewall
that performs really well, right.

299
00:16:45.570 --> 00:16:50.520
It's just that apples to apples,
it's probably not gonna

300
00:16:50.520 --> 00:16:55.379
perform as well as a hardware
based firewall, all right.

301
00:16:55.379 --> 00:16:58.277
Availability is another issue
that we have to talk about.

302
00:16:58.277 --> 00:17:02.540
Hardware based firewalls typically
have redundancy built into them.

303
00:17:02.540 --> 00:17:06.190
They might have multiple CPUs,
they might have multiple power supplies,

304
00:17:06.190 --> 00:17:08.120
multiple network adapters.

305
00:17:08.120 --> 00:17:10.140
So they've got redundancy built in.

306
00:17:10.140 --> 00:17:12.158
Software based firewalls might or
might not,

307
00:17:12.158 --> 00:17:14.808
depending on how you've
configured that machine, right.

308
00:17:14.808 --> 00:17:18.300
Whether it has that level of
redundancy and reliability.

309
00:17:18.300 --> 00:17:23.240
If I'm talking about operating systems,
I mean our operating systems

310
00:17:23.240 --> 00:17:25.930
now a days are pretty darn reliable for
the most part.

311
00:17:25.930 --> 00:17:27.690
But we still have to
reboot them now again.

312
00:17:27.690 --> 00:17:29.500
We have to apply updates.

313
00:17:29.500 --> 00:17:32.700
And, I know, hardware based firewalls,
maybe you have to update firmware, but

314
00:17:32.700 --> 00:17:38.130
not nearly as often as I might have
to reboot a software, or a server,

315
00:17:38.130 --> 00:17:42.090
or a client operating system running
one of these software based firewalls.

316
00:17:42.090 --> 00:17:45.690
So reliability becomes an issue and
availability becomes an issue,

317
00:17:45.690 --> 00:17:48.977
because if I have to reboot that
server for some reason, well,

318
00:17:48.977 --> 00:17:52.143
the firewall service of
the application that I'm running,

319
00:17:52.143 --> 00:17:55.890
that software based firewall,
is obviously gonna stop temporarily.

320
00:17:55.890 --> 00:17:58.390
So availability becomes an issue.

321
00:17:59.390 --> 00:18:02.600
Now, when we're talking
about software firewalls,

322
00:18:02.600 --> 00:18:05.950
we also have to talk about different
categories of we can do there.

323
00:18:05.950 --> 00:18:11.079
There's host based software firewalls and
there's network based software firewalls.

324
00:18:12.920 --> 00:18:16.410
Hardware based firewalls are always,
almost always, network based.

325
00:18:16.410 --> 00:18:20.730
You could, well let's differentiate first,
and then I'll explain.

326
00:18:20.730 --> 00:18:24.744
A host based firewall
protects a single host.

327
00:18:24.744 --> 00:18:27.743
So a lot of you might run firewalls
on your client operating system,

328
00:18:27.743 --> 00:18:31.529
might be built into your operating system,
like Windows 10, it might be something

329
00:18:31.529 --> 00:18:35.450
you've downloaded and installed,
purchased and installed on your system.

330
00:18:35.450 --> 00:18:39.290
And that firewall protects your computer,
right, traffic that's coming in and

331
00:18:39.290 --> 00:18:41.230
out of that one system.

332
00:18:41.230 --> 00:18:42.765
You can have another
system on the network,

333
00:18:42.765 --> 00:18:45.020
it offers no protection to that one.

334
00:18:45.020 --> 00:18:50.180
I'd have to install a host based software
based firewall on that one as well.

335
00:18:50.180 --> 00:18:53.710
Whereas a network firewall is
designed to protect the network.

336
00:18:53.710 --> 00:18:57.810
We might have a server that we
install multiple network adapters, and

337
00:18:57.810 --> 00:19:01.810
we run a network based
firewall application on that.

338
00:19:01.810 --> 00:19:05.500
And that would provide protection for
the network.

339
00:19:05.500 --> 00:19:07.010
No reason we can't use both.

340
00:19:07.010 --> 00:19:12.352
There are many times I might have network
base firewalls in place, but on particular

341
00:19:12.352 --> 00:19:17.637
hosts I'm running software based firewalls
or host based firewalls I should say.

342
00:19:17.637 --> 00:19:20.311
In fact Windows, honestly,
is running a firewall by default.

343
00:19:20.311 --> 00:19:24.269
So if you've got a domain at
your corporate organization,

344
00:19:24.269 --> 00:19:28.228
they've got firewalls at your perimeter,
each one of your

345
00:19:28.228 --> 00:19:32.995
host has the firewall as well unless
they've disabled it, all right.

346
00:19:32.995 --> 00:19:40.050
Host based firewalls can
end up being a bottleneck.

347
00:19:40.050 --> 00:19:41.900
If we take a server and

348
00:19:41.900 --> 00:19:47.240
we try to install a firewall on there,
it can eat up a lot of resources.

349
00:19:47.240 --> 00:19:50.880
Especially of we start doing
some of that stateful or

350
00:19:50.880 --> 00:19:52.630
deep inspection on those packets.

351
00:19:52.630 --> 00:19:54.600
If you're talking about every
packet that comes through and

352
00:19:54.600 --> 00:19:57.220
I've got to take a look
inside that packet.

353
00:19:57.220 --> 00:20:01.110
It's going to throw network down, it's
going to cause a, something's going to

354
00:20:01.110 --> 00:20:06.550
bottleneck on that server,
whether it's CPU or memory or hard drive.

355
00:20:06.550 --> 00:20:08.519
At some point you're gonna
have a bottleneck there.

356
00:20:11.337 --> 00:20:12.050
What else?

357
00:20:12.050 --> 00:20:14.446
I think we've covered
hardware versus software.

358
00:20:14.446 --> 00:20:19.430
Other issues,
host OSs might not be as hardened as well

359
00:20:19.430 --> 00:20:24.780
as say a dedicated hardware firewall,
because again,

360
00:20:24.780 --> 00:20:26.900
we've run other applications on there.

361
00:20:26.900 --> 00:20:29.700
Those other applications can
introduce vulnerabilities.

362
00:20:29.700 --> 00:20:32.960
The operating system itself
can introduce vulnerabilities.

363
00:20:32.960 --> 00:20:36.480
So typically, not that you can't, but

364
00:20:36.480 --> 00:20:41.270
if we don't really take the time, usually
they're not going to be as hardened

365
00:20:41.270 --> 00:20:44.820
as say a dedicated hardware
based firewall, all right.

366
00:20:46.640 --> 00:20:47.520
The good thing though,

367
00:20:47.520 --> 00:20:50.100
I mean there are some upsides to
software based firewalls, I sit here and

368
00:20:50.100 --> 00:20:52.700
talk about them like they're the most
horrible thing in the world.

369
00:20:52.700 --> 00:20:56.733
And they're not, they're very cost
effective, they're not nearly as expensive

370
00:20:56.733 --> 00:20:59.928
as going out and buying a Juniper,
a Cisco hardware based router.

371
00:20:59.928 --> 00:21:04.530
I can get a software based firewall for
a lot less money.

372
00:21:04.530 --> 00:21:07.980
So if cost is a major concern,
if I'm a small organization, sure,

373
00:21:07.980 --> 00:21:11.790
I'd love to put one f those high end
firewalls at the border of our network,

374
00:21:11.790 --> 00:21:13.020
but I can't afford it.

375
00:21:13.020 --> 00:21:14.660
I can't justify that cost.

376
00:21:14.660 --> 00:21:17.900
So maybe I go with a software
based firewall cuz I can get

377
00:21:17.900 --> 00:21:21.050
what I need at a lot less cost.

378
00:21:22.170 --> 00:21:25.310
They're typically a lot
less complex to configure.

379
00:21:25.310 --> 00:21:29.470
There's probably a Wizard that comes with
it or some kind of graphical interface.

380
00:21:29.470 --> 00:21:32.830
And some of these hardware based one
are a lot more difficult to configure,

381
00:21:32.830 --> 00:21:36.680
you might have to use a special connection
to get to them, to configure them.

382
00:21:36.680 --> 00:21:39.370
Might not be in a language
that we're familiar with.

383
00:21:39.370 --> 00:21:43.190
Creating those rules can be very,
very complex.

384
00:21:43.190 --> 00:21:46.350
So, their software based might
be a lot easier to set up.

385
00:21:46.350 --> 00:21:51.170
So there are some pros to using
software based firewalls as well.

386
00:21:51.170 --> 00:21:56.790
So Wes, that is a,
I think it pretty much covers firewalls.

387
00:21:56.790 --> 00:21:58.910
>> You just gotta make sure that
you have them turned on, right.

388
00:21:58.910 --> 00:22:01.790
And one of the great things, one of the
things that you mentioned about firewalls

389
00:22:01.790 --> 00:22:05.570
that I love, you say they are less
expensive, right, cost effective.

390
00:22:05.570 --> 00:22:09.990
I love the fact that Windows comes
bundled with a firewall in there.

391
00:22:09.990 --> 00:22:12.050
Mike, I know you're, and
I'm going to age Mike here, and

392
00:22:12.050 --> 00:22:13.050
he probably won't like this one.

393
00:22:13.050 --> 00:22:16.210
But you've probably been around Windows
when you didn't have a firewall

394
00:22:16.210 --> 00:22:16.920
in it, right.

395
00:22:16.920 --> 00:22:19.220
You had to go to some third
party like Zone Alarm.

396
00:22:19.220 --> 00:22:20.780
I remember I used to get
one from Zone Alarm.

397
00:22:20.780 --> 00:22:23.510
And then somewhere around XP,
say, service pack two.

398
00:22:23.510 --> 00:22:24.500
>> Two, three yeah.

399
00:22:24.500 --> 00:22:25.430
>> Something like that.

400
00:22:25.430 --> 00:22:27.140
We started having them bundled in.

401
00:22:27.140 --> 00:22:29.580
So, a lot of good
information on firewalls.

402
00:22:29.580 --> 00:22:32.700
However, Mike, it does look like we
are coming to the end of another episode.

403
00:22:32.700 --> 00:22:37.170
But before we do, any final words when
it comes to firewalls in general?

404
00:22:37.170 --> 00:22:38.232
>> No, I think we're good.

405
00:22:38.232 --> 00:22:40.740
>> All right, well that's a great
place to wrap this one up.

406
00:22:40.740 --> 00:22:44.820
Signing out for ITPRO.TV,
remember, I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

407
00:22:44.820 --> 00:22:45.640
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

408
00:22:45.640 --> 00:22:48.247
>> And we will see you next time.

409
00:22:48.247 --> 00:22:54.690
[MUSIC]

410
00:22:54.690 --> 00:22:57.791
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

1

when you guys aren't looking, so

13

[LAUGH]
>> Sure, sure.

14

Hey listen,
I wanted to talk about something.

15
00:00:34.620 --> 00:00:39.273
Network Isolation,
network isolation what is that?

16
00:00:39.273 --> 00:00:40.482
Explain the whole model action.

17
00:00:40.482 --> 00:00:45.291
>> It's a great question and
we should expound on that topic, right?

18
00:00:45.291 --> 00:00:50.271
Network isolation, when you talk
about security in an IT networking,

19
00:00:50.271 --> 00:00:53.930
one of the techniques,
if I can speak English here.

20
00:00:53.930 --> 00:00:57.350
One of the techniques that we
will use is network isolation.

21
00:00:57.350 --> 00:01:00.838
We can isolate portions of our
network to provide different levels of

22
00:01:00.838 --> 00:01:01.869
security, right?

23
00:01:01.869 --> 00:01:05.273
Not everything on our network needs
the same level of security, and

24
00:01:05.273 --> 00:01:08.850
we can isolate things to further
control access to them as well.

25
00:01:08.850 --> 00:01:13.071
If it's isolated and hard to get to,
or there's limited ways to get to it,

26
00:01:13.071 --> 00:01:14.684
then I can control, right?

27
00:01:14.684 --> 00:01:19.060
It's like a certain movie we all know,
we say, you shall not pass.

28
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:22.700
If there is only one path to get in there,
I can block that path, or

29
00:01:22.700 --> 00:01:25.960
I can very well control who's
allowed to come through there.

30
00:01:25.960 --> 00:01:31.042
So that's really, in a broad sense,
what network isolation is about.

31
00:01:31.042 --> 00:01:34.490
So we'll talk about some of the different
techniques we can use to accomplish that.

32
00:01:34.490 --> 00:01:37.717
>> Fantastic.
And I guess a LAN comes into play here?

33
00:01:37.717 --> 00:01:42.300
>> Yeah, if we're gonna talk about network
isolation we need to understand some basic

34
00:01:42.300 --> 00:01:44.050
networking concepts, right?

35
00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:46.007
And I know most of you
are already familiar with this.

36
00:01:46.007 --> 00:01:47.370
Just a real quick refresh.

37
00:01:47.370 --> 00:01:52.250
When we talk about a LAN,
a local area network, we're talking about

38
00:01:52.250 --> 00:01:57.120
a group of devices that are connected,
that are typically in

39
00:01:57.120 --> 00:02:01.280
a single geographical location,
and under a single administration.

40
00:02:01.280 --> 00:02:05.800
Like your office building might
be your corporate LAN, or if you

41
00:02:05.800 --> 00:02:10.100
have a single floor in a tall building
that you own, that might be your LAN.

42
00:02:10.100 --> 00:02:14.794
At your house, all of your devices,
your computer, your DVD player,

43
00:02:14.794 --> 00:02:16.606
your smart TV and all that.

44
00:02:16.606 --> 00:02:20.030
Theyre all connected together and
that is your own personal local

45
00:02:20.030 --> 00:02:24.730
area network that you operate, right,
thats under your administration.

46
00:02:24.730 --> 00:02:28.797
Now, LANs are, when we connect
a computer to a LAN like that, the way

47
00:02:28.797 --> 00:02:33.496
ethernet works, we have to think about
the types of traffic we see on there, and

48
00:02:33.496 --> 00:02:37.803
we remember that theres unicast,
multicast and broadcast traffic.

49
00:02:37.803 --> 00:02:41.822
And if you remember, broadcast traffic
is when there's no destination,

50
00:02:41.822 --> 00:02:44.385
you send it out to everybody on the LAN.

51
00:02:44.385 --> 00:02:46.750
Kinda like if you were in a group
of people sitting at a table and

52
00:02:46.750 --> 00:02:48.960
you talk loudly so everybody can hear you.

53
00:02:48.960 --> 00:02:51.180
You're not talking
specifically to one person.

54
00:02:51.180 --> 00:02:53.414
You're talking to everybody in the group,
right?

55
00:02:53.414 --> 00:02:58.857
And that's fine, but as we start
adding more and more and more devices

another issue with some of these

281
00:15:21.045 --> 00:15:22.220
software-based routers.

282
00:15:22.220 --> 00:15:26.060
They might not run the latest and
greatest routing protocol,

283
00:15:26.060 --> 00:15:28.080
which we're gonna talk about later.

284
00:15:28.080 --> 00:15:32.600
Like 2008, I think it was,
only supported RIP, or an old,

285
00:15:32.600 --> 00:15:34.900
which is an older routing protocol.

286
00:15:34.900 --> 00:15:36.940
So that could be an issue as well.

287
00:15:36.940 --> 00:15:37.940
You look at the hardware side.

288
00:15:37.940 --> 00:15:41.250
And I'll say it one more time and
I promise I won't say it again.

289
00:15:41.250 --> 00:15:44.040
Just like hardware-based firewalls, right?

290
00:15:44.040 --> 00:15:48.538
Benefits, performance, dedicated
hardware that does nothing but routing.

291
00:15:48.538 --> 00:15:53.987
Now granted in today's routers, we do
sometimes see multiple services DHCP,

292
00:15:53.987 --> 00:15:59.047
firewall, some other things like that,
but it's dedicated hardware.

293
00:15:59.047 --> 00:16:01.988
That does nothing but primarily routing.

294
00:16:01.988 --> 00:16:05.250
So we usually get great performance,
great reliability.

295
00:16:05.250 --> 00:16:06.860
They don't need updates.

296
00:16:06.860 --> 00:16:10.120
We don't have other software
that needs updates and reboots.

297
00:16:10.120 --> 00:16:15.800
Occasionally, you have to update your
firmware but very stable and reliable.

298
00:16:15.800 --> 00:16:20.210
And typically a wide protocol support
on these hardware based routers.

299
00:16:20.210 --> 00:16:23.220
But they're gonna cost me more money,
right?

300
00:16:23.220 --> 00:16:26.415
Go out and price them some routers and
see what you get.

301
00:16:26.415 --> 00:16:30.746
Depending on what you're trying to buy,
they can go from expensive to very, very,

302
00:16:30.746 --> 00:16:31.665
very expensive.

303
00:16:31.665 --> 00:16:34.805
Configuration can be very tricky.

304
00:16:34.805 --> 00:16:38.811
A lot of them you have to do a secure
shell or a special connection to get to,

305
00:16:38.811 --> 00:16:41.593
and you're using command
line to configure them,

306
00:16:41.593 --> 00:16:45.236
so it's not like your everyday
server admin or network admin job.

307
00:16:45.236 --> 00:16:49.347
You've gotta know these new set of
rules or languages to type in or

308
00:16:49.347 --> 00:16:51.231
to configure these routers.

309
00:16:51.231 --> 00:16:54.364
And it can be complex setting
up routing and thinking about,

310
00:16:54.364 --> 00:16:57.750
okay I've got a route there but
is there a route back, all right?

311
00:16:57.750 --> 00:17:00.482
So the traffic can get out and
you're wondering what's happening, but

312
00:17:00.482 --> 00:17:01.620
it's never able to get back.

313
00:17:01.620 --> 00:17:03.775
So they can be much more complex to setup.

314
00:17:05.820 --> 00:17:06.715
>> Question for you?

315
00:17:06.715 --> 00:17:07.610
>> Absolutely.

316
00:17:07.610 --> 00:17:10.805
>> So now we've been talking
about routers, and software, and

317
00:17:10.805 --> 00:17:11.930
hardware, and LAN.

318
00:17:11.930 --> 00:17:13.301
And how does this all work?

319
00:17:13.301 --> 00:17:15.384
How does this all come together and
how does it all work?

320
00:17:15.384 --> 00:17:19.034
>> Well, routers have what they
call a routing table, right again,

321
00:17:19.034 --> 00:17:22.050
think back to what we
started at the beginning.

322
00:17:22.050 --> 00:17:24.870
Routers connect multiple
networks together.

323
00:17:24.870 --> 00:17:28.679
So a router keeps track of what
networks it's connected to.

324
00:17:28.679 --> 00:17:29.879
Let's see, we'll keep it real simple.

325
00:17:29.879 --> 00:17:32.131
We'll say I got a four port router.

326
00:17:32.131 --> 00:17:37.878
And it's got one interface
connected to 192.168.1.0/24.

327
00:17:37.878 --> 00:17:41.756
Another interface is connected to 2.0/24.

328
00:17:41.756 --> 00:17:44.729
And you get the idea,
another one is 3.0 and 4.0.

329
00:17:44.729 --> 00:17:48.888
And in its table,
it's gonna keep track of that information.

330
00:17:48.888 --> 00:17:53.418
So that it knows, okay, interface 1,
any traffic that comes to me, and has

331
00:17:53.418 --> 00:17:58.880
a destination of 192.168.1., something,
I know to send it out to interface 1.

332
00:17:58.880 --> 00:18:02.466
Cuz I can look at my table, and
I know that's the network that's

333
00:18:02.466 --> 00:18:05.600
connected to that particular
interface on the router.

334
00:18:06.680 --> 00:18:09.540
Though they keep tables so
that they know what they're connected to.

335
00:18:11.150 --> 00:18:16.800
They also can keep information about what
their neighbor routers are connected to.

336
00:18:16.800 --> 00:18:19.725
So not only do they know
what they're connected to,

337
00:18:19.725 --> 00:18:24.118
but routers that they're connected to,
they get their information as well.

338
00:18:24.118 --> 00:18:27.111
Routers share this information, we'll
come back to that concept in a minute.

339
00:18:27.111 --> 00:18:30.810
Now that table,
how does that information get populated?

340
00:18:30.810 --> 00:18:33.800
How do we get that
information in that table?

341
00:18:33.800 --> 00:18:34.850
And we can do it statically.

342
00:18:34.850 --> 00:18:38.230
In other words, I can go to my
administrative console from my router and

343
00:18:38.230 --> 00:18:39.850
I can type all that information in.

344
00:18:39.850 --> 00:18:42.040
That's known as static configuration.

345
00:18:43.390 --> 00:18:45.990
Just like when we always
talk about static,

346
00:18:45.990 --> 00:18:47.610
the problem with that is it never changes.

347
00:18:47.610 --> 00:18:49.150
It's a very manual process.

348
00:18:49.150 --> 00:18:50.650
I have to go in there and do that.

349
00:18:50.650 --> 00:18:55.070
If anything changes, I have to manually
go in there and update that information.

350
00:18:55.070 --> 00:19:03.050
So very small, very static environment,
static routing tables might work okay.

351
00:19:03.050 --> 00:19:07.870
Also in some high security environments,
we might prefer to go static.

352
00:19:07.870 --> 00:19:13.680
Because there's no way other routers, bad
guys running rogue routers trying to slip

353
00:19:13.680 --> 00:19:18.590
bad routing information into my router so
that it routes information the wrong way

354
00:19:18.590 --> 00:19:22.630
and it gets outside of my network and
they can steal it, or something like that.

355
00:19:22.630 --> 00:19:27.290
With manual, you've gotta get into
the router to configure those routes.

356
00:19:27.290 --> 00:19:29.020
And I can see in a high
security environment,

357
00:19:29.020 --> 00:19:31.910
static might be a benefit, right?

358
00:19:31.910 --> 00:19:35.430
But normally,
routers are set up dynamically.

359
00:19:35.430 --> 00:19:37.660
Especially the ones that we
don't deal with everyday.

360
00:19:37.660 --> 00:19:40.520
The ones out on the internet
that allow us to

361
00:19:40.520 --> 00:19:44.610
connect to all the wonderful resources
out there in the world wide web.

362
00:19:44.610 --> 00:19:45.540
Those are gonna be dynamic.

363
00:19:45.540 --> 00:19:48.750
Nobody goes in and
manually updates those routing tables.

364
00:19:50.900 --> 00:19:54.460
They get their information
by using routing protocols.

365
00:19:54.460 --> 00:19:59.210
Languages that we can use,
that routers use to talk to each other.

366
00:19:59.210 --> 00:20:02.210
So when you plug in a new router
in a dynamic environment,

367
00:20:02.210 --> 00:20:04.910
it doesn't know anything, right, blank.

368
00:20:04.910 --> 00:20:07.350
You plug that first cable into it, and

369
00:20:07.350 --> 00:20:10.250
it learns what that network
is by the traffic coming in.

370
00:20:10.250 --> 00:20:14.394
All that traffic is gonna be coming from
a particular subnet, and so it learns.

371
00:20:14.394 --> 00:20:18.720
It says, hey, all this traffic
is coming from 192.168.1.0/24,

372
00:20:18.720 --> 00:20:21.677
that must be the network
that's out in that interface.

373
00:20:21.677 --> 00:20:25.897
It's gonna start building that table, and
then other routers that are connected to

374
00:20:25.897 --> 00:20:28.643
that network,
they'll start talking to each other.

375
00:20:28.643 --> 00:20:32.270
Well, hey, I see you're connected to
one and two, I'm connected to subnet 3.

376
00:20:32.270 --> 00:20:35.710
So if you ever need to send anything to
subnet 3, I know you're not connected to

377
00:20:35.710 --> 00:20:38.830
it, just send it to me and
I'll pass it on to subnet 3, right?

378
00:20:38.830 --> 00:20:42.390
This is how they start sharing
their information in building

379
00:20:42.390 --> 00:20:46.450
basically a layout or a map so
they learn where are these networks are.

380
00:20:46.450 --> 00:20:49.920
And now that first router says,
okay I'm connected to one and two, but

381
00:20:49.920 --> 00:20:51.900
I've got a buddy that's
connected to subnet 3.

382
00:20:51.900 --> 00:20:55.150
So if any traffic comes in for subnet 1,
I can send it right over there.

383
00:20:55.150 --> 00:20:58.060
If it comes in for subnet 2,
I can send it right over there.

384
00:20:58.060 --> 00:21:01.650
If it comes in for subnet 3,
I'm not connected to subnet 3 but

385
00:21:01.650 --> 00:21:02.450
I know somebody that is.

386
00:21:02.450 --> 00:21:05.598
I'll send it to him and
he can send it to subnet 3, right?

387
00:21:05.598 --> 00:21:09.449
So they start sharing the information and
building those routing tables up and

388
00:21:09.449 --> 00:21:10.799
that's dynamic routing.

389
00:21:12.870 --> 00:21:13.762
All right.
>> Protocols.

390
00:21:13.762 --> 00:21:14.672
>> Sure, protocol.

391
00:21:14.672 --> 00:21:15.490
>> Do we have time for this?

392
00:21:15.490 --> 00:21:17.830
Okay, so
you mentioned protocols before and

393
00:21:17.830 --> 00:21:20.350
I know that's what you were
alluding to here a second ago.

394
00:21:20.350 --> 00:21:21.700
That's a set of rules, right?

395
00:21:21.700 --> 00:21:25.450
It's like this is the way it is,
it cannot be changed.

396
00:21:25.450 --> 00:21:26.330
>> It's exactly right.

397
00:21:26.330 --> 00:21:28.560
It is a set of rules for communicating.

398
00:21:28.560 --> 00:21:30.050
It's just like a language, right?

399
00:21:30.050 --> 00:21:34.950
We have rules in the English language and
every other language has rules, right?

400
00:21:34.950 --> 00:21:36.570
How you conjugate verbs.

401
00:21:36.570 --> 00:21:40.200
How you have nouns and verbs and create
sentences so that we can communicate.

402
00:21:40.200 --> 00:21:44.445
Cuz if there were no rules and I could say
whatever I wanted in any order I wanted

403
00:21:44.445 --> 00:21:47.205
it, would be difficult to communicate,
right?

404
00:21:47.205 --> 00:21:48.157
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

405
00:21:48.157 --> 00:21:52.335
>> Well, routers, when they share
information, they use a protocol which is

406
00:21:52.335 --> 00:21:57.330
a language, or a set of rules of how
they go about sharing that information.

407
00:21:57.330 --> 00:21:59.690
Now, there are different
protocols that we can implement.

408
00:21:59.690 --> 00:22:03.727
There's a couple that are called out
in particular on the exam objective for

409
00:22:03.727 --> 00:22:04.303
this MTA.

410
00:22:04.303 --> 00:22:05.060
>> Which is important.

411
00:22:05.060 --> 00:22:06.470
>> Yes, which is definitely important.

412
00:22:06.470 --> 00:22:07.810
So we wanna make sure we cover those.

413
00:22:09.910 --> 00:22:14.550
What I should say, these are classes
of protocols rather than an individual

414
00:22:14.550 --> 00:22:19.430
protocol, like distance vector
is a type of routing protocol.

415
00:22:19.430 --> 00:22:23.020
Link state is another
type of routing protocol,

416
00:22:23.020 --> 00:22:26.720
there are examples like rip is
a distance vector protocol.

417
00:22:26.720 --> 00:22:30.630
OSPF is a link state routing protocol,
right?

418
00:22:30.630 --> 00:22:31.680
So what we're talking about here,

419
00:22:31.680 --> 00:22:35.790
just the classes of protocols
not specific protocols.

420
00:22:35.790 --> 00:22:40.367
When we're talking about distance vector,
this is an over routing protocols and

421
00:22:40.367 --> 00:22:45.170
it used to work great until we had the
internet or all these wonderful things.

422
00:22:45.170 --> 00:22:48.980
Distance vector, when the routers
share their information and

423
00:22:48.980 --> 00:22:53.860
they're using a distance vector protocol,
they send their entire routing table.

424
00:22:53.860 --> 00:22:57.650
If there's ever a change to that routing
table on a scheduled interval, or

425
00:22:57.650 --> 00:23:02.140
when there's changes,
they will resend the entire routing table.

426
00:23:02.140 --> 00:23:04.697
Now this routing table
can start to get big.

427
00:23:04.697 --> 00:23:06.848
And only one thing might
have changed on there, or

428
00:23:06.848 --> 00:23:08.497
it's just they're scheduled time.

429
00:23:08.497 --> 00:23:11.595
They will again send
the entire routing table,

430
00:23:11.595 --> 00:23:16.110
which can generate unnecessary
traffic on my network.

431
00:23:16.110 --> 00:23:19.578
So it's not the most efficient
of routing protocols, but

432
00:23:19.578 --> 00:23:21.558
back in the day with Ubrban net and

433
00:23:21.558 --> 00:23:26.260
then back before we had the world wide web
as we know it now, it was not that bad.

434
00:23:26.260 --> 00:23:27.590
It worked just fine.

435
00:23:29.590 --> 00:23:34.500
The issues we have with it now though
is that there's a lot of overhead to

436
00:23:34.500 --> 00:23:37.610
distance vector protocols,
and it doesn't scale well.

437
00:23:37.610 --> 00:23:41.900
Distance vector, there's many
different metrics that we can use.

438
00:23:41.900 --> 00:23:44.920
But distance vector uses
something known as a hop count.

439
00:23:44.920 --> 00:23:50.195
And that is how many routers I have to
go through to get to the destination.

440
00:23:50.195 --> 00:23:53.345
So if I say subnet C is two hops away,

441
00:23:53.345 --> 00:23:58.806
that means there's two routers
between the subnet I'm on And

442
00:23:58.806 --> 00:24:02.180
Subnet C, the destination, right?

443
00:24:04.660 --> 00:24:07.170
Distance vector has a limit of 15 hops.

444
00:24:08.350 --> 00:24:12.100
It's really 16,
it's 0 through 15 if I'm not mistaken.

445
00:24:12.100 --> 00:24:14.422
But there's a limit to
the number of hops it can take.

446
00:24:14.422 --> 00:24:18.700
And every router a packet goes through,
it's gonna decrement or

447
00:24:18.700 --> 00:24:21.190
reduce that hop count by one.

448
00:24:21.190 --> 00:24:25.820
And when it gets to zero, the packet
gets dropped, it can go no further.

449
00:24:25.820 --> 00:24:27.960
Which, again, was okay on small networks.

450
00:24:27.960 --> 00:24:29.630
But think about the Internet
that we have today.

451
00:24:29.630 --> 00:24:35.450
If I'm visiting some website, there could
be 15, 30 routers between me, who knows?

452
00:24:35.450 --> 00:24:38.650
And the point is is this
inspector won't go that far.

453
00:24:38.650 --> 00:24:41.100
It'll get to 15 hops and it'll just stop.

454
00:24:41.100 --> 00:24:44.160
Even if the destination
was 1 more hop away, or

455
00:24:44.160 --> 00:24:46.760
30 hops away,
it's not gonna make it there.

456
00:24:46.760 --> 00:24:48.890
So it doesn't work on the Internet.

457
00:24:48.890 --> 00:24:52.725
There are some other big issues
that we have with distance vector.

458
00:24:52.725 --> 00:24:56.720
Things like it takes a long time for
conversions.

459
00:24:56.720 --> 00:25:03.970
If there's a change, it doesn't trigger
the sharing of that information.

460
00:25:03.970 --> 00:25:07.610
The next scheduled share,
they will share the routing information.

461
00:25:09.160 --> 00:25:11.323
So convergence can take a while.

462
00:25:11.323 --> 00:25:16.950
Convergence is basically how long does it
take a change till everybody knows it.

463
00:25:16.950 --> 00:25:19.550
I might change something, but
Zach doesnt know about it yet.

464
00:25:19.550 --> 00:25:20.740
And eventually, I'll tell Zach.

465
00:25:20.740 --> 00:25:22.090
Zach will tell Peter.

466
00:25:22.090 --> 00:25:23.125
Peter will tell Titus.

467
00:25:23.125 --> 00:25:24.780
And eventually,
we all know about it, right?

468
00:25:24.780 --> 00:25:25.590
Thats convergence,

469
00:25:25.590 --> 00:25:29.290
how long does it take before everybody
is aware of a change like that?

470
00:25:29.290 --> 00:25:30.612
>> Two and a half minutes.

471
00:25:30.612 --> 00:25:35.050
>> Yeah [LAUGH] and with distance vector,
that convergence time is very long.

472
00:25:35.050 --> 00:25:37.683
We end up with two other big
issues with distance vector.

473
00:25:37.683 --> 00:25:41.548
And that is routing loops and
count to infinity problems.

474
00:25:41.548 --> 00:25:44.111
>> Well, Mike, I wanna hear all about
the protocols because it's very,

475
00:25:44.111 --> 00:25:44.760
very important.

But it's gonna have to be in

477
00:25:48.932 --> 00:25:52.140
And just give us a wrap up
of what we've gone through.

478
00:25:52.140 --> 00:25:54.860
>> Absolutely, yeah, so far we've
talked about some basics of networking.

479
00:25:54.860 --> 00:25:57.530
We talked about local area networks and
how they work.

480
00:25:57.530 --> 00:26:00.340
And we talked about broadcast and
how we can use VLANs,

481
00:26:00.340 --> 00:26:03.940
or virtual LANs to segment out that LAN.

482
00:26:03.940 --> 00:26:07.410
To make broadcast domains
without the use of routers.

483
00:26:07.410 --> 00:26:08.700
Then we talked about routers.

484
00:26:08.700 --> 00:26:10.550
And hardware and software based routers.

485
00:26:10.550 --> 00:26:11.755
And pros and cons of each.

486
00:26:11.755 --> 00:26:15.699
And then we started talking about how
routers work with the routing table.

487
00:26:15.699 --> 00:26:19.590
And the different protocols they use

00:25:59.110 --> 00:26:00.050
Yes, it does.
>> [LAUGH]

463
00:26:00.050 --> 00:26:01.920
>> And so what'll happen is it won't work.

464
00:26:01.920 --> 00:26:06.200
Your packet won't ever go, cuz it's
going to fail the integrity check and

465
00:26:06.200 --> 00:26:11.430
drop the packet, so initially IPsec and
NAT did not play along at all.

466
00:26:11.430 --> 00:26:15.780
We'll talk about in a little bit,
how they fixed some of that

467
00:26:15.780 --> 00:26:19.325
with IPsec, right?
>> Do we have enough time to go into

468
00:26:19.325 --> 00:26:22.120
something else you think?
>> You know what, let's go ahead and

469
00:26:22.120 --> 00:26:25.330
define a VPN and then we'll stop there,
before we get in IPsec,

470
00:26:25.330 --> 00:26:27.990
cuz that will be a lengthy
conversation there.

471
00:26:27.990 --> 00:26:31.715
So the last thing we'll talk about
in this episode would be a VPN or

472
00:26:31.715 --> 00:26:33.768
a Virtual Private Network, okay.

473
00:26:33.768 --> 00:26:38.580
VPN, short for Virtual Private Network
is a way that I can protect

474
00:26:38.580 --> 00:26:43.407
my data as it travels across
public infrastructure, all right?

475
00:26:43.407 --> 00:26:46.407
Let's look at this way, you've got your
corporate office sitting there and

476
00:26:46.407 --> 00:26:48.010
it's connect to the Internet.

477
00:26:48.010 --> 00:26:51.910
You're at home or you're at a hotel and
you're connected to the Internet.

478
00:26:51.910 --> 00:26:54.556
And the Internet is just one big,
fat mesh network.

479
00:26:54.556 --> 00:26:55.770
So, if your a corporate office and

480
00:26:55.770 --> 00:26:59.200
you are both connected to this
mesh network, doesn't it seem like

481
00:26:59.200 --> 00:27:02.340
you should be able to connect to
your work network from your hotel?

482
00:27:02.340 --> 00:27:03.720
And the answer is yes, you can.

483
00:27:03.720 --> 00:27:06.037
Absolutely or from home or
from wherever you are,

484
00:27:06.037 --> 00:27:07.867
if you're connected to the Internet.

485
00:27:07.867 --> 00:27:11.482
Great, well great, but
not so great, right?

486
00:27:11.482 --> 00:27:13.280
There's an issue we gotta deal with.

487
00:27:13.280 --> 00:27:18.940
Remember, between me and my corporate
network is this Internet and who-

488
00:27:18.940 --> 00:27:19.820
>> Bad actors.

489
00:27:19.820 --> 00:27:21.089
>> Yes, lots of bad actors,

490
00:27:21.089 --> 00:27:23.585
lots of threats out there
that we have to deal with.

491
00:27:23.585 --> 00:27:26.977
Lots of people trying to see my data and
capture my information and

492
00:27:26.977 --> 00:27:28.740
do no who knows what with?

493
00:27:28.740 --> 00:27:33.110
So before I just go send my data across
the Internet to get to work network,

494
00:27:33.110 --> 00:27:34.520
I need to protect it.

495
00:27:34.520 --> 00:27:38.980
And that's what VPNs do,
they create a virtual private network.

496
00:27:38.980 --> 00:27:41.298
It's not a private network,
it's the Internet, it's public.

497
00:27:41.298 --> 00:27:45.880
But we're gonna create what we like to
refer to as a tunnel through the Internet,

498
00:27:45.880 --> 00:27:48.140
that my traffic can travel through and

499
00:27:48.140 --> 00:27:51.260
nobody can get to because
the tunnel is protecting it.

500
00:27:51.260 --> 00:27:54.340
Now we obviously don't go out and
lay tunnels down or anything like that.

501
00:27:54.340 --> 00:27:57.880
But we use protocols that
will wrap up our packets

502
00:27:57.880 --> 00:28:00.700
in a way that the outside
world can't get to them.

503
00:28:00.700 --> 00:28:04.030
They might see them go by, but they
can't get inside them to figure out what

504
00:28:04.030 --> 00:28:07.870
they are and that is what VPNs or
virtual private networks are all about.

505
00:28:07.870 --> 00:28:11.040
And there's really three big use cases for
VPNs.

506
00:28:11.040 --> 00:28:13.820
You're usually talking about
a branch office connecting back to

507
00:28:13.820 --> 00:28:15.140
a corporate office.

508
00:28:15.140 --> 00:28:18.060
A remote user being at home or
the hotel or

509
00:28:18.060 --> 00:28:20.660
whatever, connecting back
to the corporate office.

510
00:28:20.660 --> 00:28:25.190
Or a business partner, giving a business
partner remote access to resources on your

511
00:28:25.190 --> 00:28:28.470
network, like web apps to order product or

512
00:28:28.470 --> 00:28:30.650
check on the status of an order or
whatever the case may be.

513
00:28:30.650 --> 00:28:33.780
And we'll talk about those
more when we come back.

514
00:28:33.780 --> 00:28:35.320
>> Yes, there's gonna be a part three.

515
00:28:35.320 --> 00:28:36.715
>> Surprise, surprise.

516
00:28:36.715 --> 00:28:38.070
[LAUGH]
>> Network isolation.

517
00:28:38.070 --> 00:28:40.420
But you know you want it and
it's great information.

518
00:28:40.420 --> 00:28:42.770
And can you just wrap up real
quick what we just discussed?

519
00:28:42.770 --> 00:28:43.981
>> I forgot everything we just

520
00:28:43.981 --> 00:28:44.670
talked about.

521
00:28:44.670 --> 00:28:45.430
Let me go back and look.

522
00:28:45.430 --> 00:28:49.120
So we talked about, we finished up
talking about distance vector and

523
00:28:49.120 --> 00:28:52.090
some of the weaknesses there,
routing loops, count to infinity.

524
00:28:52.090 --> 00:28:53.500
We also talked about link state,

525
00:28:53.500 --> 00:28:56.860
a different class of routing protocols
that work in a different way and

526
00:28:56.860 --> 00:28:59.960
avoid some of the issues we
have with our distance vectors.

527
00:28:59.960 --> 00:29:01.740
We talked about what a honey pot was.

528
00:29:01.740 --> 00:29:04.620
We talked about perimeter networks and

529
00:29:04.620 --> 00:29:08.610
how we can do them with a sandwich
type situation with two firewalls and

530
00:29:08.610 --> 00:29:14.330
a DMZ in between or a single firewall
with multiple interfaces to set that up.

531
00:29:14.330 --> 00:29:16.850
And then we talked about
network address translation.

532
00:29:16.850 --> 00:29:17.410

00:29:17.410 --> 00:29:18.940
>> And we wrapped it up with VPNs.

00:29:18.940 --> 00:29:20.120
>> That's right, wonderful job

00:29:20.120 --> 00:29:24.270
as usual Mike, fantastic, can't wait for

There's a whole bunch in this series,

And you have access to that
because you're an IT pro.

00:29:32.840 --> 00:29:36.290
And did you know that an IT pro,
a good IT pro is always learning.

I'm Zach Memos.

541
00:29:38.090 --> 00:29:39.006

6

7
00:00:26.570 --> 00:00:28.280

8
00:00:28.280 --> 00:00:29.525
This smart guy right there.

9

>> And Mike Rodrick,

Part three.

12
00:00:32.310 --> 00:00:35.030
>> Part three, I know, it's another
one of those darn miniseries, right?

13
00:00:35.030 --> 00:00:36.320
>> Yeah.
>> I'm getting good at this.

14
00:00:36.320 --> 00:00:36.990
>> I love them, a lot.

15
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:37.920
>> All right, but

16
00:00:37.920 --> 00:00:41.500
yeah, there's a lot of information
when it comes to network isolation.

17
00:00:41.500 --> 00:00:45.190
So we left of Zach talking about VPNs and

18
00:00:45.190 --> 00:00:48.140
now what we're gonna do is talk about
a couple of the different protocols or

19
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:51.730
ways we can create VPNs, or
at least the ones they call on the exam.

20
00:00:51.730 --> 00:00:53.670
Cuz there are several out there.

21
00:00:53.670 --> 00:00:56.495
But for this one-
>> IPsec.

22
00:00:56.495 --> 00:00:58.560
>> IPsec it is, that's where we'll start.

23
00:00:58.560 --> 00:00:59.850
We had a couple to choose from.

24
00:00:59.850 --> 00:01:02.087
Access IPsec that's where
we'll go first then.

25
00:01:02.087 --> 00:01:02.623
>> Thank you.

26
00:01:02.623 --> 00:01:07.385
>> So IPsec is actually protocol suite,
IPsec is short for

27
00:01:07.385 --> 00:01:14.390
IP security which is really short for
still for Internet Protocol security.

28
00:01:14.390 --> 00:01:18.100
It is a way to add security
to Internet protocol.

29
00:01:18.100 --> 00:01:22.207
That protocol we use to send packets
back and forth on the Internet,

30
00:01:22.207 --> 00:01:24.490
we're on a TCP/IP based network.

31
00:01:24.490 --> 00:01:26.710
I should say not necessarily the Internet.

32
00:01:26.710 --> 00:01:28.100
So it is a set of standards.

33
00:01:28.100 --> 00:01:28.810
And it is a suite.

34
00:01:28.810 --> 00:01:33.590
In other words, there is more than
one protocol, it's not just a single

35
00:01:33.590 --> 00:01:38.230
set of rules but as long as we know it's
a suite I think we are good enough there.

36
00:01:38.230 --> 00:01:40.630
But again,
way to secure IP communications.

37
00:01:40.630 --> 00:01:42.220
Other important thing we
want to know about this,

38
00:01:42.220 --> 00:01:45.718
is it operates at layer
3 of our OSI model.

39
00:01:45.718 --> 00:01:48.130
And I might think well,
why is that important?

40
00:01:48.130 --> 00:01:52.640
I'll tell you why it's important because
it's operating way down on the OSI model.

41
00:01:52.640 --> 00:01:57.290
Remember your OSI model all people
seem to need delicious pizza.

42
00:01:57.290 --> 00:02:00.590
If I have to translate that
out application layer,

43
00:02:02.110 --> 00:02:06.470
presentation layer, session, transport,
network, data link, physical.

44
00:02:06.470 --> 00:02:09.290
If I didn't skip any of those
there it should of been seven.

45
00:02:09.290 --> 00:02:13.870
We're way down on layer three,
we're at the network layer.

46
00:02:13.870 --> 00:02:17.282
Have to double check myself there
do my little acronym real quick.

47
00:02:17.282 --> 00:02:18.590
With IPsec,

48
00:02:18.590 --> 00:02:22.566
the reason that's advantageous is my
applications are up here at layer seven.

49
00:02:22.566 --> 00:02:27.000
At my application layer, my presentation
layer what this means to us

50
00:02:27.000 --> 00:02:31.230
is that IPsec can be used with
just about any application.

51
00:02:31.230 --> 00:02:35.325
The application doesn't have
to understand IPsec, so

52
00:02:35.325 --> 00:02:38.469
it makes it a very
convenient thing to use.

53
00:02:38.469 --> 00:02:41.631
Because by the time the traffic gets
down to IPsec it takes care of it,

54
00:02:41.631 --> 00:02:44.694
it protects it it travels across
a network it gets to the other end.

55
00:02:44.694 --> 00:02:46.755
It goes back up the OSI model,

56
00:02:46.755 --> 00:02:51.360
the IPsec's removed well before
the application gets the data.

57
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:55.220
So the application doesn't have to
be aware, which is a good thing.

58
00:02:55.220 --> 00:02:59.600
Like with, say, SSL,
this occurs in your browser.

59
00:02:59.600 --> 00:03:04.950
So the application itself has to be
coded to understand how to work SSL.

60
00:03:04.950 --> 00:03:06.660
Now with IPsec that's not the case.

61
00:03:07.750 --> 00:03:10.410
IPsec is actually now a part of IPv6.

62
00:03:10.410 --> 00:03:13.110
It was an add-on for IPv4.

63
00:03:13.110 --> 00:03:18.690
With IPv4 security, when IPv4,
if I can slow down a little bit,

64
00:03:18.690 --> 00:03:23.230
was developed, security was not
at the forefront like it is now.

65
00:03:23.230 --> 00:03:27.460
It wasn't our top concern because
of our smaller isolated networks.

66
00:03:27.460 --> 00:03:32.090
Didn't have thought the Internet and
the World Wide Web as we see it today.

67
00:03:32.090 --> 00:03:36.400
So, as the World Wide Web and
the Internet came out and

68
00:03:36.400 --> 00:03:40.995
we saw our security issues,
IPsec was kind of bolted on to IPv4.

69
00:03:40.995 --> 00:03:46.185
So it worked but add-ons never work as
well as if you design it from the ground

70
00:03:46.185 --> 00:03:49.795
up with this built in and
that is the way IPv6 is.

71
00:03:49.795 --> 00:03:51.561
But back to what we want to talk about,
and

72
00:03:51.561 --> 00:03:53.360
that's a little bit about IPsec itself.

73
00:03:53.360 --> 00:03:58.170
IPsec is a protocol we can
use to create tunnels.

74
00:03:58.170 --> 00:03:59.500
Now we said with the VPN or

75
00:03:59.500 --> 00:04:03.340
a virtual private network we're gonna
tunnel through insecure portions of

76
00:04:03.340 --> 00:04:09.640
a network like the Internet to create
a secure way to send data back and forth.

77
00:04:09.640 --> 00:04:11.900
And IPsec can be used to do that.

78
00:04:13.280 --> 00:04:18.730
Now there is three big components that
we need to be familiar with with IPsec.

79
00:04:18.730 --> 00:04:21.580
There is something known
as authentication header,

80
00:04:21.580 --> 00:04:25.170
there is something known as
encapsulating security payload.

81
00:04:25.170 --> 00:04:28.570
And there is also something
known as Internet key exchange.

82
00:04:28.570 --> 00:04:31.180
And we'll talk about each one
of these pieces of IPsec.

83
00:04:31.180 --> 00:04:35.040
So these are the inner
workings of IPsec if you will.

84
00:04:35.040 --> 00:04:40.180
Authentication header or For
short, is a way to provide

85
00:04:40.180 --> 00:04:45.450
integrity for packet headers, for
data, for user authentication.

86
00:04:45.450 --> 00:04:49.890
If you go back to some of our previous
episodes, we talked about the CIA triad,

87
00:04:49.890 --> 00:04:51.845
we talked about what integrity is.

88
00:04:51.845 --> 00:04:57.330
So a way to make sure that something has
not been modified either accidentally or

89
00:04:57.330 --> 00:04:58.500
maliciously.

90
00:04:58.500 --> 00:05:01.620
So when I say authentication header
provides integrity for data packets,

91
00:05:01.620 --> 00:05:04.170
data headers, for user authentication,

92
00:05:04.170 --> 00:05:09.850
what I'm saying is that packet leaves
the source it gets digitally signed.

93
00:05:09.850 --> 00:05:14.760
And when it gets to the other end,
that digital signature is verified

94
00:05:14.760 --> 00:05:19.140
to make sure it still matches the data in
that packet or the header in that packet.

95
00:05:19.140 --> 00:05:22.060
Whatever we are trying
put that protections for.

96
00:05:22.060 --> 00:05:25.000
If it doesn't match anymore I
know something's been modified,

97
00:05:25.000 --> 00:05:29.280
I don't know how I don't know why but
I know it's not what was originally sent.

98
00:05:29.280 --> 00:05:31.430
So I drop the packet and
I say, send it again.

99
00:05:31.430 --> 00:05:35.150
And hopefully this time I'll get the
actual packet the way it was meant to be.

100
00:05:35.150 --> 00:05:39.430
That is what we mean when we say
authentication header provides integrity.

101
00:05:39.430 --> 00:05:44.350
It can also provide some replay attack,
replay protection,

102
00:05:44.350 --> 00:05:45.920
I should say, not replay attack.

103
00:05:45.920 --> 00:05:48.370
To protect against replay attacks.

104
00:05:48.370 --> 00:05:51.360
Somebody capturing packets and
trying to reuse them later.

105
00:05:51.360 --> 00:05:56.610
But another key we want to remember about
authentication headers It doesn't encrypt.

106
00:05:56.610 --> 00:06:00.330
It's providing integrity,
but not confidentiality.

107
00:06:01.410 --> 00:06:05.690
So we're only providing one
leg really of that CIA triad

108
00:06:05.690 --> 00:06:07.270
when we're using authentication header.

109
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:09.830
But that might be all we need.

110
00:06:09.830 --> 00:06:13.800
It might be a scenario where I'm
not worried about confidentiality,

111
00:06:13.800 --> 00:06:18.520
I just have to make sure that the data
maintains its integrity as it travels.

112
00:06:18.520 --> 00:06:22.820
Maybe it's not, IPsec can be used in
many places, not just VPN tunnels.

113
00:06:22.820 --> 00:06:26.680
So there are times when I don't
necessarily need the extra overhead of

114
00:06:26.680 --> 00:06:28.450
say encryption or something like that.

115
00:06:28.450 --> 00:06:30.119
So authentication header is all I need.

116
00:06:31.800 --> 00:06:36.420
If we're gonna use authentication header,
another key very possible test question.

117
00:06:36.420 --> 00:06:38.540
Hint, hint, write this one down.

118
00:06:38.540 --> 00:06:41.270
IP protocol 51, it has to be enabled or

119
00:06:41.270 --> 00:06:45.820
allowed on your firewalls in order
to use authentication header.

120
00:06:45.820 --> 00:06:51.669
If a firewall blocks IP protocol 51, then
authentication header cannot function.

121
00:06:52.840 --> 00:06:57.740
The other mode, or another I should
say component not mode, is ESP.

122
00:06:57.740 --> 00:07:00.140
So IPsec is actually psychic.

123
00:07:00.140 --> 00:07:05.285
It knows what you're gonna
do before you do it.

124
00:07:05.285 --> 00:07:06.041
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm just kidding.

125
00:07:06.041 --> 00:07:07.058
>> No you're not kidding.

126
00:07:07.058 --> 00:07:10.411
>> [LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK] it's crazy.

127
00:07:10.411 --> 00:07:15.680
>> Not ESP in that sense, but
ESP as in Encapsulating Security Payload.

128
00:07:15.680 --> 00:07:17.050
And if you read that to yourself slowly.

129
00:07:17.050 --> 00:07:18.330
You're thinking about slowly.

130
00:07:18.330 --> 00:07:23.320
You probably come to the conclusion
that we're going to provide security for

131
00:07:23.320 --> 00:07:23.850
the payload.

132
00:07:23.850 --> 00:07:25.030
This is the data part right.

133
00:07:25.030 --> 00:07:27.890
This is how we can encrypt the packets.

134
00:07:27.890 --> 00:07:32.460
To make sure that any bad actors can't
get to the data if they try to steal it.

135
00:07:32.460 --> 00:07:34.260
As it travels across the network.

136
00:07:34.260 --> 00:07:37.520
So this is going to provide authenticity.

137
00:07:37.520 --> 00:07:41.160
It's also gonna provide integrity
as well as confidentiality.

138
00:07:41.160 --> 00:07:43.815
You get a lot of the CIA triad there,
right?

139
00:07:43.815 --> 00:07:44.730
>> Mm-hm.

140
00:07:44.730 --> 00:07:46.770
>> By encrypting it,
we get confidentiality.

141
00:07:46.770 --> 00:07:51.260
Because if you don't know the decryption
key, you can't see the information.

142
00:07:51.260 --> 00:07:52.753
So it's confidential.

143
00:07:52.753 --> 00:07:57.645
We get authenticity and integrity,
because encrypted data If it can

144
00:07:57.645 --> 00:08:01.270
be decrypted at the other
end with your public key,

145
00:08:01.270 --> 00:08:05.845
then it had to be signed with your
private key in the first place.

146
00:08:05.845 --> 00:08:09.050
And I know that might be too deep for
this particular class.

if you wanna talk to any computer in my

Social engineering takes on many,
many, many forms.

585
00:30:54.640 --> 00:30:58.480
We'll talk about phishing, that's
really a form of social engineering.

586
00:30:58.480 --> 00:31:01.920
Me, putting on a fake worksuit and
going up to the front desk of your

587
00:31:01.920 --> 00:31:05.740
business saying hey,
I'm here to repair the electrical system.

588
00:31:05.740 --> 00:31:07.350
Can you let me in the server closet?

589
00:31:07.350 --> 00:31:08.980
That's social engineering.

590
00:31:08.980 --> 00:31:14.080
Me calling you up on the phone and saying
hey, this is JoJo from the helpdesk and

591
00:31:14.080 --> 00:31:17.580
we need your password so I can make sure
you get inputted into the new system.

592
00:31:17.580 --> 00:31:19.180
Right, so that's social engineering.

593
00:31:19.180 --> 00:31:22.090
Trying to convince somebody
to give up information

594
00:31:22.090 --> 00:31:24.940
that they shouldn't be giving out.

595
00:31:24.940 --> 00:31:27.040
Takes advantage of human nature.

596
00:31:27.040 --> 00:31:28.770
We want to be liked, we want to help.

597
00:31:30.990 --> 00:31:34.140
Lots of episodes in the course
library on social engineering.

598
00:31:34.140 --> 00:31:37.760
Software vulnerability,
taking advantage of vulnerable software.

599
00:31:37.760 --> 00:31:41.150
If you're not patching your software,
if you're not paying attention when they

600
00:31:41.150 --> 00:31:45.270
put out updates for software, you could be
running software that has vulnerabilities.

601
00:31:45.270 --> 00:31:48.830
And so even though your network is secure,
your operating system is secure,

602
00:31:48.830 --> 00:31:53.735
if you're not patching your software
as well, then you're gonna be exposed.

603
00:31:53.735 --> 00:31:55.617
Now, for overflows,
we've talked about that.

604
00:31:55.617 --> 00:31:58.917
That is when applications,
operating systems included,

605
00:31:58.917 --> 00:32:01.690
have buffers that they
use to store information.

606
00:32:01.690 --> 00:32:05.356
And if I can feed too much
information into that buffer,

607
00:32:05.356 --> 00:32:07.462
That buffer will overflow, and

608
00:32:07.462 --> 00:32:13.156
then what'll happen is either the system
will crash, or the application will crash,

609
00:32:13.156 --> 00:32:17.696
or potentially I could run malicious
code with system level access.

610
00:32:17.696 --> 00:32:20.570
SQL injections,
this is an oldie but a goodie.

611
00:32:20.570 --> 00:32:25.949
It's been around for a long time, and
it's still a very, very common attack,

612
00:32:25.949 --> 00:32:30.385
because this is where a lot of
websites nowadays are data driven.

613
00:32:30.385 --> 00:32:33.995
In other words when you go to a website,
it reaches out and

614
00:32:33.995 --> 00:32:38.435
talks to a database to pull up information
like when you go to Newegg and

615
00:32:38.435 --> 00:32:41.390
you wanna see all
the motherboards they sell.

616
00:32:41.390 --> 00:32:45.330
Well, it queries a database and it shows
you a list of all the motherboards their

617
00:32:45.330 --> 00:32:47.590
features, that are priced,
that are manufactured.

618
00:32:47.590 --> 00:32:49.430
All that's stored in a database.

619
00:32:49.430 --> 00:32:51.720
If your website is allowing user input,

620
00:32:51.720 --> 00:32:56.860
maybe you've got a form that they can fill
out to create an account or what have you.

621
00:32:56.860 --> 00:33:00.710
If those forms are done properly,
I could potentially type my own

622
00:33:00.710 --> 00:33:05.680
SQL commands in that form and have
them executed against your SQL server.

623
00:33:05.680 --> 00:33:07.220
Not what's intended.

624
00:33:07.220 --> 00:33:11.680
But if the code is not done properly and
if there are not validation checks done

625
00:33:11.680 --> 00:33:15.860
on input forms, this is a very,
very real possibility.

626
00:33:15.860 --> 00:33:19.336
And it's extremely dangerous
because as a bad guy,

627
00:33:19.336 --> 00:33:24.392
if I can submit SQL queries against
your database, I could potentially pull

628
00:33:24.392 --> 00:33:30.010
back all the information that's in there,
wipe out information, delete things.

629
00:33:30.010 --> 00:33:33.669
It's dangerous,
it's a very bad, bad thing.

630
00:33:33.669 --> 00:33:36.012
It's really simple to prevent, [LAUGH] but

631
00:33:36.012 --> 00:33:39.201
unfortunately sometimes when
we create these web pages,

632
00:33:39.201 --> 00:33:43.709
security is not at the forefront, and
it's not something that they think about.

633
00:33:44.788 --> 00:33:49.920
But anyway SQL Injection is when I
inject SQL commands into a website

634
00:33:49.920 --> 00:33:53.160
in hopes that it will get
executed by your SQL server.

635
00:33:54.190 --> 00:33:56.603
And the last one on the list
is Cross-Site Scripting.

636
00:33:56.603 --> 00:34:01.648
And Cross-Site Scripting is a way that
the bad guy, if I want to attack you,

637
00:34:01.648 --> 00:34:06.710
rather than attack you directly, I will
attack a web server that you are known to

638
00:34:06.710 --> 00:34:11.760
frequent and
I can put malicious code on the website.

639
00:34:11.760 --> 00:34:15.900
If I can find a vulnerable web server,
I can put my malicious code up there and

640
00:34:15.900 --> 00:34:18.750
then wait for people to visit
the website and when they download

641
00:34:18.750 --> 00:34:23.150
the web pages like normal it's
downloading the malicious code as well.

642
00:34:23.150 --> 00:34:27.490
And that's getting executed and
being run on that victim's machine.

643
00:34:27.490 --> 00:34:29.532
This is what's called
Cross-Site Scripting.

644
00:34:29.532 --> 00:34:33.451
I think way back in one of our beginning
episodes, I talked about how it's no

645
00:34:33.451 --> 00:34:37.490
longer where if as long as you don't
click on something you're safe.

646
00:34:37.490 --> 00:34:40.805
Nowadays, just visiting a website,
you can infect your machine.

647
00:34:40.805 --> 00:34:44.809
Cross-Site Scripting is one of,
in fact, this one makes the top ten.

648
00:34:44.809 --> 00:34:45.825
It's been in the top ten.

649
00:34:45.825 --> 00:34:48.249
There's a place called
OWASP that records or

650
00:34:48.249 --> 00:34:51.428
keeps tracks of all the different attacks.

651
00:34:51.428 --> 00:34:56.150
And Cross-Site Scripting, I would say,
in the top five in the last several years.

652
00:34:56.150 --> 00:34:57.580
It is a very, very common attack.

653
00:34:57.580 --> 00:35:01.200
>> In fact, I remember an IT
guru that I used to listen to.

654
00:35:01.200 --> 00:35:02.130
I knew him well.

655
00:35:02.130 --> 00:35:04.950
But he said he doesn't go on the Internet.

656
00:35:04.950 --> 00:35:05.802
He simply doesn't do it.

657
00:35:05.802 --> 00:35:06.681
[LAUGH]
>> Really?

658
00:35:06.681 --> 00:35:09.435
[LAUGH]
>> There's not enough security you can

659
00:35:09.435 --> 00:35:12.897
build around, but of course he was
also a governing a huge network,

660
00:35:12.897 --> 00:35:14.920
in a company we've all both belong to.

661
00:35:14.920 --> 00:35:19.542
>> It is scary out there, you don't want
to put the fear in humanity, and say,

662
00:35:19.542 --> 00:35:21.745
never going in the Internet again.

663
00:35:21.745 --> 00:35:23.733
Almost like saying, hey don't drive a car.

664
00:35:23.733 --> 00:35:26.382
There's risk you have when
you get in the automobile,

665
00:35:26.382 --> 00:35:28.890
there's risks being out there on the road.

666
00:35:28.890 --> 00:35:30.940
But the benefits hopefully
out weigh the risk.

667
00:35:30.940 --> 00:35:32.250
It's the same thing here.

668
00:35:32.250 --> 00:35:36.340
Yeah, the Internet can be a scary place,
but if we follow common sense.

669
00:35:36.340 --> 00:35:40.750
If we follow best practices we can really
keep ourselves and our network safe.

670
00:35:40.750 --> 00:35:41.690
>> Protocol security.

671
00:35:41.690 --> 00:35:43.020
Great episode as usual Mike.

672
00:35:43.020 --> 00:35:45.000
Thanks for all the wonderful information.

673
00:35:45.000 --> 00:35:46.360
MTA Security Fundamentals.

674
00:35:46.360 --> 00:35:50.490
There's a lot of episodes in this series,
make sure you watch them all.

675
00:35:50.490 --> 00:35:52.290
Well you're watching ITPRO.TV.

676
00:35:52.290 --> 00:35:55.060
Do you know that a good IT
pro is always learning?

677
00:35:55.060 --> 00:35:55.920
I'm Zach Memos.

678
00:35:55.920 --> 00:35:56.950
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

679
00:35:56.950 --> 00:35:59.690
>> We'll see you soon.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:06.403
Welcome to IT pro TV i'm
your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.403 --> 00:00:08.372
[MUSIC].

3
00:00:08.372 --> 00:00:12.228

4
00:00:12.228 --> 00:00:16.998
>> Hello, and thank you again for making
that intelligent choice to watch ITProTV,

5
00:00:16.998 --> 00:00:19.080
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:19.080 --> 00:00:23.639
I'm your host Zach Memos we're continuing
on with MTA Security Fundamentals.

7
00:00:23.639 --> 00:00:27.820
And today, were talking about client
protection, that could even mean you.

8
00:00:27.820 --> 00:00:29.170
And whos bringing you the information but

9
00:00:29.170 --> 00:00:32.040
our very own Mike Rodrick right here,
hello sir.

10
00:00:32.040 --> 00:00:33.565
>> Hi, Zach,
hows everybody doing out there?

11
00:00:33.565 --> 00:00:37.130
Hope you doing well on this fantastic day.

12
00:00:37.130 --> 00:00:40.430
And yeah, youre right, were gonna be
talking about client protection, right?

13
00:00:40.430 --> 00:00:44.070
Some of the stuff weve already
hinted at in other episodes, so

14
00:00:44.070 --> 00:00:45.570
it might be a little bit of a rehash.

15
00:00:45.570 --> 00:00:48.470
But hearing things more than once
is always a good thing, right?

16
00:00:48.470 --> 00:00:51.260
That's why you can go back to our library
and watch this stuff any time you want.

17
00:00:51.260 --> 00:00:53.530
As many times as you want.

18
00:00:53.530 --> 00:00:56.815
>> Or as they say [FOREIGN]
>> Yes, I like that.

19
00:00:56.815 --> 00:01:00.070
[LAUGH]
>> So lets define client protection.

20
00:01:00.070 --> 00:01:02.500
How can we ensure client protection?

21
00:01:02.500 --> 00:01:03.560
>> That's a great question.

22
00:01:03.560 --> 00:01:06.620
And first lets make sure we understand
when we say client we're talking about

23
00:01:06.620 --> 00:01:08.000
a client operating system.

24
00:01:08.000 --> 00:01:12.650
This is one that you would run on your
computer at home or on your laptop or

25
00:01:12.650 --> 00:01:14.290
on your computer at work.

26
00:01:14.290 --> 00:01:17.280
A client operating systems are meant for
daily use.

27
00:01:17.280 --> 00:01:20.960
They really put most of their power
in whatever application you're

28
00:01:20.960 --> 00:01:22.620
currently running.

29
00:01:22.620 --> 00:01:24.911
So like when you open up a program,

30
00:01:24.911 --> 00:01:27.999
it gets most of the resources
delivered to it.

31
00:01:27.999 --> 00:01:30.280
Again, it's meant to be a daily driver.

32
00:01:30.280 --> 00:01:34.650
Versus a server operating system
which is very, very similar, but

33
00:01:34.650 --> 00:01:39.380
servers are really designed to provide
services and run things in the background.

34
00:01:39.380 --> 00:01:42.550
We don't sit at a server everyday and
surf the internet and check our e-mail.

35
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:46.330
But in the background, on a server, it's
performing things like DHC, and DHCP, and

36
00:01:46.330 --> 00:01:49.830
DNS, and Active Directory, right?

37
00:01:49.830 --> 00:01:52.870
Background services are what gets
the majority of the resources

38
00:01:52.870 --> 00:01:53.900
as it is on servers.

39
00:01:53.900 --> 00:01:57.750
But, so now we know what a client is,
a client operating system.

40
00:01:57.750 --> 00:02:02.508
And it is very important that we
keep these protected because they

41
00:02:02.508 --> 00:02:04.331
are where our users sit.

42
00:02:04.331 --> 00:02:08.987
And they're one of those things that gets
exposed a lot to the dangerous parts of

43
00:02:08.987 --> 00:02:09.830
our network.

44
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:14.420
They go out to the internet so they can be
expose to many things out there untrusted

45
00:02:14.420 --> 00:02:18.870
network laptops move,
a server sits in my network and

46
00:02:18.870 --> 00:02:22.602
it never leaves there, it remains in
that trusted confine of my network.

47
00:02:22.602 --> 00:02:26.940
Whereas your laptop is at work,
but then it goes to Starbucks, or

48
00:02:26.940 --> 00:02:30.150
to McDonald's, or
to some other hotel hotspot, right?

49
00:02:30.150 --> 00:02:32.980
These untrusted networks
picking up who knows what,

50
00:02:32.980 --> 00:02:37.140
and then coming back to my network or
our network and plugging in, and

51
00:02:37.140 --> 00:02:39.070
possibly bringing things
in that we didn't want.

52
00:02:39.070 --> 00:02:41.730
So, client protection is
obviously very important.

53
00:02:41.730 --> 00:02:44.690
We've got users surfing the Internet,
checking emails,

54
00:02:44.690 --> 00:02:48.440
clicking on links maybe they shouldn't
click on, installing software.

55
00:02:48.440 --> 00:02:49.628
So, very important that we protect them.

56
00:02:49.628 --> 00:02:54.989
Now, your question then, how do we
provide this level of protection?

57
00:02:54.989 --> 00:02:57.024
Several ways that we can,

58
00:02:57.024 --> 00:03:02.460
that we want to make sure we
are providing adequate protection.

59
00:03:02.460 --> 00:03:07.150
First and foremost, is probably, well,
maybe I won't say first and foremost,

60
00:03:07.150 --> 00:03:10.490
but one important thing is
antivirus software, righ?

61
00:03:10.490 --> 00:03:14.440
We spent some time on malware, we talked
about the different classes of malware,

62
00:03:14.440 --> 00:03:19.170
viruses, worms, trojans, all that fun
stuff, right, all that dangerous stuff.

63
00:03:19.170 --> 00:03:24.040
Antivirus software is software that's
meant to protect us from that.

64
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:28.870
Hopefully prevent it, if not prevent it,
detect it, quarantine it,

65
00:03:28.870 --> 00:03:32.090
prevent it from spreading and
infecting anything else on our machine.

66
00:03:32.090 --> 00:03:33.960
And then possible removing that.

67
00:03:33.960 --> 00:03:37.460
So, running good antivirus
software is extremely important.

68
00:03:37.460 --> 00:03:41.814
We almost can't run without it nowadays or
you're really at risk.

69
00:03:41.814 --> 00:03:45.196
Zach, it's funny, years ago, decade ago,

70
00:03:45.196 --> 00:03:50.595
I wouldn't run anti virus software
because it would slow my system down.

71
00:03:50.595 --> 00:03:51.922
It took a lot of resources.

72
00:03:51.922 --> 00:03:53.455
>> You're talking about the n word, right?

73
00:03:53.455 --> 00:03:57.590
>> Yeah, it would be kind of clunky.

74
00:03:57.590 --> 00:04:00.320
And I knew that as long as I
didn't go to bad websites,

75
00:04:00.320 --> 00:04:04.150
download things I didn't trust, click
on links in e-mails I was pretty safe.

76
00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:05.410
That's not the case anymore today.

77
00:04:05.410 --> 00:04:07.140
We get drive by infections.

78
00:04:07.140 --> 00:04:11.240
We can visit a website, not do anything,
just open up a website and

79
00:04:11.240 --> 00:04:12.120
it can infect us.

80
00:04:12.120 --> 00:04:14.858
We can open up an email and
it can infect our system.

81
00:04:14.858 --> 00:04:17.991
We can open up a Word document and
it can infect our system.

82
00:04:17.991 --> 00:04:20.816
So anti-virus is very important.

83
00:04:20.816 --> 00:04:22.432
It doesn't matter which one.

84
00:04:22.432 --> 00:04:25.938
That's something that you or
your organization is going to decide.

85
00:04:25.938 --> 00:04:29.220
But there are some things that we need
to do when we run anti-virus software.

86
00:04:29.220 --> 00:04:33.648
The one thing is, make sure it's installed
and then two keep it up to date.

87
00:04:33.648 --> 00:04:37.618
Right, because anti-virus software,
it's changing a little bit, But

88
00:04:37.618 --> 00:04:40.463
a lot of anti-virus software
works on definitions.

89
00:04:40.463 --> 00:04:45.138
In other words, these anti-virus vendors,
like Semantec, or

90
00:04:45.138 --> 00:04:47.770
Norton or McAfee or whomever.

91
00:04:47.770 --> 00:04:49.422
They sell you their product, and

92
00:04:49.422 --> 00:04:52.969
then their product relies on definitions
that you download from them.

93
00:04:52.969 --> 00:04:57.672
And as new viruses and malware is
discovered, they write new definitions so

94
00:04:57.672 --> 00:05:01.960
that their program will know
what to look for and stop it.

95
00:05:01.960 --> 00:05:04.380
But if you're not getting
those new definitions,

96
00:05:04.380 --> 00:05:07.280
then your program's not
gonna be able to identify

97
00:05:07.280 --> 00:05:11.610
those new types of malware that
are coming out on a daily basis.

98
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:12.640
So when I say keep it up to date,

99
00:05:12.640 --> 00:05:17.590
I don't mean once a month go update your
program, your antivirus application.

100
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:19.920
It should be updated on a daily basis.

101
00:05:19.920 --> 00:05:24.320
In some environments, more than once
a day is actually not too much.

102
00:05:24.320 --> 00:05:27.280
So keeping it up to date
is extremely important.

103
00:05:27.280 --> 00:05:30.270
>> And I need to define something when
I said, in word I've referring to,

104
00:05:30.270 --> 00:05:35.000
the early versions of a certain
product made by a certain company, and

105
00:05:35.000 --> 00:05:36.620
now it's much, much better of course.

106
00:05:36.620 --> 00:05:39.960
>> Yeah, Norton I think is the,
we can say them.

107
00:05:39.960 --> 00:05:40.532
>> Okay, good.

108
00:05:40.532 --> 00:05:42.077
>> I will give them all credit.

109
00:05:42.077 --> 00:05:46.140
The other thing we want to make sure we
have in a good anti-virus application.

110
00:05:46.140 --> 00:05:48.511
Is real time protection, right?

111
00:05:48.511 --> 00:05:52.691
Real time protection means it's
gonna analyze things as they happen,

112
00:05:52.691 --> 00:05:54.580
rather than after they happen.

113
00:05:54.580 --> 00:05:57.600
It's okay, it's still better than nothing.

114
00:05:57.600 --> 00:05:59.930
If it finds something
after it's infected you,

115
00:05:59.930 --> 00:06:02.050
that's good, quarantine and get rid of it.

116
00:06:02.050 --> 00:06:04.200
But I'd really like it to
watch things as they happen.

117
00:06:04.200 --> 00:06:05.520
Files I download?

118
00:06:05.520 --> 00:06:06.220
Scan it.

119
00:06:06.220 --> 00:06:09.428
Before I even get to open it,
let me know if it's a bad thing.

120
00:06:09.428 --> 00:06:12.331
And that's what's called
real time protection, and

121
00:06:12.331 --> 00:06:17.100
most anti-virus software today does
real time protection if we turn it on.

122
00:06:17.100 --> 00:06:19.855
>> Question, is the virus hoax a thing?

123
00:06:19.855 --> 00:06:21.021
I've seen it.

124
00:06:21.021 --> 00:06:22.729
>> I've seen which is-
>> Yes, you've got a virus but

125
00:06:22.729 --> 00:06:23.780
there really wasn't one.

126
00:06:23.780 --> 00:06:24.900
What is that all about?

127
00:06:24.900 --> 00:06:27.161
>> Yeah, hoax is just that,right.

128
00:06:27.161 --> 00:06:29.940
A virus hoax is not really a virus.

129
00:06:29.940 --> 00:06:32.600
It could be an e-mail, a phone call or

130
00:06:32.600 --> 00:06:36.351
anything like that where
