00:18:16.238 --> 00:18:20.230
The down side is now the UAC will
pop up but nothing else is frozen.

358
00:18:20.230 --> 00:18:23.420
So that application could technically
still be trying to do things in

359
00:18:23.420 --> 00:18:26.500
the background while you're sitting
there starting at that UAC.

360
00:18:26.500 --> 00:18:30.901
So it's not as secure, but if you've got
an older system that the UAC bogs down,

361
00:18:30.901 --> 00:18:32.740
might be something you wanna do.

362
00:18:32.740 --> 00:18:34.927
Bottom option, never notify me.

363
00:18:34.927 --> 00:18:36.590
In this case, it won't bother you.

364
00:18:36.590 --> 00:18:38.846
It's gonna say alright, all right,
I'm not gonna bother you.

365
00:18:38.846 --> 00:18:41.020
If you're an administrator,
it'll let you do it.

366
00:18:41.020 --> 00:18:43.703
If an application tries to do it and
you're logged in as an administrator,

367
00:18:43.703 --> 00:18:44.604
it'll just let it do it.

368
00:18:44.604 --> 00:18:45.220
Won't care.

369
00:18:45.220 --> 00:18:47.250
You told it not to notify you.

370
00:18:47.250 --> 00:18:50.836
If you're a standard user however,
it won't notify you, and

371
00:18:50.836 --> 00:18:54.740
you can't do anything that
requires administrative access.

372
00:18:54.740 --> 00:18:57.009
Cuz you're never gonna get
a pop-up that says, hey,

373
00:18:57.009 --> 00:19:00.183
provide credentials that have
administrative access, so it won't work.

374
00:19:00.183 --> 00:19:03.680
So those are your options there for
configuring the UAC.

375
00:19:03.680 --> 00:19:05.531
Again, that's on an individual basis.

376
00:19:05.531 --> 00:19:06.578
So I would need to do that for

377
00:19:06.578 --> 00:19:09.160
the different user accounts
that are on this system.

378
00:19:09.160 --> 00:19:11.706
In a domain,
we'd do that through group policy,

379
00:19:11.706 --> 00:19:15.540
making sure we could set it once and
not have to touch every single machine.

380
00:19:15.540 --> 00:19:17.290
>> Mike, what about Windows Firewall?

381
00:19:18.290 --> 00:19:20.039
>> Well,
we've talked about that firewall before.

382
00:19:20.039 --> 00:19:23.958
We talked about the concept of a firewall,
what it does.

383
00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:27.030
We've talked about host-based
versus network-based.

384
00:19:27.030 --> 00:19:31.454
And on Windows 10, I think it was actually
started with XP Service Pack 2 or

385
00:19:31.454 --> 00:19:34.526
Service Pack 3,
Windows has a built-in firewall.

386
00:19:34.526 --> 00:19:38.456
So it's a host-based firewall
that is turned on by default and

387
00:19:38.456 --> 00:19:40.467
that we can go in and configure.

388
00:19:40.467 --> 00:19:43.035
And this is gonna to protect not
any other machines on my network,

389
00:19:43.035 --> 00:19:44.680
it's gonna protect the host.

390
00:19:44.680 --> 00:19:47.069
And a lot of people think,
well why do I need that?

391
00:19:47.069 --> 00:19:51.212
If I've already got firewalls at the
perimeter of our network, my company has

392
00:19:51.212 --> 00:19:56.290
firewalls, ao I'm inside the firewall,
I should be safe, and you are kind of.

393
00:19:56.290 --> 00:19:59.989
But the problem is, if something
gets through the firewall, and

394
00:19:59.989 --> 00:20:03.697
there's no other firewalls like
on your host, it has free rein.

395
00:20:03.697 --> 00:20:05.120
There's nothing left to stop it.

396
00:20:05.120 --> 00:20:08.523
We never put all of our eggs in
one basket, so to say, right?

397
00:20:08.523 --> 00:20:13.380
Not one layer of defense, the perimeter
is not our only line of defense.

398
00:20:13.380 --> 00:20:16.680
So even though we've got
defenses at the perimeter,

399
00:20:16.680 --> 00:20:19.520
we still put up the firewall
on our individual machines.

400
00:20:19.520 --> 00:20:23.102
That way, if something does get in and
it affects Zach's computer,

401
00:20:23.102 --> 00:20:25.217
it can't just jump over to my computer.

402
00:20:25.217 --> 00:20:30.927
Because my computer has a firewall on it,
especially on your sensitive hosts.

403
00:20:30.927 --> 00:20:35.098
If you've got servers that you need to
control access to, will run of course our

404
00:20:35.098 --> 00:20:39.690
network based firewall but also host
based firewalls on those as well.

405
00:20:39.690 --> 00:20:42.980
The Windows Firewall,
lets take a peek at it real quick.

406
00:20:42.980 --> 00:20:46.345
I'm just going to go to my Start Menu and
try typing firewall.

407
00:20:46.345 --> 00:20:48.060
We'll see if it wants to play along.

408
00:20:48.060 --> 00:20:51.472
Now what you'll see here is there's
actually two different options.

409
00:20:51.472 --> 00:20:54.066
That's an interesting zoom.

410
00:20:54.066 --> 00:20:57.516
The top one here says Windows Firewall
with Advanced Security and

411
00:20:57.516 --> 00:20:59.407
then I also have Windows Firewall.

412
00:20:59.407 --> 00:21:00.730
There is only one firewall.

413
00:21:00.730 --> 00:21:02.530
There's just two different consoles.

414
00:21:02.530 --> 00:21:06.183
The Windows Firewall, which I'm looking
at now, gives me basic control.

415
00:21:06.183 --> 00:21:11.704
I can turn it on, turn it off, allow
a particular app through the firewall.

416
00:21:11.704 --> 00:21:14.310
Let me expand this out and
I'll zoom in for you, and

417
00:21:14.310 --> 00:21:18.540
you can see over here I've got options,
turn Windows Firewall on or off.

418
00:21:18.540 --> 00:21:20.440
So I can turn the firewall on or

419
00:21:20.440 --> 00:21:24.020
off, depending on the network
that I'm connected to.

420
00:21:24.020 --> 00:21:26.080
I'm gonna zoom back out cuz
I can't see anything there.

421
00:21:27.910 --> 00:21:30.565
I can allow an app or
feature through the Windows firewall.

422
00:21:30.565 --> 00:21:34.274
So I can click on that, and I can come
in here and I can say you know what?

423
00:21:34.274 --> 00:21:37.860
I need,
let's see what's a good one to show you.

424
00:21:39.730 --> 00:21:42.892
I don't know, let's just pretend
we were gonna do Twitter.

425
00:21:42.892 --> 00:21:45.930
Well, Twitter already has
an exception on here.

426
00:21:45.930 --> 00:21:47.250
But whatever the case is,

427
00:21:47.250 --> 00:21:51.277
let's say that SNMP trap was something
I wanted to allow through the Firewall.

428
00:21:51.277 --> 00:21:53.782
Come in here and I could say,
yes, I wanna allow you and

429
00:21:53.782 --> 00:21:56.760
then I can choose domain network,
private, or public.

430
00:21:56.760 --> 00:22:00.010
So if I only want this app to
work when I'm on the domain, but

431
00:22:00.010 --> 00:22:03.731
not when I'm at Starbucks,
I can just check domain and not public.

432
00:22:03.731 --> 00:22:07.672
Now the other firewall option,
let's go back to the Start Menu.

433
00:22:07.672 --> 00:22:09.596
And I'll show you the long
way to get there,

434
00:22:09.596 --> 00:22:13.680
we'll type firewall again, is
the Windows Firewall of Advanced Security.

435
00:22:13.680 --> 00:22:16.649
What I wanna make sure we understand
is it's still the same firewall.

436
00:22:16.649 --> 00:22:19.422
There's only one firewall
running on this client, but

437
00:22:19.422 --> 00:22:21.690
this gives me more granular control.

438
00:22:21.690 --> 00:22:25.627
Now I can see inbound rules
versus outbound rules.

439
00:22:25.627 --> 00:22:27.479
The traffic is coming into my computer,

440
00:22:27.479 --> 00:22:30.280
versus traffic that's
going out of my computer.

441
00:22:30.280 --> 00:22:34.924
Also I can work with IP6, we talked
about that in some other episodes.

442
00:22:34.924 --> 00:22:37.490
So I can work with that
within this consoles list.

443
00:22:37.490 --> 00:22:42.617
So again, same firewall it's
just a more granular control.

444
00:22:42.617 --> 00:22:46.754
Last thing I want to say about firewalls,
one of things I hear people say,

445
00:22:46.754 --> 00:22:48.442
is should I run more than one?

446
00:22:48.442 --> 00:22:54.784
You can, but it's really not necessary and
it's going to make more work for you.

447
00:22:54.784 --> 00:22:59.050
If you think about it, the firewall
closes all the ports, and then you make

448
00:22:59.050 --> 00:23:03.340
exceptions to open up some of those
ports to allow traffic either in or out.

449
00:23:03.340 --> 00:23:06.372
Now if I put two walls and
I make a hole in the first one,

450
00:23:06.372 --> 00:23:09.686
it gets through the first one and
then hits the second one.

451
00:23:09.686 --> 00:23:12.072
So now I've got to make an exception
on the second one as well.

452
00:23:12.072 --> 00:23:14.842
So every program that I wanna
allow through has to go through,

453
00:23:14.842 --> 00:23:17.360
I have to make exceptions in for
both firewalls.

454
00:23:17.360 --> 00:23:20.949
Not really getting any extra protection
cuz the first one's doing it just fine,

455
00:23:20.949 --> 00:23:24.243
I'm just making more work for myself
because now I've got to do it twice.

456
00:23:24.243 --> 00:23:28.919
So, running more than one firewall really
doesn't get you anything other than

457
00:23:28.919 --> 00:23:29.841
frustration.

458
00:23:29.841 --> 00:23:34.911
[LAUGH] Is what I will say,
in my humble opinion.

459
00:23:34.911 --> 00:23:37.340
All right, so
we talked about anti-virus software.

460
00:23:37.340 --> 00:23:40.469
We talked about hoaxes,
unwanted software, UAC, firewall.

461
00:23:40.469 --> 00:23:41.530
What's next on our list here?

462
00:23:41.530 --> 00:23:42.560
>> Software updates?

463
00:23:42.560 --> 00:23:45.450
>> Software updates, all right.

464
00:23:45.450 --> 00:23:48.160
We've mentioned this in other episodes,
as well.

465
00:23:48.160 --> 00:23:51.444
We know that our operating system,
for example Windows.

466
00:23:51.444 --> 00:23:55.453
Microsoft puts out updates all the time
and we wanna get those updates because

467
00:23:55.453 --> 00:23:58.669
those updates are usually
fixing something that's broken.

468
00:23:58.669 --> 00:23:59.730
A security flaw,

469
00:23:59.730 --> 00:24:04.690
a bug, some other thing that maybe the bad
guys can try to take advantage of.

470
00:24:04.690 --> 00:24:05.840
and compromise my machine.

471
00:24:05.840 --> 00:24:10.079
So here I just want to stress, it's very
important that we keep our systems up to

472
00:24:10.079 --> 00:24:12.443
date and that were applying those patches.

473
00:24:12.443 --> 00:24:13.630
Now we can do that in different ways.

474
00:24:13.630 --> 00:24:15.486
We can go use Windows update,

475
00:24:15.486 --> 00:24:19.727
which is the update client that is
built in to our operating system.

476
00:24:19.727 --> 00:24:23.387
Reaches out to Microsoft servers and
it says, hey, I'm running Windows 10.

477
00:24:23.387 --> 00:24:25.242
What updates do you have for me?

478
00:24:25.242 --> 00:24:28.174
And it looks at your system,
sees what updates you already have.

479
00:24:28.174 --> 00:24:31.538
And then Microsoft Server says, here's
the list of updates you don't have yet,

480
00:24:31.538 --> 00:24:33.111
that apply to your operating system.

481
00:24:33.111 --> 00:24:36.930
Would you like to get them, and
we can choose to get them or not.

482
00:24:36.930 --> 00:24:38.513
But not only the operating system,

483
00:24:38.513 --> 00:24:41.483
we've got to think about
the applications we run as well, right?

484
00:24:41.483 --> 00:24:45.021
If I'm running Adobe software, well I
need to check with Adobe periodically and

485
00:24:45.021 --> 00:24:46.852
make sure I'm updating their software.

486
00:24:46.852 --> 00:24:50.430
Because even if my operating system is
patched the software I'm running on

487
00:24:50.430 --> 00:24:54.089
the operating system has a vulnerability,
then I'm vulnerable, right?

488
00:24:54.089 --> 00:24:57.263
So I need to make sure that
I'm updating the software,

489
00:24:57.263 --> 00:24:59.127
not just the operating system.

490
00:24:59.127 --> 00:25:03.778
Corporate environments,
it might be centrally managed.

491
00:25:03.778 --> 00:25:07.676
They might run something called
a Windows Server Update Service,

492
00:25:07.676 --> 00:25:10.607
where they download
the updates from Microsoft.

493
00:25:10.607 --> 00:25:14.458
And then your client machines are
configured to connect to your local server

494
00:25:14.458 --> 00:25:15.791
to download the updates.

495
00:25:15.791 --> 00:25:19.602
Reason they do this is because they can
now control which updates you get and

496
00:25:19.602 --> 00:25:20.280
don't get.

497
00:25:20.280 --> 00:25:24.046
Some updates have been known to cause
problems with software maybe that you're

498
00:25:24.046 --> 00:25:26.018
running or printers that you connect to.

499
00:25:26.018 --> 00:25:27.121
So by doing WSUS,

500
00:25:27.121 --> 00:25:31.619
your company can test updates first
before you apply them to the system.

501
00:25:31.619 --> 00:25:36.823
It can save them a lot of headache
later on if an update causes a problem.

502
00:25:36.823 --> 00:25:40.794
But you're still going to be
applying those updates as often, or

503
00:25:40.794 --> 00:25:43.770
as soon as we get them
once they've been tested.

504
00:25:43.770 --> 00:25:48.127
System center configuration
manager is even higher end way to

505
00:25:48.127 --> 00:25:52.911
centralize this process in very large,
corporate environments.

506
00:25:52.911 --> 00:25:56.431
Now as far as the update
classifications go,

507
00:25:56.431 --> 00:25:59.955
I tell you what Zach,
you give me the signal.

508
00:25:59.955 --> 00:26:02.661
We're getting close on time, and
I get about three more topics and

509
00:26:02.661 --> 00:26:04.075
I don't think it's going to fit.

510
00:26:04.075 --> 00:26:05.221
>> We'll fit in two minutes.

511
00:26:05.221 --> 00:26:10.018
>> It won't [LAUGH]
>> Keep pre bowing everything

512
00:26:10.018 --> 00:26:10.806
you've been saying so.

513
00:26:10.806 --> 00:26:11.697
>> Okay, absolutely.

514
00:26:11.697 --> 00:26:14.718
So far we've been talking about
keeping our clients secure,

515
00:26:14.718 --> 00:26:16.003
protecting our clients.

516
00:26:16.003 --> 00:26:19.461
And we've said we need to be
running anti-virus software.

517
00:26:19.461 --> 00:26:23.133
And we need to make sure were keeping
that anti-virus software up to date.

518
00:26:23.133 --> 00:26:26.538
Whether that's Windows Defender
that's built into Windows 10 or

519
00:26:26.538 --> 00:26:29.894
some other third party,
we need to make sure we're updating that.

520
00:26:29.894 --> 00:26:34.680
We talked about the UAC and
how we can use that to control,

521
00:26:34.680 --> 00:26:38.671
to kind of protect us from
software doing things

522
00:26:38.671 --> 00:26:42.682
in the background without our consent,
okay?

523
00:26:42.682 --> 00:26:45.717
And we talked about the Windows Firewall,

524
00:26:45.717 --> 00:26:48.929
as well as the beginning
of Windows Updates.

525
00:26:48.929 --> 00:26:54.190
>> So this is Part One of MTA Security
Fundamentals Client Protection.

00:26:56.864 --> 00:26:59.097
Part two will be coming up and

00:26:59.097 --> 00:27:00.943
Hey, thank you so much, terrific.

529
00:27:00.943 --> 00:27:02.610
Great information as usual.

530
00:27:02.610 --> 00:27:05.703
ITPRO.TV, we are helping
you learn wherever you go.

531
00:27:05.703 --> 00:27:08.489
And an IT pro,
a good IT pro is always learning.

532
00:27:08.489 --> 00:27:09.509
I'm Zach Memos.

533
00:27:09.509 --> 00:27:10.267
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

534
00:27:10.267 --> 00:27:13.065
>> We'll see you soon.

00:01:21.315 --> 00:01:25.310

00:01:30.820 --> 00:01:31.623

So that's something I really want.

38
00:01:46.980 --> 00:01:49.060
That's important.

39
00:01:49.060 --> 00:01:52.660

a bug discovered that causes the system to

00:01:56.290 --> 00:02:00.200

I now have corporate data on my computer
that could be potentially compromised.

281
00:14:11.430 --> 00:14:13.176
So make sure you apply that encryption.

282
00:14:13.176 --> 00:14:15.455
>> Mike, maybe we can wrap this up.

283
00:14:15.455 --> 00:14:17.083
What is the principle of least privilege?

284
00:14:17.083 --> 00:14:17.675
What is that?

285
00:14:17.675 --> 00:14:20.232
>> The principle of least privilege, we've
had to do that before I think a few times

286
00:14:20.232 --> 00:14:22.237
as well, probably more than hinted,
we've talked about it.

287
00:14:22.237 --> 00:14:26.240
But it applies to client
protection as well.

288
00:14:26.240 --> 00:14:28.670
Remember, principle of least
privilege is simply saying,

289
00:14:28.670 --> 00:14:32.260
only give people what they need
to do their job and nothing more.

290
00:14:32.260 --> 00:14:36.230
And I say people, that goes for
services, applications as well.

291
00:14:36.230 --> 00:14:38.960
We'll focus on users here since
this is client protection.

292
00:14:40.230 --> 00:14:41.530
And when it comes to client protection,

293
00:14:41.530 --> 00:14:45.430
really what we're trying to say when we
talk about principle of least privilege is

294
00:14:45.430 --> 00:14:48.830
not everybody needs to be
an administrator, right?

295
00:14:48.830 --> 00:14:53.759
You need administrative rights to do
certain tasks, but most of my end users

296
00:14:53.759 --> 00:14:58.468
shouldn't be doing things that
require administrative credentials.

297
00:14:58.468 --> 00:15:01.751
A while back we had the old
lazy admin syndrome and

298
00:15:01.751 --> 00:15:07.490
we made everybody local admins on their
machines because it simplified things.

299
00:15:07.490 --> 00:15:10.426
If they downloaded and
wanted to install some software,

300
00:15:10.426 --> 00:15:14.167
they didn't have to come find us and
ask us to install software for them.

301
00:15:14.167 --> 00:15:17.730
So like I said,
we did the lazy admin thing.

302
00:15:17.730 --> 00:15:20.420
But it turns out,
that's not a very good idea.

303
00:15:20.420 --> 00:15:25.080
Because users either intentionally or
unintentionally are gonna get into things

304
00:15:25.080 --> 00:15:28.120
that they don't know what their doing,
shouldn't be messing around with.

305
00:15:28.120 --> 00:15:30.800
And if they've got those credentials,
something's gonna go wrong.

306
00:15:30.800 --> 00:15:35.790
And it's it gonna end up causing more
work for us in IT as well as downtime and

307
00:15:35.790 --> 00:15:37.260
frustration for them as well.

308
00:15:37.260 --> 00:15:38.410
So in the end,

309
00:15:38.410 --> 00:15:42.470
not giving them administrative access
really is gonna make everybody happy.

310
00:15:42.470 --> 00:15:46.242
Now it is tough to take it away
if they've already had it.

311
00:15:46.242 --> 00:15:47.768
I feel-
>> [LAUGH]

312
00:15:47.768 --> 00:15:49.599
>> Your pain there because as soon as you

313
00:15:49.599 --> 00:15:53.940
tell somebody, hey, you're not gonna be
an administrator on your machine any more.

314
00:15:53.940 --> 00:15:58.550
They might've never once used anything
that required administrative access, but

315
00:15:58.550 --> 00:16:00.580
you tell them they're not gonna
be an administrator any more,

316
00:16:00.580 --> 00:16:02.280
they're not gonna be happy.

317
00:16:02.280 --> 00:16:03.090
But that's not the point.

318
00:16:03.090 --> 00:16:04.900
We're not here to keep them happy.

319
00:16:04.900 --> 00:16:08.050
We're here to make sure that they're safe,
and that our network is safe, and

320
00:16:08.050 --> 00:16:09.560
that their computer's safe.

321
00:16:09.560 --> 00:16:13.893
And so principle of least privilege means
don't give them anything more than they

322
00:16:13.893 --> 00:16:15.795
need to do their job.

323
00:16:15.795 --> 00:16:19.673
That's the old saying, my mom use to love
to throw at me, I give you an inch and

324
00:16:19.673 --> 00:16:20.744
you take a mile.

325
00:16:20.744 --> 00:16:22.940
>> My, I've heard that so
many times, my gosh.

326
00:16:22.940 --> 00:16:25.410
>> Yeah, and
that's what happens with our users.

327
00:16:25.410 --> 00:16:28.970
You give them administrative access,
and it might not even be intentional,

328
00:16:28.970 --> 00:16:32.050
but they're gonna get somewhere that
they shouldn't be and goof something up.

329
00:16:32.050 --> 00:16:35.150
Then you're gonna get the call
at the help desk that says, hey,

330
00:16:35.150 --> 00:16:37.070
I can't get access to
any network resources.

331
00:16:37.070 --> 00:16:38.480
I don't know what's going on.

332
00:16:38.480 --> 00:16:41.363
And you go, and you find that their
TCP/IP information is all changed.

333
00:16:41.363 --> 00:16:43.110
We're like, were you?

334
00:16:43.110 --> 00:16:44.230
No, I wasn't in there.

335
00:16:44.230 --> 00:16:45.970
It wasn't me, I don't know.

336
00:16:45.970 --> 00:16:50.340
>> Yeah, so
follow that principle of least privilege.

337
00:16:50.340 --> 00:16:51.190
>> Well, that's it.

338
00:16:51.190 --> 00:16:53.060
Client protection part two wrapped up.

339
00:16:53.060 --> 00:16:55.450
Anything else you'd like to add?

340
00:16:55.450 --> 00:16:57.150
>> No, we've pretty much covered.

341
00:16:57.150 --> 00:16:58.670
Again, with client protection,

342
00:16:58.670 --> 00:17:03.080
some of this stuff that we've talked about
can be done at a group policy level.

343
00:17:03.080 --> 00:17:06.840
In other words, not on an individual
machine, but have that setting pushed out.

344
00:17:06.840 --> 00:17:09.690
Remember, we talked about domain
controllers in a prior episode.

345
00:17:11.310 --> 00:17:14.200
So just keep in mind that
if you go to a machine and

346
00:17:14.200 --> 00:17:16.150
some of those settings are grayed out.

347
00:17:16.150 --> 00:17:20.310
If you find that you go to a laptop or
a desktop in your environment and

348
00:17:20.310 --> 00:17:23.410
you open up those firewall settings and
all the check marks are gray and

349
00:17:23.410 --> 00:17:27.220
you can't change anything, it could
be that they're pushing settings out

350
00:17:27.220 --> 00:17:31.360
to your machine so that they can
configure from a central location.

351
00:17:31.360 --> 00:17:35.570
And you won't be able to undo or change
those, and that's typically a good thing.

352
00:17:35.570 --> 00:17:38.970
But just to be aware, don't go,
my gosh, what's wrong with my machine?

353
00:17:38.970 --> 00:17:41.430
It should give you a little
message across the top that says,

354
00:17:41.430 --> 00:17:44.510
some settings are controlled
by your system administrator.

355
00:17:44.510 --> 00:17:46.140
>> Awesome, Mike, as usual.

356
00:17:46.140 --> 00:17:49.960
>> And that is client protection part two,
MTA security fundamentals.

357
00:17:49.960 --> 00:17:50.700
There is part one.

358
00:17:50.700 --> 00:17:52.010
Make sure you watch that and

359
00:17:52.010 --> 00:17:54.460
watch everything in this series
of MTA security fundamentals.

360
00:17:54.460 --> 00:17:55.625
It's awesome.

361
00:17:55.625 --> 00:17:58.092
An IT Pro is always learning.

362
00:17:58.092 --> 00:17:59.533
I'm Zach Memos.

363
00:17:59.533 --> 00:18:00.470
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

364
00:18:00.470 --> 00:18:01.681
>> And we'll see you soon.

365
00:18:01.681 --> 00:18:09.129
[MUSIC]

366
00:18:09.129 --> 00:18:11.354
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss understanding email protection, methods of attack such as spam-virus-spoofing-phishing-& pharming, using smartscreen filter, client vs. server protection, difference between 'client' & 'server' protection, what SPF records are, DNS, and what PTR records are.
episodes.title: Email Protection
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:07.841
Welcome to ITPRO TV, I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.841 --> 00:00:10.767
>> You're watching, ITPRO TV.

3
00:00:10.767 --> 00:00:16.401
>> Lucky you, you've made the smart
choice to watch ITPRO TV, thank you.

4
00:00:16.401 --> 00:00:18.339
You know, an ITPRO is always learning.

5
00:00:18.339 --> 00:00:20.015
I'm Zach Memos, your host for

6
00:00:20.015 --> 00:00:23.311
MCA Security Fundamentals as
we continue with this series.

7
00:00:23.311 --> 00:00:26.453
And today, we're talking about
email protection with a man who

8
00:00:26.453 --> 00:00:28.619
knows everything about it, I know he does.

9
00:00:28.619 --> 00:00:30.463
>> [LAUGH]
>> Mike Rodrick, right over here.

10
00:00:30.463 --> 00:00:31.777
>> I don't know about everything.

11
00:00:31.777 --> 00:00:34.020
That might be overstating it a little bit,
but thank you for that, Zach.

12
00:00:34.020 --> 00:00:35.884
And yeah, email protection, right?

13
00:00:35.884 --> 00:00:39.914
We need to make sure we understand part
of security fundamentals is going to be

14
00:00:39.914 --> 00:00:43.838
email, protecting ourselves from
email because email can be dangerous.

15
00:00:43.838 --> 00:00:45.930
It's like wait,
how can email be dangerous?

16
00:00:45.930 --> 00:00:52.780
Well, email is a big avenue for
the bad guys to get into your system.

17
00:00:52.780 --> 00:00:56.290
So, we need to make sure we're
following best practices and

18
00:00:56.290 --> 00:00:58.550
just being safe when
we're approaching emails.

19
00:00:58.550 --> 00:01:01.934
So, let's talk about some of
the things that we can do with email.

20
00:01:01.934 --> 00:01:04.103
And the first one is spam, right?

21
00:01:04.103 --> 00:01:06.360
We were having this
conversation the other day.

22
00:01:06.360 --> 00:01:10.300
We were talking about the good
old snail mail or here in the US,

23
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:15.745
the US Postal Service, and I had recently
gone on vacation, put my mail on hold.

24
00:01:15.745 --> 00:01:19.176
I went to pick it up when I got back, and
I'm gonna have a stack of mail like this.

25
00:01:19.176 --> 00:01:22.766
95% of that went right in the trash.

26
00:01:22.766 --> 00:01:25.007
It was junk fail, right?

27
00:01:25.007 --> 00:01:28.382
But with snail mail like that,
regular postal mail,

28
00:01:28.382 --> 00:01:33.033
the worst thing that happens is we lose
a tree or two and my garbage is full.

29
00:01:33.033 --> 00:01:35.350
But nothing bad happens to me, right?

30
00:01:35.350 --> 00:01:38.570
With email, however,
spam can be a little bit different.

31
00:01:38.570 --> 00:01:42.640
Still junk mail, but
it can potentially be dangerous.

32
00:01:42.640 --> 00:01:47.070
Because sometimes that spam has links in
it, they want us to click on things and

33
00:01:47.070 --> 00:01:51.950
those links can take us to bad places and
can end up infecting our machine.

34
00:01:51.950 --> 00:01:56.010
So, now we're talking about spam,
how do we protect ourselves from it?

35
00:01:56.010 --> 00:01:59.297
Well, one is use common sense, right?

36
00:01:59.297 --> 00:02:02.040
I get emails all the time from
things that I don't recognize.

37
00:02:02.040 --> 00:02:02.762
I don't even open them up.

38
00:02:02.762 --> 00:02:04.110
You just delete them.

39
00:02:04.110 --> 00:02:05.270
You get rid of them.

40
00:02:05.270 --> 00:02:09.755
A better solution is to have some
type of spam filter in place.

41
00:02:09.755 --> 00:02:13.745
Most corporate networks, or
corporations spend a lot of money and

42
00:02:13.745 --> 00:02:16.505
effort on trying to reduce
the amount of spam that's

43
00:02:16.505 --> 00:02:19.795
coming into their users' inboxes,
because it reduces productivity.

44
00:02:19.795 --> 00:02:22.125
You know, you've got 40 emails.

45
00:02:22.125 --> 00:02:26.140
Two of them are work related,
the rest are advertising fences, or

46
00:02:26.140 --> 00:02:28.949
some pill you don't need,
or who knows what.

47
00:02:28.949 --> 00:02:32.599
So, stopping those before they
get to the inbox can make for

48
00:02:32.599 --> 00:02:34.358
a more productive end user.

49
00:02:34.358 --> 00:02:38.496
Can also keep our system safe,
because there is no chance of opening up

50
00:02:38.496 --> 00:02:43.140
a malicious email, or clicking on a link
that's taking you to some bad place.

51
00:02:43.140 --> 00:02:47.916
This can be done on your email server,
could be a special device that we put in.

52
00:02:47.916 --> 00:02:52.539
We have a barracuda device that all stuff
comes thru before it even comes to my

53
00:02:52.539 --> 00:02:53.486
email server.

54
00:02:53.486 --> 00:02:57.230
And it has, much like anti virus,
it has definitions that it uses.

55
00:02:57.230 --> 00:03:02.093
And it scans those emails looking for key
phrases that we know that we associate,

56
00:03:02.093 --> 00:03:05.036
or words that we associate
with a lot of the spam.

57
00:03:05.036 --> 00:03:10.300
And it'll prevent it from
even getting to your system.

58
00:03:10.300 --> 00:03:13.310
Now we do have to be careful with
those because of a couple things.

59
00:03:13.310 --> 00:03:15.432
One, they're not gonna be 100% accurate.

60
00:03:15.432 --> 00:03:19.686
They're gonna let a few come through,
but that's okay.

61
00:03:19.686 --> 00:03:22.473
But I do have to make sure that they
don't get anything that shouldn't be

62
00:03:22.473 --> 00:03:23.210
considered spam.

63
00:03:23.210 --> 00:03:26.180
You want to make sure
you're tweaking these.

64
00:03:26.180 --> 00:03:30.355
These kind of devices usually
need a tuning period and

65
00:03:30.355 --> 00:03:33.980
a constant maintenance where we go in and
see.

66
00:03:35.210 --> 00:03:38.848
Like our Barracuda, for example,
gave us the option as an end user,

67
00:03:38.848 --> 00:03:40.876
we could go see what had been blocked.

68
00:03:40.876 --> 00:03:45.320
And if any of it was not spam, that we
wanted it come through, we could mark it.

69
00:03:45.320 --> 00:03:46.124
And it would learn, right?

70
00:03:46.124 --> 00:03:48.636
It would add to its engine.

71
00:03:48.636 --> 00:03:51.610
Say, okay,
we're not gonna stop that anymore.

72
00:03:51.610 --> 00:03:54.858
Cuz if somebody happened to use
the word free in their subject,

73
00:03:54.858 --> 00:03:57.813
maybe it catches it,
because it thinks its a sales ploy.

74
00:03:57.813 --> 00:04:02.041
So reducing the amount of spam
can keep our client computers,

75
00:04:02.041 --> 00:04:04.003
as well as our network safe.

76
00:04:04.003 --> 00:04:07.771
Antivirus, I think we've spent enough
time on that, we understand what that is.

77
00:04:07.771 --> 00:04:12.643
But antivirus can also be used along
with email, where it scan your emails

78
00:04:12.643 --> 00:04:17.529
that are coming in, checking for
potential malware inside your emails.

79
00:04:18.760 --> 00:04:23.710
Spoofing is another issue that we have
to deal with when we talk about email.

80
00:04:23.710 --> 00:04:29.270
It is very easy for
a bad actor to forge the to field.

81
00:04:29.270 --> 00:04:32.530
Make it look like it's from
somebody that you recognize or

82
00:04:32.530 --> 00:04:36.900
somebody that you know,
tempting you to open up that email.

83
00:04:36.900 --> 00:04:39.300
They can forge the from field,

84
00:04:39.300 --> 00:04:42.960
who it's from,
they can forge the source IP addresses.

85
00:04:42.960 --> 00:04:46.590
So, again, we have to do our part.

86
00:04:46.590 --> 00:04:50.390
We have to think,
I'm not expecting an email from Zach.

87
00:04:50.390 --> 00:04:53.460
He never told me he was
sending me this spreadsheet.

88
00:04:53.460 --> 00:04:58.052
So, before I click on that attachment and
open up that spreadsheet,

89
00:04:58.052 --> 00:04:59.566
I'm gonna call Zach.

90
00:04:59.566 --> 00:05:01.630
We say, hey, Zack,
did you just send me a spreadsheet?

91
00:05:01.630 --> 00:05:03.880
Yeah, that was the thing I told
you I wanted you to look at.

92
00:05:03.880 --> 00:05:05.130
That's right, I forgot about that.

93
00:05:05.130 --> 00:05:07.670
Now I feel safe and I can click on that.

94
00:05:07.670 --> 00:05:10.258
But if he tells me, no,
I didn't send you a spreadsheet.

95
00:05:10.258 --> 00:05:12.074
I'm gonna delete the email, right?

96
00:05:12.074 --> 00:05:14.879
Because it's not from him,
it's probably spoofed and

97
00:05:14.879 --> 00:05:17.394
the spreadsheet probably
has a macro virus in it.

98
00:05:17.394 --> 00:05:20.640
And as soon as I open it up,
I'm going to infect my system.

99
00:05:20.640 --> 00:05:22.100
So, yeah, using common sense.

100
00:05:22.100 --> 00:05:27.012
If I get a notice, if i looked at my junk
mail right now on my personal account,

101
00:05:27.012 --> 00:05:31.851
I guarantee you I can see at least five
emails in there telling me about Amazon

102
00:05:31.851 --> 00:05:34.065
orders that have been cancelled.

103
00:05:34.065 --> 00:05:36.996
I haven't ordered a thing
from Amazon lately.

104
00:05:36.996 --> 00:05:41.754
It's not really from Amazon,
there is no order that they canceled.

105
00:05:41.754 --> 00:05:44.358
Or a Fed Ex notification about
a package that wasn't delivered and

106
00:05:44.358 --> 00:05:45.900
I need to come down there and pick it up.

107
00:05:45.900 --> 00:05:49.690
Or they need more information
in order to ship it to me.

108
00:05:49.690 --> 00:05:52.470
I didn't order anything,
I'm not expecting anything from Fed Ex.

109
00:05:52.470 --> 00:05:55.940
That's most likely spam, it's trying
to get me to click on something.

110
00:05:55.940 --> 00:06:01.450
So, not just assuming that everything
that comes into my inbox is safe.

111
00:06:01.450 --> 00:06:05.760
We've gotta help keep our machines safe.

112
00:06:05.760 --> 00:06:08.850
A couple other terms I want you to be
familiar with, phishing and pharming.

113
00:06:08.850 --> 00:06:11.690
These are things you've probably
seen on the news lately.

114
00:06:11.690 --> 00:06:14.560
They are very common attacks.

115
00:06:14.560 --> 00:06:18.079
Phishing is when I try to get
somebody to give up information,

116
00:06:18.079 --> 00:06:22.478
like their username and their password,
or their credit card information,

117
00:06:22.478 --> 00:06:24.994
or personally identifiable information.

118
00:06:24.994 --> 00:06:28.190
Usually it's done by email, but
it can be done through phone and text, and

119
00:06:28.190 --> 00:06:29.180
other methods.

120
00:06:29.180 --> 00:06:32.312
But email phishing scams are very popular.

121
00:06:32.312 --> 00:06:35.308
Hey, its PayPal and
your account password is expired,

122
00:06:35.308 --> 00:06:38.440
you need to change it before you
lose access to your account.

123
00:06:38.440 --> 00:06:41.610
Here's a link to update your password.

124
00:06:41.610 --> 00:06:42.954
Don't click on that.

125
00:06:42.954 --> 00:06:47.270
Go to your browser, go to PayPal, log in.

126
00:06:47.270 --> 00:06:49.550
See if you really need
to change your password.

127
00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:52.164
Pretty sure that email
was not from PayPal.

128
00:06:52.164 --> 00:06:56.799
You can almost be guaranteed,
nowadays, that no legitimate business

129
00:06:56.799 --> 00:07:01.500
is ever going to ask you for
any personal information via email.

130
00:07:01.500 --> 00:07:03.440
Email is not secure.

131
00:07:03.440 --> 00:07:05.160
It's just not.

132
00:07:05.160 --> 00:07:07.820
You have to get that in your brain.

133
00:07:07.820 --> 00:07:09.001
Email is not secure.

134
00:07:09.001 --> 00:07:12.490
It's not a way to send secure information.

135
00:07:12.490 --> 00:07:15.640
I'm never gonna try to send personal
information in an email, and

136
00:07:15.640 --> 00:07:19.650
I'm never gonna respond to an email that's
requesting for information like that.

137
00:07:19.650 --> 00:07:23.774
If my bank really needs my social
security number, I'll call them up, or

138
00:07:23.774 --> 00:07:27.318
I'll stop by on my way home from work,
or something like that.

139
00:07:27.318 --> 00:07:30.346
I'm not gonna click on that link
in an email, cuz it's too easy for

140
00:07:30.346 --> 00:07:33.990
the bad guys to spoof that stuff and make
it look like it's from Bank of America.

141
00:07:33.990 --> 00:07:38.144
And click on a link and it opens up a web
page that looks just like Bank of America,

142
00:07:38.144 --> 00:07:40.200
and I try to login and nothing happens.

143
00:07:40.200 --> 00:07:42.070
Well, something happened.

144
00:07:42.070 --> 00:07:45.299
The bad guys just got my password and
now they're logging into my actual bank

145
00:07:45.299 --> 00:07:48.990
account while I'm sitting here staring at
this fake Bank of America page, all right?

146
00:07:48.990 --> 00:07:52.290
So that's phishing,
using email typically, or

147
00:07:52.290 --> 00:07:56.015
some other method to try to
fish information out of you.

148
00:07:56.015 --> 00:08:01.609
Pharming is when the bad guys
set up bogus websites and

149
00:08:01.609 --> 00:08:04.728
try to redirect you to there.

150
00:08:04.728 --> 00:08:10.200
Where it might be a fake Bank of
America site or a fake PayPal site.

151
00:08:10.200 --> 00:08:11.840
But they're using a different technique.

152
00:08:11.840 --> 00:08:18.880
Pharming typically involves modifying the
way your computer connects to those sites.

153
00:08:18.880 --> 00:08:22.600
Without going too deep,
our computers use something known as DNS,

154
00:08:22.600 --> 00:08:24.120
Domain Name System.

155
00:08:24.120 --> 00:08:28.381
We type in names,
we type in www.bankofamerica,

156
00:08:28.381 --> 00:08:31.340
www.paypal.com, what have you.

157
00:08:31.340 --> 00:08:36.490
And our computers turn that name into an
IP address and connect to the IP address.

158
00:08:36.490 --> 00:08:39.563
Much like you type in,
you look up a name in a phonebook and

159
00:08:39.563 --> 00:08:41.300
then you dial the phone number.

160
00:08:41.300 --> 00:08:43.450
That's kind of what's going
on with our computers.

161
00:08:43.450 --> 00:08:48.771
Well, if a bad guy can forge those DNS
entries, and points you to a different IP

162
00:08:48.771 --> 00:08:54.110
address, not the actual Bank of America,
but this fake Bank of America site.

163
00:08:54.110 --> 00:08:59.950
That's pharming, they're trying to farm
people to come to their fake site.

164
00:08:59.950 --> 00:09:05.010
And still, the end result is, giving up
personal information, your user name,

165
00:09:05.010 --> 00:09:09.310
your password, your credit card numbers,
your social security numbers, things that

166
00:09:09.310 --> 00:09:14.250
they can use to do more damage to you,
steal your identity, things like that.

167
00:09:14.250 --> 00:09:15.908
>> And these are not friendly farmers.

168
00:09:15.908 --> 00:09:17.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> No way.

169
00:09:17.800 --> 00:09:20.152
What's a SmartScreen Filter?

170
00:09:20.152 --> 00:09:22.483
>> A SmartScreen Filter,
as I almost fall over here.

171
00:09:22.483 --> 00:09:24.213
SmartScreen Filters
are something that's built

172
00:09:24.213 --> 00:09:24.871
in-
>> I would have caught you.

173
00:09:24.871 --> 00:09:25.582
>> Yeah, thank you.

174
00:09:25.582 --> 00:09:27.140
>> I would've grabbed you.

175
00:09:27.140 --> 00:09:30.585
SmartScreen Filter is something that
Microsoft has built into their browser

176
00:09:30.585 --> 00:09:32.872
that's trying to protect
me from known bad sites.

177
00:09:32.872 --> 00:09:37.306
They maintain a list of known
pharming sites, malware sites,

178
00:09:37.306 --> 00:09:40.410
sites that if you go to
you can get infected.

179
00:09:40.410 --> 00:09:44.329
And what the SmartScreen Filter does is,
when you type in a URL or

180
00:09:44.329 --> 00:09:49.410
attempt to go to a link, the browser's
gonna send that information to Microsoft,

181
00:09:49.410 --> 00:09:52.480
compare it against their
list of known bad sites.

182
00:09:52.480 --> 00:09:56.450
And if it pops up on the list, it's gonna
stop your browser from going there.

183
00:09:56.450 --> 00:09:59.160
And it's gonna pop up a warning saying,
hey,

184
00:09:59.160 --> 00:10:02.089
this could be potentially
bad news if you go here.

185
00:10:02.089 --> 00:10:03.550
Are you sure you want to?

186
00:10:03.550 --> 00:10:06.000
You should really heed those warnings.

187
00:10:06.000 --> 00:10:10.020
They don't put sites in there just
because they think they might be bad.

188
00:10:10.020 --> 00:10:12.650
These are known bad sites.

189
00:10:12.650 --> 00:10:15.343
So, if your browser tells you,
hey, this is a bad site.

190
00:10:15.343 --> 00:10:17.096
Are you sure you want to continue?

191
00:10:17.096 --> 00:10:18.976
Say no, don't go to that site.

192
00:10:18.976 --> 00:10:21.590
I can show you an example here.

193
00:10:21.590 --> 00:10:25.651
If I open up my Internet Explorer, and
I just want to show you the settings for

194
00:10:25.651 --> 00:10:27.884
where it can work with that SmartScreen.

195
00:10:27.884 --> 00:10:31.856
Typically, the first time you open up
your browser, at least on Windows,

196
00:10:31.856 --> 00:10:34.540
it will ask you if you want
to enable SmartScreen.

197
00:10:34.540 --> 00:10:38.233
And it's a good idea, like I said,
it's taking a look at known bad sites and

198
00:10:38.233 --> 00:10:39.870
making sure you don't go there.

199
00:10:39.870 --> 00:10:42.979
This machine does not have Internet
access, so it's not actually gonna connect

200
00:10:42.979 --> 00:10:45.380
to anything, but
I can still show you this setting.

201
00:10:45.380 --> 00:10:49.832
If I go under the little gear icon up
here in that top right hand corner,

202
00:10:49.832 --> 00:10:54.222
I can go down to Safety, and
then here is turn on Smartscreen Filter.

203
00:10:54.222 --> 00:10:58.784
I'll center this guy a little bit,
and there are my options.

204
00:10:58.784 --> 00:11:02.729
Designed to warn you if a website you're
visiting is impersonating another website

205
00:11:02.729 --> 00:11:04.570
or contains threats to your computer.

206
00:11:04.570 --> 00:11:08.910
Now you can see that I do have it turned
on, and that is the recommended option.

207
00:11:08.910 --> 00:11:13.500
So, just another way that we can try to
keep ourselves safe from known bad sites.

208
00:11:13.500 --> 00:11:16.270
And why not take advantage of that, right?

209
00:11:16.270 --> 00:11:18.480
They've got a list of known bad sites.

210
00:11:18.480 --> 00:11:22.004
Why would I wanna ignore that and
go to one of those sites anyway?

211
00:11:22.004 --> 00:11:25.637
And again, if you get a warning from
something like SmartScreen or whatever

212
00:11:25.637 --> 00:11:29.400
program you happen to be using, heed
those warnings, pay attention to them.

213
00:11:29.400 --> 00:11:32.466
Unless you know that the site is okay,
don't go there.

214
00:11:32.466 --> 00:11:39.785
All right Zach, now we look at
client versus server protection.

215
00:11:39.785 --> 00:11:43.360
A kind of a topic that doesn't really
fit with everything else here.

216
00:11:43.360 --> 00:11:45.853
But I wanna make sure I
throw it in somewhere,

217
00:11:45.853 --> 00:11:48.480
because it is an exam objective.

218
00:11:48.480 --> 00:11:52.253
Really what we wanna keep in mind when
we're talking about client versus server

219
00:11:52.253 --> 00:11:55.425
is that when we talk about
protecting a client, it's important.

220
00:11:55.425 --> 00:11:59.303
But at the end of the day, if something
happens to this clients' machine that

221
00:11:59.303 --> 00:12:02.580
I'm sitting at, or
that one you're sitting at.

222
00:12:02.580 --> 00:12:03.950
Who's actually getting affected by that?

223
00:12:03.950 --> 00:12:06.730
Just that one person, right?

224
00:12:06.730 --> 00:12:08.052
The user of that system, bad.

225
00:12:08.052 --> 00:12:12.175
And I want to get them back online or
get their system working again and

226
00:12:12.175 --> 00:12:14.250
make them a productive employee.

227
00:12:14.250 --> 00:12:19.270
But it is only affecting one
person versus my servers.

228
00:12:19.270 --> 00:12:21.030
If a server goes down for

229
00:12:21.030 --> 00:12:25.560
some reason, that's affecting multiple
users, my entire staff potentially.

230
00:12:26.690 --> 00:12:32.655
So we usually spend a little more time,
effort, resources

231
00:12:32.655 --> 00:12:37.685
on hardening or protecting our servers
than we do our client systems, all right?

232
00:12:37.685 --> 00:12:39.687
So servers are going to require a little
more protection for that reason.

233
00:12:39.687 --> 00:12:44.800
Also, because servers are exposed more,
right?

234
00:12:44.800 --> 00:12:48.402
Because they have to open up ports for
these services that we depend on.

235
00:12:48.402 --> 00:12:50.822
We wanna connect to them
to get to those files.

236
00:12:50.822 --> 00:12:53.342
We wanna connect to them to do DNS lookup.

237
00:12:53.342 --> 00:12:56.840
We wanna connect to them to
get an IP address from DHCP.

238
00:12:56.840 --> 00:12:59.730
So they're open to provide these services.

239
00:12:59.730 --> 00:13:03.380
Each one of those openings
though is an avenue of attack.

240
00:13:03.380 --> 00:13:07.630
It's part of what we call, their attack
surface, and so there's a lot more work

241
00:13:07.630 --> 00:13:11.750
involved hardening and
protecting servers than there are clients.

242
00:13:11.750 --> 00:13:13.440
Now not to diminish or

243
00:13:13.440 --> 00:13:15.660
say that we shouldn't spend
any time protecting clients.

244
00:13:15.660 --> 00:13:18.700
I mean, we're spending a whole
episode here talking about it, or

245
00:13:18.700 --> 00:13:19.659
we did previously.

246
00:13:20.940 --> 00:13:23.930
But more efforts typically
goes into servers.

247
00:13:23.930 --> 00:13:29.548
All right, back to email protection Zach,
sender policy framework.

248
00:13:29.548 --> 00:13:30.800
>> That's the SPF, right?

249
00:13:30.800 --> 00:13:33.092
>> That is, SPF is the acronym for that.

250
00:13:33.092 --> 00:13:33.917
And really,

251
00:13:33.917 --> 00:13:39.140
for this exam, we're not gonna go into
a lot of details of how to create these.

252
00:13:39.140 --> 00:13:41.855
But I do want you to be familiar with
what they are and what their purpose is.

253
00:13:41.855 --> 00:13:44.410
Cuz we are talking about email here.

254
00:13:44.410 --> 00:13:47.138
And we're talking about spam and
how bad that is.

255
00:13:47.138 --> 00:13:52.009
And what the bad guys do is they love to
try to find email servers that are not

256
00:13:52.009 --> 00:13:57.522
protected, that have what we call open
relay, where they will forward emails on.

257
00:13:57.522 --> 00:13:59.650
Because they want to send
out a whole bunch of emails.

258
00:13:59.650 --> 00:14:02.290
And they need an email
server to bounce those off

259
00:14:02.290 --> 00:14:04.990
to make it more difficult
to trace back to them.

260
00:14:04.990 --> 00:14:08.004
So they're looking for
servers that would allow them to do that.

261
00:14:08.004 --> 00:14:10.459
Anonymously send a whole bunch of emails,

262
00:14:10.459 --> 00:14:13.410
kind of bouncing them
off your email server.

263
00:14:13.410 --> 00:14:15.280
Ends up looking like it came from you.

264
00:14:15.280 --> 00:14:19.790
Your company can end up on blacklist and
have problems delivering

265
00:14:19.790 --> 00:14:23.950
emails to legitimate users or
business partners because of this.

266
00:14:23.950 --> 00:14:26.540
So, this is not what we're gonna
talk about protecting email servers.

267
00:14:26.540 --> 00:14:32.025
But this part, we are talking about SPF,
that's really what we are doing.

268
00:14:32.025 --> 00:14:34.415
A SPF record,

269
00:14:34.415 --> 00:14:39.415
or the Sender Policy Framework
records are added to our DNS zones.

270
00:14:39.415 --> 00:14:43.555
And our DNS zone,
this is where we store resource records,

271
00:14:43.555 --> 00:14:46.135
name to IP address mappings.

272
00:14:46.135 --> 00:14:50.500
And what an SPF record does,
is it states who or

273
00:14:50.500 --> 00:14:57.180
what machines are allowed to send
emails on our domain's behalf, right?

274
00:14:57.180 --> 00:14:59.297
And when a receiving unit,

275
00:14:59.297 --> 00:15:03.720
like those Barracuda Spam filters and
things like that.

276
00:15:03.720 --> 00:15:05.282
When they get these emails,

277
00:15:05.282 --> 00:15:08.770
they can look at the IP address
that the email came from.

278
00:15:08.770 --> 00:15:10.258
And they can do what's
called a reverse lookup.

279
00:15:10.258 --> 00:15:13.873
They're gonna use something
known as PTR records,

280
00:15:13.873 --> 00:15:19.295
which are pointer records,
to turn that IP address back into a name.

281
00:15:19.295 --> 00:15:24.075
And if that name doesn't match
who the email came from,

282
00:15:24.075 --> 00:15:26.455
it can mark it as spam or it can drop it.

283
00:15:26.455 --> 00:15:30.125
It can say nope, that's no good, and
that's what the SPF record does.

284
00:15:30.125 --> 00:15:32.650
That sender policy framework denotes

285
00:15:32.650 --> 00:15:36.670
what machines are allowed to send
out emails on behalf of our domain.

286
00:15:36.670 --> 00:15:39.895
So you go a new DNS, and again we're not
going to get into the technical details.

287
00:15:39.895 --> 00:15:46.430
It's a text record that gets placed in
DNS that lists your valid email servers.

288
00:15:46.430 --> 00:15:50.835
And that way, when somebody's trying to
determine whether your email is spam or

289
00:15:50.835 --> 00:15:53.122
not, they can look that information up.

290
00:15:53.122 --> 00:15:56.173
And if it's something you sent
that came off your email server,

291
00:15:56.173 --> 00:15:58.080
everything should be good.

292
00:15:58.080 --> 00:16:01.520
But if it's a bad guy trying to
fake an email from your company,

293
00:16:01.520 --> 00:16:03.660
it's gonna be able to detect that.

294
00:16:03.660 --> 00:16:07.610
And it's gonna mark those as spam,
and not allow them to be delivered.

295
00:16:07.610 --> 00:16:10.320
And I kind of already, then,
hinted at the last topic.

296
00:16:10.320 --> 00:16:11.560
It was the-
>> The PTR records?

297
00:16:11.560 --> 00:16:12.792
>> Yeah, the PTR records.

298
00:16:12.792 --> 00:16:17.140
Normally, when we talk about DNS,
we do what's called a forward lookup.

299
00:16:17.140 --> 00:16:21.440
Where I know the name, I wanna go to
newegg.com or I wanna go to facebook.com.

300
00:16:21.440 --> 00:16:25.420
I know the name,
what I need is the IP address.

301
00:16:25.420 --> 00:16:29.020
So DNS provides what's called forward
look up, give me the name and

302
00:16:29.020 --> 00:16:30.600
I'll tell you the IP address.

303
00:16:30.600 --> 00:16:33.460
Just like when you take a phone book out,
you look up the name and

304
00:16:33.460 --> 00:16:35.020
you find the number that you want to call.

305
00:16:35.020 --> 00:16:36.330
That'd be a forward lookup.

306
00:16:36.330 --> 00:16:40.410
Occasionally, however, we need to know
the name that goes with the number.

307
00:16:40.410 --> 00:16:43.550
I know the number,
I want to know the name that goes with it.

308
00:16:43.550 --> 00:16:46.680
You guys might have done this before,
if you've ever got a call and

309
00:16:46.680 --> 00:16:50.084
it just shows a phone number instead
of a name and you go look that number

310
00:16:50.084 --> 00:16:54.060
up to try to figure out what names
goes with it, that's a reverse lookup.

311
00:16:54.060 --> 00:16:55.840
We can do that with DNS as well.

312
00:16:55.840 --> 00:17:00.690
So PTR records are reversed
look up records.

313
00:17:00.690 --> 00:17:04.710
They'll say, hey, this IP address
goes to this particular name.

314
00:17:04.710 --> 00:17:09.826
And those are used in conjunction
with SPF and other things, but

315
00:17:09.826 --> 00:17:16.190
it's one of the ways we can verify the
validity of the originator of that email.

316
00:17:16.190 --> 00:17:17.166
>> Wow, lots of good information.

317
00:17:17.166 --> 00:17:19.338
You know MTA, security fundamentals, and

318
00:17:19.338 --> 00:17:23.160
we're looking to email protection right
this second and you did a great job.

319
00:17:23.160 --> 00:17:25.350
Let's wrap it all up, though.

320
00:17:25.350 --> 00:17:28.344
>> In the end, I think the biggest
thing we can do is one, just for

321
00:17:28.344 --> 00:17:30.310
our own benefit not so much for the exam.

322
00:17:30.310 --> 00:17:32.590
Keep in mind that email is not secure.

323
00:17:32.590 --> 00:17:37.074
It is not a way to transmit sensitive
information, it cannot be trusted.

324
00:17:37.074 --> 00:17:39.617
I mean,
I don't want to scare everybody and

325
00:17:39.617 --> 00:17:42.665
sound like I'm running
around with a tin foil hat.

326
00:17:42.665 --> 00:17:47.341
Email definitely has it's purposes, but
not for sensitive information, not for

327
00:17:47.341 --> 00:17:49.560
personal identifiable information.

328
00:17:49.560 --> 00:17:55.500
Never trust the origin validate,
verify, call.

329
00:17:55.500 --> 00:17:57.032
Say, hey, did you send me that email.

330
00:17:57.032 --> 00:17:59.282
Because email is a easy way for

331
00:17:59.282 --> 00:18:04.610
the bad guys to bypass our security,
and infect our machines.

332
00:18:04.610 --> 00:18:05.930
So be careful with email.

333
00:18:05.930 --> 00:18:08.920
Yeah, I think that's where we'll leave it.

334
00:18:08.920 --> 00:18:09.446
>> That's perfect, though.

335

>> [LAUGH]
>> That's absolutely perfect.

And you can,
because it's all in the library, right?

339
00:18:17.866 --> 00:18:18.430
>> That's it.

00:18:18.430 --> 00:18:18.978
>> Great job, Mike.

00:18:18.978 --> 00:18:22.564
You know a good IT Pro is always learning.

00:18:22.564 --> 00:18:23.624
I'm Zach Memos.

than we typically spend on clients.

22
00:00:53.831 --> 00:00:55.681
And that's because of a few things.

23
00:00:55.681 --> 00:01:00.290
One, an outage on a server typically
affects a lot more than just one person.

24
00:01:00.290 --> 00:01:01.120
>> It could be devastating.

25
00:01:01.120 --> 00:01:03.040
>> Yeah, so that's never gonna be good.

26
00:01:03.040 --> 00:01:06.120
And that they are exposed a little
more than our clients, usually,

27
00:01:06.120 --> 00:01:08.010
because they are offering services.

28
00:01:08.010 --> 00:01:10.830
They have listeners that are waiting for
connections.

29
00:01:10.830 --> 00:01:13.940
That's all just avenues of attack for
the bad guys.

30
00:01:13.940 --> 00:01:15.110
They like that.

31
00:01:15.110 --> 00:01:19.240
So they do require a little more work
when it comes to protecting them.

32
00:01:19.240 --> 00:01:21.920
And we call it hardening a server.

33
00:01:21.920 --> 00:01:26.080
And we'll kind of come back around to
that concept and what it means, but

34
00:01:26.080 --> 00:01:28.518
really that's what we
are talking about here.

35
00:01:28.518 --> 00:01:32.790
And one of the first things we can do is,
when we are getting ready to deploy a new

36
00:01:32.790 --> 00:01:36.680
server, what we need to think about is,
where are we deploying it?

37
00:01:36.680 --> 00:01:39.350
And I mean physically
as well as logically.

38
00:01:39.350 --> 00:01:41.100
>> Like offsite or onsite,
that type of thing?

39
00:01:41.100 --> 00:01:43.700
>> Well, more about like,
it could be though,

40
00:01:43.700 --> 00:01:45.360
we might be running it out on the cloud,
or

41
00:01:45.360 --> 00:01:51.280
we might be renting rack space from
somewhere, it might be on-premise.

42
00:01:51.280 --> 00:01:53.380
But let's say we're doing it on-premise,

43
00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:55.480
because that's really
where we have the control.

44
00:01:55.480 --> 00:02:00.186
Usually, we've talked about this before,
we've talked about layers of defense and

45
00:02:00.186 --> 00:02:02.645
wetalked about the zones and
the perimeter.

46
00:02:02.645 --> 00:02:06.279
And then the exterior of our building,
and then inside our building, and

47
00:02:06.279 --> 00:02:08.610
then secure zones within our building.

48
00:02:08.610 --> 00:02:10.260
Well when we deploy a new server,

49
00:02:10.260 --> 00:02:13.970
we don't just put it under
the receptionist desk, right?

50
00:02:13.970 --> 00:02:19.090
Or in a corner somewhere, we want good
physical security over those servers.

51
00:02:19.090 --> 00:02:21.770
We typically have an area
within our building that has

52
00:02:21.770 --> 00:02:23.860
another layer of security on it.

53
00:02:23.860 --> 00:02:25.610
If we were to go look at
our server closet, and

54
00:02:25.610 --> 00:02:30.430
a lot of you have seen it in Studio Four
over there, when you look there,

55
00:02:30.430 --> 00:02:34.550
there's a door that leads in that server
closet, and it has a keypad on it.

56
00:02:34.550 --> 00:02:37.640
So even if you have an access
card to get in the building,

57
00:02:37.640 --> 00:02:39.780
you might not be able to
get into the server closet.

58
00:02:39.780 --> 00:02:42.260
That's an extra layer of security there.

59
00:02:42.260 --> 00:02:45.780
Not everybody needs to be able to
lay hands on those servers, right?

60
00:02:45.780 --> 00:02:47.050
That physical access.

61
00:02:47.050 --> 00:02:50.980
So that's the first thing, is just
physical security on the those servers.

62
00:02:52.060 --> 00:02:57.088
Then logically as well, even though its
secured physically inside a server closet,

63
00:02:57.088 --> 00:03:00.770
logically I wanna protect it
from the rest of the network.

64
00:03:00.770 --> 00:03:04.200
That means isolating it,
we've talked about domain and

65
00:03:04.200 --> 00:03:07.230
server isolation, we talked about VLANs,

66
00:03:07.230 --> 00:03:10.892
this is how I can separate that
server from the rest of our network.

67
00:03:10.892 --> 00:03:14.092
It's gonna help performance, first of all,
because if I put it on its own subnet or

68
00:03:14.092 --> 00:03:17.060
its own VLAN, it doesn't have to
compete with all the other nodes and

69
00:03:17.060 --> 00:03:18.900
all the other broadcast traffic.

70
00:03:18.900 --> 00:03:22.360
It also gives us a chance to
control what types of traffic or

71
00:03:22.360 --> 00:03:26.660
who is allowed to connect to
that particular VLAN or subnet.

72
00:03:26.660 --> 00:03:28.970
So that's another, again,
layer of security.

73
00:03:28.970 --> 00:03:32.698
So when you deploy it, there's some things
you gotta think about before you even put

74
00:03:32.698 --> 00:03:34.024
that server on your network.

75
00:03:34.024 --> 00:03:35.742
Where am I gonna deploy it physically?

76
00:03:35.742 --> 00:03:37.960
And then,
how am I gonna deploy it logically?

77
00:03:37.960 --> 00:03:42.270
How am I gonna segregate it out from
the rest of my network, all right?

78
00:03:42.270 --> 00:03:45.770
And then there's something known
as a read-only domain controller.

79
00:03:45.770 --> 00:03:48.960
They throw this in the objectives,
so I wanna go ahead and cover it.

80
00:03:48.960 --> 00:03:53.070
Again, this class,
this is not our MCSA or MCSE.

81
00:03:53.070 --> 00:03:55.740
At this point, we just wanna
kinda understand these topics.

82
00:03:55.740 --> 00:03:59.250
So don't kill yourself learning
how to install read-only

83
00:03:59.250 --> 00:04:00.770
domain controller, things like that.

84
00:04:00.770 --> 00:04:02.790
Just be familiar with this concept.

85
00:04:02.790 --> 00:04:05.164
And really the name kinda
tells you a lot about it.

86
00:04:05.164 --> 00:04:10.420
Read-only domain controller,
just from that I can infer that one,

87
00:04:10.420 --> 00:04:14.120
it's a domain controller, and two, I'm
not gonna be able to make changes on it.

88
00:04:14.120 --> 00:04:18.337
I can read things on it, but
I can't make changes to it.

89
00:04:18.337 --> 00:04:22.820
Read-only domain controllers were
designed for a specific purpose.

90
00:04:22.820 --> 00:04:30.430
Places where I do not have a good level of
physical security, like my branch office.

91
00:04:30.430 --> 00:04:32.890
Here at the corporate office we
got all the bells and whistles.

92
00:04:32.890 --> 00:04:35.620
We've got our server closet,
we've got big IT staff.

93
00:04:35.620 --> 00:04:36.560
Everything's hunky-dory.

94
00:04:36.560 --> 00:04:40.175
Out there at the branch office,
there is no server closet, right?

95
00:04:40.175 --> 00:04:44.230
It's a little small office space,
I've got four employees out there.

96
00:04:44.230 --> 00:04:48.660
But when they go to login in the morning,
they're having to go across the WAN to

97
00:04:48.660 --> 00:04:51.080
connect to the corporate office
to talk to the domain controller.

98
00:04:51.080 --> 00:04:54.850
Which can be lengthy, and if there's
any congestion or network outage,

99
00:04:54.850 --> 00:04:58.010
they can't authenticate,
they can't connect to resources.

100
00:04:58.010 --> 00:04:59.500
So that becomes a problem.

101
00:04:59.500 --> 00:05:02.910
So hey, let's put a domain controller
out there at the branch office.

102
00:05:02.910 --> 00:05:06.920
Now think back to what we just said,
when you deploy a server, what do we do?

103
00:05:06.920 --> 00:05:11.550
I'm talking about physically deploying
it to a secure location, and logically.

104
00:05:11.550 --> 00:05:15.630
Well, the branch office,
there is no server closet, right?

105
00:05:15.630 --> 00:05:19.220
So I don't have that luxury,
that physical security.

106
00:05:19.220 --> 00:05:22.810
So what I can do is deploy
a read-only domain controller.

107
00:05:22.810 --> 00:05:26.280
This is gonna reduce
my risk because I know

108
00:05:26.280 --> 00:05:28.780
I don't have the physical
security I would like.

109
00:05:28.780 --> 00:05:31.280
So how can I deal with that?

110
00:05:31.280 --> 00:05:32.810
Make a read-only domain controller.

111
00:05:32.810 --> 00:05:36.546
That way, if the bad guy is able to
get into that branch office, like when

112
00:05:36.546 --> 00:05:40.725
nobody's looking or pretending to be
a phone repair guy or something like that.

113
00:05:40.725 --> 00:05:43.567
And he tries to get access to that
domain controller cuz it's not

114
00:05:43.567 --> 00:05:45.800
locked away in another level of security.

115
00:05:45.800 --> 00:05:49.932
If he does get access to it,
he can't do anything but read information,

116
00:05:49.932 --> 00:05:53.858
which is bad, but not as bad as if
he could make new accounts on there,

117
00:05:53.858 --> 00:05:55.625
give himself-
>> Or corrupt it.

118
00:05:55.625 --> 00:05:59.500
>> Yeah, or corrupt it, and have that
corruption replicate back to my corporate

119
00:05:59.500 --> 00:06:01.518
office and hit all those
domain controllers, all right?

120
00:06:01.518 --> 00:06:06.160
So read-only domain controllers
allow me look up information,

121
00:06:06.160 --> 00:06:10.800
to authenticate things like that, but
not make changes, not create new accounts.

122
00:06:10.800 --> 00:06:12.320
I can't even change passwords.

123
00:06:12.320 --> 00:06:15.350
If a legitimate user is trying to
change a password, the read-only

124
00:06:15.350 --> 00:06:19.220
demand controller has to forward it
back to a read-write domain controller,

125
00:06:19.220 --> 00:06:21.140
one of my normal domain controllers.

126
00:06:21.140 --> 00:06:24.150
So it's a way I can provide
a little bit of security or

127
00:06:24.150 --> 00:06:28.480
reduce my risk when I don't have
that physical security I would like.

128
00:06:28.480 --> 00:06:33.150
>> Can you run all services on one server
or through one server, or should you?

129
00:06:33.150 --> 00:06:34.015
>> Yeah, that's a better question.

130
00:06:34.015 --> 00:06:35.042
>> That's a better question.

131
00:06:35.042 --> 00:06:35.563
Should you do that?

132
00:06:35.563 --> 00:06:37.520
>> The answer to the first
question is absolutely.

133
00:06:37.520 --> 00:06:40.420
I mean, if you've got enough horsepower,
you can do that.

134
00:06:40.420 --> 00:06:41.488
Should you?

135
00:06:41.488 --> 00:06:43.390
No.
>> No, I didn't think so.

136
00:06:43.390 --> 00:06:45.740
>> I think I've used the old
phrase several times,

137
00:06:45.740 --> 00:06:46.980
putting all your eggs in one basket.

138
00:06:46.980 --> 00:06:50.200
And that's really what you're doing if
you try to run all your services on

139
00:06:50.200 --> 00:06:51.060
a single server.

140
00:06:52.200 --> 00:06:55.450
If that one server goes down,
and it will eventually, right?

141
00:06:55.450 --> 00:06:57.560
I mean, something is gonna happen,

142
00:06:57.560 --> 00:07:00.930
you lose everything,
all of a sudden nothing is available.

143
00:07:00.930 --> 00:07:03.800
Whereas if I had separated
out my services,

144
00:07:03.800 --> 00:07:07.750
if I had put my website on a different
server from my domain controller,

145
00:07:07.750 --> 00:07:11.650
if that server that's hosting the website
goes down, I still have Active Directory.

146
00:07:11.650 --> 00:07:13.350
I still have DNS, whatever.

147
00:07:13.350 --> 00:07:20.940
So splitting services is up is a way
that I can provide a little bit

148
00:07:20.940 --> 00:07:26.500
of protection against that failure, of not
losing everything if it all goes down.

149
00:07:26.500 --> 00:07:30.480
Typically what we say is
think about the services and

150
00:07:30.480 --> 00:07:32.270
the level of security they require.

151
00:07:32.270 --> 00:07:37.330
Like Active Directory, that's a sensitive
service, not everybody has access to that.

152
00:07:37.330 --> 00:07:39.135
I don't want that exposed to the public.

153
00:07:39.135 --> 00:07:42.630
A web server does need
access to the public,

154
00:07:42.630 --> 00:07:46.540
I want them to be able to come to
my website and buy my product.

155
00:07:46.540 --> 00:07:49.737
So I'm not gonna put those two
roles on the same machine,

156
00:07:49.737 --> 00:07:52.747
because they require
different levels of security.

157
00:07:52.747 --> 00:07:57.775
That's usually how we divide things up,
is based on security requirements,

158
00:07:57.775 --> 00:08:02.207
as well as access requirements,
as well as resource requirements.

159
00:08:02.207 --> 00:08:04.750
That's typically what
we're looking at there.

160
00:08:04.750 --> 00:08:07.017
And then earlier you mentioned hardening.

161
00:08:07.017 --> 00:08:07.841
So can we go back to that?

162
00:08:07.841 --> 00:08:09.830
>> Yeah, let's do.

163
00:08:09.830 --> 00:08:15.210
When we talk about hardening, it's a name
that we've given to really applying

164
00:08:15.210 --> 00:08:20.510
the best security practices to our
machines, hardening them against attack.

165
00:08:20.510 --> 00:08:22.170
It is really what they're
talking about there.

166
00:08:22.170 --> 00:08:24.280
And there's several things that we can do.

167
00:08:24.280 --> 00:08:27.320
You've heard me mention this term as well,
attack surface.

168
00:08:27.320 --> 00:08:28.680
A server, well, any machine, but

169
00:08:28.680 --> 00:08:32.420
we're talking about servers here,
has what's known as an attack surface.

170
00:08:32.420 --> 00:08:36.250
And that is all of the different ways
that this machine might be vulnerable.

171
00:08:36.250 --> 00:08:40.860
The different ways that bad guys
might try to compromise that machine.

172
00:08:40.860 --> 00:08:43.760
And so what we do,
when we're hardening a server,

173
00:08:43.760 --> 00:08:46.010
is we try to reduce that attack surface.

174
00:08:46.010 --> 00:08:48.670
We wanna eliminate as many as possible

175
00:08:48.670 --> 00:08:51.688
of those different ways that
the bad guys can get in.

176
00:08:51.688 --> 00:08:55.860
By reducing the attack surface we're
reducing the risk we're exposed to

177
00:08:55.860 --> 00:08:59.260
by operating that server.

178
00:08:59.260 --> 00:09:03.080
And so,
how do we reduce that attack surface?

179
00:09:03.080 --> 00:09:05.430
Well we eliminate
unnecessary applications.

180
00:09:05.430 --> 00:09:07.830
We don't run anything that we don't need.

181
00:09:07.830 --> 00:09:11.810
Services that are running,
if we don't need them, we turn them off.

182
00:09:11.810 --> 00:09:14.960
The services that are running,
we follow our best practices.

183
00:09:14.960 --> 00:09:19.210
You know Microsoft puts out all
kinds of security best practices and

184
00:09:19.210 --> 00:09:21.720
base lines that we can
apply to our servers.

185
00:09:21.720 --> 00:09:27.060
When I say base line, these are base
security settings that should be applied.

186
00:09:27.060 --> 00:09:31.050
So Microsoft has baseline security
settings for a server in general.

187
00:09:31.050 --> 00:09:33.490
These are things you should do
to every one of your servers.

188
00:09:33.490 --> 00:09:37.100
And then if that server is running DNS,
we can go out to Microsoft and

189
00:09:37.100 --> 00:09:39.072
we can get a DNS best practice.

190
00:09:39.072 --> 00:09:42.500
And it'll tell us, hey this is the kind
of things you should do to harden a DNS

191
00:09:42.500 --> 00:09:46.290
server, or if it's a DHCP server,
or a domain controller.

192
00:09:46.290 --> 00:09:49.550
So take advantage of that, go out there
to Microsoft and get those resources.

193
00:09:49.550 --> 00:09:53.340
You can download them freely, Microsoft
has been doing this for some time.

194
00:09:53.340 --> 00:09:57.640
They have a lot of experience,
they deal with a lot of customers and

195
00:09:57.640 --> 00:09:59.830
over time they've developed
these best practices.

196
00:09:59.830 --> 00:10:03.030
And so rather than start from scratch and

197
00:10:03.030 --> 00:10:06.380
have to learn everything on our own,
why not take advantage?

198
00:10:06.380 --> 00:10:09.810
What is it they say about standing
on the shoulders of giants,

199
00:10:09.810 --> 00:10:10.722
that's what we wanna do.

200
00:10:10.722 --> 00:10:15.360
We wanna take advantage of that
information that's out there.

201
00:10:15.360 --> 00:10:16.620
So apply your best practices.

202
00:10:16.620 --> 00:10:18.890
Apply those security guidelines.

203
00:10:18.890 --> 00:10:21.210
We've talked about updates and patching.

204
00:10:21.210 --> 00:10:23.260
Servers are no different than clients.

205
00:10:23.260 --> 00:10:27.510
We have to go out to Microsoft or
use our WSUS or whatever it is and

206
00:10:27.510 --> 00:10:30.760
apply those critical and
security related updates.

207
00:10:30.760 --> 00:10:34.070
Any applications that are running
on that server also need to be

208
00:10:34.070 --> 00:10:35.460
patched and updated.

209
00:10:35.460 --> 00:10:37.840
So make sure we're paying
attention to that.

210
00:10:37.840 --> 00:10:40.472
>> Can you put a firewall around a server?

211
00:10:40.472 --> 00:10:43.830
>> Absolutely, we talked about that
when we were talking about clients.

212
00:10:43.830 --> 00:10:47.270
I can have a perimeter firewall
that protects my entire network.

213
00:10:47.270 --> 00:10:49.500
I might have a firewall at
the edge of that VLAN or

214
00:10:49.500 --> 00:10:52.350
subnet that protects
just that little subnet.

215
00:10:52.350 --> 00:10:54.590
But then I'm also gonna have
a firewall on the host or

216
00:10:54.590 --> 00:10:57.638
the server itself that's
protecting that server.

217
00:10:57.638 --> 00:11:00.820
Because that's gonna allow me to
control the traffic that's going in and

218
00:11:00.820 --> 00:11:03.230
out of that particular machine.

219
00:11:03.230 --> 00:11:05.170
So, definitely run, especially,

220
00:11:05.170 --> 00:11:09.540
your servers, we want that firewall
on there to protect it again.

221
00:11:09.540 --> 00:11:12.400
It's really all about
reducing that attack surface.

222
00:11:12.400 --> 00:11:14.355
>> I'm just full of questions today,
I can't help myself.

00:11:14.355 --> 00:11:16.310

>> Do we need to update a server,

00:11:16.310 --> 00:11:20.260
we update devices, we update personal
computers, do we update servers as well?

225
00:11:20.260 --> 00:11:21.490
>> Yeah, absolutely.

226
00:11:21.490 --> 00:11:24.930
Make sure that you're going
to be applying those.

227
00:11:24.930 --> 00:11:27.930
Again, whatever your company is doing,
if you're using WSUS or

228
00:11:27.930 --> 00:11:32.760
System Center Configuration Manager to
control what updates are going out,

229
00:11:32.760 --> 00:11:35.616
giving you the ability to test

230
00:11:35.616 --> 00:11:39.640
cuz you don't wanna apply an untested

00:11:39.640 --> 00:11:43.660
So it's important that we test

00:11:43.660 --> 00:11:46.420

remember what we said a little bit ago,

00:11:46.420 --> 00:11:49.420
client goes down,

00:11:49.420 --> 00:11:52.650
Server goes down, that's bad for

00:11:52.650 --> 00:11:55.040
So we definitely want to be careful.

236
00:11:55.040 --> 00:11:58.975
We want to apply updates, but
we wanna test them as well.

237
00:11:58.975 --> 00:12:02.710
So, all of that together is really
what hardening is all about.

238
00:12:02.710 --> 00:12:06.230
Like I mentioned services,
disabling unnecessary services.

239
00:12:06.230 --> 00:12:09.230
It's a lot better nowadays with
our modern operating systems.

240
00:12:09.230 --> 00:12:12.100
I remember back in, Server 2000 or

00:12:12.100 --> 00:12:17.400
2000 Server, where you would install IIS

00:12:17.400 --> 00:12:21.890
IIS is internet information services,
it's Microsoft's web server role.

243
00:12:21.890 --> 00:12:25.080
And when you installed it,
it installed IIS but

00:12:25.080 --> 00:12:29.110
it also installed your network
news transfer protocol, your NNTP,

00:12:29.110 --> 00:12:33.620
it installed FTP, I think it installed,

00:12:33.620 --> 00:12:37.102
It installed three or four different

00:12:37.102 --> 00:12:40.784
So you as an admin would go and
configure and harden IIS, but
